column2: Winter is particularly bad time for 84-year-old Sebastiano Ferlito, of Freeport. It is too cold for him to meet his friends in the park and there is no public transportation to the nearest senior center. So he sits in his apartment waiting for spring.

Winter Is particularly bad time for 84-year-old Sebastiano Ferlito, of Freeport. It is too cold for him to meet his friends in the park and there is no public transportation to the nearest senior center.

A sweeping Caomel snunile today was being interpreted in political quarters as a signal that President Park Chung Hee might be easing his repressive rule in the face of a growing t anti-Government movement among university students, intellectuals, churchmen and journalists.

Laffit Pincay discovered yesterday that he was a millionaire four times over in the matter of purses won for the current season. When he was secure in the knowledge, he decided to take the rest of the year off, starting today.

Scientific history has been made with the flight of Pioneer 10 within 100,000 miles of Jupiter, the largest and most massive planet of the solar system. To accomplish this historic rendezvous, the Pioneer vehicle had flown more than 600 million miles, a distance so enormous as to make earlier rocket flights to the moon, Mars and Venus seem almost like local excursions.

A small American spacecraft, Pioneer 10, sped within 81,000 miles of Jupiter tonight, sailing past the glowing giant ball of primordial gages for man's first close-up exploration of the largest planet in the solar system.
A six-day-old effort to force passage of a landmark measure financing Federal election campaigns with public funds col-. lapsed today in the Senate.

Although Gilles Marotte's debut as a New York Ranger Sunday night was not a complete artistic success, the fans and Coach Larry Popein liked what they saw. The fans were delighted to see "Captain Crunch" administer at least half a dozen of his trademarked body jolts
A controversial measure putting the state's moral pledge behind the financing of a $280-million sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands cleared the New Jersey Legislature here this evening.

ARE YOU NOW OR HAVE YOU EVER BEEN, a play by Eric Bentley. Directed by Jay Broad; settling by Alan M. Beck; costumes by Pamela Dendy; Lighting by Lee A Goldman; production stage manager, Thomas Mark Eaton. Presented by TRC'S Perterming Cooperative Arthur Barlow, producer At the Theater of the Riverside Church, 20th Step and riverside Drive.

On the eve of the first meeting of his National Commission on Critical Choices for America, Governor Rockefeller was host last night at a private dinner for Vice President-designate Gerald R. Ford and other members of the commission.
Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger, as a fuel conservation measure, has given up his Cadillac limousine in favor of a smaller sedan furnished by the Pentagon motor pool, a spokesman said today,
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has named a woman for the first time to the post of associate vicar for religious, Cardinal Cooke announced yesterday.
The lights on the Madison Square Garden basketball court Saturday night were still dimmed as the crowd slowly filtered in for the Knicks' game with the Cleveland Cavaliers.
Garbage trucks, which have long jarred the nerves of sleepy New Yorkers, may be quieter soon if a new model displayed yesterday outside City Hall lives up to advance notices.
David Ben-Gurion, Israel's first Premier, was buried here today in a starkly simple 45minute religious service near the Negev Desert kibbutz where he spent the contemplative final years of his life.

Just as it seemed as though a cure had been found for the mysterious malady that has been besetting the Giants this season, a relapse flattened the patient in Washington over the weekend. It struck somewhat unexpectedly in the fourth quarter against the Redskins, and the more learned medical minds are now recommending a long winter of rest and seclusion, provided the ailing Giants can survive the rigors of the next fortnight.
A controversial measure putting the state's moral pledge behind the financing of a $280-million sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands cleared the New Jersey Legislature here this evening.
President Nixon, in a reversal of position, has decided to ask the House of Representatives to proceed with the big foreign trade bill despite the risk of strong anti-Soviet amendments.
James A. Mulvey, a vice president of the Brooklyn and Los Angeles Dodgers since 1937 and retired president of Samuel Goldwyn Productions, died here last night. He was 74 years old.

David Ben-Gurion, Israel's first Premier, was buried in a starkly simple service in Sde Boker, Israel, near the desert kibbutz where he spent the contemplative final years of his life. A group of 300 political and military leaders, representatives of foreign governments, family members and former associates attended the service.

Robert Stigwood has decided not to open his production of "Rachel Lily Rosenbloom and Don't You musical by Paul Jabara, which had been scheduled to make its Broadway debut tomorrow at the Broadhurst Theater.
Manufacturers' inventories continued to rise moderately in October as shipments and new orders boomed, the Commerce Department reported today.

About 40 Soviet Jews who were unhappy in Israel and have been trying to return to their homeland forced their way into the Soviet consulate here today and stayed there for three and a half hours demanding re-entry visas.

William Whitelaw, Britain's Secretary for Northern Ireland, achieved something of a miracle last month when he brought hitherto irreconcilable Protestant and Catholic leaders into an agreement to share political power in the province. This was a prodigious accomplishment after five years of bloody sectarian strife, even if it was only "a good start," as Mr. Whitelaw said, on the road to lasting peace and political stability in Ulster.

Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, leader of Kashmir's Moslems, warned Pakistan yesterday against "interference in the internal affairs" of Kashmir. Speaking at a Moslem prayer meeting here, the Sheik warned Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Prime Minister of Pakistan, to keep his "hands off' Kashmir.

Government officials and utility company representatives from across the country generally endorsed at a conference here today the idea of burning garbage to generate power but they warned that what appears to be a simple and ideal solution entails problems.
The lights on the Madison Square Garden basketball court Saturday night were still dimmed as the crowd slowly filtered in for the Knicks' game with the Cleveland Cavaliers.

Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton, identified as members of a militant group known as the Black Liberation Army, obtained a one-day delay of their bank-rcbbery trial yesterday, then scuffled briefly with armed marshals guarding them in the Federal courthouse here.

The Argentine Government has offered armed protection against guerrilla attacks to foreignowned plants that request it. Interior Minister Benito Llambf said today that the protection would be provided by contingents from the paramilitary force that normally guards the country's frontiers and strategic installations such as power stations and dams.

Foreign Minister Juan Antonio Tack and Ellsworth Bunker, the special United States envoy, said today that their talks in the last week represented a "significant effort" toward a new Panama Canal treaty.
The intercepted pass has been called the best play in football because it shifts a team so swiftly from defense to offense and often advantageously.

Local school boards in New Jersey will soon be considering a recommendation made last week by Edward Kilpatrick, acting state commissioner of education, that night and weekend athletic activities be eliminated in an effort to conserve fuel. Many school officials see minimal difficulty in shifting the competition in basketball and wrestling, the two major winter sports, to weekdays.
An explosion, apparently caused by a short circuit in the aircraft Maintenance section, closed Orly Airport today, forcing the evacuation of passengers and the temporary cancellation of all flights.

Bobby Clarke of the Philadelphia Flyers, who was the National Hockey League's most valuable player last season, required 20 stitches to close a gash in his face after a brawl between the Flyers and the California Golden Seals on Sunday night in Philadelphia.

Nicholas Johnson, the feisty, reform-minded member of the Federal Communications Commission, plans to resign his seat this week but to continue goading the broadcast establishment and the F.C.C. as a private citizen.

The Giants have two games to play this season, against the Rams in Los Angeles next Monday night and Dec. 16 against Minnesota in the Yale Bowl. The Rams and Vikings are two of the strongest teams in pro football, probably opponents in the National Conference championship Dec. 30, with the winner going on to the Super Bowl.

A small American spacecraft, Pioneer 10, sped within 81,000 miles of Jupiter tonight, sailing past the glowing giant ball of primordial gases for man's first close-up exploration of the largest planet in the solar system.

The wild, scruffy game of street hockey, which began 100 years ago in Canada with youngsters flailing with branches at pucks composed of frozen horse manure, took another step toward respectability yesterday.

American Medical Association members argued, often bitterly, today over whether to support or oppose a new Federal law that is to create a national monitoring system to examine the quality of each doctor's services.

Police Officer Harvey Gronwald, who was flown to California by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in an attemp to replace his ailing heart with a healthy one, died Sunday night at the Stanford Medical Center.

Frank Sinatra is working hard to raise money for his close friend, former -Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, according to knowledgeable sources here. The entertainer recently called and wrote to a number of his friends, asking them to contribute up to $3,000 to help defray Mr. Agnew's sizable legal expenses, the sources said.

The Soviet Union, concerned by recent West European moves toward political and military cooperation, sought today to maintain the momentum of reconciliation in Europe in separate talks with the British Foreign Secretary and the French Defense Minister.
John A. Hill, who retired in 1969 as chairman of Airco, Inc., formerly the Air Reduction Company, died Sunday night while visiting his daughter's home in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico.

Retail sales will slow down in the months ahead because of unemployment problems arising from the energy crisis, Franklin M. Jarman, chairman of Genesco, Inc., said today after the company's annual meeting here.
Columbia University's first woman trustee said last night that she would be "naive" not to think that being a woman had something to do with her nomination.

Mayor Lindsay last night presented the Diamond Jubilee Medallion of the City of New York to Ada Louise Huxtable in recognition of her appointment to the editorial board of The New York Times, where she had been architecture critic.

The United States Environmental Protection Agency announced a new set of regulations yesterday designed to reduce the use of automobiles in 14 of New Jersey's 21 counties without reliance on the steep parking charges that touched
Talk of good export buying spurred a rise in wheat futures prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. As a result, the March contract closed at $4.84 a bushel, up from $4.72 on Friday.

The Babcock Wilcox Company reported yesterday receipt of contracts for the manufacture of nuclear components valued at $64.5-million. The awards were made by the Atomic Energy Commission and the work would be performed at the company's facility at Lynchburg, Va.

The new rules for promotion of pupils in the city's elementary and junior high schools should be viewed not as a punitive toughening of standards but as a humane and honest effort to give meaning to secondary education.

A study to consider setting up a sound-and-light show at the nation's Capitol to recount its history was approved today by the House and sent to the Senate. The show would be conducted nightly at the Capitol's east front, where Presidents are inaugurated,

CHICAGO - In his energy crisis speech President Nixon called on America's scientific community to develop new sources of energy. The presumption made by the President is that the current crisis is in some way a scientific, technological problem. If that were so, we would be in greater trouble, for the American scientific community is in difficulty at the moment because the Nixon Administration has begun to dismantle this country's strength in basic research.

Sounding like a Presidential candidate again, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama declared last night that he did not trust either the Soviet Union or China despite their current accommodation with the United States.

Some of the coziest people in town this winter may be in some of the oldest houses and tenements, in firehouses or in classrooms-provided that the 471 public schools heated with coal do not have to close on cold days because of a fuel-oil shortage in the rest of the school system.

TONGDUCKON, South Korea--Three outbursts of racial violence erupted among American troops here on Oct. 7, after a period of relative quiet. The incidents apparently touched off outbreaks among American forces elsewhere in South Korea.

Wrecking crews have destroyed one of the last remaining relics of the old west to make way for a motel. Destruction of the old United States express office where the first Pony Express rider picked up his pouch of mail for the trip to California in 1860 marked the end of a two-year losing fight by historical groups to preserve the structure.
Officials at Montclair State College are considering delaying the opening of the spring term by at least two weeks and perhaps longer in the face of the oil shortage.
LAI KHE, South Vietnam-A thin young man in wrinkled green North Vietnamese Army fatigues folded and unfolded his hands as he sat and talked in the South Vietnamese division commander's office.
A state prosecutor charged yesterday that judges, Assemblymen, commissioners, marshals and their deputies had made nighttime trips to an apartment in Brooklyn to get their parking tickets fixed.
The New York Philharmonic picks up an interrupted melody today, resuming rehearsals at Avery Fisher Hall for the orchestra's first concert there since a strike broke off the season on Sept. 25.
Fulton Fish Market employes struck yesterday, halting most deliveries of fresh fish throughout the metropolitan area.

A plan to weld the legislators from New York City, Westchester and Nassau into a political block to present a united front in Washington and Albany on matters of mutual concern was decided upon yesterday at a meeting of Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame, County Executive Ralph G. Case of Nassau and Alfred Del Bello, Mayor of Yonkers and County Executive-elect of Westchester.
The General Motors Corporation said today that previously announced layoffs to cut production of slow-selling big cars would affect 137,000 United States and Canadian auto workers this month.

Hofstra University concluded its Southern trip by losing to Mercer University tonight, 89-74. Inexperience showed again as the Dutchmen, after cutting a Mercer lead to eight midway in the second half, committed key turnovers that resulted in the final margin. Rich Laurel, a freshman, paced the Dutchmen with 19 points and Len Hardin of Mercer scored 25 points.

The Supreme Court took the following actions today: ARMED FORCES Declined to review a decision denying damages to the operator of a language school at Lackland Air Force Base after the Air Force had let his $40,000-a-year contract lapse and then hired all
President Nixon, in a reversal of position, has decided to ask the House of Representatives to proceed with the big foreign trade bill despite the risk of strong anti-Soviet amendments.

Massachusetts leads the states in per -capita sales of lottery tickets, William E. Perrault, director of the state lottery, said yesterday. He said that the total sale for the week ending Nov. 22 was $2.1-million, which was a rate of 37 cents a person.

Joseph Stuart Murtaugh, a health science administrator who helped shape policy of the National Institutes of Health during their period of greatest expansion, died today at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 61 years old.

President Nixon's "New Federalism" was harshly criticized today before a large gathering of United States mayors and city officials as "a mandate from the White House to accept its definition of a more orderly process of government."

Disgruntled passengers said today they were disturbed by the news that Eastern Airlines was ending its shuttle service between Newark International Airport and Boston and Washington, as of Jan. 7, to save fuel.

David Ben-Gurion, Israel's first Premier, was buried in a starkly simple service in Sde Boker, Israel, near the desert kibbutz where he spent the contemplative final years of his life. A group of 300 political and military leaders, representatives of foreign governments, family members and former associates attended the service.

Jim Willis, a union carpenter in Bonner, Mont., (pop. 250), grossed $408.01 on his most recent weekly pay stub and is getting a 6 per cent raise, his second of the year. But Mr. Willis feels squeezed financially and is starting to worry about the future.

The Defense Department, under the pressure of a Congressional budgetary cut, has reversed itself and decided it does not have an adequate system to warn of an attack by submarine-launched ballistic missiles.
The Supreme Court upheld today the law that limits New York State Regent Scholarships to award winners who decide to go to college inside the state.

Twenty-eight American officers arrived today to join the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization. A United Nations spokesman said that the men would take up positions along the Israeli side of the Suez and Syrian fronts for 90 days.

Not long after Walt Michaels had departed the Jets after 10 seasons as their defensive architect, some people suggested his methods had become outmoded and were one of the reasons the Jets had crumbled since their Super Bowl championship.

In a postscript to the five-team race in the National League's East last September, the Denver Bears of the American Association today signed Bill Virdon, who was dismissed as manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates with three weeks to go in the season.

Scores of truck drivers, enraged over the high price of fuel and lowered speed limits, staged a protest on Interstate 80 in the Pocono Mountains last night that continued into this morning, blocking all traffic more than 15 miles in each direction, the state police reported.
Considering it was a world premiere, the crowd was rather small-but select. But, then, the film wasn't too long either, just 15 minutes.
A 67-year-old East Harlem woman on welfare put up $67,500 in bail money several weeks ago after she and her son were arrested on narcotics charges, welfare officials said yesterday.

OTTAWA--In the October issue of Foreign Affairs, Prof. Robert M. Dunn Jr. of George Washington University characterizes relations between the Governments of Canada and the United States as "probably more strained than at any time in living memory."

A Rome court of appeals has revoked an arrest warrant against Prince Junio Valerio Borghese, the wartime Fascist leader who was suspected of heading a right-wing plot to overthrow the Italian Government in December, 1970.

By a vote of 6 to 3, the Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal by the Penn Central Railroad to overturn a lower court ruling that blocked the sale of four New York City properties owned by the bankrupt railroad.

Tom Weiskopf shot a final three-under-par 67 today and won the rain-delayed South African P.G.A. championship by three strokes with a 72-hole total of 273. A string of four birdies on the back nine clinched the victory for the American. Vince Baker of South Africa was second. South Africa's Gary Player faded to fifth with a 72 for 280. The victory brought Weiskopf $9,000.

Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, announced yesterday that a group of geologists and engineers had left for the Soviet Union to make an onthe-spot study of natural gas fields that may supply part of United States energy needs in the nineteen-eighties.

Highly placed Arab diplomats here said today that Egypt and Syria had decided to boycott the proposed Middle East peace conference at Geneva unless Israeli forces carried out at least a limited withdrawal in the Suez city area.

A plan to weld the legislators from New York City, Westchester and Nassau into a political block to present a united front in Wash ington and Albany on matters of mutual concern was decided upon yesterday at a meeting of Mayor-elect
The doors to a free choice between working and staying at home have been opening wide for middle-class women.

Dog may be man's best friend most of the time, but with smugglers of narcotics it can be different. This was demonstrated yesterday when Duke, a German shepherd with experience with the Military Police in Vietnam, took only 40 seconds in the new U.S. Customs House at the World Trade Center to locate a pound of marijuana in one of 14 sealed cartons.
John A. Love, who gave up the governorship of Colorado five months ago to be President Nixon's energy "czar," resigned today because he had been shunted aside in a shake-up of energy policy-making.
At least one third of South Vietnam's stock of gasoline for civilian use was reperted destroyed early today by a rocket attack on a petroleum depot seven miles southeast of here.

Jim Willis, a union carpenter in Bonner, Mont., (pop. 250), grossed $408.01 on his most recent weekly pay stub and is getting a 6 per cent raise, his second of the year. But Mr. Willis feels squeezed financially and is starting to worry about the future.
Facilities for a conference on the abolition of torture have been withdrawn by the headquarters of UNESCO in Paris.

Chris Fernandez, 30-yearold welterweight from the Dominican Republic, scored a. decision over Adolphus McClendon of Paterson, N. J. last night in a 10-round bout at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

Surrounded by the sights and sounds of winter games, baseball opened the busiest talent market in sports today with a flurry of trades and a steepening of the argument over who will manage the New York Yankees.
One of Greece's principal political leaders, former Premier Panayotis Canellopoulos, joined today in the public criticism of the nation's new military rulers, which was begun last week.

The city's Department of Investigation and the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York have conducted inquiries into cash contributions to Mayor Lindsay's Presidential campaign by asphalt and paving contractors who do business with the city, some of the principals of the investigations have disclosed.

By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER A 14-year-old boy who spoke no English was stabbed to death on a Brooklyn subway platform yesterday as he and a companion attempted to evade a holdup by two 16-year-olds, the police reported.

The House voted today to require states to establish a uniform 55-mile-an-hour speed limit for automobiles, buses and trucks. The bill cleared the House by voice vote with no debate. It now goes to the Senate, which earlier attached to an oil allocation bill an amendment giving the President discretionary authority to establish national speed limits to conserve fuel.

The tape of the conversation between President Nixon and H. R. Haldeman that has been partly obliterated by an 18minute hum is being studied in a nondescript loft on West 131st Street, well within earshot of the elevated Broadway local subway trains.
More than 19,000 people last night attended a memorial tribute in Madison Square Garden to David Ben-Gurion, a founding father of Israel and her first Premier.
The Saigon milltary spokesman announced today that South Vietnamese aircraft had flown 124 bombing sorties yesterday against Communist positions.

Fifty-five chanting, sign-cartrying women protested the transfer of Lieut. Julia Tucker from commanding officer of the Police Department's sex crime analysis squad to patrol duty in Brooklyn's 88th Precinct, during a one-hour demonstration outside Police Headquarters yesterday.
John A. Love, who gave up the governorship of Colorado five months ago to be President Nixon's energy "czar," resigned today because he had been shunted aside in a shake-up of energy policy-making.
Assemblyman Edawrd M. Kinsel- N la, a two-term Republican Conservative of nearby Solvay, died this afternoon in Community General Hospital here after a long illness. He was 62 years old.
Philip Morris, Inc., has taken an option to purchase 460 acres of land in Oldham County, Ky., about 20 miles from Louisville.

Two separate explosions and fires damaged two Manhattan office buildings last night, one blast slightly injuring two staff workers of the United States Committee for Justice for Latin American Political Prisoners at 150 Fifth Avenue.
Five Japanese companies signed a $3-billion contract today with Pertamina guaranteeing a yearly supply of 7.5 million tons of Indonesian liquefied natural gas to Japan over a 20-year period.
The Senate wound up today a week-long debate on legislation that would overturn the traditional American system of paying for election campaigns with money collected from private donations.

On the eve of the first meeting of his National Commission on Critical Choices for America, Governor Rockefeller was host last night at a private dinner for Vice President-designate Gerald R. Ford and other members of the commission.
John Newcombe of Australia will face Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia in an opening match of the $50,000 Commercial Union Masters tennis tournament tomorrow at Haynes Auditorium.
Secretary General Waldheim today opened the third Law of the Sea Conference here by stressing that it was urgent to reach international agreement on the peaceful development of the ocean's resources.

The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that Mississippi had complied with an order to make plans to desegregate its statesupported colleges and universities, but that Louisiana had failed to comply and might be subject to legal action.

On the operatic stage, both Evelyn Lear and Thomas Stewart show signs of vocal wear. Miss Lear can no longer sing out at the top of the soprano range with ease or purity, and Mr. Stewart's lightness of voice and shortness of range have become more and more troubling when he essays the heavy Wagner baritone parts.

Tony Dorsett of the University of Pittsburgh, a running back, became the first freshman in 29 years to be named to The Associated Press all-America college football team, announced yesterday. The team has three repeaters, Randy Gradishar and John Hicks of Ohio State and Richard Wood of Southern California.
Mayor Lindsay filled the only vacancy on the City Planning Commission yesterday, placing in doubt the job of the current commission chairman when Abraham D. Beame takes over as Mayor.

The United States Treasury, blocked yesterday by Congress from borrowing the $4.3-billion it normally gets each Monday, scheduled its sale of threemonth and six-month bills for 1:30 P.M. today instead.

Being on the highways during the first "gasless Sunday" was an oaa experience. Virtually everyone seemed to be observing the new gas-saving speed limits-55 m.p.h. in North Carolina-and service stations were closed as bidden, with few exceptions.

The Governor's transition office announced yesterday that Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne would take the oath of office at an indoor ceremony in Trenton at noon on Jan. 15 in the War Memorial Building near the State House. The inauguration festivities will begin the night before with a concert at the War Memorial by the New Jersey Symphony.

The wild, scruffy game of street hockey, which began 100 years ago in Canada with youngsters flailing with branches at pucks composed of frozen horse manure, took another step toward respectability yesterday.

Jupiter reached out with its exceptionally strong gravitational field last night and gave to the first manmade intruder into its vicinity a tremendous yank throwing Pioneer 10 into a trajectory that will carry it far beyond the solar system.
A decade ago, long before needlework became a national mania, embroidery enthusiasts quickly graduated from the limited stock of commercial kits and patterns to designing their own.

THE SATURDAY NIGHT SPECIAL. By Robert Sherrill. Illustrated by Julio Fernandez. 338 pages. Charterhouse. $8.95. The full title of Robert Sherrill's splenetic report on guns in American society is "The Saturday Night Special, and Other Guns With Which Americans Won the West, Protected Bootleg Franchises, Slew Wildlife, Robbed Countless Banks, Shot Husbands Purposely and by Mistake and Killed Presidents--Together With the Debate Over Continuing Same."
Stock prices tumbled sharply yesterday amid Investors' concern over the increasing energy crisis, the possibility of a recession and rising interest rates.
The House of Representatives voted today to remove a constitutional impediment to the nomination of Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, to be Attorney General.

Mayort Richard J. Daley said today that Chicago was "re-evaluating" its proposal to impose a tax on stock and commodity transactions in the face of vocal opposition from the city's business and investment cormmunity.
David Ben-Gurion, Israel's first Premier, was buried here today in a starkly simple 45minute religious service near the Negev Desert kibbutz where he spent the contemplative final years of his life.
American motorists went back to the gasoline pumps yesterday, crowding into stations that had been closed Sunday, and traffic returned to normal levels on the highways.

Earl Wild is one of those strange pianists who play better as the music gets worse. In his Alice rully Hall recital on Sunday night, he reached his peak of acceptability in Liszt's "Grande tarantelle di bravura sur la tarantelle de 'La muette de Portici', d'Auber,' a depressing piece of trash that must figure low on the quality scale of Lizst arrangements and transcriptions.
The old Romans said, "You can't argue about taste" ("De gustibus non est disputandum").

Fred L. Turner, president of McDonald's Corporation, the giant fast-food chain with 2,600 franchised and owned stores throughout the world, has been named chief executive officer. He succeeds Ray A. Kroc, 71, who continues as chairman.

Jimmy Connors won but Stan Smith lost at the start of the Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament today. The eight top finishers in the year-long Commercial Union Grand Prix were meeting in a roundrobin with $15,000 as the first prize.

James E. Rudder's car collided with a river barge recently. Mr. Rudder, 29 years old of Romeoville, drove his car through warning gates at a drawbridge over the Des Plaines River, sheriff's deputies reported.

Dixy Lee Ray, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, has told President Nixon that, even with a five-year, $10-billion research and development program, the United States is unlikely to attain his "Project Independence 1980" goal of energy self-sufficiency by 1980.
Thomas S. Kleppe, administrator of the Small Business Administration, rejected today allegations that his agency was a riddled with political and criminal corruption and was badly mismanaged
Corporate bond prices were marked down yesterday and the tax-exempt market drifted lower as dealers and investors assessed a large volume of new offerings.

A lawyer for Howard R. Hughes opened a brown attache case at a Senate Watergate committee interrogation today, pulled out two manila envelopes containing 1,000 hundred-dollar bills and slammed them on the table in front of Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr.
The Treasury will shortly announce an increase to 6 per cent from 5 1/2 per cent in the interest rate paid on Government savings bonds, authoritative official sources said today.

The East Coast's most highly prized light-tackle marine game fish, the striped bass, will be the subject of a lecture series at the College of Mount St. Vincent in the Bronx Saturday. The program opens at 10 A.M. in the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium.
President Nixon is scheduled to have his physical examination at Bethesda Naval Medical Center around mid-December, the White House physician said today.
The first private foundation on a national scale devoted solely to the arts and the humanities is now being incorporated by a group of arts patrons and professionals.

Congress Is slowly trying to master the old and difficult problem of its own responsibility for the nation's budget. A President can act decisively in shaping the multitudinous money requests of the agencies and departments into a reasonably unified and coherent document. But when the budget reaches Capitol Hill, power is divided between the two houses of Congress and

Prodded by Government legal action, the major steel companies and the steelworkers union are quietly negotiating a historic nationwide program aimed at ending racial discrimination in employment practices throughout their industry.

Sheik Ahmed Zaki al-Yamani, the Saudi Arabian Minister of Petroleum Affairs, said here yesterday that the mere bargaining of peace talks between the Arabs and Israelis would not alter the Arabs' oil embargo and production cutbacks that had brought about worldwide energy crisis.

President Nixon indicated today that he would veto the trade bill if it finally reaches himth provisions aimed at curbing trade with the Soviet Union. The President's position was outlined in a letter to Carl Albert, the Speaker of the House, requesting that the House of Representatives proceed with the basic legislation. The existence of the letter was made known last night and its contents were released today.
Robert Notte, executive director of the Newark Housing Authority, today assailed Judge Joseph F. Walsh's recent ruling reducing rents by 80 per cent in the Stella Wright public housing project.
Chris Worthy recorded his first shutout of the World Hockey Association season tonight to pace the Edmonton Oilers to a 2-0 victory over the Chicago Cougars.

Two gunmen held up a branch of the Chemical Bank at 93-01 Northern Boulevard, Jackson Heights, Queens, shortly after 2 P.M. yesterday and fled with $10,000. The police said the robbers were middle-aged, with beards and mustaches that might have been disguises.... Three armed men wearing ski masks held up a crowded, newly

Securities held for clients of Bache Co. will be insured for up to $250,000, the company said yesterday. Such insurance applies to fully owned securities left in custody for safekeeping in addition to $50,000 in protection provided by the Securities Investors Protectin Corporation.

The Phillips Petroleum Company and its former board chairman, William W. Keeler, pleaded guilty in United States District Court here today to contributing $100,000 illegally to President Nixon's 1972 campaign.

Justice Department officials said today that they would shortly turn over to a Federal judge a key White House tape and other documents related to a possible link between Administration help to the milk industry and campaign contributions by dairymen.

A. Ernest Fitzgerald, who was dismissed in 1970 after disclosing cost overruns of $2-billion on the C-5 jet transport plane, said today that he did not want the new job the Air Force was offering in place of his old one.
Two persons were killed last night on the New Jersey Turnpike when their automobile hit a truck that was blocking the road after an earlier accident.

In an open letter to Mr. Agnew, published on the Op-Ed page on Oct. 15, Roy M. Cohn took the former Vice President to task for making "a dumb mistake ... in quitting and accepting a criminal conviction." Having himself been acquitted after three separate Federal indictments on charges of conspiracy, bribery and fraud, Mr. Cohn evidently considered himself particularly well qualified to suggest that Mr. Agnew's "chances for legal and political survival were excellent."
Lady Beatty, widow of Earl Beatly, was married to John Grenfell Nutting in Westminster Abbey today. The ceremony was performed in the Henry VII Chapel by the Very Rev.

The first private foundation on a national scale devoted solely to the arts and the humanities is now being incorporated by a group of arts patrons and professionals. To head it, W. McNeil Lowry will leave

It's interesting to see how a good writer can make us care about a "bad" character. I mean bad in a moral sense. Talent, it seems, can find the humanity behind the inhuman, the pathos that comes from being out of step with the world, the loneliness, like death, that is the wages of sin.

State Senator Bernard Gordon, the senior state legislator from Westchester County, expressed strong opposition yesterday to the plan evolved on Monday by Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame of New York: City, County Executive Ralph G. Caso of Nassau and County Executive-elect Alfred Del Bello of Westchester to weld the legislators from those three areas into a political bloc in Washington and Albany on common problems.

National Airlines announced yesterday that it planned to cancel scheduled daily roundtrip service between Miami and London on five dates this month to conserve fuel.

An exhibition, "Central Park: A Beginning for the Second Century," opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum to publicize the city's campaign' for the restoration of the park, including restoration of all bridges and arches, a tree-preservation program, and restoration of major park areas such as the Mall, the Bethesda Fountain and the Sheep Meadow.

A $5.8-billion foreign-aid appropriation bill restoring the full $2.2-billion President Nixon requested to replace the arms Israel lost in the Middle East war was approved today by the House Appropriations Committee.

Richard P. Malkin, president of Richard Malkin Company, an advertising and marketing consultant concern of Westport, and executive vice president of Curriculum Studios, New York, died today of cancer in Norwalk Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived here.

Copper futures climbed once again yesterday, with the December delivery touching its recent record high of $1.07/2 a pound. The contract closed on the Commodity Exchange at $1.07. up 2 cents since Monday.
There are three reasons for going to see the National Folk Ensemble of Pakistan, which made its local debut, for a run through Sunday, at the Felt Forum last night.

The Senate Democratic t leader, Mike Mansfield, said today that Congressional leaders were planning two moves to guard against any surprise maneuvers by President Nixon during a month-long Christmas adjournment.
The big three auto makers urged Congress today to decide at this session whether to approve White House or alternative proposals to ease the laws on automobile pollution.

A tentative contract agreement was reached yesterday between Fulton Fish Market employers and their workers, who went on strike Monday. As a result, fresh fish is expected to be to be back in ample supply in restaurants and retail market.

The City Council, increasing in size by six members on Jan. I and already too large for City Hall, has. decided to take more than two floors of additional space in a 31-story office skyscraper across Broadway from City Hall Park.

Coast Guard surface and air units and a French ore carrier joined forces in the Atlantic 150 miles southeast of here yesterday afternoon to rescue the 19-man crew of the sinking Cypriot freighter Aegis Duty.

France's most popular satirical newspaper, Le Canard Enchaine, charged today that the French Government had sent a team of five men to break into the weekly's new offices last night to install electronic listening devices.
District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn announced the indictment of 10 state examiners yesterday for accepting bribes from businessmen in exchange for underestimating their annual sales taxes.

Baseball's winter trading market started to boom today when the Pittsburgh Pirates sent Nelson Briles to the Kansas City Royals and the Cincinnati Reds got Merv Rettenmund from the Baltimore Orioles for Ross Grimsley.
The Pioneer 10 spacecraft cruised beyond Jupiter tonight, continuing to return scientific data and apparently unharmed by its rough passage through the giant planet's belts of intense radiation.

Robert A. Morse, United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, plunged to his death from his fifth-floor Brooklyn Heights apartment yesterday afternoon, hours after he had, told the chief judge of the district that he intended to resign.

Britain and the Soviet Union agreed today to put their relations on a more normal, cordial basis after two years of diplomatic coolness, but remained at odds on the issue of a freer flow of people and information between East and West.
Shares on the London Stock Exchange, feeling the effect of the growing energy crisis and industrial disputes, plunged to their lowest levels in more than two and a half years today.

The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia said tonight that a former employee of the United States-financed Radio Liberty, regarded here as antiSoviet, had come to Moscow and was planning to reveal the secrets of the station.

Dr. Ernest. R. Granger, past president of the American Academy of Restorative Dentistry, died Friday at Polyclinic Hospital after suffering a heart attack at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He was 68 years old and lived in Pelham Manor N. Y.

Wentworth A. Matthew, rounder and chief Rabbi of the Beth Ha-Tphila Ethiopian Congregation, One West 123d Street, died monday at Harlem Hospital, following a heart attack he suffered last month. He was 81 years old.

Both the state and the city were notified by their gasoline suppliers yesterday that allocations would be cut sharply this month. For the city, which is supplied by Exxon, it means that government agencies will have to cut back services as of next Monday because of a 14 per cent reduction.

Algeria, China and 31 other countries opened a drive in the General Assembly today to expel the Cambodian Government of President Lon Nol and seat instead that of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed leader now living in Peking.
The United States today resumed full diplomatic contacts with Greece's new army-backed Government, which took power in a bloodless coup Nov. 25.

Prodded by Government legal action, the major steel companies and the steelworkers union are quietly negotiating a historic nationwide program aimed at ending racial discrimination in employment practices throughout their industry.
The Senate approved tonight emergency legislation sought by President Nixon to put the nation on year-round daylight saving time for the next two years to help ease the energy shortage.

Secretary of State Kissinger reportedly told a leading Egyptian editor last month that peace in the Middle East was "not around the corner" and that it might take six months to a year for concrete results from the Arab-Israeli negotiations due to begin in Geneva on Dec. 18.
It took Mother Nature precisely 100 years to equal the record high temperature she provided on Dec. 4, 1873: 66 degrees measured in New York on that date then and again at 2:30 P.M. yesterday.
A grenade was exploded in the crowded main shopping area of Jerusalem's. Old City to-day, injuring 18 persons, the police said.

The Whitlock Golf Club of Hudson Heights, Quebec, held a one-stroke lead over Truro Golf Club, Nova Scotia, and York Downs Golf Club, Unionville, Ontario, at the halfway stage of the 21st annual Bermuda Goodwill golf tournament today.

With Vice President-designate Gerald R. Ford at his side, praising him as Presidential timber, Governor Rockefeller held the first meeting of his new National Commission on Critical Choices for America yesterday and denied that it was a "stepping stone" toward tht White House.

Edward B. (Ted) Wilson 2d, who has spent his entire agency career at J. Walter Thompson, need not look for' a change now. On Jan. 1 he'll become the sixth president of the 109-year-oldcompany, the world's largest single agency, which expects to bill more than $800-million this year.
Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 14 of his 32 points in the second quarter tonight, breaking open a tight game and leading the Milwaukee Bucks to a 124-109 victory over the Houston Rockets.
O'Shea, the stage, film and television actor, was found dead in his apartment here today. His death was attributed to a heart attack. He was 67 ears old.
Hundreds of tractor - trailer drivers blocked highways in at least five states yesterday, contending that lower speed limits and higher fuel prices were. costing them money.
The American Petroleum Institute's president, Frank N. Ikard, said today that the oil shortage would last "as long as most of us will live."
nationwide run on gasoline today caused clogged highways and jammed service stations, forcing dealers to close early to conserve dwindling supplies.

Boris Anisfeldt, an artist who had designed costumes and decor for the Ballet Russe when it was directed by Diaghilev, died today at the New London Convalescent Home, Waterford. He was 94 years old and lived here.

Health problems that civilized man often attribute to civilization can also afflict primitive people living in isolation from modern industrial society, studies begun eight years ago in the Amazon jungles have disclosed.

Bentsen Jr., is the junior Senator from Texas and chairman of the Senate financial market subcommittee.

A mother and four of her children were killed today in an early-morning explosion and fire that destroyed their home. Capt. Pierre Hollingsworth, head of the Fire Prevention Bureau, said the fire was believed to have been started when a child playing with matches threw one under a gas stove, which exploded.

Clyde took a ride yesterday. He drove his burgundy Rolls-Royce across the Manhattan Bridge to Brooklyn, where he eventually wound up in a wood-paneled room with a sign over the door that said: "The Clyde Room."

At the entrance to "Central Park: A Beginning for the Second Century," an exhibition that opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a series of old photographs tracing the construction of park roads and landscaping.

Richard J. Vizzini, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, and three other union officials-as well as the union itself - pleaded guilty yesterday to contempt of court for leading and participating in the five-and-a-half hour strike by the city's firefighters on Nov 6.

Five African heads of slate met here yesterday to work out agreenients on tile transit of cattle and farm produce, fishing rights and the sharing of debts and responsibilities in the area of Lake Chad in Central Africa.
American Automobile Association has urged motorists to reduce the use of their automobiles voluntarily by at least 25 per cent, to forestall the prospects of gasoline rationing.

North Vietnamese tanks and troops yesterday assaulted and seized a district capital in remote, mountainous Quang Duc Province, once again taking the offensive in a month-old struggle for control of a key road system in the Central Highlands, the Saigon command announced this morning.

The latest battle in the Senate to get some honest rules for financing political campaigns was defeated, but this was only the opening skirmish in a long war, and maybe the vote to delay a decision was not all bad.

Crib death, which mysteriously takes the lives of an estimated total of 10,000 seemingly healthy infants in this country each year, may be caused by a failure of the breathing mechanism while the baby sleeps, according to newly published findings.
In the last few days, the state-owned oil and gas combine and Italy's large Communist party have come out for a change in foreign policy that would involve a closer relationship with Arab countries.

But it does not prove, as Senator Jackson and others argue, that the detente has now been exposed as an illusion.

The Burroughs Corporation said yesterday that the Society de Banque Suisse, the Swiss Bank Corporation, had ordered six medium-scale B3700 computers, 200 system and communications processors and 1,000 on-line terminal units. Burroughs said the purchase price was more than $20-million.

A group of investors filed a $500-million suit yesterday against Gulf Western Industries, Inc., charging that a pending tender offer is part of a conspiracy to destroy the value of Madison Square Garden stock.

Ralph Nader said here yesterday that the oil industry was to blame for the nation's energy problems and that consumer apathy in general - fostered for years by oil and other industries-made it likely that even dramatic increases in fuel prices would get by with relatively little outcry.

Hofheinz, a 34-year-old liberal lawyer and the son of a former Houston Mayor, narrowly defeated tonight a conservative City Councilman in a non partisan runoff election to succeed Mayor Louie Welch, who held the office for 10 years and is retiring.
A judge rejected today a motion for a hearing on whether the prosecution had suppressed evidence in the murder case involving Mrs. Laura Carpi, whose head was severed after her death.

Gaylord Perry's so-called "spitball," .his psychological ace-in-the-hole againstAmerican League batters, may be doomed by the new rule adopted Monday that allows umpires to call the illegal pitch "a ball" if, in their judgment that's what they think a pitcher is throwing. No proof needed.

Walt Frazier of the Knicks and Geoff Petrie of Portland were one of the backcourt matchups last night at Madison Square Garden. In the first half, Petrie could do no wrong.
Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said here yesterday that although he couldn't prove it, he believed that Arthur H. Bremer, the man who shot him two years ago, did not act alone.

Coach Dick Motta cleared the Chicago Bulls' bench tonight as the club posted its highest scoring game of the season in a 130-107 decision over the Seattle SuperSonics.

An old chestnut mare named Tiki Minx completed a rare kind of triple at Aqueduct yesterday by racing to her third victory in a week. Listed as the day's best bet in the Daily Racing Form, Tiki Minx took the fifth race by two lengths as a 7-5 favorite. She was ridden by Jorge Velasquez.

semblyman J. Edward Meyer, Republican of Chappaqua, announced today that he was switching his allegiance to the Democratic party.

President Nixon welcomed President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania today with full state honors and warm words. The independentminded Communist leader is here for talks on trade and the Middle East.

The Daytona 24-hour sports car race, scheduled for Feb. 2-3, has been postponed until later in the year, Bill France, president of Daytona International Speedway, announced today. France emphasized, however, that the remainder of the track's annual February "Speed Weeks" program is on schedule, including the $236,325 Daytona 500 for stock cars Feb. 17.

Denmark's ruling Social Democrats and the three-party non-Socialist opposition both suffered heavy defeats in Parliamentary elections today and Premier Anker Jorgensen announced he would resign.

Brendan T. Byrne, the Governor-elect, announced today that he had 'chosen J. Edward Crabiel, the Democratic Senate minority leader from Middlesex County and one of his opponents in the party's gubernatorial primary, as Secretary of State.

The Supreme Court ruled today that brokerage rules promulgated by the New York Stock Exchange could be overridden by state laws if the rules did not further a national plan to protect the investing public.

For the third time in four years, Benny Carter, one of the great style-setting alto saxophonists in jazz, as well as a celebrated composer, arranger and big-band leader, has come from his home in Hollywood to teach and perform at Princeton University.

Brendan Byrne, the Governor-elect, announced today that he had chosen J. Edward Crabiel, the Democratic Senate minority Leader from Middlesex County and one of his opponents in the party's gubernatorial primary, as Secretary of State.
A major wholesale supplier of some heating oil in the New York City area raised the price to retailers yesterday by 11.1 cents a gallon, an employee of the concern said last night.
The first round of forecasts concerning the economic impact of the energy shortage has drawn an unusual number of participants and disclosed an extraordinary
Premier Kim Jong Pil promised today that his new Cabinet would carry out "administrative reforms" to try to dispel mistrust of the Government.

Plans for rival stadiums advanted yesterday as Governor Rockefeller announced that he had received a favorable report on the feasibility of a sports complex in Suunnyside, Queens, and Governor Cahill signed legislation placing New Jersey's "moral pledge" behind the New Jersey complex proposed for the Hackensack Meadowlands.

The Netherlands today said for the first time that she felt Israel's occupation of Arab territory was "illegal." A Foreign Office spokesman, asked to elaborate on the Government's Middle East policy at a news briefing, said:
Walt Frazier of the Knicks and Geoff Petrie of Portland were one of the backcourt matchups last night at Madison Square Garden. In the first half, Petrie could do no wrong.

Many people believe that the military spends a disproportionate share of our national wealth. In addition, they believe that the military continually raises the specter of the threats to our national security just to obtain more money and to perpetuate themselves. This simply is not true.

The agonized impotence of cripples and their hopes for heroism and survival are the subject matter of a documentary - style play called "Creeps," which opened last night at Playhouse 2 on West 48th Street.
The Senate approved tonight emergency legislation sought by President Nixon to put the nation on year-round daylight saving time for the next two years to help ease the energy shortage.

The Xerox Corporation, blocked in its plan to build an office campus in the rural "back country" of Greenwich, announced today that it had acquired instead sites in Stamford and in downtown Greenwich.
Nine elderly residents of a nursing home were killed and 42 others hospitalized today when fire enveloped a nursing home in this affluent Philadelphia suburb.
A moderate technical rebound yesterday evaporated in the last hour of trading, and stock prices ended lower in heavier trading.

The Federal Government said today that it had decided to cut back by 1 million gallons-about 11 per cent-the amount of diesel fuel requested by the United States Postal Service to deliver mail during the Christmas season.
The United Mine Workers of America said today that it would seek a six-hour work day in negotiations for a 1974 contract.

John Cappelletti, the big, fast tailback on Penn State's undefeated team, was named winner of the 39th annualHeisman Trophy yesterday as "the outstanding intercollegiate football player in the United States" for 1973.

The Federal Reserve, which began to intervene in the foreign exchange market in July to prop the dollar, disclosed yesterday that its activity tapered off substantially during the three-months from early August to late October.

The White House confirmed today that its Congressional liaison office dispatched an Air Force plane Sunday to Oklahoma, where it picked up two Republican Senators and returned them to Washington, where they voted to uphold a filibuster aimed to kill an amendment to the debt ceiling bill.
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, in an unusual action, has lent about $500,000 to a company formerly headed by C. Arnholt Smith, the San Diego financier.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell again yesterday for the fourth consecutive session after a spate of afternoon buying failed to overcome early losses. Volume was moderate. Prices in the over-the-counter market also continued to decrease in slightly increased trading.
The Dallas Cowboys announced today that for the first time signs would be allowed to be exhibited in Texas Stadium on a Sunday.

PARIS-In 1950 Mao Tse-tung published an essay saying: "All Chinese without exception must lean either to the side of imperialism or to the side of socialism. Sitting on the fence will not do, nor is there a third road."
John A. Love, the President's former chief energy adviser, returned home today, describing himself as "battered and bruised a little bit" by his experiences in Washington.

Calling owners complainers "because now they only make thousands instead of millions," the head of the National Hockey League Players Association indicated yesterday the league would be taken to court to overthrow its new option clause.
Fifteen "courageous dissenters" in the Soviet Union were chosen here yesterday as winners of the 1973 Freedom Award by the nonprofit private organization known as Freedom House.

That special solicitude the defenders of free choice on Capitol Hill keep showing for the poor was in evidence last week when the Senate whooped through an anti-abortion rider to the bill liberalizing Social Security benefits.

John Jennings, historical novelist and travel writer, died Tuesday at his home at Miller Place in Suffolk County, L.I. His age was 66. Mr. Jennings's first book was "Our American Tropics," published in 1938.

A report by a Rutgers College faculty committee today criticized campus policies affecting black students and urged a sweeping re-evaluation and change of admissions, counseling and financial aid policies.
Joe Carithers, superintendent of Big Bend National Park, said today that parts of the Southwest Texas park would be closed to the public beginning next week because of the energy crisis.

Gina Monasco bought a huge, orange, plush fish at Macy's yesterday. "It's for my mother," the 10-year-old explained. "She's going to like it," solemnly agreed Margaret Quinones, who attends P.S. 122 in Brooklyn with Gina.

It was supposed to bring back the glories of nightclub life in New York before muggings and television kept people off the streets. It was to reproduce the titillating zaniness of Alcazar, the popular Paris cabaret, with its singing and female impersonators.
Negotiators from South Korea and North Korea met today at the armistice border camp of Panmunjom to discuss the resumption of political talks between the two countries.
Syria denied today that her soldiers had killed Israeli prisoners of war and said such allegations by Israel were part of a campaign of hatred to cover her own war crimes.
An environmental group went into Federal Court in New Haven to block constructinn of a second section of the new Route 7 in Fairfield County.

Teresa Escandon, a Cubanborn pianist now on the Hartt College of Music faculty in Hartford, has studied with some of the best teachers in the country--Isabelle Vengerova, Edward Steuermann, Ward Davenny--and it shows.

The Department of Transportation, concluding a three-year investigation, supported today the Ford Motor Company's refusal to recall more than four million passenger cars for correction of a suspected safety defect.

The witness swore to tell the whole truth, and counsel began his examination: "General Haig, where are you employed?" For just a moment in Judge John Sirica's courtroom there was the flickering illusion of an ordinary judicial proceeding. Alexander M. Haig Jr. described his education, his career, his position at the White House.
The National League will meet again tomorrow morning to consider the disposition of the San Diego franchise. A four-hour session today ended with no votes taken and no decisions made.

LALALA Ron Eliran, the Israeli singer, once described those lilting syllables as an "area code" and the area to hear both them and Mr. Eliran is at El Avram, one flight down at 80 Grove Street, near Seventh Avenue and Fourth Street (243-9661, 243-0602).

Player representatives yesterday authorized the National Hockey League Players Association to reject an option clause proposed by N.H.L. owners for future contracts. R. Alan Eagleson, the Toronto lawyer who is-executive director of the association, said the owners were trying "unilaterally" to achieve something that had been turned down in joint negotiations. The option clause would, replace the traditional reserve clause, which the N.H.L. owners have been enjoined from using.
Jacob J. Kalter, a former political columnist at The Hudson Dispatch in Union City, died today at his home here. His age was 74.

Glassboro State College has stopped participating in an educational program for prison inmates following the filing of assault charges against one Leesburg Prison Farm inmate who attended evening classes at the school. The program, sponsored by the Garden State Educational
MetroGoldwyn-Mayer, Inc., entered the hotel business here tonight with all the hoopla that attended the premieres of its movies in tile nineteen-thirties.

Bridge may well be the only sport or recreation in which 25,000 people take part actively in one event at the same time-although not at the same place. The event is the continentwide charity game of the American Contract Bridge League, to be played Friday, Dec. 14. Play is at 300
Nicholas Johnson announced tonight that he was stepping down as a Federal Communications Commisioner without waiting for the Senate to confirm a succesor.

Ralph Newman, the Chicago rare books expert who appraised President Nixon's VicePresidential papers at $570,000, said today that he valued them "conservatively" because he knew Mr. Nixon planned to give them to the Government.

The Coast Guard cutter Unimak arrived here yesterday morning with the 19 crew members of the Cypriot freighter Aegis Duty. The 488-foot Aegis Duty, bound from Newfoundland to Savannah, Ga., with a cargo of gypsum, sent out a distress message Tuesday morning when she was 150 miles southeast of here.

A 16-year-old youth arrested for a murder in a subway station Monday is believed by officials to be the youngster who was sent home from a state training school last July after a landmark decision by the state's highest court.

Governor Rockefeller and Brendan T. Byrne, New Jersey's Governor - elect, exchanged friendly, generalized promises of cooperation here yesterday, then politely disagreed over their rival plans for sports complexes.

Herbert J. Stern, the United States Attorney for New Jersey who won a national reputation for his successful prosecution of corruption on the state and local level, was nominated yesterday by President Nixon to a Federal judgeship. Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, who submitted Mr. Stern's name to the White House, has recommended Jonathan Goldstein, first assistant United States Attorney for New Jersey to succeed Mr.

The running of the $28,450 Interborough Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday seemingly went off without mishap, with Soul Mate carrying the silks of Robert Dodderidge to a clear success in the six-furlong test for fillies and mares.

Governor Rockefeller will give sworn testimony on Tuesday in an investigation by George F. Berlinger, the state's Welfare Inspector General, of circumstances surrounding a controversial computer contract awarded to H. Ross Perot, the Texas millionaire.
