The Senate has added so many amendments to a bill increasing Social Security benefits that it would "serve no purpose" to seek a House-Senate compromise, the acting chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said today.

Robert D. Timm, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said yesterday that his agency must take from airline management many of its prerogatives for scheduling flights if adequate service is to be maintained in the face of massive projected cutbacks due to fuel shortages.

A Monmouth County judge, overruling the conviction of a woman who was arrested while picketing a store here, has questioned the practice by the Middletown police of stripping and searching woman prisowners.
Christmas is a major selling season for bicycles--although the bicycle business has been booming all year long--and this year there is some added information for shoppers.
It was enough to make a public agency long to be private once again. First the management of Norman, Craig Kummel International showed slides that recorded the growth of the book value of its stock.

Most of the Tuesday night recital by Rudolf Serkin in Carnegie Hall was prime Serkin. This great pianist has never been known for infinite variety in program making, and more often than not he is content to concentrate on the things he loves best-Mozart, Schubert, Beethoven. But every once in a while he surprises.

A report by a Rutgers College faculty committee today criticized campus policies affecting black students and urged a sweeping re-evaluation and change of admissions, counseling and financial aid policies.

Former United States Representative Richard Pillsbury Gale died yesterday. He was 73 years old. Mr. Gale won honors as a sheep breeder, raised thoroughbred horses and experimented with raising certified seed and developing a nursery on eroded land.

Representative Ogden R. Reid formally opened his campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor yesterday by charging that Governor Rockefeller was "out of touch, aging and insensitive" and that a likely Democratic opponent for the governorship, Howard J. Samuels, was a three-time loser.

Denmark's election has confirmed a strong trend against the once-dominant Social Democrats in Scandinavia, but it has also turned up a disturbing tendency by voters to endorse the quack doctrines once hawked in France by Pierre Poujade. The over-all result is a badly fragmented Parliament, which will make effective government exceedingly difficult and prospects for the near future as cloudy as those in Norway and Sweden.
The House passed a bill today intended to strengthen the hand of Congress in contests with the White House over spending. The vote was 386 to 23.

The Government decided today to let refiners increase the price of heating oil by 2 cents a gallon, an increase that will be passed on to consumers in January and add about 7. per cent to the average home-heating bill.
Conservatives within the Presbyterian Church in the U.S. founded a new denomination today and named in the National Presbyterian Church.

The appointment of Mrs. Joan Whitman as Family/ Style editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor. Mrs. Whitman, who has been with The Times since 1955, had held positions as
Mrs. Grace Higby Peck, the widow of F. Hamilton Peck, a long-time newspaper man, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 68 years old and lived at 915 West End Avenue.

Fewer Americans are satisfield with their standard of living today than 10 years ago, according to the Gallup Poll. Seventy-one per cent of those queried in the latest survey said they were satisfied with their lot, as against 77 per cent in 1963.

A 42-member task force on health and hospitals appointed by Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame has recommended a complete overhaul of the Health and Hospitals Corporation and the Health Services Administration.
The enterprise of American Black Muslims has been pointed to as a showcase, an example of industry, competence and self-help that the entire black community should emulate.

Wheat farmers reaped a windfall of nearly half a billion dollars in Government subsidies last summer because the Agriculture Department under-estimated by 60 per cent how much the price of bread grain would go up. The subsidies, totaling $475.7-million, included "preliminary payments" authorized by Congress in a 1970 farm law.
This has been a bad year for Soviet international sports champions. It almost seems someone prefers to have their images somewhat tarnished.

The Soviet Union has begun flying military reconnaissance missions from the West African nation of Guinea, apparently to monitor ship movements in the South Atlantic, Pentagon officials reported today.

Governor Rockefeller and Brendan T. Byrne, New Jersey's Governor - elect, exchanged friendly, generalized promises of cooperation here yesterday, then politely disagreed over their rival plans for sports complexes.

John Engels scored 26 points and grabbed 14 rebounds tonight to pace Pennsylvania to a 91-79 victory over Manhattan at the Palestra. In the opener of the twin bill, St. Joseph's College downed Rider, 65-46.
Larry Kenon, the rookie forward of the New York Nets, scored a game high of 25 points and snared 15 rebounds tonight to spark a 108-103 victory over the Indiana Pacers.

Sheik Ahmed Zaki al-Yamani, the Saudi Arabian Petroleum Minister, met with Secretary of State Kissinger for 90 minutes today and said later that peace in the Middle East was "now more feasible than at any time in the past."

A stand rise in street crime, an expansion of organized crime, and the hampering of law enforcement operations are all distinct possibilities as a result of the nation's energy crisis, the administrator of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration said today.

An 84-year-old retired railroad engineer, who claimed his privacy was invaded by a television commercial, which put his head over the body of a naked lady, accepted a cash settlement today from the filmmaker Allen Funt and dropped the charges.

John Newcombe of Australia, jealously guarding his position as the world's No. 1 player, defeated Tom Gorman for the second time in four days today to remain the only player with a 100 per cent record in Masters tennis play.

The Afo-A-Kom, the centuryold sacred wood carving( was returned to the Fon of Kom today, seven years after it had mysteriously disappeared from the royal compound in its tiny kingdom and less than two months after it was found on sale in a New York art gallery.

The Right Rev. Walter H. Gray, Bishop Emeritus of the Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut, died yesterday at his home. He was 75 years old. Bishop Gray headed the state dioceses from 1951 until his retirement in 1969.

The campaign for Governor has begun nearly a year before Election Day with Representative Ogden Reid's announcement that he wants the Democratic nomination. His solitary position in the field will not last long. On the contrary, the probability is strong that the 1974 gubernatorial race will be the most open in a decadewith harsh primary contests a possibility for both Democrats and Republicans.
The Rockefeller Public Service Awards, the highest civilian distinctions awarded to Federal Government employes, were presented here today to five career officials.

The board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange is scheduled to consider at its regular meeting today the membership application of Harold R. Bobedee, the son of a Big Board employee, Harold H. (Bud) Robedee.

The Health Department released yesterday the names of 33 more restaurants and food stores in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that persisted through two inspections.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill.--A long-ignored idea may soon become the key to solving two major problems facing the United States-the Middle East conflict and the immediate energy crisis. The idea is a defense pact between the United States and Israel.

President Ferdinand E. Marcos met today with Moslem rebel leaders as part of his martial-law Government's continuing efforts to make peace with insurgents, but increasing difficulties were reported with youths and militant Roman Catholic clergymen.

The United States succeeded tonight in its effort to stave off until next year a Chinese-led drive to expel from the United Nations the present Government of Cambodia and seat instead the exile government of Prince Norodom Sihanouk.
The New York Rangers, enjoying a relaxed evening, gave a hockey lesson to the St. Louis Blues last night at Madison Square Garden, beating them, 5-1.

Ralph J. cordiner, whose wide-ranging philosophies of professional management as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the General Electric Company made him one of the best-known men in American industry, died of cancer today. He was 73 years old.

The State Board of Education today ordered all school districts in the state to extend the Christmas recess for three days to save heating oil. The canceled classes will be added to the school year in June.

A 10-year-old boy has been committed to a children's institution for 18 months. A court ruled he helped start a fire that destroyed a church. The fire gutted the Monroe Avenue United Methodist Church, valued at $456,000, last May 7.
Sweden announced to-night that she would not replace her Ambassador to Santiago, Harald Edelstam, who was ordered to leave by the Chilean Government yesterday.

Bernard S. Bercovici, a former political commentator for the Mutual Broadcasting System and more recently editorial director of WNBF-TV in Binghamton, N. Y., died Friday at his home near Harpursville, N. Y. He was 78 years old.

A 16-year-old youth arrested for a murder in a subway station Monday was believed by officials yesterday to be the youngster who was sent home from a state training school last July after a landmark decision by the state's highest court.
The editor and publisher of Lebanon's leading newspaper was imprisoned today for hav ing published the "secret resolutions" of the recent conference of Arab chiefs of state.
" Fashion," a new musical with a clever idea, a bubbly score and a disarming tone of sly, clean amusement, proves that at least one Off Broadway house is ready with the Christmas spirit.

On Feb. 20, 1969, one month after his inauguration, President Nixon announced that he was personally assuming "full responsibility for oil import policies." From that day to this he has followed a bewildering series of bureaucratic reshuffles and reorganizations. The substance of the energy problem was forever getting lost amid the managerial confusion; about the only

This evening the Actors Studio officially becomes a venerable institution. It celebrates its 25th anniversary with simultaneous benefit balls in New York and Los Angeles. Actually, the Studio is not 25 years old, but 26 years old.

President Nixon was "very, very disturbed" and "almost incredulous" when he finally learned of the full extent and import of the 18-minute gap on a crucial White House tape recording, his chief of staff, Alexander M. Haig Jr., testified to- -Re day.

Justin Laurent Galatoire, owner of the famous New Orleans French restaurant that bears his family name, died yesterday. He was 87 years old. He is survived by his widow, Mrs. Clarisse Houlne Galatoire
Five persons, including a pregnant woman and three of her children, were killed early today when fire destroyed a basement apartment on Chicago's Northwest Side.
The Boston Celtics merrily chopped the New York Knicks to pieces tonight and then proclaimed -as only superconfident winners can - that their 119-97 victory didn't mean a thing.
Mike Marshall, baseball's top relief pitcher of 1973, was traded by Montreal to Los Angeles today for Willie Davis, the 33-year-old center fielder who is one of baseball's biggest everyday stars.
Mrs. Jean Tomlinson Auringer, secretary - treasurer of the Morristown Daily Record, Inc., died of cancer yesterday in the Community Medical Center here. She was 42 years old and lived in Madison.

Snowstorms and icy roads in the Far West curtailed delivery of live cattle at major terminals, with a result that cash and futures prices for the near months rose early yesterday. Later, futures prices fell sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, partly because of
The New York Yankees lost big yardage today in baseball's celebrated "case of the stolen managers" when Charles O. Finley of the Oakland A's refused to relax his legal grip on Dick Williams.

The two houses of Parliament, which elect the seven ministers who make up the Swiss Federal Government, filled three vacancies today in an untraditional manner. They rejected the three candidates proposed by the coalition parties.

Premier Anker Jorgensen submitted his Government's resignation today to Queen Margrethe II after the parliamentary elections yesterday in which both the Government and main Opposition parties suffered major setbacks.

A State Controller's audit of the Sheltered Workshop at the Central Islip State Hospital charged yesterday that the program had engaged in massive underpayments of patients, improper withholding of wages, illegal employment of minors and violations of the Code of Etics for state employes.

Prices continued to decline in the corporate bond market yesterday with some older utility issues showing losses of 1 1/2 to 2 points so far this week. Dealers suggested the downturn reflected uncertainty over the economic outlook in the face of the energy problems.

For the second day in a row, Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton were escorted out of a Federal courtroom several times yesterday after they repeatedly shouted complaints and epithets at the judge presiding at their trial on bank robbery charges.

The leadership of the governing Labor party formally adopted a revised election platform tonight that authorizes the Israeli Government to enter peace negotiations with the Arabs in Geneva later this month.
Prices continued their downward trend on the American Stock Exchange and in overthe-counter trading yesterday as volume rose.
Miss Lizanne Seabrook, daughter of John M. Seabrook of Salem, N. J., and Mrs. Anne S. Seabrook of New York, was married is London yesterday to Jonathan Grant Leatham of London.

After a summer of playing basketball against some of the toughest and meanest competition around, Charlie Barker has become a star. Barker, a junior forward, studied at Playground U. and now is refining his numerous skills under Coach Julie Levine at Samuel Gompers High School.

The Soviet Union has begun flying military reconnaissance missions from the West African nation of Guinea, according to Pentagon officials, who said that the flights are apparently used to monitor ship movements in the South Atlantic.

Real growth in the economy next year will be limited to sixtenths of 1 per cent, the University of Pennsylvania predicted yesterday. Gross National Product without the inflationary factor, it was said, will come to a total of $841.6-billion for the year.
Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame called yesterday for the resignation of 265 high-ranking officials in the Lindsay administration.
Warren Strasser Davidson, member of the New York law Firm of Silberfeld, Danziger Bangser, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at Old Wagon Road.
More than three months ago, Premier Chou En-lai announced that China's top legislative body, the National People's Congress, was about to hold its first session in nine years.

Stock prices kept tumbling yesterday as uncertainties aroused by the energy crisis spread fears of recession-plusinflation for 1974. On rain-pelted Wall Street, the atmosphere was one of shock and bewilderment rather than panic. "This decline," one broker said quietly, "is staggering."

United States Attorney Robert A. Morse, who leaned to his death from his Brooklyn apartment Tuesday, left a suicide note saying that he had considered taking his life many years ago and had consulted a psychiatrist at that time, investigators said yesterday.

Fifty persons were driven from their homes last night by a fire in a seven-story tenement at 524 East 12th Street, between Avenues A and B, Twenty-four firemen were treated at Bellevue Hospital for smoke inhalation and minor injuries.
When it comes to football, some coaches quit, others take new jobs and some stay put no matter what. In the first category is Bill Fulcher, who left the head post at Georgia Tech yesterday

The Soviet Union, mindful of the uproar that the Arab embargo has created in the West, has he reacted angrily to speculation in the West European press that the Kremlin might have its hand in the cutback of oil from the Middle East.

President Nixon was "very, very disturbed" and "almost incredulous" when he finally learned of the full extent and import of the 18-minute gap on a crucial White House tape recording, his chief of staff, Alexander M. Haig Jr., testified today.
The first Government survey of business plans to invest in plant and equipment next year generally confirmed today earlier private estimates of strong capital investment in 1974.

Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board told Congress today that the renewed strength of the dollar in the world's foreign exchange markets has "served to bolster confidence in our nation's future at a time when we have been beseiged with all sorts of unhappy economic and political news."
The New York Yankees lost big. yardage today in baseball's celebrated "case of the stolen managers" when Charles O. Finley of the Oakland A's refused to relax his legal grip on Dick Williams.

The Chicago Police Department, plagued in recent months by document instances of police brutality and by numerous indictments of policement on charges of bribery and extortion, is poised for one of its periodic bouts of reform.
The Egyptian Government has Informed the United Nations that it has not yet reached a decision on resuming the military talks with Israel that were suspended at its request a week ago.

WASHINGTON--The confirmation of Gerald Ford to be Vice President will come to its unsuspenseful conclusion today as the House of Representatives overwhelmingly votes to endorse the nomination. We will be confirming a man whose honesty, integrity and decency are above reproach-a welcome change from our recent history.

Robert D. Timm, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday that his agency must take from airline man agement many of its prerog atives for scheduling flights i adequate service is to be main trained in the face of massive projected cutbacks due to fue shortages.

Mattel, Inc., the nation's largest toy producer, which had losses in all but one of the last eight quarters, reported yesterday a profit in the third fiscal quarter ended Nov. 3. Net income came to $9.6-mil lion, up 19.5 per cent from the similar three months last year.

More black women residents here than white received abortions in the year ended June 30. 1973, although the 1970 Census figures indicate that there are twice as many white women of child-bearing age as black.

Israel today announced new and tougher restrictions on news coverage of military activities. The measures require advance permission for interviews with senior officers, several of whom have been critical of the nation's war strategy.

Blockades by truck drivers protesting higher fuel prices and lower speed limits ended in Pennsylvania late last night but continued in Ohio despite six arrests and the forcible removal of 300 vehicles.

Foreign Secretary Sir Alec Douglas-Home returned today from two days of talks with Soviet leaders in Moscow and said relations between Britain and the Soviet Union were "now back to normal after the coolness of the past two years."

Canadian Javelin, Ltd., has contested charges by the United States Securities and Exchange Commission in hearings before the British Columbia Securities Commission and Vancouver Stock Exchange officials.
John Tiernan, who spends much of his spare time during the winter dreaming about ski-touring trips, is hoping the snow falls with more regularity than last year in this Morris County region.

Hudson County Democrats have apparently re-established their traditional dominance over New Jersey Democratic politics by getting Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne to agree to a political arrangement on the leadership of the overwhelming Democratic majorities in the new l.egislature.

Alvin Alley has a particular dream for American modern dance. He wants to form an ecumenical dance company. Not only does he want to create new works, by himself and other choreographers, but he also wants to provide a permanent home for historic modern-dance works.
A Bronx high-school principal pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he attempted to extort money from an assistant principal on the ground that he could save his job for him.

The Administration, responding to wildcat blockades of the nation's highways by truck drivers, promised today to take immediate action to alleviate the truckers' problems and to give high priority to fuel for trucks in a national energy allocation program.

Protestant and Roman Catholic hospital groups, representing a large share of the nation's hospitals, have joined in threatening legal action to force changes in proposed Federal price control regulations.

Attorneys for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said today that they would appeal a Federal appeals court ruling yesterday that refused to grant expanded school desegregation and busing in Memphis.

It is typical of Elina Mooney's intelligence and sensitivity toward spatial relationships that, in a concert at Theater at St. Clement's on Tuesday, she used a stage already quite specifically prepared for a resident play and made it her own.

Moving to fill a vacancy created more than a year ago, President Nixon announced yesterday his plans to nominate Arthur S. Flemming to succeed the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh as chairman of the Commission on Civil Rights.
President Nixon and President Nicolae Ceausescu signed a joint statement in the White House today pledging "the continued development of friendly relations" between the two countries.

The New York Times has filed a motion in United States District Court here to prevent lawyers for John D. Ehrlichman, a former aide to President Nixon, from forcing one of The Times's reporters to testify or turn over his notes

Computer studies by the General Motors Corporation show that large trucks can save about 15 per cent in fuel by driving 50 to 55 miles an hour instead of 70, primarily because of reduced air resistance.
France has barred all auto racing "until further notice" and there were indications yesterday that other European governments would follow.
This has been a bad year for Soviet international sports champions. It almost seems someone prefers to have their images somewhat tarnished.
The New York Rangers, enjoying a relaxed evening, gave a hockey lesson to the St. Louis Blues last night at Madison Square Garden, beating them, 5-1.
The Skylab 3 astronauts aimed powerful cameras today at Kohoutek , a comet from deep space that is expected to loop around the sun during the Christmas holidays.
Thousands of persons stood in the rain for hours yesterday to apply for examinations for city jobs in the Sanitation and Police Departments.
A fist-swinging brawl broke out in the newly established Northern Ireland Assembly today between rival Protestant factions, causing the, Speaker to adjourn the session and call for police help.

The microphone went dead at one point last night as Eleanor Steinholtz, an economic consultant, was explaining to hundreds of residents here why they should accept a mixed-income housing project that would double the size of their town in eight years.

Sister of Adele J. Nolan. Friends may call at the "Abbey", 81 St. and Madison Ave., Friday, 9-12 noon, Requiem

Sliding stock prices have moved scores of corporations to seek their own shares in the stock market but not without some misgivings in Washington. Yesterday, the Securities and Exchange Commission modified and reissued a proposed rule that would place price and volume restrictions on such purchases.

C.B.S. Reports takes an hour-long look at "The Corporation" on the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight at 10. Jay McMullen, the producer - writer - reporter, attempts to explore the "corporate mind" primarily from the perspective of the executive suite.

On the eve of a general strike, the French Government disclosed today new moves to check inflation, now running at more than 10 per cent annually, and at the same time insure high employment during the energy crisis.

The Government decided today to let refiners increase the price of heating oil by 2 cents a gallon, an increase that will be passed on to consumers in January and add about 7 per cent to the average home-heating bill.

Prime Minister Heath met today with the Prime Minister of the independent Irish Republic and the members of the new executive body for British - controlled Northern Ireland. They immediately agreed in principle on the basic structure for a Council of Ireland.
A pair of Canadian teams pulled away from the field today after 54 holes of the 21st annual Bermuda Goodwill golf tournament.
Robert L. Vesco has been granted permission to live in Argentina, the press office of the Argentine judiciary announced here today.

William (Buddy) Gilmour has conceded that he will not overtake Herve Filion in the race for the national earnings and victories title in harness racing, but, as he said at Yonkers Raceway yesterday, "I'm doing all right."

Jonathan L. Goldstein, who reportedly has been recommended to succeed United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern here, will be honored by the Department of Justice next week for "distinguished service."

Human ingenuity in making virtues out of necessities is boundless. Lately we have been having a glorification of monotony, as a visitor to Wednesday's Evenings for New Music concert at Carnegie Recital Hall can testify.

The America's Cup yacht races will be sailed on schedule next September, the New York Yacht Club said yesterday in denying a request from an American syndicate for a one-year postponement. The syndicate that is backing a new aluminum-hulled 12-Meter craft named Courageous had asked that the sailing be postponed until 1975, saying that the energy crisis made the delay necessary. ... . ....
The White House avoided today responsibility for halting the truck driver blockades of interstate highways and instead called on the state Governors to take action.
President Nixon announced the appointment today of three ambassadors and six high State Department officials.

Four employes of the City Correction Department have been indicted on charges of selling heroin, cocaine and marijuana, it was announced yesterday by the office of the state's anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadiari.
The Standard Poor's Corporation said yesterday that the credit standings of longterm debt of W. T. Grant Company totaling about $125 million had been downgraded.
Francis Shackelford, who served as Assistant Secretary of the Army in the Truman Administration, died today after open-heart surgery. He was 64 years old and lived here.
A leading medical publication has warned about the potential hazards of allergy and deafness among infants whose skin is smeared with an antibiotic ointment for diaper rash.

People keep on asking where are the good American plays? And the curious thing is that season after season, as regular as wheat or clockwork, the good American plays keep turning up. Last night one turned up at the Eastside Playhouse.

Federal prosecutors disclosed last night that the White House had agreed to provide the tape recording of a conversation between President Nixon and John W. Dean 3d for the trial of two former Cabinet officers.
The' General Motors Corporation said today it was planning capital spending in 1974 that could exceed the corporate record of t $1.3-billion.

Grain and soybean prices rebounded yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after reports of good export demand. Traders also continued to talk of shortages of hexane, a fuel used in crushing soybeans into oil and meal, and shortages of fertilizers.
Gov.-elect Brendan T. Byrne proposed last night that New Jersey sponsor hotel gambling casinos in Atlantic City to revive the faded popularity of the resort city.

President Juan D, Peron intends to reform the Constitution and the move could bring a general election next September, a key political aide said today.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation marshaled a threeyear nationwide counterintelligence program "to expose, disrupt and otherwise neutralize" what the late Edgar Hoover called the New Left movement, according to internal agency memos made public today.

Thousands of air 'travelers were delayed here yesterday as employes of Trans World Airlines, on strike for a month, set up picket lines at the terminals of American Airlines and Pan American World Airways.

Premier Golda Meir won a 291to-33 vote of confidence from the Central Committee of the governing Labor party today. The vote came after she had accepted full responsibility for Israel's setbacks at the start of the October war.

Larry Jacobson, who cut his left foot on a piece of glass last June at a swimming pool, may start at his regular defensive tackle post for the New York Giants Monday night in Los Angeles.

Dr. Alan Ross Anderson, former chairman of the University of Pittsburgh department of Philosophy, died yesterday at his home here. He was 48 years old.

Lauritz G. Haugen, a retired lawyer and former vice president of the First National City Bank, died Wednesday in Miami at the age of 81. He lived here and in Surfside, Fla.

A former official of the Small Business Administration served simultaneously as director of a foreign bank controlled by Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive New Jersey financier, sources at the Securities and Exchange Commission confirmed yesterday.

Stock prices soared yesterday in a strong technical rally--a recovery generated in the absence of any compelling news developments--that added more than 25 points to the Dow-Jones industrials. Trading volume was heavy.

Hialeah Race Course, Inc. pleaded guilty yesterday to covering up a $1,000 contribution to the 1969 campaign of Governor Cahill. United States District Court Judge Lawrence A. Whipple, who had rejected an earlier defense request to plead nolo contender, fined the Florida track $2,500.

Federal Judge Edward T. Gignoux decided today against imposing any jail sentences on the four men found guilty of contempt of court Tuesday for their conduct during the Chicago Seven riot conspiracy trial.

If the rites of politics occasionally include finding the best man for the job, Mayor-elect Beame would be welladvised to keep John Zuccotti as chairman of the City Planning Commission. The fact that the position is considered a comparatively well-paid political plum makes its disposition a particular temptation and danger.

An Air Force sergeant with a 15-year unblemished service record pleaded guilty today to charges that he tried to pass secret documents to a Soviet diplomat. He was sentenced to two years at hard labor and given a dishonorable discharge.

A present-day novelist would scarcely dare to create Gerald R. Ford. He is "square," his wife says. He is sincere, loyal, hardworking and honest, his friends say. He is dull, unimaginative, lacking in flair, his critics say. According to one aide, he is a mixture of Tom Swift and Jack Armstrong, the allAmerican boy.
The Nixon Administration has quietly impounded $550-million voted this year for development of water and sewer systems despite a directive from Congress to spend the money.
President Nixon's attempt to restore lost confidence in his Administration "has plainly failed," Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, said tonight.

David Lavin, a sociologist, grew up in Scarsdale, where he now lives with his wife and three children. Scarsdale he says, "has a fine public school system." But he uses the word "fine" a little ironically, and goes on to say that the system "has not maintained its leadership."
The Bank of China has reported major policy shift, begun borrowing hard currency a finance imports into China.

November sales and redemptions of Government Savings Bonds both declined from October levels, the Treasury Department said today. Sales of E and H bonds totaled $467-million last month, compared with $482-million in October and $454-million in November, 1972.
Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman disclosed yesterday that the city's banks so far had "not agreed" to cash checks for 200,000 aged, blind and disabled poor here, starting in January.
A pair of Canadian teams pulled away from the field today after 54 holes of the 21st annual Bermuda Goodwill golf tournament.

Word has been received here of the death in Tokyo on Sept. 18 of Ken Harada, a Japanese diplomat who was his country's charge d'affaires in Vichy, France, in 1941, and special envoy to the Vatican from 1942 to 1945. He was 80 years old.
Indian legislators voiced criticism and uneasiness today over the Sovit Union's accelerating ecoDomic assistance here.
The Senate passed and sent to President Nixon today a $32.9-billion money bill carrying funds for the Government's health, education, labor and welfare programs. The vote was 85 to 3.

As one of his final major actions in his last month and a half in office, Governor Cahill signed into law this afternoon a bill that would require the three members of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners to serve full time.

Observers of the fastchanging political scene in Greece think the new President, Lieut. Gen. Phaidon Gizikis, has, if nothing else, given a boost to paint sales by notifying all Government services that he does not wish to see his portrait displayed in offices or such private places as village cafes, as is customary.
To the Editor: It may be useful to regard the current Middle East situation as resulting from a major event: the emergence of a unified Arab nation, constituting a new superpower.
The Montreal Stock Exchange said today that shares of Canadian Javelin, Ltd., would be reinstated for trading at the opening of business on the exchange on Monday.
Sandy Hawley, unhurt after being tossed from his mount before the fourth race at Laurel today, came back in the fifth and broke Bill Shoemaker's one-year record of 485 victories.

Landlords of 1.5 million New York City apartments warned yesterday that enforcing the existing statutory minimum heat standard of 68 degrees could leave their tenants with no heat at all by the end of this month.

Cynthia Driano, an 18-yearold from Lake Placid, led the field of senior women today after the compulsory, figures event in the North Atlantic figure skating championships at Clearfield Recreation Center.

Now that Gerald R. Ford has become the nation's 40th Vice President, a number of Republicans in Congress hope that he will soon become the 38th President.

Mrs. Marjorie Lindheimer Everett, leader of the group that tried to keep the Padres in San Diego, expressed disappointment yesterday over the bid's failure. "I'm disappointed for all the city officials and other nice people in San Diego," Mrs. Everett said, speaking by phone from her home in Scottsdale, Ariz. "Of course, I guess we have to say 'Congratulations to Mr. Danzansky.'"

In an attempt to increase supplies of natural gas, the House Commerce Committee approved today legislation which would allow the importation of liquified natural gas without controls of the Federal Power Commission.

Larry Kenon, returning to the site of his college stardom, scored 21 points and led the New York Nets to a 111-94 American Basketball Association victory over the Memphis Tams tonight.
Gerry Philbin announced his retirement from the Philadelphia Eagles yesterday to be effective at the end of the season, but he still wishes, just a little bit, it had been from the New York Jets.

TORONTO-The Senate Armed Services Committee and House Appropriations Committee hearings on the Pentagon budget until July 1974 are now out, and the traditionally diligent censors released alarming new information on the Nixon Administration's plans for Indochina.

In the last month, the fighting in South Vietnam has reached its fiercest levels since the January signing of the agreement for an ostensible cease-fire, which has since been shattered.

Sir Robert Watson-Watt, developer of the world's first practical radar system, which aided the repulsion of Germany in the Battle of Britain in 1940, died yesterday in a hospital at Inverness, Scotland.

In a part of the world where such institutions have become almost non-existent, Venezuela through fifteen difficult years has maintained a democratic system and an open society. In 1968, the system met one of the most difficult tests of all: peaceful transfer of power after the Social Christian party (COPEI) narrowly upset Democratic Action (A.D.), the base from which Romulo Betancourt restored democracy to Venezuela in 1958.
Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, said tonight that there had been "wrongdoing" in campaign fundraising in his behalf, but insisted he had done nothing wrong.

Major producers of copper and aluminum moved swiftly yesterday to raise prices for these commodities. The companies' actions followed by a day the decision by the Cost of Living Council to remove price ceilings for copper and aluminum, although keeping them under control.

The New York Philharmonic, on Thursday night in Avery Fisher Hall, picked up where it would have been had there not been a strike. That is, the program originally listed for the week went on as scheduled, but with a different conductor. Georg Semkow replaced Daniel Barenboim, who is in England with his ailing wife.

The Federal Power Commission approved today the "backward integration" of two local natural gas distributors that decided to get into the production end of the natural gas business to augment supplies available to their customers.

Osmond K. Fraenkel, the civil-liberties activist who has served for the past 36 years as general counsel to the American Civil Liberties Union and the New York Civil Liberties Union, was honored by his colleagues at a dinner. More than 450 persons jammed the starlight roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to hear friends and relatives praise the activist lawyer, whose 85th birthday was yesterday.

Ritha Devi is an exceptional performer of Indian dance. In the true Hindu classical dance tradition, she is as superb an actress as she is a dancer. Both aspects were very much in evidence in her solo-dance concert Thursday night at the Exchange Theater, and it would be folly for anyone interested in either dance or drama to miss her repeat program at the Cubiculo Sunday night at 8 P.M.

Vincent A. Schiano, the chief trial attorney for the Immigration and Naturalization Service here until he was quietly demoted a year ago, abruptly resigned yesterday under controversial circumstances after 20 years of service.

The Federal Power Commission in Washington has posted an order permitting the Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Corporation to bring increased supplies of natural gas to the Elizabeth Town Gas Company. A spokesman for the State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners said that the move had broken a 16-month deadlock on the request for the additional gas.

ACKERMAN-Jack J. The Makin Society deeply mourns the passing of its cnarter member, who died in Florida on December S. Funeral services will be at the Park West on Sunday at 12 Noon. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Irene, and family. ROBERT ACKERMAN, Treasurer.
John Havlicek and Dave Cowens scored 24 points each and Cowens had 17 rebounds and lead the Boston Celtics to a 116-112 victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

Mrs. Laure Young Scafuri, a fashion model and the wife of Patrick J. Scafuri, an investment banker, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 32 years old and lived at 301 East 69th Street.

District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx announced yesterday that a man who pleaded guilty Wednesday to a shakedown charge was, in fact, a guidance counselor at Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx, and not the principal, as the prosecution had stated originally.
Egypt has decided to attend the Middle East peace conference opening in Geneva Dec. 18 even in the absence of a prior Israeli troop withdrawal from the Suez area, informed diplomats said today.
South Vietnamese infantry units last night retook a district capital in the Central Highlands that was overrun by North Vietnamese soldiers and tanks four days ago, the Saigon command announced.
Out in Sasquism, Ecuador, an hour out of Quito, the honeymoon continued for Princess Anne and Capt. Mark Phillips. A woman called her "the Queen of London";

Four year have passed since the American painter Jules Olitski made his New York debut as a sculptor in an unusual exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. (It was only the third time in its entire history that the Met had mounted a one-man show by a living artist.
Fourteen persons have been arrested here in connection with a series of bomb attacks in Spain's northern Basque provinces, police sources said today.

For the first time in recent memory, Republicans in the House of Representatives changed leaders today without a fight and elected Representative John J. Rhodes of Arizona as minority leader to succeed Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, who was sworn in yesterday as Vice President.
Half of a pedestrian bridge spanning the Van Wyck Expressway in Queens was sheared off by a dump truck yesterday, the police reported.
John C. Doyle, the chief executive officer of Canadian Javelin, Ltd., was arrested today in a police raid on the company's head office here.
The nation's unemployment rate, after a dip in October, returned in November to the level that had prevailed since last spring, the Labor Department reported today.
ERFURT, East Germany-The Christmas shopping season was well under way in East Germany by the middle of November, and perhaps even before that.

Independent truck owner-operators, dissatisfied with Government assurances of special help during the fuel shortage, are moving ahead with plans for a nationwide truck stoppage next Thursday and Friday,
The First Annual Wine and cheese Festival begins today at the Coliseum. Its promoers say it is the only show around at which you can eat and drink the exhibits.
The United States and the Soviet Union are transferring the Washington-Moscow Hot Line to a network of space satellites.

Pierre Jarry scored his first goal as a Detroit player tonight to earn the Red Wings a 1-1 tie with the St. Louis Blues in a National Hockey League game. Jarry was acquired by the Wings nine days ago from the Toronto Maple Leafs in exchange for Tim Ecclestone.

Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame reappointed Nicholas Scoppetta as Commissioner of Investigation yesterday, commeeting that it was the first time in the 100 years of the deapartment that its head had been retained by a new Mayor.

Many people thought he would be the Jets' next head coach, most believed he was a good defensive coach. But he won't be the next coach and, after he left after last season, some instant critics suggested he had not been a defensive mastermind after all.

Dick Williams said today he was taking a wait-and-see attitude for the present regarding his managerial status, but noted the possibility of legal action if the American League president, Joe Cronin, and the baseball commissioner, Bowie Kuhn, continue to refuse to rule on the matter.

American Jewish leaders were told yesterday that their communities would have to raise "unprecedented sums" to enable Israel to cope with pressing humanitarian problems in the wake of recent hostilities and tensions in the Middle East.

Policemen used a bulldozer to day to break down the door of the Chilean Embassy here after 80 young Communists staged an occupation-to publicize their call for the release of political prisoners in Chile.

Trans World Airlines, which has been shut down by a strike of attendants since Nov. 5, announced yesterday that 350 additional pilots would be laid off beginning in January because fuel shortages would require fewer flights when the strike ended.

A Nassau County District Court judge, a long-time enrolled Republican who defeated the county Republican organization in a bid for reelection three years ago, announced today that he was resigning his post, saying his political independence had cost him chances for promotion.

Dave DeBusschere put in 41 points, tying his National Basketball Association career high, as the Knicks rallied from an 8-point deficit midway in the final quarter tonight to post a 113-108 triumph over the Buffalo Braves at Memorial Auditorium.
The present happy relationship between Poland and the United states expresses itself in many ways. American exports to Poland in the first six months of the year reached $197-million;
North Vietnam charged today that the United States had stationed the aircraft carrier Midway off its coast and demanded it be withdrawn, the Chinese news agency Hsinhua reported.

With the formation of the Newark Preservation and Landmark Committee, the first step has been taken to restore and preserve the city's historical sites. There are about 30 buildings that are considered important enough to save. To this end, the committee plans to organize tours, print guide books and promote special events to focus attention on local history.

The LTV Corporation announced yesterday that after an additional review, its directors had reaffirmed the original plan whereby LTV would acquire 100 per cent ownership of Wilson Co., Inc., through a distribution of Wilson debentures to holders of Wilson common stock.

Governor Cahill signed into law today a bill increasing the pension for Chief Justice-designate Richard J. Hughes. The bill will also increase benefits for the family of the late Chief Justice Pierre P.
Wheat futures set a record high of $5.55 a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The previous high was $5.48 set in September.

Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley said yesterday that because he had been appointed to a specific term in office, he had declined to submit the resignation requested of highranking Lindsay administration officials by Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame.

The Senate passed 82 to 0 today a bill calling for a massive 10year research and development program to make the United States self-sufficient in sources of energy.

Termination of air express service by the nation's airlines no later than June 5, 1974, has been ordered by the Civil Aeronautics Board, which said that "many of the historical advantages of air express had withered away."

The nation's newest religious denomination, the National Presbyterian Church, ended its first general assembly here today after formalizing its separation from the Presbyterian Church in the United States.

The General Electric Company received a $78.8million contract addition from the Air Force for warheads for Minuteman III missiles. The Gulf Oil Corporation received a $15.3-million Defense Supply Agency contract for jet aircraft fuel.
The House gave final Congressional approval today to a bill designed to eliminate a constitutional obstacle to the nomination of Senator William B. Saxbe to be Attorney General.

For generations the people of the Middle East have watched Western oil companies invest little and relentlessly pump out enormous quantities of irreplaceable wealth while the region stagnated. For example, while the consortium of Western companies in Iraq put in no more than $50 million in the early 1900's, by the early 1960's they had taken out over $2 billion.

While the Arab embargo on oil shipments is reducing United States oil imports, the country continues to export crude oil and petroleum products. In October for instance, the United States exported 7,514,754 barrels of crude and products, or 242,000 barrels a day.
Dave Budd sank two free throws with three seconds remaining to assure Iona a 55-51 victory in basketball over Columbia at the loser's University Gym last night.
Frankly, it's a puzzlement. "Marshall Efron's Illustrated, Simplified and Painless Sunday School" is the latest product to enter the lion's den of children's programing.

The Department of Housing and Urban Development has authorized "disciplinary action" against 55 regional employes for continuing to approve housing applications after they were ordered not to, a high ranking department official said today.
Premier In Tam today offered his resignation to President Lon Nol for the second time in two months, well-informed sources said tonight.

Alex Haberstroh, producer of educational films on astronomy, and a special-effects expert on science-fiction films, died yesterday of a stroke at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 463 West Street.

Stock prices soared again yesterday as the Dow-Jones industrial average recorded its best back-to-back point gains in history. Trading was heavy.
The annual media award of AVANT, the Association of Voluntary Agencies on Narcotics Treatment, has been won by James M. Markham, a reporter for The New York Times.

Parents of children at Public School 208 in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn kept about 40 per cent of the pupils out of school for an hour yesterday morning in a renewal of a lingering dispute over the appointment of a principal.
The White House will make public tomorrow "all of the pertinent information" regarding President Nixon's personal finances, the President's deputy press secretary, Gerald L. Warren, said today.

" Excuse me, gentlemen, but I've got to get on to my next crisis," Transportation Secretary Claude S. Brinegar said last week in bidding good-by to Governor Rockefeller, Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame and the Nassau County Executive, Ralph G. Caso.

Three teams, with a composite total of 305 previous appearances in its programs, will share the spotlight this afternoon when Madison Square Garden laurches its 40th intercollegiate basketball season.

James Elward's "HalleluJah!," a new drama of a faithhealer's world, is quite a play. And Jim Jensen, the craggy-faced television newscaster, turns out to be quite an actor, heading a fine cast. Even the church-basement cavern of the Central Arts Theater at 108 East 64th Street (758.6327) suits the occasion.

In response to the fuel shortage, the governments of New York City, New York State, Connecticut and New Jersey are phasing out intermediate and large cars from their official fleets and are buying compacts and subcompacts instead.
Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's former appointments secretary, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he had committed perjury before a grand jury investigation the Watergate scandals.

Bargain hunters moved into the depressed London stock market in force today, sending prices up sharply and recouping the losses of yesterday's slump. Brokers said they expected little follow-through, however, and prices were dwindling again in after-hours trading.
Democratic leaders were divided yesterday on the effect Governor Rockefeller's expected resignation would have on their prospects for winning the office next year.

New thinking about food production and population control is needed to avert hunger, malnutrition and perhaps even famine in the next 30 years, according to Roy V. Edwards, chairman of Wilson Co., one of the nation's largest meat-packing and processing companies.

The New Jersey All-Sports Hall of Fame, which will stage its annual testimonial dinner Monday night here at the Town and Campus Inn, has leaned heavily upon track and basketball in the selection of its 1973 inductees.
President Park Chung Hee ordered today that all the students arrested for recent antiGovernment demonstrations be freed at once and those expelled from their schools be reinstated.

Getting to know Art Deco is definitely a sensual experience, as can be seen in two current exhibitions of furniture from the Roaring Twenties-designs not quite vintage enough to be legally classified as antiques but collected as if they were.

The American League voted today to make the designated hitter a permanent boarder, and the New York Yankees promptly celebrated by trading Lindy McDaniel to the Kansas City Royals for one of the league's established hitters, Lou Piniella.

An unidentified woman was burned to death and nine other persons injured, one of them critically, in an apartmenthouse fire on West 52d Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues last night, fire officials reported.

In dependent truck owner-operators, dissatisfied with Government assurances of special help during the fuel shortage, are moving ahead with plans for a nationwide truck stoppage next Thursday and Friday, according to unofficial spokesmen for the truckers.

The General Assembly today put off until next year its debate on terrorism over protests by Israel that the decision demonstrated United Nations helplessness and a lack of will to take on the issue.

I. Vote on motion to cut off debate on debt-limit and campaign-financing bill. The motion required a two-thirds vote for passage. Motion defeated, 47 to 33, Dec. 2.

The General Assembly approved tonight a Soviet proposal calling on the five major powers to cut their miliitary budgets by 10 per cent and to devote 10 per cent of the savings to helping poorer countries.
Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut announced that he had viewed plans for the controversial redevelopment and modernization of the Merritt Parkway and ordered them scrapped.
The Connecticut State Board of Education has run into opposition as a result of its orders to local school authorities to alter their schedules to save fuel.

Among the practitioners or the geometric mode of abstraction, the American painter Leon Polk Smith has had a curious career. Mr. Smith, now 67, began his career in the nineteen-forties, a follower-with a difference-in the Mondrian tradition.
One of two surviving gyroscopes aboard the Skylab space station has begun to act erratically, but officials said today that it was "cause for concern, but not for alarm.

Benn W. Levy, a playwright, stage and motion-picture director and former Labor member of Parliament, died today in Oxford. His age was 73.

Robert L. Vesco's month-long fight to stave off extradition to the United States ended successfully today when a Bahamian court ruled that the wire fraud charge on which the financier was indicted in New York was not an extraditable offense.

The Fall National Championships began here this afternoon with attention focused on the mixed-pair championship. A total of 810 pairs are entered in the foursession event, which ends tomorrow night.

Richard Rendell, a former newscaster, magazine correspondent and Associated Press reporter, died Tuesday at a hospital here after suffering a stroke. He was 67 years old.

In a move widely anticipated in the recording industry, Bob Dylan has left Columbia Records to form his own label, Ashes and Sand Records. It will be distributed by the newly merged Elektra/Asylum record group.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday for the second straight day as traders bought up stocks at what they believed to be bargain prices. The same situation prevailed in the over-the-counter market. Before Thursday's advance, prices on both markets had dropped sharply for several sessions.

American League voted today to make the designated hitter a permanent boarder, and the New York Yankees promptly celebrated by trading Lindy McDaniel to the Kansas City Royals for one of the league's established hitters, Lou Piniella.

A fierce dog sniffing out contraband mail and a televised X-ray machine that looks for drugs and guns were displayed here today as a Federal postal facility was opened by the United States Customs Service.

Three teams, with a composite total of 305 previous to a appearances in its programs, will share the spotlight this afternoon when Madison Square Garden launches its 40th intercollegiate basketball season.

Leonard Piazza, 44 years old, of Lynn, was arraigned in United States District Court here today on charges of armed robbery in connection with a robbery of about $1-million in rare coins from a Harvard University museum.

Vice President Ford quoted President Nixon as having told him today that he has no intention of resigning. "I can assure you that the President has no intention whatsoever of resigning," Mr. Ford said at his first news conference since taking office as Vice President last night.
Herbert C. Skinner. first general vice president of the 900,000-member United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, died today at the age of 61.

All of the Big Three automobile manufacturers have now agreed to pay the full employee share of any payroll tax Congress may levy if it enacts Federal health insurance in the next three years. In Japan polar bears may be the first victims of the fuel shortage this winter. Because of reduced deliveries by a local oil company, the Sapporo Zoo on Japan's northern island of Hokkaido has had to stop heating the water in its pool for polar bears. If the water freezes and the beat s can't swim regularly, their rich furry coat will turn dark, zoo officials say.

Here, in no particular order, are some of the good results that may be expected in coming months: Perhaps 5,000 Americans will be alive a year from today who otherwise would have been killed on the highways-if the lower speed limits are observed and maintained.

A general alarm fire believed to have been set by vandals swept through a Salvation Army warehouse in Atlantic City, destroying the interior of the one-story brick building and slightly injuring one fireman. Sandy Hawley, who last Thursday broke Willie Shoemaker's record of 485 triumphs in a season won the first North American Riding Championship today at rainswept Suffolk Downs.

Three top-ranking Chinese Communist officials, Chou En-lai, Chiang Ching and Wang Hungwen, appeared publicly together in Peking over the weekend in a display that may have been staged as a show of unity following speculation of a rift in their relationship.
The newspaper Maariv reported today that an interministerial committee had decided on the location of the first Israeli city in the occupied Golan Heights of Syria.

Those graduating from college next June with engineering degrees will find the most favorable job market in years, according to a report released today on this spring's employment outlook.

Roy Wilkins, the civil rights leader, called on Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame yesterday to start programs that would ease tensions between New Yorkers and improve the relationship between Jews and blacks.

In 20 sinless years as a ballplayer in the majors, Joe Cronin was a good enough shortstop, but it was his bat that got him into the Hall of Fame, not the way he handled hot grounders by Babe Ruth or Al Simmons. Today he can't handle the shots Charley Finley hits his way. How much can an infielder slow down without taking root?

The French Alpine ski team, once the most powerful in the world but recently torn by dissension, dismissed six of its stars today "to renew and rejuvenate" the squad. Dismissed, in effect "fired," were:

Santa Claus has a Zip Code. It is 47579. Now some people may think that is the North Pole, which shows how much they know, because Santa Claus is a town in southwestern Indiana, where Christmas is not just a holiday to celebrate but a business and a way of life.
President Nixon examined today proposals for a national health insurance plan that would pay most medical bills about $150 a year and all of the costs beyond $1,500.

A major landlord group announced yesterday that it had begun court action to force immediate city approval of a large backlog of rent-rise applications submitted by owners who had made significant improvements in their rent-controlled buildings.
Executives of Litton Industries, Inc., now believe they will be able to retain the company's Triumph-Adler typewriter operation, the annual stockholders meeting was told here yesterday.

Assemblyman Andrew stein charged yesterday that Blue Cross had ignored an internal audit that found $3-million worth of "questionable" payments to 24 hospitals in 1971 and had done nothing to monitor payment procedures as recommended by the audit.

Although the Washington Redskins lost to the Dallas Cowboys yesterday, they did not lose their chance to qualify for the playoffs. They can get there as the wildcard entry in the National Conference by defeating the Eagles in Washington next Sunday, assuming that the
THIMPHU, Bhutan-Bhutan, a landlocked kingdom nestled in the wild forests and steep valleys of the Himalayas, is emerging from seclusion with rapid but nervous steps.
Jerry Priddy, former infielder with the New York Yankees, was found guilty today by a Federal jury of attempted extortion for threatening to set of an explosion aboard a luxury cruise ship.
The stock market broke its blue Monday jinx of losing sessions yesterday as it extended the strong rally that got under way late last week. Trading activity was moderate.

A bill to grant a $10,000 yearly raise to the eight members of the Board of Estimate was introduced in the City Council yesterday after a three-hour session behind closed doors. Council members predicted passage later this month.

The injury-plagued Willis Reed will be examined today in Oklahoma City by Dr. Donald O'Donoghue, an orthopedic surgeon. The Knicks' captain has a sprain behind his right knee that has failed to respond to treatment. He has missed 14 of the 29 games this season, including the last seven.
A 53-year-old Ohio anesthesiologist was shot and critically wounded in his 19th-floor room at the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday afternoon, apparently during an attempted robbery, the police said.
Shildrick A. Kendrick, chief of research for the College Entrance Examination Board, died of cancer yesterday at his home, 39 Claremont Avenue. He was 50 years old.

Governor Rockefeller certainly knew that his launching of a National Commission on Critical Choices for America-scheduled to report its findings late in 1975would be interpreted as the launching of his Presidential campaign for 1976. Nevertheless, the scope and purpose of the commission raise it above the level of a mere political device.
If action-adventure has any serious competition for popularity in TV schedules, it probably is in the category of the creepy-crawler, the tale dabbling in the supernatural and occult.

The New York State County Executive Association, which numbers 13 of the major counties representing 80 per cent of the state's population outside New York City focused on mass transit proposals in the association's legislative program for next year at a meeting vesterday in Buffalo.
Kenneth E. BeLieu, an official in the Nixon, Johnson and Kennedy Administrations, was named today by Vice President Ford as his consultant on legislative affairs.
If Pennsylvania is still a fair guide to the political balance in the country, the Republican party faces a national Watergate disaster in major elections next year.

Secretary of State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Michel Jobert of France clashed over whether the improved relations between the United States and Soviet Union undermined the security of Western Europe. At a meeting of Atlantic alliance foreign ministers in Brussels, Mr. Jobert said the agreement reached in Washington last June on the prevention of nuclear war called into question the American nuclear guarantees to Western Europe. [1:1.]
A Hungarian journalist asked an American today if Secretary of State Kissinger would hold a news conference while in Brussels.
Worshipers wound through the cavernous Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine on a recent Sunday, shaking tambourines, singing plainsong and watching medieval mystery plays.
Chilean military Government authorities have announced that 115 nationalized companies, including 12 controlled by foreign capital,' be returned to their former owners.

Documents filed in court today indicate that Senate investigators are considering a theory that the men who broke into the Democratic headquarters in the Watergate complex in June, 1972, were trying to find out what information the Democrats had linking President Nixon's brothers to Howard R. Hushes.

A 58-year-old Passaic doctor was charged yesterday by the state police with having dispensed narcotics illegally to an undercover agent. Dr. Phillip Snell pleaded not guilty to the charge before Judge Charles S. Joelson in Superior Court in Paterson and was released in $7,500 bail.

Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said here today that Israel would not enter peace talks with Syria unless that country first disclosed the fate of Israeli prisoners of war. Israel has reported 102 men missing on the Syrian front, and Damascus has refused to say how many are being held prisoner.
The Government abolished price and wage controls over the auto industry today in exchange for promises by three manufacturers that they would limit increases on 1974 models.

A report from a House subcommittee today charged the Food and Drug Administration with undue delays and errors in judgment in its actions against a hormone drug that wads used to increase the growth of beef cattle and other food animals.

The Governor's Cabinet Energy Committee today recommended that the state declare Dec. 24 and 31 legal holidays, thus closing all banks and government offices, and that retail establishments in the state curtail their hours to conserve fuel.
The Supreme Court raised the possibility today that it may liberalize or at least clarify the new restrictions on obscene plays, motion pictures and publications that were handed down last June.

Representative Barber B. Conable Jr., a Rochester, N. Y., Republican who is a strong supporter of President Nixon and an old, close ally of Governor Rockefeller, has emerged as a leading contender for the post of chairman of the House Republican Policy Committee.
The Federal Census Bureau has estimated a population drop for New York State for the first time in census history-a decrease of 102,000 as of last July 1 from a year ago.
There is a good deal of music to be heard in Soho (the area south of Houston Street), but most of it is so highly experimental that an average audience might not recognize it as music at all.

Chester S. Spatt is one of thousands of students currently seeking admission to law school. However, unlike most of his counterparts, Mr. Spatt already has taken a case to the United States Supreme Court.

A science study group urged the Government today to ban further installation of asbestos cement pipe to carry drinking water until researchers can determine whether the asbestos might contribute to stomach cancer.

A match between a divisional champion sharpening up for the playoffs and a last-place team that has won only one game in nearly three months turned out to be just what one would expect: Los Angeles Rams 40, New York Giants 6.
Disclosure by President Nixon of his tax returns for the last four years has highlighted two quite different questions about the tax laws and the way he has used them.
The Administration's Committee on Interest and Dividends yesterday requested to large commercial banks which have raised their prime or base lending rate to 10 per cent to justify the increses.

The State Pension Commission today proposed lumping public employes in the state into two coalitions for pension negotiations, rather than the four suggested by the Legislature and the commission's own consultant.
The Supreme Court refused today to review lowercourt decisions that Blue Cross is exempt from Federal antitrust laws in areas where it operates under state supervision.
The stock market extended yesterday the strong rally that began last week. The Dow-Jones industrial average bounded in afternoon trying to finish at 851.14, a gain of 13.09 points.

The political stability of the United States is challenged not by the Watergate episodes, which in themselves are aberrational, but by the decline of the two major political parties as the key instruments for moderation in politics and a guarantee of conformity to constitutional government.

To the Editor: We, the undersigned members of the economics faculty at Princeton University, are distressed at the present prospects of an elaborate rationing scheme to deal with the current shortages of petroleum.
Fans who watch the Jets' game with Buffalo at Shea Stadium next Sunday will see 0. J. Simpson most likely break Jim Brown's rushing record and Weeb Ewbank coach his last game for the Jets.

The most difficult winter since World War II is in prospect for Western Europe, and Britain in particular, as the energy crisis intensifies. The shorter days and colder temperatures of December have begun to demonstrate how dramatically the oil shortages arising from the Middle East war will affect the lives of everyone at least for the next few months, and perhaps much longer.
The overwhelming Democratic majority in the newly elected New Jersey Assembly tonight unanimously chose S. Howard Woodson, a 57-year-old black Baptist minister here, to be Assembly Speaker.
The cause of effective law enforcement in New York City will suffer if a battle over prerogatives between Mayor-elect Beame and Police Commissioner Cawley should result in the Commissioner's ouster.

The most diabolical curse to be inflicted on the world of sports in this century was the device known as the point spread. It gave the gambling industry a come-on of matchless appeal and even hired nonbettors into taking plunges into the bottomless pit of false hopes and empty returns.
Rent-control legislation incorporating local options was urged yesterday by Nassau County members of the State Legislature testifying before a state commission investigating rent increases.

The party ended today for 606 passengers aboard the grounded luxury liner Federico-C. They were ferried ashore in a flotilla of small boats. "The entertainment has stopped, the party's over," said Tom Combs of Pompano Beach, Fla., a passenger.

Tips amounting to more than $50,000, including a fortune in old silver, were disclosed yesterday to have been the reward of a supermarket delivery boy who befriended an elderly widow who lived alone on Manhattan's East Side.

The Alabama National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has asked a Federal judge to start criminal contempt proceedings against Gov. George C. Wallace on the grounds that the Governor has obstructed a court order directing state officials to hire more Negro policemen.
LANSING Mich.--The State of Michigan is claiming exceptional success for an unusual programmer for helping children who are seriously behind in school.

Steel production last week slipped 1.8 per cent to 2,907,-000 net tons from the week-earlier 2,961,000, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The production index fell to 119.2 from 121.4 in the week ended Dec. 1.

The White House announced today that the interest rate on United States Savings Bonds was being increased to 6 per cent to make the bonds more attractive to investors. The increase will be retroactive to Dec. 1. Both old and new bonds will benefit from the higher interest.
Hedgemon Lewis, the topranked welterweight boxing contender, pressured Johnny Gant with a sharp left hook last night and scored a unanimous 10-round decision at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

Since the performance of Handel's "Messiah" Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall was the third of five that David Randolph is giving around town this Christmas season-the last two will be Dec. 23 in Avery Fisher Hall--he must be doing something right.

Public balloting will determine tile winners of popularmusic awards for an American Broadcasting Company special on Feb. 19. The special, to originate in Hollywood with Steve Lawrence as host, will run for 90 minutes.
A favorite and growing custom of friends of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is to make contributions to the cause in lieu of Christmas cards or gifts.
Plans to build Courageous, a 12-Meter yacht for defense of the America's Cup this summer, were abandoned yesterday because of financial considerations. A second new Twelve, Mariner, will be built.
President Nixon presented a collection of official papers to the Government shortly before entering the White House, valuing them at $80,000 as a deduction on his 1968 tax return.

The 3,400 workers laid off at the Ford Motor Company here last Tuesday will turn to work on Dec. 19, according to a Ford spokesman. Donald Bastian, a Ford management vice president, said that the Mahwah plant was among eight that were resuming production.

The Federal Census Bureau has estimated a population drop for New York State for the first time in census history--a decrease of 102,000 people as of last July 1, from a year ago.

When Prime Minister Heath went before the House of Commons this afternoon to report on the hard-won agreement reached yesterday over Northern Ireland, he was showered with congratulations from both sides of the floor.

South Vietnamese troops advanced into the Communist-held town of Kien Duc today, but North Vietnamese artillery and troops were massing nearby, military sources said.
Yields on United States Treasury bills rose for three-month bills and fell for six-month bills in the Government's year, weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities.

If Pennsylvania is still a fair guide to the political balance in the country, the Republican party faces a national Watergate disaster in major elections next year. In Washington, most Republican officials are still outwardly optimistic about the impact of the affair.

The Marines named their first woman unit commander today over a company that includes more than 2.000 men. Col. Mary E. Bane, 44 years old, is the first woman in the 198-year history of the Marine Corps to be given direct command over men, a spokes. man said.

Around the Grand Ole Opry and down on Music Row, there is a saying that when one country musician gets cut, they ail bleed. Within the last month, four members of the tightly knit "family" have been murdered. They were fatally shot in what probably were two unrelated robbery attempts.
The Soviet Jewish ballet dancer Valery Panov has said that be has been threatened with imprisonment on charges of living like a parasite.
The Nixon Administration's farreaching trade legislation cleared a major hurdle in the House today and appeared headed for easy passage tomorrow.

Colombia qualified today to meet the United States in 1974 Davis Cup tennis competition by beating Mexico. The series with the United States will be played in the Colombia capital of Bogota early next year.
Venezuela's two majo center parties both claimed victory today as the returns came in slowly from the presidential election yesterday.

Three New York detectives were arrested yesterday on charges that they had taken a $3,000 bribe to go easy on a husband and wife they apprehended with more than 100 cartons of smuggled, untaxed cigarettes.

John G. Nicholson, vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in charge of the branch at Third Avenue and 53d Street, died yesterday at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N. J. He was 54 years old and lived at 3 Lincoln Garden, Elberon, N. J.

WASHINGTO-Retail sales held essentially flat in November at the October level, the Commerce Department reported today on the basis of preliminary figures. Last week the original estimate for Octoberwhich had shown a strong increase of 2 per cent in retail sales over September-was revised downward. Now the October figure shows an increase of slightly more than 1 per cent.

Commuter and eastbound main-line rail traffic from Chicago to New York was delayed for about half an hour at rush hour this morning when a "piggy-backed" truck trailer fell off a Penn Central freight car and blocked the two eastbound lines.

The state's Water Policy and Supply Council began public hearings here today on a controversial proposal to construct a $20million dam and reservoir north of the Wanaque Reservoir in northern Passaic County.

Bernard L. Flynn, vice president for purchases of the Lever Brothers Company and former chairman of the Soap and Detergent Association, died yesterday at his home, 264 Warwick Avenue. He was 61 years old.

Herbert Plank of Italy, a 19-year-old farmer's son, won the men's downhill ski race today in the First Snow Critierium.
A Police Department anticorruption team in Brooklyn is handing out an "insurance policy" that promises all patrolmen a minimum guaranteed income of $500,000.
Shares of Canadian Javelin, Ltd., were traded on the Montreal Stock Exchange today for the first time since being suspended Nov. 27.
Lawyers for Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive New Jersey financier, moved in the United States Court of Appeals here yesterday for a reversal of an order freezing certain Vesco assets.

The natural gas industry remains convinced that removal of price controls at the wellhead would be "the single most important step which can be taken now" to ease natural gas supply problems, Herbert D. Clay, chairman of the American Gas Association, said here yesterday.
The new regional director of the Federal energy program in the metropolitan area is a tough-minded native New Yorker who says he will fight to make sure the area gets its fair share of fuel supplies.

With the defendants banished from the courtroom and their lawyers virtually mute in protest, the bank-robbery trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton got off dead center yesterday in Federal Court.
George D. Busher, former president of the Bronx Real Estate Board, died Saturday at his home, 22 Cassilis Road, Bronxville, N. Y. He was 75 years old.
Leaders of the nation's independent gasoline station owners urged their members today not to stage protest shutdowns, which they describe as illegal actions.

The House small-business subcommittee was told today that President Nixon had personally directed top Administration officials to provide "all assistance possible" to Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, the New York neurosurgeon convicted last month of illegal use of Medicaid funds.
The world's greatest collection of master points seemed likely to get even bigger at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here today.

The City Council tonight adopted a municipal rent-control ordinance described by its sponsor as "the strongest in the nation." The council's action came after a raucous three-hour public hearing during which there were two shoving matches and one city official was forcibly ejected.

In the first international tournament, at the Crystal Palace of the London Exhibition in 1851, the problem of draws was neatly solvedthey didn't count. The competition was run on the knockout system and only victories mattered.
