Egypt expects Secretary of State Kissinger's visit to the Middle East later this week to give a new impetus to the deadlocked military talks on the Cairo-Sdez road between Egyptian and Israel generals.

Secretary Kissinger's recent attempt to rebut European complaints about lack of consultation during the Mideast war brought a wry rejoinder from Britain's Earl of Cromer, the one NATO Ambassador he had roused out of bed by telephone, at 1:07 A.M., to inform of the controversial American worldwide military alert Oct. 25.

The four games in the first round of the National Football League's playoffs line up in this probable order: Dec. 22, Washington Redskins at Minnesota Vikings, 1 P.M., Channel 2; Pittsburgh Steelers at Oakland Raiders, 4 P.M., Channel 4.

Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau easily won a vote of confidence in the House of Commons tonight, and the way he did it reflects the Canadian Government's recent moves toward an informal kind of two-party coalition.
In a survey of political attitudes of Maryland voters, Gov. Marvin Mandel is asking for opinions on his marital problems and the possible effect on his chances for another term.

Ten men cited for exploring new paths of knowledge received 1973 Nobel Prizes today and were honored at a formal tie ceremony for rendering the "greatest service to mankind during the preceding year."

Senate and House conferees agreed today on legislation that could put the nation on yearround daylight saving time as early as Jan. 6 to conserve energy. The measure agreed on by the conferees, who took only two and one-half hours to reconcile differences in bills already passed by both houses, is scheduled to be ratified by the House and Senate and sent to President Nixon for his signature by the end of this week.

Protests abounded at Aqueduct yesterday, and the prospect is that there may be more to come. Angel Cordero Jr. submitted the most notable objection, when he requested re-examination of a five-day suspension handed to him for a riding violation last week.
Diplomats commemorated the 25th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights today with speeches pointing to evidences of continuing religious and racial persecution.

Dorothy Shakespear Pound, widow of the American poet Ezra Pound, died Saturday at her home near Cambridge. She was 87 years old.

The United Mine Workers approvedd today contract demands that are expected to stir controversy when preliminary talks with the coal industry begin next month.

Anxieties over the state of the British economy led to heavy selling of the pound here today in the foreign-exchange markets. Sterling traded at its lowest level ever against the United States. dollar.

Walter Kennedy, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, said yesterday that the league's security division was invesigating charges that the Seattle SuperSonics purposely lost a game to the Philadelphia 76ers last season.
Mrs. Edwynna Wilson Davis of New York, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Bird Wilson, was married here Saturday to Jay Bucknell Lippincott Reeves, a widower, of Philadelphia.
Commodore Gail Morgan, U.S.N., retired, for many years a ranking aviation officer, died here Saturday. He was 80 years old.

The decision of Arab oil ministers to reduce production by a further 5 per cent in January is expected to lead to new conservation measures and, according to industry estimates, may produce a shortfall in Europe's petroleum supplies by as much as 25 per cent early next year.

Three New York detectives were arrested yesterday on charges of taking a $3,000 bribe to go easy on a husband and wife they had apprehended with more than 100 cartons of untaxed cigarettes that had been smuggled into the city.

Herbert Plank of Italy, a 19-year-old farmer's son, won the men's downhill ski race today in the First Snow Critierium.

Repetitive movement and hypnotic sound are natural performance companions. During the weekend the choreographers Laura Dean and Nancy Topf used these elements in different proportions and individual ways.
Eli P. Reich resigned today as head of the Office of Petroleum Allocation, according to an announcement by the Federal energy administrator, William E. Simon, The Associated Press reported.

Several small companies have regarded the low prices of their shares in the bear market as offering them a suitable opportunity to go private-or nearly so. Their tenders for stock are not without irony.

Protests abounded at Aqueduct yesterday, and the prospect is that there may be more to come. Angel Cordero Jr. submitted the most notable objection, when he requested re-examination of a five-day suspensionn handed to him for a riding violation last week. The sentence starts today.

James Noland, a tenor who gave a recital Sunday in Carnegie Recital Hall. shares with many others in his voice category at least one damaging characteristic. Regardless of whether he is singing Strauss's "Standchen" or Schubrt's."

The peasants here are being told that the sinuous one-and-a-half-mile gash they are digging in the earth is an irrigation canal. But in truth the huge ditch is one section of a vast network of antitank trenches that Saigon has decided to construct in a wide arc north of the capital.
The remains of Old Tornado, the greatest bull of them all, are up on Persimmon Hill in the Cowboy Hall of Fame.

Bobby Jones, a senior center, scored 21 points and pulled down 12 rebounds tonight to lead fifth-ranked North Carolina to a 104-84 victory over Kentucky, the third straight loss of the college basketball season for the Wildcats.
A California tax official disputed today a White House contention that President Nixon's lawyers had consuited state officials on whether the President was required to pay state income taxes.
Arab diplomatic pressure on Japan built up today as two Arab envoys concluded two days of highlevel talks here and Japan's Deputy Premier took off on an oil-seeking mission to Arab capitals.

Presidential tape recordings and documents, a point of explosive confrontation between the former Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, and President Nixon, have begun to flow to Mr. Cox's successor, Leon Jaworski.

In a gothic monastery in Avila, Honor Tracy was startled to hear, over a loudspeaker, a man confessing his sins to a priest. At first it was not clear whether this was not one more novelty in Spain's mad rush at modernization.

President Nixon has at last made what appears to be a complete disclosure of his financial affairs. Only a team of qualified accountants can fully understand all of the financial data that Mr. Nixon has released and determine whether they are complete and accurate. Similarly, experienced tax lawyers have to examine the deductions he has taken and the decisions about tax liability he has made.
The ugly hand of illegal basketball recruiting came under attack yesterday by metropolitan area college coaches, the Eastern College Athletic Conference and black community leaders.
The Government announced today it was assuming control and supervision over all crude oil and petroleum products, including those produced by the foreign oil companies here.

The longawaited trial of Alderman Thomas E. Keane, chairman of the City Council Finance Committee, on charges of official misconduct and conflict of interest, opened today in Cook County Circuit Court.
THIMPHU. Bhutan-The 18-year-old King of Bhutan would be glad to surrender some of his royal powers, but his subjects refuse to let him.

The state filed an antitrust suit today against 186 companies and 24 former Hudson County and Jersey City officials, seeking more than $500-million in damages as a result of an alleged kickback system that officials say operated between 1957 and 1971.

Presidential tape recordings and documents, a point of explosive confrontation between the former Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, and President Nixon, have begun to flow to Mr. Cox's successor, Leon Jaworski.
Oscar Luis Valdez Mena, a Dominican pianist who graduated from the Juilliard School in 1971, gave his third New York recital on Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

A. Lyle King, director of marine terminals for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey since 1952, died yesterday of a heart attack in United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y. He was 67 years old and lived at 1064 Bay Head Drive, Mamaroneck, N.Y.
The St. Joe Minerals Company, the largest domestic producer of lead and zinc, announced yesterday that it was raising the price of these two commodities.

Dr. W. Clarke Wescoe, vice chairman of Sterling Drug, Inc., has been named chairman and chief executive officer, effective Feb. 1, 1974. He succeeds Dr. J. Mark Hiebert-both are medical doctors-who will retire at the age of 69.

A 20-year-old suspect in a grand larceny case was shot to death in a police station in Harlem last night in a gunfight that erupted after he seized his arresting officer's service revolver, the police reported. None of the police officers involved were hurt.

Louis Farrakhan, the national representative of Eiijah Muhammed, the leader of the Black Muslims, has denied, that the organization is in financial trouble and he asserted that the Nation of Islam's temples had not become "a repository of crime."

Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana, vice chairman of the Congressional committee that will review President Nixon's tax returns, said today that he believed the committee would want to conduct a complete audit of the returns.
Ihe Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced here yesterday that it had signed a $10-million contract with Poland to design and equip an advanced electronics manufacturing plant near Warsaw.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi installed a new administration in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh today after ending a period of rule by the central Government.

Governor Rockefeller is expected to announce his resignation at a news conference this morning in Albany, setting in motion his final run for the Presidency and his succession by Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson after 15 years of silent loyalty and labor.
The overwhelming Democratic majority in the newly elected New Jersey Assembly tonight unanimously chose S. Howard Woodson, a 57-year-old black Baptist minister here, to be Assembly Speaker.
PARIS--Of all the cultural enterprises favored by President Pompidou, the least polemical and, so far, the most successful has been the Festival d'Automne.

A class action was filed in New Jersey State Court last week by former employes of Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., to compel the company to pay pensions that were not vested following the closing of its plant in Passaic in June of 1973.

After four days of practically non-stop negotiations at the highest level, Britain, the Republic of Ireland and political leaders of both Catholic and Protestant communities in Northern Ireland have achieved a historic agreement. They will set up a Council of Ireland, the first official entity representing the whole of Ireland since partition of the island 52 years ago.

An unemployed tool and die maker from Rockland County was arrested in lower Manhattan last night by two plainclothes men who watched him collect coins from a parking B meter much the way regular daytime collections are made by the Traffic Department, the police reported.
The executive council of the American Federation of Teachers has formally asked David Selden to resign immediately as president of the 400,000-member union.

Mrs. Ruth Davis Stevens, wife of David H. Stevens, former director of humanities at the Rockefeller Foundation in New York, died here Saturday at the Bellin Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived in Ephriam.

Secretary of State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Michel Jobert of France clashed openly today over whether improved relations between the United States and the Soviet Union under- few mined the security of Western Europe.
The Senate passed a sweeping energy conservation bill today that would require automobile manufacturers to give more miles to the gallon by 1978.

The state filed an antitrust suit today against 186 companies and 24 former Hudson County and Jersey City officials, seeking more than $500-million in damages as a result of an alleged kickback system that officials say operated between 1957 and 1971.

Wheat, soybean and corn futures prices fell yesterday while potato and meat futures prices rose. On the Chicago Board of Trade, December wheat futures fell from $5.54 a bushel to $5.43 and the March contract dipped to $5.23 from $5.29 a bushel.

Ten reporters from around the country have won Washington Journalism Center fellowships for 1974. providing them with five months of public affairs reporting experience in the nation's capital and a $4.200 stipend.
Theodore Bolton, art historian, artist and former librarian of the Century Association here, died Friday at his home in Coconut Grove, Fla. His age was 84.

The Health Services Administration, in a report to Mayor Lindsay, that contradicted previous statements by some persons involved in the case, asserted yesterday that the Medical Examiner's office had acted appropriately when it severed the head of an unidentified woman who was believed to have drowned in the East River in 1971.
The New York Post and the New York Newspaper Guild have reached a tentative agreement on a new two-year contract, 3ohn Sladek, chairman of the guild unit, announced yesterday.
Five Governors of New York State have resigned in the past, each to assume a high Federal office.

Estimating that 30 to 50 per cent of all gas used by the nation's 41 million gas range is consumed by their convenience pilot lights, Representative Lester B. Wolff plans to introduce legislation that would require the shuit-off of such lights and bring back the kitchen match as a conservation measure.
The American Can Company announced yesterday that it had signed a preliminary agreement with the Soviet Union to help develop advanced container and packaging technology.

The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday that would construct a major polystyrene plant in Hong Kong. The plant, Hong Kong's first production facility for plastic raw materials, will require an investment of $20-million and will be capable of turning out 150-million pounds of polystYrene a year.
Senate Democratic leaders decided today to delay indefinitely action on a bill to empower the courts to appoint a special prosecutor for the Watergate criminal investigations.

Secretary of State Kissinger repeated his denial tonight that he had had any involvement in the White House plumbers or had known that David R. Young Jr., his former aide, was engaged in the group's clandestine activities.

Politics and postponements seem the ritual game of the Board of Estimate this month. Lindsay-sponsored programs are being deliberately held up in the transfer of power to a new administration.

The application of the Lloyds Bank Group of London to acquire the First Western Bank ind Trust Company of Los Angeles has been approved by The Federal Reserve Board. here is a statutory period of 30 days before the approval becomes effective.

A street fight in the Bronx last April in which one participant suffered a broken arm culminated Monday night in the fatal shooting of his 29-yearold opponent by assailants bent on revenge, the police reported yesterday.

Dr. Johanna Reisberg Hilkowich, gynecologist and obstetrician and the widow of Dr. Abe Maurice Hilkowich, died yesterday at Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital. Her age was 80 and she lived at 315 Central Park West.
A Federal investigation into the multiple collisions last Oct. 23 and 24 on the New Jersey Turnpike opened in East Brunswick. The accidents left 9 dead and 37 injured.
Bishop Thomas Patrick Collins, a Maryknoll missionary for 31 years, died on Friday at the Ferncliff Nursing Home in Rhinebeck. He was 58 years old and was a resident of St. Teresa's. Marvknoll.
The British heavyweight boxing champion, Danny McAlinden, scored a fourth-round knockout over an American, Vern MacIntosh, tonight at the Royal Albert Hall.
The Chrysler Corporation confirmed today that it was building a nearly one-million-squarefoot assembly plant to house an assembly line for full-size and intermediate-size car body frame.
Harry R. Wall, vice chairman of the board of the Consumers Power Company, died at his home on Sunday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.
Senator Lowell P. weicker Jr. released today a detailed argument questioning whether President Nixon was legally entitled to deduct from his income taxes the value of his VicePresidential papers.

For the first time in a protracted dispute involving this community and neighboring New Brunswick, black and white parent and. neighborhood groups sent their leaders to a coalition confer-. ence here last night to demands that "regionalization" of their school systems be dropped.

In a reversal of policy, President Nixon has shifted the authority to set radiation standards for individual nuclear power plants from the Environmental Protection Agency to the Atomic Energy Commission.
Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that he planned to meet tomorrow with Governor Rockefeller and Governor-to-be Malcolm Wilson "to further our efforts to have the 35-cent fare."
The House Judiciary Committee reached informal agreement today that its inquiry into the impeachment of President Nixon should be conducted by a select subcommittee.
Cesar Cedeno, the Houston Astros' star center fielder, was accused this morning of "voluntary manslaughter" in the fatal shooting of a 19-yearold woman.
It was an ordinary afternoon, and the police tow truck was prowling. On West 47th Street there was a car next to a meter, and the meter had run out of time.
Representative Bob Price, Republican or Texas, today introduced a bill that would allow a tax deduction for home. owners who insulate their homes better, thus saving heat.

Fourteen Vietnam veterans, many of whom directed traffic as military policemen, were assigned to duty at busy city intersections yesterday by the city's Traffic Department.

The Texas Offshore Terminal Commission, speeding up its schedule of studies to hasten the start of construction of the nation's first port to handle supertankers, will be ready to make recommendations to the Texas Legislature on Dec. 20.
The city's Environmental Protection Administration has proposed alternatives to Consolidated Edison's controversial 2-million kilowatt Storm King pumped-storage generating project.
One of the world's great partnerships scored a popular victory here last night in the life master men's pairs, one of the major events in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

The Supreme Court broadened today the power of law enforcement officers to search persons without a warrant. On a vote of 6 to 3, the Court held that persons taken into custody on minor charges may then be searched for evidence of more serious but unrelated crimes.
Dr. Wolf V. Vishniac, a microbiologist, fell to his death in Antarctica while on a scientific expedition, it was reported today. He was 51 years old.
Top-level changes were announced yesterday for the executive suites of three major corporations-International Paper, Borden and the Bank of New York.
The Nixon Administration plans to require a reduction of gasoline production by as much as 20 per cent, informed sources said tonight.
The performance of "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night was more than just the annual re-entry into the repertory of the popular Puccini work, for there were three important debuts.

A Superior Court judge presiding in the trial of John J. Kenny, former Hudson County Democratic chairman, questioned the "fanfare" with which state officials announced a civil suit involving Mr. Kenny on Monday. The judge, Thomas O'Brien, made the statement after Mr. Kenny's lawyer moved for a mistrial in the case here because of the publicity over the civil suit.
The General Assembly approved today financing arrangements for the United Nations Emergency Force in the Middle East, which is to cost $30-million for the first six months of operation.

The resignation of Governor Rockefeller, the most powerful New York politician since 1959, weakened the state Republican party and gave Democrats their best hope of victory in more than a decade, politicians in all parties agreed today.
The three-day rally staged by the American Stock Exchange. and the over-the-counter market halted yesterday as selling late in the session drove prices lower in active trading.
The Iranian Government announced yesterday that it had sold oil for as high as $17.40 a barrel, which represents a quadrupling in price, the Associated Press reported from Teheran.

The two national commissions for which Governor Rockefeller is resigning to devote his full energies are composed of leaders of government, education and industry, each with a projected budget of $20-million and each expected to complete its work within two years.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today a five-year phaseout of Government insurance of private business investment against political risks abroad. The committee accepted by a 9-to-7 vote the recommendation of its subcommittee on multinational corporations headed by Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho.
The disclosure that sewage sludge was nearing Nassau County's South Shore beaches and could pose a health hazard drew sharp comments today from the County Executive and a State Assemblyman.

Some major food corporations routinely defraud consumers by marketing as "prime quality" food products that are underweight or substandard in quality, according to testimony today before a subcommittee of the Senate.

Gilhooley, president of Transport of New Jersey, the nation's largest private masstransit carrier, today proposed a sweeping fuel conservation program that would include the elimination of bus tolls and other fees charged by port authorities and the relaxation of some rules imposed by regulatory agencies.
Poised and ready for its first entrechats, the New York City Ballet goes back into business after a fourweek dancers' strike with a 6 P.M. performance tonight of "The Nutcracker."
David McKay Co., Inc., the 90-year-old New York book publishing house is to be bought for $3.6-million by MorganGrampian Ltd., a British magazine publishing concern, it was announced yesterday.
Leopold Chouinard, the only person to live after a Delta Airlines jet crashed in Boston last July, became the 89th victim of the crash when he died tonight.
The case of the 1970 shootings at Kent State University will go to a Federal grand jury in Cleveland next week, the Justice Department announced tonight.
The Iranian Government announced yesterday that it had Sold oil for as high as $17.40 barrel, which represents a quadrupling in price, the Associated Press reported from Teheran.

The North American Soccer League awarded yesterday franchises to four West Coast cities. The league, which operated with 17 teams in 1968 and only five in 1969, will function with at least 12 teams in 1974.

After a 15-year reign over New York's government and politics, Governor Rockefeller announced that he would resign to pursue a new national role and turn his authority over to Lieut. Gen. Malcolm Wilson on Tuesday.
Officials of Amnesty International, an organization that seeks to defend the rights of political prisoners, were completing a report today that was said to charge Chile with torture.

The federal Government today opened an investigation to the series of accidents that killed nine persons on the New Jersey Turnpike last month and it promptly encountered the issue of who was responsible for the lack of visibility that caused massive collisions on the state's major expressway.
Six persons were killed and 38 injured today when fire broke out aboard the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk 700 miles east of the Philippines, the Naval Air Force Pacific Fleet announced.
A shot was fired last weekend into the home of Pele, the soccer star, police said today. The bullet smashed into the trophy room, causing little damage.
The State Department said today that what the United States Government considered a direct threat against the life of Secretary of State Kissinger had been made over the weekend.

Reggie Smith, who accused Boston, among other things, of being a racist town, said yesterday he was through knocking baseball in Boston but had the "feeling of getting into the big leagues" in his new surroundings-St. Louis.
The owner of an auto repair shop here, upset at the rash of recent thefts in his area, has raised the ire of the city police by proposing a larceny lottery.

Nelson A. Rockefeller has been a Governor in the fine tradition of New York State. His years in Albany, particularly the early years, kept unbroken a bipartisan chain of distinction that began more than a half-century ago with Alfred E. Smith and stretched on through F.D.R., Lehman, Dewey and Harriman.

The country's largest and finest collection of Italian drawings in private hands, owned by the cellist and art patron Janos Scholz, will be acquired by the Pierpont Morgan Library, Mr. Scholz announced last evening.

" Historic offer" and "spectacular breakthrough" were the words Bowie Kuhn chose a year ago to characterize minor modifications in the reserve system proposed by the men who own baseball. When he spoke, the commissioner was aware that the players had already rejected the offer as inadequate.

The move by members of government agencies to deregulate radio has been challenged by a defender of public rights in broadcasting, who asserted that many small radio stations were "most in need of regulation" because they regularly broadcast extremist propaganda or were guilty of advertising abuses.

Mayor Lindsay and Ronald H. Walker, the director of the National Park Service, signed the legal papers yesterday to convey 14,000 acres of cityowned land to the Federal Government for the creation of the Gateway National Recreation Area at the mouth of New York Harbor.
Stock prices fell sharply yesterday as Wall Street's stirring, three-day technical rally ground to a jarring halt. Volume rose to 20.1 million shares from Monday's 18.59 million shares.

A rare 18th-century Italian silver tray, given by an old woman to a helpful delivery boy by means of a pawn ticket and later appraised to sell for $3,000 to $5,000, bought $8,250 at auction yesterday.
Secretary of State Kissinger arrived here from Brussels tonight after three days of talks with allied officials that apparently succeeded in easing recent strains within the Atlantic alliance.

In the spirit of St. Paul, who told the Corinthians in a letter that "God loveth a cheerful giver," and in the belief that giving can be fun, Mrs. Albert H. Clayburgh sent $5 in cash to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
Milton R. Leader, a former builder who had been active for many years in real estate, died yesterday at his home, 145 Central Park West. He was 68 years old.
The Knicks defeated the Phoenix Suns, 105-97, last night at Madison Square Garden. It wasn't much of a game after the first quarter.

An unemployed tool and dye maker who was caught looting a parking meter at Elizabeth and Broome Streets Monday night pleaded guilty to petty larceny yesterday in Criminal Court. He will be sentenced Jan. 28 and could receive a year in jail.
Two more players were named today to complete the rosters for the Shrine East-West football game at Candlestick Park on Dec. 29.

The 44-year-old son of Abraham Chait, a trucking and rackets figure well known a generation ago in the garment district, was arraigned yesterday in Criminal Court on a charge of grand larcency in connection with an illicit check.
Brendan T. Byrne was running for Governor he was fond of telling the voters that the one thing New Jersey did not need was another politician, given the state's reputation for political corruption.

Wilson S. Johnson, president of the National Federation of Independent Business, said today that the Administration should reveal the extent of the energy crisis before "fear of the dark" causes a recession.

The local omnipresence of Duke Ellington includes not only his nightly performances at the Rainbow Grill and the publication of his book, "Music Is My Mistress," but also the release of a two-disk album, "The Golden Duke" (Prestige P-24029, $6.98), which focuses on two notable moments in his career.
A straight party-line vote today defeated a proposal that the California Franchise Tax Board publicly announce that it would try to collect state income taxes from President Nixon.
Ron Santo, the slugging third baseman, was traded to the Chicago White Sox today after 14 years with the Chicago Cubs.

Disputes over financing new or expanded schools continued yesterday as the City Planning Commission held its second session of hearings on the proposed capital budget for the year beginning next July 1.

Americans may use indoor Christmas tree lights this holiday season, but other ornamental lighting of private residences as well as commercial establishments is banned, William E. Simon, head of the Federal Energy Office, said today.

Eli T. Reich, the 60-year-old Navy vice admiral who retired Oct 31 to head the Government's new oil allocation effort, re signed "with genuine regret" today, bringing to an end a series of confrontations with William E. Simon, head of the Federal Energy Office.

The dollar rose to its highest point ever against the pound today, when it was quoted at $2.3040 to the pound in early trading. It weakened to $2.3120 at midday but strengthened to close at $2.3075 as the pound drifted downwards.
Middendorf, Colgate Co. and Laidlaw-Goggeshall, Inc., two member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, said they had agreed in principle to merge.

John Patrick Curley, director of athletics at Boston College from 1929 to 1957, died today at the Cape Cod Community Hospital. He was 82.

The Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corporation has been awarded a contract to build four submarines at a cost of $269-million. Last month the same shipyard at Groton, Conn., received the largest submarine contract in its hitory, a $500-million contract to build seven of the same type of nuclear attack vessels in the 688 series.
Vladimir M. Ankudinov, former head of Intourist, the Soviet Government travel agency, died Dec. 3 in Moscow. He was 65 years old.

The appeal made by Angel Cordero Jr. against a five-day suspension handed him by the stewards at Aqueduct was denied by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday.

The Halliburton Company, a major builder of oilfield equipment, raised $171.2-million yesterday in one of the largest sales of stock by a corporation in at least 10 years.
John Spoltore, Republican state chairman, died early today of a heart attack at St. Francis Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived in Bridgeton, where he served as Mayor from 1953 to 1957.

The International Automobile Association is ready to use substitute fuels to save Grand Prix competition, badly hit by the fuel crisis, Claude Leguezec, secretary-general of its International Sports Committee, said today. Drivers, managers, manufacturers and racing officials from. the leading auto racing countries are meeting here this week about the future of the sport in 1974.

There were almost more sponsors than composers Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall when the United States 'section of the League of Composers-International Society for Contemporary Music joined with the Carnegie Hall Corporation and the Swiss Music Library to present the first of this season's "Continuing AvantGarde" programs.
Greece's military police said tonight that former politicians had instigated last month's student revolt but then lost control to anarchists who attempted to seize power.

Mrs. Jean Lithgow Paul, widow of the Rev. Dr. James A. Paul, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, was married here yesterday noon to Sinclair Hatch, a member of the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley McCloy.

United States Attorney Paul J. Curran said yesterday that his office would not make a second attempt to extradite the New Jersey financier Robert L. Vesco from the Bahamas, United Press International reported.

Plans to build a downtown shopping center here-the first in a decade-were announced today by Irving Feist, president of Feist Feist, a 70-year-old Newark realty concern, and Lester Crown, a Chicago industrialist.

S. Howard Woodson Jr., the black legislator elected Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, said today that he intended to strengthen the role of the Legislature during the incoming Democratic administration of Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne.
Michael C. Gray, president of the Guild of Catholic Lawyers, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Beekman Downtown Hospital on Monday evening after having collapsed in Small Claims Court.

The M-G-M Grand Hotel stood out like Polaris. Electricians tossed every switch they could muster in the still incompleted newest hotel on the Strip to bath its 26 stories in a golden glow. Searchlights swept the sky.
Two regional planning groups ended a three-year study of the mid-Hudson region today with a strong recommendation that growth now be directed toward the cities rather than the open countryside.

To the Editor: Defamation of Arab character seems to be the accepted style nowadays in United States communications media. Arabs are characterized as cheaters, blackmailers, stabbers-in-the-back and warmongers.
The Supreme Court broadened today the power of law enforcement officers to search persons without a warrant.

About a year ago, instructions went out to all United States Government agencies to eliminate the use of the word "poverty" from all official documents and to replace it with "low-income." The Pentagon made semantic history when it coined the abominable phrase "protective reaction strike." The pronouncement that declared "inoperative" all previous Presidential statements on Watergate will long be remembered.

Don't envy the Jets this week. They go to work today to set up what for them seems impossible, a defense that will keep O.J. Simpson away from a precious, publicized record, most yards gained rushing in a single season.

C.B.S. Evening News was disrupted briefly last night when a demonstrator from an organization called "The Gay Raiders" ran in front of the camera and held up a yellow sign saying "Gays Protest CBS Prejudice."

Roger Jellinek, assistant editor of The New York Times Sunday Book Review, has been named editor in chief of Quadrangle/The New York Times Book Company, a subsidiary of The New York Times Company.
President Anwar Ol-Sadat met here today with his Syrian ally, President Hafez al-Assad, to plan diplomatic strategy for the Geneva peace conference, which is to open a week from today.

The International Automobile Association is ready to use substitute fuels to save Grand Prix competition, badly hit by the fuel crisis, Claude Leguezec, secretary-general of its International Sports Committee, said today. Drivers, managers, manufacturers and racing officials from the leading auto racing countries are meeting here this week about the future of the sport in 1974.

Federal marshals dragged about 20 shouting spectators out of the courtroom where Joanne Chesimard and Fred Hilton were on trial yesterday then battled with them in the corridors of the Federal Court House at Foley Square.

The House approved today by a vote of 362 to 54 legislation that would authorize the President to extend $2.2-billion in emergency military aid to Israel to rebuild her forces in the wake of the October war.
Ken Rosewall has signed a one-year contract to become player-coach of the Pittsburgh Triangles of the World Team Tennis league, the team said today.

More than two months late but still welcome, the Philadelphia Orchestra opened its annual New York series on Monday night atAvery Fisher Hall, which had been offlimits because of the New York Philharmonic's strike and picket lines there.

9:06-10 A.M., WQXR: Piano Personalities. E. Robert Schmitz and Mischa Levitzki. Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun, Debussy; Piano Sonata No. 23 in F minor, Beethoven. 10-11, WNCN. Violin Sonata No. 5. Bach: Nine Epitaphs, Chanler; Cello Sonata in A minor, Schubert.
The Rev. Dr. O. Clay Maxwell, pastor for 40 years of Mount Olivet Baptist Church at 201 Lenox Avenue, died on Monday at his home, 114 West 120th Street. He was 88 years old.

James Madison High School in Brooklyn was ordered closed again yesterday by its principal after renewed violence involving black and white teen-agers resulted in one stabbing, at least three other injuries and five arrests.
Carlos Andres Perez, a Social Democrat, today held a substantial and probably winning lead over the Government candidate in Venezuela's presidential election.
Two more players were named today to complete the rosters for the Shrine East-West football game at Candlestick park on Dec. 29.

Democratic leadership of the new State Legislature was completed here this evening when the party's overwhelming majority in the Senate chose Frank J. Dodd of Essex County to be President and Matthew J. Feldman of Bergen County as majority leader.
The "big four" United States auto makers began putting new price tags on their cars today, taking the full $150 increase allowed by the Cost of Living Council on their fast-selling small cars.

A massive campaign is under way in the Soviet Union to modernize economic management, automate the planning system and upgrade industry to stimulate lagging technological growth and keep up with tne West.

Chief Judge John J. Sirica of the United States District Court will turn over to Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, tomorrow the tape recordings of President Nixon's March 21 "cancer on the Presidency" talks with John W. Dean 3d, former White House counsel.
This is the first of three articles on efforts by the Soviet Union to make its planned economy more productive and efficient through the introduction of new technology.
Inter-County Blood Banks which serves Nassau and Suf folk Counties, announced today that it was merging with the Greater New York Blood Program.

The Senate approved today by voice vote a bill that would provide counseling services for parents whose infants were victims of. "crib death." In adedition to creating regional counseling centers, the bill would provide support for research.

The Manhattan District Attorney's office yesterday charged the former security manager of Gimbels East and two of his private detectives with demanding $3,000 from a Yorkville restaurant owner for not testifying against him in a case involving gift certificates stolen from the department store.

Dresser Industries, Inc., a major producer of oil and gasfield equipment and mineral, machinery and industrial specialties lines, reported yesterday record earnings for. the fourth quarter and the year.

Egypt, Saudi Arabia and three oil-rich Persian Gulf states have agreed on terms for forming a joint stock company to run the projected Suez-to-Alexandria oil pipeline, the Middle East News Agency said today.
Ken Rosewall has signed a one-year contract to become player-coach of the Pittsburgh Triangles of the World Team Tennis league, the team said today.

The White House announced yesterday that Robert C. Hill would be nominated to become Ambassador to Argentina, succeeding John Davis Lodge.

With demand accelerating and sellers scarce, wheat future prices rose their daily permissible limit of 20 cents a bushel yesterday. Maine potato futures contracts also increased the daily limit of 40 cents.
A 34-year-old Philadephia man wanted in the death of five people in an Atlantic City nightclub shootout was arrested last night, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported.
Wilt Chamberlain, who "jumped" from the Los Angeles Lakers to become player-coach of the San Diego Conquistadors, will not be able to play this year.

In a reversal of policy, President Nixon has shifted the authority to set radiation standards for individual nuclear power plants from the Environmental Protection Agency to the Atomic Energy Commission.

One of President Nixon's chief advisers in preparing the statement of his personal finances also acted as a key intermediary in the return of $100,000 in cash from Charles G. Rebozo, the Florida banker, to a lawyer for Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire, it was disclosed today.
The Milwaukee Bucks, sparked by 28 points by Lucius Allen and 20 by Bob Dandridge, routed the Seattle SuperSonics, 130-91, tonight for their 10th consecutive National Basketball Association victory.
Dr. Frankenstein's Monster was clown in the Ethical Culture Society's basement at 2 West 64th Street the other day. Macy's Santa Claus was up on the ninth floor at Herald Square, just 30 blocks away.
Republican handicappers here and around the country were saying today that Nelson Rockefeller has finally learned some of the basic rules of Presidential politics.
The New England Power Pool announced today that New England utilities would get 24 per cen less oil than needed this winter, which could lead to severe power shortages

An Arizona observatory has heard radio signals from the comet Kohoutek, the national space agency reported today. It said this appeared to be the first strong evidence of radio emissions from any comet.

A spokesman for the nation's airlines asserted yesterday that reduced Federal jet fuel allocations effective Jan. 7 would cause elimination of 1,600 additional flights each day, the grounding of 275 airliners and the laying off of more than 25,000 employes during 1974.
A proposal to amend the bylaws and permit women delegates was defeated by 25 ballots at the quarterly meeting of the American Kennel Club in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.
The women's liberation movement appears to be on the threshold of a second phase--when feminist consciousness reaches beyond white, middle-class women.

Three spokesmen for consumers and poor people took issue today with the oil industry's contention that it needs higher fuel prices and the Nixon Administration's view that the present shortage should be bridged by squeezing personal, not industrial, consumption.
A 16-year-old youth driving a stolen Lincoln Continental led the police on a hectic, hourlong chase through side streets and highways in three boroughs last night, the police reported.

Willis Reed, the chief sore spot of the wounded Knicks, will undergo surgery today at St. Anthony's Hospital in Oklahoma City for a torn cartilage in his right knee. Dr. Donald O'Donaghue, an orthopedic surgeon, will perform the operation.
A dreadful game, in which the Zamboni ice cleaning machine was the only performer that worked, was salvaged in the final minutes tonight by the Islanders.

John Shumate scored 26 points for Notre Dame as the sixth-ranked Fighting Irish beat Indiana, ranked third, 73-67, tonight before 17,463 fans, the largest crowd to attend a basketball game in Indiana.

After a brief rally from its lows, the stock market, off sharply yesterday, is still anxious and uncertain. For the short term, investors appeared to have decided that the market was oversold after hitting bottom a week ago. But the more fundamental issue remained:
Partly sunny skies and cold temperatures will continue across most of the Northeast today; snow flurries may develop in northern New England and the lower lake region.
Mayor Lindsay said last night that if the City Council passed a bill raising the salaries of Board of Estimate members by $10,000 he would veto it.
The Senate Securities subcommittee approved today a bill giving the Securities and Exchange Commission broad authority over a proposed new central market system for stock exchanges.

The 76-foot-long blue whale that has awed millions of schoolchildren, their parents and teachers at the American Museum of Natural History for 62 years met the workman's hammer and ax yesterday as a four-day dismantling process began.
A shot was fired last weekend into the home of Pele, the soccer star, police said today. The bullet smashed into the trophy room, causing little damage.

The House of Representatives cast a resounding vote against the Soviet Union's emigration policies today and then approved and sent to the Senate the most comprehensive foreign trade legislation in at least 40 years.

Despite a lackluster 6-5 won-lost record, it was a historic year for the Rutgers football team. Several weeks ago, Rutgers made the longest trip in its 104-year history by flying to Colorado Springs to play the Air Force Academy.

All things considered, a pretty rosy future was predicted yesterday for the advertising industry. Now let's see if the predictions help the price of public ad agencies' stock.

Following five successive months of net deposit outflows totaling over $2.2-billion, the nation's mutual savings banks experienced a moderate $275million net inflow in November, according to figures released yesterday by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

The North American Soccer League awarded yesterday franchises to four West Coast cities. The league, which operated with 17 teams in 1968 and only five in 1969, will function with at least 12 teams in 1974.

Representatives of Bulgaria and West Germany signed preliminary documents today establishing diplomatic relations between the two countries, Government sources said. Foreign Minister Lyuben Petrov, signed for Bulgaria.

Sex discrimination continues at the American Kennel Club. Twenty-one years ago a motion to amend the bylaws and accept women as delegates was overwhelmingly defeated.

The Consolidated Edison Company asked the Public Service Commission yesterday for permission to raise electric rates by 22.6 per cent over the next two years.

The director of the Cost of Living Council expressed doubt today that wage-price restraints would be lifted quickly in the steel industry.
The Illinois Bell Telephone Company's $30-million offering of new 31-year debentures, priced at par with 8 per cent coupons, sold out quickly yesterday.

A serious clash on the Golan Heights front, involving tank, artillery and mortar fire, was reported today by Syria. Dr. Anthony A. Antoville, an internist for more than 40 years, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home here. He was 68 years old.

As the seminar on investment opportunities in the media and ad agencies moved into its second and final day yesterday, at the New York Hilton, the tenor of the speeches remained one of cautious optimism.

The Federal Communications Commission today turned down a request by the American Telephone Telegraph Company to reconsider a 1971 decision opening the private line communications field to new competition.
Members of New York.State's Republican Congressional delegation said today that despite its drawbacks, Governor Rockefeller's resignation would strengthen the state Republican party.

A commissioning program for American music, described by its planners as "unprecedented" in scope and likely to result in a "massive infusion" of new works by native composers, was set in motion yesterday by the New York State Council on the Arts.
The Bridgeport Brass Company announced yesterday it was discontinuing the shipment of zinc-bearing alloys immediately.

George Metesky, the onetime "Mad Bomber," who for 16 years in the nineteen-forties and fifties terrorized the city with the explosives he set off in theaters, terminals, libraries and offices, is going home to Waterbury today.

Prices continued downward for the second straight day on ;he American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market as economic uncertainties generated by the energy crisiss and the Middle East peace talks persisted.

The Nippon Steel Corporation said today that it expected a 5 per cent to 6 per cent reduction in crude steel output during December and an even deeper production cut in January as a result of reduced supplies of petroleum products and electricity.

At a superficial glance, the temptation seems irresistible for City University acceptance of the offer to buy a new 40-story office building at 2 New York Plaza near Battery Park as the new campus of Baruch College. The vocal supporters of the purchase, including many part-time members of the Baruch faculty employed in the Wall Street area, cite the attractiveness of locating a business-oriented institution near the financial district.

After a year of steadily declining popularity ratings in the Gallup Poll, President Nixon has now shown an increase of 4 points. He has climbed from 27 to 31 per cent in approval of the way he is performing as President.

With more than a touch of irony, the plans for a controversial debate that made some universities and colleges curiously shy, that gave some student groups an opportunity to become howling censors have been partly realized on television, a medium frequently and justifiably attacked for its timidity.

The House Subcommnittee on Small Business agreed today to recommend a six-month extension in loan-making authority for the Small Business Administration while a Congressional investigation of the agency continues.

President Nixon's decision that the Atomic Energy Commission rather than the Environmental Protection Agency should set radiation standards for nuclear power plants has implications that go beyond radiation and environment, to the unatomy of the Federal Government.

The Soviet leadership, signaling continuing interest in reduction of East-West tensions, disclosed today a scaled-down economic plan for 1974 that promises increased growth in the consumer sector and a slight cutback in the formal military budget.

Mrs. Ruth Schweigert Tukey of Woodland, Mich., widow of Harold Bradford Tukey, was married here yesterday afternoon to Emmert Warren Bates of New York, senior vice president of the Litton Educational Publishing Company.

A leading United States manufacturer of plastic products, faced with a serious shortage of raw materials, has concluded an unusual arrangement with the Rumanian Government to buy its entire export of petrochemical materials.

Investors' concern over the increasing energy crisis and its effects on the economy sent stock prices sharply lower yesterday in lighter trading. The biggest losers on the New York Stock Exchange were the blue-chip and glamour issues which had losses ranging from 2 to 10 points. The star performers were the gold-mining stocks, which made strong advances.
A definitive- agreement for the acquisition of American Finance System, Inc., by the First Chicago Corporation was reached yesterday. The transaction involves an excess of 590-million.
Mrs. Gisela Bergman Schneier, a leader in the resurgence of the Jewish community of Vienna after World War II, died yesterday in a convalsecent home at the age of 71.

Steve Kuberski scored 10 of his 12 points in the fourth quarter tonight to lead the Boston Celtics to a 126-119 victory over the Buffalo Braves.

President Nixon left the White House unannounced tonight to pay tribute to an old friend and to meet with business leaders.

Of the last great trilogy, "A Moon for the Misbegotten," "Long*Day's Journey Into Night" and "The Iceman Cometh," it is the last that is the. most difficult, and even the least immediate. It was given last night at the Circle in the Square Joseph E. Levine Theater. See it-it is the kind of theater that jumps between life and drama. But it never forgets that it is really drama, and, indeed, at times it can be overly theatrical. But this is a small price to pay for poetic insight. The theme of "The Iceman Cometh" is simple. Illusion is better as a reality than reality is as an illusion. We live with pipe dreams, and support those dreams the best we may. For some, the people O'Neill understood, tomorrow is more of a drug than a promise, and its withdrawal pressures may be so severe that the heroism it demands is impossible. In this play O'Neill gives us three life heroes-one who is led away to the electric chair on a charge of murder, one who jumps from a fire escape .and one who is left, all conscience and bleeding. O'Neill never suggested life was easy. This deeply moving excursion into another life-might be compared to Maxim Gorky's "The Lower Depths." They are both great plays of this century that show existence through the microscope of degradation. O'[Neill] did it with more humor and, in my opinion, more understanding.

The proposed World Football League awarded its eighth franchise to Detroit today. The league's founder, Gary L. Davidson, announced that a group of 10 local business and political figures, closely allied with Detroit's Mayor-elect Coleman Young, had put up more than $500,000 to buy the franchise.

John D. Ehrlichman, former White House domestic affairs aide, and two of his assistants lost their appeal today to get burglary and conspiracy charges against them dismissed on the ground they were acting in the interests of national security.

Three workmen cleaning a sewer north of Newark International Airport were killed today after they were apparently felled by sewer gases and slipped into four feet of water and sludge.
A school bus turned over after colliding with a car at a rural intersection today, injuring 14 pupils and the driver of the car, who was charged with driving while under the influence of alcohol.
The State Board of Social Welfare has decried "shocking" and "alarming" conditions at the city's Jennings Hall, a temporary shelter for boys aged 14 to 18.
President Lon Nol of Cambodia has announced that a new government will be formed shortly with the emphasis on foreign policy and internal security, following the resignation of Premier In Iam.
Prepackaged frozen entrees in some of San Francisco's world-famed restaurants? Absolutely, says Supervisor Dianne Feinstein who wants to do something about it.
District Attorney Maximo Hendriquez Saladin recommended today that Cesar Cedeno, a center fielder for the Houston Astros, be held in jail.
The Government announced today that it would end the official state of emergency and the curfew in the country on Jan. 1.
Twenty states have lowered daytime speed limits for trucks on major roads to 55 miles an hour or less in an effort to cope with the energy crunch, an Associated Press survey shows.

The new fashion show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a dazzler. You don't have to be a fashion buff to enjoy it. It spans 30 years before World War II, when the century was young, the arts were in ferment, and much of the excitement was reflected in clothes.
LAIKOM, Cameroon--Listen to the old man from Kom: "Long, long ago the ancestors of the Kom people left their home in Ndobo along the Mbam River and went to Bamessi.

The Soviet Union, which has been looking to American investment in its Siberian oil and gas resources, has apparently not been deterred by the prospect of a cutoff of large credits from the United States and has been moving forward on several fronts through its own efforts.

The eight Palestinians accused of killing the American Ambassador, Cleo A. Noel Jr., his charge d'affaires, George C. Moore, and the Belgian charge d'affaires, Guy Eid, in the Saudi Embassy, appealed a ruling that Sudanese courts had full jurisdiction over the case.
A Montreal amateur baseball group is $5,000 richer today because Mike Marshall earlier refused the $5,000 cash award that accompanied his selection as the Expos' 1973 player of the year.
Secretary of State Kissinger and Le Duc Tho, who negotiated the Vietnam cease-fire, will meet in Paris next Thursday, the White House announced today.

William J. Casey's nomination to be president of the ExportImport Bank ran into trouble today in the Senate Banking Committee because of allegations that he tried last year to conceal information about the relationship between the Nixon Administration and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

A former ragtime piano player and movie-house organist of the silent-film era died today at the age of 90, leaving in his rundown home a collection of sheet music and rare books valued by experts at up to $2-million.

John R. Fratianni, former deputy commissioner of the City Purchase Department, implicated himself and named three Brooklyn Assemblymen as among those who had tried to have almost 2,000 parking tickets fixed, a State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn was told yesterday.

Chile's military Government has named a former finance minister to negotiate with United States copper companies over compensation for property nationalized by the previous Marxist Government, a high official said.

If the Federal Reserve last Friday took a tentative step to ward making it easier to bor row money - as Wall Streel quickly concluded - the cen tral bank's data released yesterday did not include much evidence of such a subtle shift in monetary policy.

Men in brightly colored tribal dress punched at the air with spears, joyously reliving the triumphs of old wars. Ancient flintlock rifles barked in salute. Women waved raffia fronds in welcome and they swayed and chanted in unison, "The Afo-AKom is with us once more. There is peace. There is joy."
James Madison High School in Brooklyn is to reopen this morning with additional security forces on hand to prevent any recurrence of the racial violence that closed the school last Tuesday.
A prosecutor questioned today whether the weapon with which a 19-year-old woman was fatally shot while in a motel room with Cesar Cedeno was registered to the baseball player.
A California campaign official for President Nixon received a large Small Business Administration contract subsidy despite objections from a review panel, Government documents disclosed today.
Jonathan Dayton Regional High School here boiled with indignation today as a result of an article by a student who reported the widespread smoking of marijuana at the school.

A tape of a conversation in the White House between President Nixon and his former counsel, John W. Dean 3d, about a $200,000 gift to the Nixon campaign fund from Robert L. Vesco, an international financier who is now a fugitive, has been turned over to the United States District Court here.
Jerry Quarry had good reason to be jubilant in his dressing room last night after he had demolished Earnie Shavers in the first round.

Fred Carter scored 23 points and Leroy Ellis pumped in 18 tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers broke a five-game losing streak and snapped the Detroit Pistons' seven-game winning streak with a 96-93 National Basketball Association victory.
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of Robert S. Ingersoil, U.S. Ambassador to Japan, to be Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia and Pacific Affairs.
An appeals court has blocked further action temporarily in a suit in which H. R. Haldeman is charged with conspiring to encourage political dissent against President Nixon.
A 572-foot tanker carrying gasoline and oil ran aground yesterday at about 3 P.M., on the Ways Reef near the Hell Gate Bridge in the East River. It was finally freed by tugboats at 8:15 last night.
Dr. George Scatchard, professor emeritus of chemistry at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died Monday at Mount Auburn Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Cambridge.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., a large supermarket chain operating on the East Coast, which also runs a chain of discount department stores known as J. M. Fields, showed a sharp rebound in profits in its first fiscal quarter ended Nov. 17, according to results announced yesterday.
At the prodding of the White House, Senators Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, and Lowell P. Weicker, Republican of Connecticut, made public, their 1972 income tax returns today.
The entry and starting fees for next year's 100th running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs has been raised to keep out some horses that might not belong.
President Anwar el-Sadat today ruled out "direct negotiations" with Israel at the Middle East peace conference opening in Geneva on Tuesday.

Federal energy planners disclosed today that the alternatives to gasoline rationing that were under consideration included a mandatory one-day-a week driving ban and the closing of filing stations on Saturdays as well as Sundays to limit long-distance weekend driving.

Because of what Dr. Konrad Lorenz wrote on racial purity, as a professor in wartime Germany, the propriety of awarding him a Nobel Prize has been questioned in the December issue of The Sciences, organ of the New York Academy of Sciences.
John Marshall Booker, who retired several years ago as a partner in the New York brokerage firm of Wagner, Scott Co. Inc., died yesterday at his home here. He was 81 years old.
A class-action suit has been filed against the nation's biggest stock brokerage house for allegedly charging illegal rates of interest on margin loans to tens of thousands of California investors.
The Interstate Commerce Commission approved yesterday a recapitalization plan under which the Mississippi River Corporation would become the majority stockholder of the Missouri Pacific Railroad.
Bill Enis, television sportscaster, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. His age was 39.
Tom Donahue of the North Jersey Striders won the featured two-mile race in an Amateur Athletic Union development meet at the 102d Engineers Armory tonight.

While the city was announcing a reduction of 3,281 persons on welfare rolls for October, it was filing an unpublicized report to the state that showed an actual increase of 88 relief recipients during the month.

Joe Namath has been working out and barring an unforeseer. development will start tomorrow against Buffalo. He missed last Sunday's game because of a sore and swollen right knee. Namath says the leg is stronger and he has had no problem bending it as he did a week ago....

A spokesman for the all-black ad hoc committee on the Sugar Bowl announced today that street demonstrations would be staged next week to protest what is called the "Racist" policies of the organization operating the annual football game. The committee also is trying to block the broadcast of the game between Alabama and Notre Dame.
Three Arabs, charged with having plotted to shoot down an El Al airliner with missiles on Sept. 5, went on trial here today.
President Nixon postponed plans to undergo a thorough physical examination tomorrow morning so he could meet with his two top energy policy advisers.

The prospects of Congressional financing of Governor Rockefeller's $20-million Commission on Critical Choices for America dimmed today amid criticism that the commission was a Rockefeller vehicle for a 1976 Presidential campaign.
The Curtiss-Wright Corporation, which has made a tender offer for 20 per cent of the stock of Airco, Inc., said yesterday that it had filed a counterclaim against a suit brought by Airco.

Governor Rockefeller announced the resignation of Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo yesterday, six months after the cabinet member had been embroiled in controversy, then cleared of contract-interference charges.
Skylab 3 is one-third of the way through its 84-day mission, and officials? say they are pleased with its accomplishments so far.

The Rutgers College alma mater, 100 years old this week, is running into a little flak. The song, one woman student said in a letter to the student newspaper, is "an influencing factor in hindering the progress of the school."

City and state officials announced agreement yesterday on a plan to save the 35-cent subway and bus fare in New York City until May 1, 1974, and beyond that date if Federal funds for mass-transit subsidies become available.
Mrs. Dorothy B. Mery, former director of the State Office on Women, was honored tonight at a dinner given by four statewide women's organizations.
Jack Corbett, a former minorleague baseball-team owner who challenged the reserve clause and lost, died today after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

The editor and publisher of Lebanon's leading newspaper was released today after being jailed 10 days ago on charges of publishing so-called secret resolutions of the conference of Arab chiefs of state in Algeria last month.

Some of the several hundred political prisoners held by the military police since last month's student riots were released today. They included a dozen professors, journalists, actors and lawyers.

WASHINGTON --Tomorrow is the bicentennial of the Boston Tea Party. It is an occasion to consider the consequences of bigness in eighteenthcentury America. As every school child knows, the tax on tea was enacted by Parliament to bail out the East. India Company.

New York City has filed a suit in Federal court here in an effort to prevent the Federal and state governments from holding up grants on millions of dollars worth of federally assisted construction projects. The dispute is over the hiring of minority-group employes.

1. Vote on motion to table an amendment to energy bill that would call for reduced busing of school children. Motion tabled, 16 to 45, Dec. 10. 2. Vote on bill establishing a national fuels and energy policy, which passed, 75 to 15, Dec. 10.
Willie Davis, the center fielder obtained last week by Montreal from the Los Angeles Dodgers in a trade for Mike Marshall, ace relief pitcher, signed a two-year contract with the Expos yesterday.
The Standard Poor's Corporation raised its rating of New York City's bonds to "A" from "BBB" - a shift that means it now regards the city's securities as good investment instead of medium-grade.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia -- After 13 centuries of virtual seclusion from all but the Moslem world, the people of Saudi Arabia are being drawn into a relationship with the I world of modern technology, high finance and the power struggles of the 20th century.

American Metal Climax, Inc., said yesterday that the United States Court of Appeals in Philadelphia had upheld settlement of the pending litigation against Amax arising out of the reonganization in 1970 of Roan Selection Trust, Ltd.
Eighteen Chicago policemen received today prison sentences ranging from six years to 18 months for extorting money from bar owners.

A full-blown romanticism characterizes the large selection of paintings in the exhibition "American Landscape Artists of the 19th Century," now on view at the Hirschl and Adler Galleries, 21 East 67th Street.

Restaurant Associates Industries, Inc.- whose 145 units throughout the country include such well-known names as Mamma Leone's, Brasserie, Trattoria and Zum Zum--has named Richard A. Blumenthal as president.

Striking workers at the Helene Fuld Hospital in Trenton agreed yesterday to return to work for $1 more a week than the hospital offered them 12 weeks ago when the strike began. Although the 225 strikers had demanded a $20-a-week raise over a two-year period, they settled for an increase of $7.50, bringing the salary level to $140 a week, effective September, 1974.

The House voted today to allow Congress to override the President in the event he ordered gasoline rationing. The authority for a Congressional veto over rationing was approved by voice vote as the House sought to move toward final action on an emergency energy bill.

Valery Giscard d'Estaing, France's Finance Minister, announced today that the Government had decided to accept the late Pablo Picasso's priceless collection of paintings by other artists, some of which helped inspire his own genius.

Bearish Government reports and continuing concern over the energy crisis sent futures prices of farm products down sharply yesterday in early trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, but there was some small recovery at the close.

President Nixon, assisted by a Campfire Girl and a Boy Scout, pressed the button today to light the national Christmas tree. The tree was lighted with a single large star at its top and eight flood lights at its base.

Glenn W. Turner, a target of civil and criminal prosecutions for promoting pyramid sales of business franchises, was sentenced yesterday to 169 days in jail. Two of his companies were fined a total of $65,000.

The first blackouts of Britain's energy crisis darkened large areas of London and the rest of the nation last night. Thousands of homes in the southwest, west and north of London were affected. The blackouts began at 10:30 P.M. and lasted up to 90 minutes in places.

MILLBROOK, N. Y.-Joseph Labonte Jr. drove over a rutted dirt road into a state-owned forest near here the other day, started his chain saw, and cut down a towering hickory tree. He cut the felled tree into 18inch lengths, loaded the wood onto his pickup truck, and drove out again.
Chrysler Corporation and American Motors announced price increases on their cars and trucks today, ending the second round of price increases on 1974 models.

A 57-year-old man with a record of arrests for bookmaking, policy and narcotics offenses was charged yesterday with killing his sister-in-law and her husband and wounding his nephew in their home at 147-03 10th Avenue. in the Whitestone section of Queens, at about 6:30 P.M. Thursday.
Spurred by memories of the 1972 Eagleton case, a Democratic party commission has proposed creation of a screening committee to check the background of future VicePresidential possibilities.

City and state officials announced agreement yesterday on a plan to save the 35-cent subway and bus fare in New York City until May 1, 1974, and beyond that date if Federal funds for mass-transit subsidies become available.
Growth of industrial production has slowed markedly in the last three months but there is still growth, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Mrs. Marie Lombardi, the widow of the famed football coach, was the honored guest this week at a luncheon given by the Deal Golf and Country Club, to announce the winners of the second annual Vince Lombardi Awards.

Blockades at truck stops and scattered incidents of violence yesterday marked the second day of a wildcat work stoppage by thousands of independent truck drivers protesting higher fuel prices and lower speed limits.

The new Federal Energy Administration, acting on a request by the Department of Defense, has ordered the diversion of 500,000 barrels of crude oil to a refinery on Guam whose crude oil supplies have been depleted.

After dominating the first half and surviving some anxious moments in the second, the Oakland Raiders wrapped up their fifth division championship in six years by beating the Denver Broncos, 2117, today.

Billy Paultz tallied 26 points, 19 in the second half, and picked up a game high of 16 rebounds, 13 off the defensive boards, to lead the New York Nets to a 129-109 victory over the Utah Stars before a crowd of 6,043 in the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

With his best game coming on the lastigame of the regular season, Larry Brown pulled the Washington Redskins into the National Football League playoffs today as he scored four touchdowns in a 38-20 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles on a slick, snow-covered field.

When President Park Chung Hee announced early this month he was replacing the widely feared head of his Central Intelligence Agency and relaxing its surveillance of schools, churches and the press, the South Korean Government hoped this would mollify criticism that it had become too authoritarian.
Third-period goals by Jim Harrison and Ross Perkins capped an Edmonton rally today as the Oilers edged the Jersey Knights, 7-6, in a World Hockey Association game.
Two persons in an apartment lighted by candles in what officials said might have been an effort to conserve electricity, were killed yesterday when a candle fell from a table and started a fire.
Thousands rallied here today for the impeachment of President Nixon at an official Bicentennial reenactment of the Boston Tea Party.

When you have walked into a buzzsaw it's hard to tell which tooth bit you first. Earnio Shavers didn't use those words, but that's what he was saying after being stuck back together again Friday night. He knew Jerry Quarry had taken him apart in the first round, but there was no way he could tell which punch started him on his wobbly way down Queer Street.
A cargo plane carrying Christmas trees has brought tragedy to a Miami neighborhood, leaving eight persons dead, including three members of a family that fled from Cuba four years ago.

The Soviet Union, after a record grain harvest, indicated today that it was ready to push ahead with agricultural consolidation that could, in time, bring an end to that classic Soviet institution-the collective farm.
Truckers in Ohio and West Virginia ended their blockade of truck stop fuel pumps yesterday, and one of the drivers aid the protest had "just about lost all its steam."
Credit-market analysts remain somewhat divided on the question of whether or not an easing of credit policy is really underway at the Federal Reserve.
A baseline jump shot by Jimmy Walker at the buzzer gave the Kansas CityOmaha Kings a 105-104 National Basketball Association victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight.
Jim Garrison's luck ran out yesterday. He was defeated for a fourth term as district attorney in the Democratic primary. It was one of the closest election contests in the city's history.

The Arms Control and Disarnfament Agency is challenging the Army's plan for production of a new type of nerve gas on the ground that it is militarily unnecessary Ind would complicate international attempts to control chemical warfare.
