Fire destroyed garages of the Haverstraw Transit Lines on lower West Street tonight. The line provides local transportation in a large part of Rockland County. Apparatus and men were called in from the villages of West Haverstraw, Stony Point, Garnerville, Thields, Congers, New City and Rockland Lake to fight the blaze.

" I'm in trouble," said Phil Jackson before the Knicks left yesterday on a six-day road trip. The center was talking about his Christmas shopping, not any problems on the basketball floor, a good indication of why the New Yorkers had a fourgame winning streak with Jackson handling the pivot duties.

A Christmas tree without lights? Not so unthinkable when you think about it. There are multitudes of ways you can do an appealing tree without strings of bulbs, say floral designers, decorators, artists and display people. After all, on a good-sized tree all those bulbs can add up to about 500 watts.
LONDON-"The Party," a new play by Trevor Griffiths, will open next week at the National Theater. It deals with the notion of revolution in Britain.
A satellite tough enough to withstand atmospheric friction has been placed in orbit to make the first thorough study of the thermosphere-the atmospheric layer from 72 to 120 miles above the earth.

MOSCOW-About two months have passed since the Soviet Union ratified the International Covenants of Human Rights guaranteeing the right of citizens to freely leave any country, including their own, and return. All powers, large and small, ought to implement these covenants.

New Jersey's weekly lottery will be revamped in the new year to provide more chances for winning and more cash. The revisions are designed to bolster sagging ticket sales, which have leveled off recently at about 16 million tickets a month.
Hubert Berchtold, a 23-yearold mechanic, raced to his first victory in a World Cup ski event today, leading an Austrian sweep of the first four places in the giant slalom.

Miss Ilene Sharon Tanner, daughter of Mrs. Al M. Gordon of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Lester W. Tanner, was married here at noon to James Landau Rothernberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Rothenberg of New York.
Food shortages are now expected in Britain in the new year because of the three-day work week the Government has ordered to cope with the energy crisis.
The college basketball scene had something for everybody Saturday: U.C.L.A. showed how awesome it could be when it had to.

Reacting once again to a foreign threat, the countries of the European Economic Community have just drawn closer together and decided that only through unity can they "ensure the survival of the civilization which they have in common."
Unsold magazines, or returns, have always meant an income loss to publishers. But with development of the paper shortage, the paper waste alone has become as important as the lack of sales.
David Laine, secretary of the American Die Casting Institute since 1944, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home, 116 Central Park South. He was 67 years old.
For Bunny Orkin, the President's recent plea to keep automobile speeds down to 50 miles an hour is one of the year's larger chuckles.
The Soviet grandmaster Anatoly Karpov has been chosen world's best chess player of 1973, organizers of the Eighth International Madrid Chess Tournament announced today.

The unwillingness of the Soviet Union to allow Valery Panov, former principal dancer with the Kirov Ballet Company, and his wife, Galina, to leave the Soviet Union has placed the entire 1974 American tour of the group in jeopardy, according to officials of New York's City Center.

Republican campaign planners are beginning to compare 1974 with 1958, when the G.O.P. suffeared losses of 13 Senate seats, 47 House seats and five governorships. Like 1958, 1974 falls in the middle of a President's second term-historically a bad year for the party in the White House, as it was for the Democrats and President Johnson in 1966.
Third-period goals by Jim Harrison and Ross Perkins capped an Edmonton rally today as the Oilers edged the Jersey Knights, 7-6, in a World Hockey Association game.

Miss Marjorie Ann Costello and Bernard J. Rostanski were married yesterday afternoon at the International Synagogue at John F. Kennedy International Airport in Jamaica, Queens. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Eugene J. Cohen.

Carlo Bonomi, a 32-year-old Italian banker, has been named winner of the Sam Griffith Memorial Trophy, embelmatic of the world offshore powerboat racing championship. The Milan racer amassed a total of 62 points in eight of the 21 races on the 1973 offshore schedule approved by the Union of International Motorboating. His closest competition came from Don Shead of England, with 39 points.
There's an old joke college coaches like to tell on themselves at the start of the season. Question: Coach, of all your returnees, who are you happiest to have back? Answer: Me.

Three more apartment houses are under construction here and at least three more are on the drawing boards, but some of the momentum seems to be going out of a building boom that has given Hackensack a new skyline.

The National Satety Council said today that it had reduced by 50 its estimate on the numher of people who will die from traffic accidents over the Christmas holiday. It attributed the reduction to lower speeds and the gasoline shortage.

Egyptian officials today expressed satisfaction with the progress of preparations for the Middle East peace conference in Geneva. The postponement of the start of the conference from Tuesday to Friday, announced yesterday, was not welcomed here as Egyptians are eager to press forward with the negotiations, especially on Israeli troop withdrawal.

Gerald L. Warren, the deputy White House press secretary, denied today that President Nixon had any plans to take advantage of a potential tax deduction on the gift of his home in San Clemente, Calif., to the Government.
Dr Thomas A. Morrissey, former chief of urological surgery at the Hospital for Special Surgery and St. John's Queens Hospital, died here Saturday at the age of 73. He lived at 176 East 64th Street.

Congress in its collective wisdom decided last year and again this year to appropriate funds for the construction of needed water and sewer systems in rural areas. The executive branch decided that the program was unnecessary and impounded the money.

Ralph W. Guild, a senior vice president of Brett, Wyckoff, Potter Hamilton, Inc., a New York real estate firm, and a specialist in the management of luxury co-operative apartment houses, died yesterday at his home here, after a long illness. He was66 years old.
City officials have expressed concern about the city's ability to make emergency fuel deliveries to apartment buildings on a wide-scale basis beyond the middle of January.

Claude L. Alexander, who retired in 1959 as executive secretary of the Esso Foundation after 20 years as secretary of the corporate contributions and memberships committee of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), died Friday in Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Laude dale, Fla., where he had been living. He was 75 years old.
A Federal court injunction three hours before a strike deadline forced the Teamsters to postpone a strike against Detroit area supermarkets that had ASENbeen scheduled for midnight.
Mayor Lindsay last night called the world oil shortage an "outrage" caused by a "handful of international conglomerates and sheiks" and said that fears that it had created would "hurt human freedom."

The 20,000 tenants of Stuyvesant Town have received notice from the owner of the Manhattan housing project that rents will be increased by $45 to $100 a month when a 25year-old tax-relief agreement with the city expires next June 30.

A member of the 1972 United States Olympic basketball team and a staff member of Governor Rockefeller's Commission on Critical Choices were among 32 winners of Rhodes Scholarships, disclosed yesterday.

Michael Tilson Thomas came up with an attractive program idea for the Boston Symphony Orchestra concert he conducted at Carnegie Hall on Saturday. It consisted of Arnold Schoenberg's orchestral arrangement of Brahms's Piano Quartet in G minor and Brahms's Piano Concerto No. 2.
A two-hour free concert was presented yesterday at Jennings Hall, a temporary city shelter for boys, because the producer of the concert "wanted to do something for the kids."

The Indian press, one of the liveliest and freest in Asia, is undertaking a somber appraisal of its role, methods and future. In recent months newspapers and commentators have sharply analyzed the flaws of the press, and their conclusions are blunt, even harsh.

Mortimer L. Janis, president of the Franklin Simon chain of apparel stores, a division of the City Stores Company, died Saturday night, apparently of a heart attack, in Bellevue Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 400 East 56th Street.

Only 27 per cent of New York City residents who hold jobs drive cars to work, a far smaller percentage than in any other major metropolitan area, according to a Census Bureau study of commuting habits.

DETROIT - If Detroiters are taking the energy pinch seriously, it is not evident from the bumper-to-bumper traffic. But when it comes to retail sales, it is another matter, for business at most of the city's big store's has slipped since the news of the energy crisis worsened.

With national elections only 15 days away, Israelis appear too preoccupied with the life-and-death issues of national policy to pay much heed to politics. Political campaigning is on a low key, and the electorate takes little notice.

Skiers and ski-resort operators welcomed the season's first snowfall yesterday, and the long-delayed skiing season got under way. The agreement by House and Senate conferees on a bill to finance health maintenance organizations as an alternative form of health services is seen by the concept's originators as a first step in reforming the health delivery system, although no such over-all reform has been legislated.

Some 400 Roman Catholics who had just attended mass demonstrated today in Seoul's downtown shopping district, demanding democratic reforms and denouncing what they called economic subjugation by Japan.

Thirty-one members of a group demonstrating in Elizabeth for the impeachment of President Nixon were arrested after a clash with the police. Two tourists from Argentina spotted a sidewalk Santa outside Macy's at the corner of Broadway and 34th Street the other day and asked him to pose for a photograph with them.

State Supreme Court Justice Beatrice M. Judge told the police her chambers had been looted of $5,000 worth of antique jewelry, a .32-caliber revolver, a desk radio, $12 worth of eight-cent stamps and $2 in pennies. Justice Judge told the police that the burglary had occurred sometime between 1 P.M. Thursday and 5 P.M.:Friday in her chambers on the 11th floor of the Supreme Court Building at 360 Adams Street in downtown Brooklyn.

A 38-year-old woman was killed yesterday and four persons were slightly injured in a one-alarm blaze in Queens Village, the Fire Department rePorted, Officials said firemen found the woman, Lucille Moore, dead in her 1 1/2-story home at 205-21 113th Road.

Japan announced today a series of measures designed to prevent a rapid deterioration of her balance of payments. The steps, scheduled to take effect on Monday, became necessary in view of a record deficit of $1.7-billion in her balance of payments for November, the Finance Ministry said.

The number of minorityowned banks in the United States has more than tripled in the last 10 years, and it is expected to continue to rise rapidly, the Conference Board reported in an analysis published today.

What does an incoming County Executive worry about on the eve of his inauguration? Well, garbage, for one thing, at least in Westchester. Mayor Alfred P. Del Bello of Yonkers, the first Democrat to win the top post in the heavily Republican county, shaped an imaginary mound of garbage with his hands as he waited for the main course at lunch.
Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame's advisers told him yesterday that there was a projected $1.3-billion gap in the city's basic operating budget in the fiscal year that will begin next July 1.

G.D. Crain Jr., publisher of Advertising Age, which he founded in 1930, and other business journals, died yesterday in Evanston Hospital. He was 88 years old.
A Post Office custodian who had been on his way to work overtime during the Christmas rush was found dead in the Melrose section of the Bronx yesterday, apparently of a gunshot wound in the head.
Hazel Longden's Money Lender held off a closing charge by Printo today to win the $111,700 California Juvenile Stakes at Bay Meadows by a length.

The reaction of American Jewish college students during the latest Mideast war-an outpouring of activist support for Israel that astonished Jewish communal leaders by its intensity-has "demolished the myth of a generation lost to Judaism," the B'nai B'rith Hille Foundations said today.
In the span of only a generation Italy has changed from a predominantly rural society into one of the world's 10 most industrialized countries-and now the nation fears a collapse of its agriculture.

Israeli officials said today that their country's agreement to participate in the Middle East peace conference at Geneva had been given in exchange for assurances from Secretary of State Kissinger that American support in the talks would be firm.

Stan Fritts, a fullback, ran for two touchdowns to overcome the sparkling passing of David Jaynes and pace North Carolina State to a 31-18 victory over Kansas tonight in the Liberty Bowl football game.

The storm that gripped the New York area, as well as snow in the Middle West discourage some of the trading activity yesterday in commodity futures. However, there were enough buyers on hand to send prices sharply higher in some instances.

Surrounded by friends from the world of art and theater, Leonard Lyons, an elder statesman of Broadway syndicated columnists, received from Mayor Lindsay yesterday the city's bronze medallion and a special scroll for distinguished and exceptional service.
Skylab 3's astronauts have grown up to an inch or more in height and lost some inches around the waist since they left earth, a space doctor sair today.
The British Government abandoned its goal of economic growth today land chose instead a policy aimed solely at economic survival.

To the Editor: The energy crisis is a moral crisis that will ultimately force a reconceptualization of our place within the cosmic order. For too long we have sanctioned the. compulsive acquisitiveness of the Protestant ethic, which encouraged a consumptive and exploitive attitude toward nature.

Prices showed little change yesterday in the corporate and tax-exempt bond market in quiet trading. Dealers said many of their colleagues did not get to their desks because of sleet and freezing rain.
A leading newstand concern, now in bankruptcy proceedings, has been fined $204,200 for exacting special payments from three New York newspapers, the Federal Trade Commission disclosed yesterday.
Over a million football fans bought tickets to the pro games for the season that ended on Sunday and then failed to show up. This was a 63 per cent increase over last year.
Two retired generals who held high commands during World War II should get costof-living increases matching those of the active forces, the House decided today.
The Senate Watergate committee won statutory authority today to seek help from the Federal courts in obtaining some of President Nixon's tape recordings and documents.

The New York Knicks, again playing unselfish team basketball, demonstrated that a five-man was more effective than a three-man offense as they subdued the Houston Rockets, 109-97, before a gathering of 5,341 at Hofheinz Pavilion tonight.

Wally Butts, the former University of Georgia football coach, recognized as a pioneer of the passing game in the South, died today, apparently of a heart attack, shortly after he had returned home from a morning walk. His age was 68.
Frances Witherspoon, a cofounder with the late Tracy D. Mygatt of the War Resisters League in 1923, died Sunday in Philadelphia. She was 87 years old.

The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Ford Foundation to issue notes and debentures to the foundation early in 1974 in exchange for about 5.9 million shares of the nonvoting Class A stock of the automobile manufacturing company.
Italy's Piero Gros won the first special slalom race of the season's World Cup ski competition today and took the lead in the over-all standings.
Joseph W. Bingham, a retired professor of law at Stanford University, died Saturday in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 95 years old.

Irving S. Shapiro was named yesterday, as expected, as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., succeeding Charles B. McCoy, who will retire at the end of the month.

Diarmuld Russell, a founder and recently retired president of Russell Volkening, Inc., a leading literary agency, died Sunday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N. Y. He was 71 years old and lived in Crotona, N. Y.

Foreign Minister Walter Scheel is eminently qualified to be President of the Federal Republic of Germany, His election next spring, with the backing of his Free Democratic party (F.D.P.) and Chancellor Brandt's Social Democrats (S.P.D.) now seems assured. What is far less certain is the impact on the coalition Government and on the West German political scene of Mr. Scheel's departure from the Cabinet and his party's leadership.
Joe Thomas, general manager of the Baltimore Colts, said today he would announce a decision after the first of the year whether Coach Howard Schnellenberger would be dismissed or get a new contract.
The House voted 339 to 21 today to give the Small Business Administration more money to lend, rejecting arguments that it is too scandalridden to handle the money wisely.
The sharp decline in money market interest rates in late September and early October posed a dilemma for the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, it was disclosed today.
Iran, the second-largest producer of oil in the Persian Gulf, reportedly has come under pressure from Arab states to limit oil shipments abroad, but has steadily refused to do so.

The new National Commission on Critical Choices for America seems to be up against a critical choice of its own. Republican members of the Assembly late this evening ratified their previous election of Perry B. Duryea as Speaker and expressed their confidence in Majority Leader John E. Kingston and Assemblyman Alfred A. Delli Bovi, all three of whom have been indicted on charges of violating the Election Law.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circult here upheld a civil contempt citation yesterday that threatens the giant International Business Machines Corporation with a $150,000-a-day fine for refusing to hand over some of its files to the Justice Department. The court, however, did not impose a fine.
Three experts capped a remarkable tournament year here last night by capturing the Reisinger open team title, the concluding event of the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals.

Teamsters defied a court injunction and their own union leaders today and continued a wildcat strike against five supermarket warehouses in the Detroit area.

Joe Cronin, president of the American League, is expected to approve tomorrow the Detroit Tigers' signing of Ralph Houk as their manager, moving baseball's hierarchy one step closer to another confrontation with Charlie Finley. Houk resigned on Sept. 30 as manager of the New York Yankees.
Farnham Lefferts, president of Tiffany Co. and a relative by marriage of one of the founding families, has resigned after 25 years with the world famous jewelry stores.
The circle Theater--with one of those juggles of nomenclature that strangers find puzzling about our theater--is an Off Off Broadway Theater on Broadway.

Big-time college basketball, born 40 years ago in Madison Square Garden, is dead there now, but remains unburied. The five-year-old, 19,500-seat arena, has become a dismal place for college double-headers. It's doubtful that as many as 5,000 paying customers have attended the first three programs this season. A college basketball ticket in the previous Garden was once the toughest ticket in town and a haven for scalpers.

They saw the snow yesterday and remembered that perfectly forgettable knit cap that was charged at a Fifth Avenue store, picked off a pushcart, snapped up at a discount counter, bought on a whim one night in a bar where they stopped for a little something to take away the chill.

Governor Cahill said yesterday that John F. McCarthy Jr. had asked not to be reappointed as chairman of the State Commission of Investigation. Mr. McCarthy, whose term expired Sunday, was appointed to the commission on July 30, 1970.
Directors of the Gulf Oil Corporation approved yesterday a record capital budget for 1974 of almost $2-billion, or 34 per cent higher than the $1.5-billion expected to be spent this year.
Dennis Ralston, who has coached or played for every Davis Cup team since 1960, except in 1967, was reappointed nonplaying captain and coach yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

Who showed up at Aqueduct racetrack yesterday? Exactly 5,724 committed horseplayers, that's who. The weather, unbearable as it might have been to any normal segment of the population, made little difference to those diehard fans who form the hard, nutty core of attendance at the local tracks.
Two women were among the three persons named to important posts yesterday by Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame. They were the first women named so far by Mr. Beame, who said there would be others.

It would be unrealistic--even irresponsible-to argue that the nation's energy problems can be met without some setbacks to the cause of environmental protection and other socially oriented policies. Compromises between what is ultimately desirable and what is momentarily necessary must be accepted.
Marvin Barnes scored 20 points and made the game-clinching play for Providence tonight as the eighthranked Friars handed Niagara its first defeat of the college basketball season, 78-74.

Israeli officials said today that their country's agreement to Participate in the Middle East peace conference at Geneva had been given in exchange for assurances from Secretary of State Kissinger that American support in the talks would be firm.
Duke Ellington received the Handel Medallion, the city's highest cultural award, from Mayor Lindsay at a dinner at the Plaza Hotel Sunday night.

New York State's Welfare Inspector General, George F. Berlinger, said in a report that "sloppy administration" by the State Department of Social Services under Commissioner Abe Lavine was responsible, in part, for "baseless" outcries over contracts to a company headed by H. Ross Perot.

Dr. Charles Greeley Abbot, former secretary (chief executive officer) of the Smithsonian Institution and a noted astrophysicist, died today in Leland Memorial Hospital. He was 101 years old and lived in Hyattsville.

The City University's 21member Board of Higher Education, which has been appointed solely by the Mayor since 1926, met in its present form for the last time last night. Next month it will be replaced by a 10-member board appointed by the Mayor and the Governor.
Nelson A. Rockefeller spent his final full day as Governor of New York yesterday without ceremony and immersed in office routine built of 15 years' experience.

Katharine Hepburn's television acting debut in Tennessee Williams's "The Glass Menagerie" on the American Broadcasting Company received impressive ratings in New York and Los Angeles, although more viewers in both cities watched an episode of "Columbo" on the National Broadcasting Company.

After trading opened an hour late because of the storm in New York, prices on the American Stock Exchange fell on a broad front in quiet activity yesterday. The same conditions prevailed in the over-the-counter market.

Arab guerrillas attacked an American jetliner at Rome's international airport, spraying it with submachine-gun fire, hurling hand grenades into it and setting it on fire. At least 29 people aboard were killed, and two persons outside the plane were shot dead.
Secretary of State Kissinger ended his visit here on a poignant note today in a driving, cold rain.
George Foreman, the world heavyweight champion, has agreed to defend his title against Ken Norton, Norton's manager said today.

The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority estimated today that the cost of the proposed Meadowlands stadium and race track had increased by another $10-million to $15million, and said it hoped to market by Jan. 15 the $290million-plus bond issue required to finance the project.

Stock prices closed modestly lower yesterday after a snow and ice storm delayed the market opening by one hour to 11 A.M. Trading volume, reflecting the storm and the absence of many brokers from their desks, skidded to 12.93 million shares from Friday's turnover of 20 million shares.

Two engineering companies and three of their officials were indicted in Queens yesterday on charges of criminally negligent homicide in connection with the collapse of a cofferdam at a Consolidated Edison plant in August.
House and Senate conferees, after reaching a compromise with the Administration, approved today a multi-billiondollar comprehensive manpower act that includes an emergency public employment program.
It was a week before Christmas and all through the woods, not a creature was stirring except Joanne and Walter Lott of Great Neck, L.I.

Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne tonight effectively killed plans for the New Jersey Turnpike Extension through the center of the state, declaring that it represented a danger to the environment and that the fuel shortage had reduced the need for the road.

" Drumming" (1971) remains Steve Reich's most extensive composition, at least in terms of time. It lasts an hour and a half, but is built around a single rhythmic cell, which the players alter by phasing, pitch, timbre and subdivision.

One dozen pines, 300 mailings, somebody's cape, six altar boys, an extra priest and at least 14 choir rehearsals. That list, which fortunately does not include turtle doves or a pear tree, reflects a fragment of the things All Saints Episcopal Church at 230 East 60th Street must get or do to prepare for Christmas.

B'nai B'rith called on the Nixon Administration today to initiate a policy of "economic self-defense" that would include "selective control" of exports, tourism and technology to any nation cooperating with the Arab oil embargo.

The Senate Watergate committee won statutory authority today to seek help from the Federal courts in obtaining some of President Nixon's tape recordings and documents.

Justice Joseph P. Pfingst of the State Supreme Court, suspended after his conviction last year in a bankruptcy fraud case, was denied a new trial yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals here. Justice Pfingst contended that the prosecutor had concealed a deal to grant leniency to a co-defendant, the key witness against him.
Efforts to get negotiations going in the labor disputes that threaten to paralyze Britain made uneven progress today.

A group of blacks and Puerto Ricans, led by the National As sociation for the Advancemen of Colored People, filed a sui in Federal Court in Brooklyr yesterday charging the ?? County Police with systematic physical brutality, verbal abuse and harassment of minority group members.

Benjamin H. Danskin, the Monmouth County Republican chairman, who is considered a moderate, said yesterday that he would be in touch with members of the state committee this week to round up support for his bid to be state chairman.
William Lewis has substituted for a number of indisposed tenors at the Metropolitan Opera, and Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall he deputized in concert for George Shirley.
Senator Barry Goldwater said in a newspaper article published here today that President Nixon had failed to heed his call of eight months ago to clear up the Watergate scandal.

Rain, sleet and snow, propelled by the subfreezing winds of an 800-mile-wide storm, spread destruction and caused massive disruption of normal life yesterday throughout the metropolitan region. At least four deaths were reported.

Some of the best friends of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are children. A youngster's concern for the welfare of his less-fortunate peers has been a hallmark of the fund since it was founded in 1912 by the late Adolph S. Ochs, then publisher of this paper.

Andy Robustein, the captain of the New York Giants' defensive unit in their glory seasons but not involved with the team for the last nine years, was named director of operations yesterday with what he described as "full authority" over the selection of the new head coach, trades, signing of players and scouting.
Two stew ardesses with less than 12 months of service were among the crew members of the hijacked Lufthansa Boeing 737 airliner, a Lufthansa spokesman said tonight.

The Finance Ministers of the nine Common Market members agreed today on a package of monetary and economic measures that advanced their threeyear-old economic and monetary union into a "second stage of development.

Account losses generally don't affect the price of publicly held ad agency stock. And they don't automatically affect earnings results, either, Paul C. Harper Jr., chairman of Needham, Harper Steers, pointed out last week.

A committee of four Democratic State Senators yesterday outlined a legislative program designed to end discrimination by medical schools against students living in New York State and other parts of the Northeast, and to halt "an unconscionable" drain of statefinanced manpower.
Sixteen of the General Motors Corporation's 24 North American car assembly plants were closed today in the start of a one-week shutdown that some observers fear may be a common occurrence in 1974.

If a pediatrician wanted to, he could make a cogent argument against the traditional early-morning telephone hour. He could argue, as some do, that telling a parent he will be available every morning from 7:30 to 8:30 to answer questions encourages too much dependence.

The Soviet Union charged today that the countries of the Atlantic alliance had impeded the first phase of the troop-reduction talks in Vienna by advancing proposals calculated to alter the balance of power in Central Europe.

" We are going to conduct a slaughter at Athens airport," an Arab guerrilla leader reportedly said here early today aboard the West German airliner he and his followers had hijacked in Rome yesterday.

Rear Adm. William A. Sessions, a Naval Reserve officer who was promoted to flag rank on his retirement in 1957, died Saturday in the Veterans Administration Hospital, Northport. He was 76 years old and lived on Chateau Drive.

Shortages that could endanger the ill and injured throughout the United States are developing because of the national energy crisis, spokesmen for doctors, hospitals and makers of drugs and medical supplies told a Senate subcommittee today.

Yesterday's snowstorm was the kind that sorts people into two groups-those who take it as a personal plot against them and those who take it in stride and even find a little humor and camaraderie in coping with it.
Some followers of Muni Sr Chitrabhanu call him the Pope John of Jainism because they say that he, like the late John XXIII, opened the windows of his faith "to let the fresh air in."

A group of blacks and Puerto Ricans, led by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, filed a suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday charging the Suffolk County Police with systematic physical brutality, verbal abuse and harassment of minoritygroup members.
The General Accounting Office disclosed today that at least $100,000 had been spent to provide offices, aides and other privileges for Spiro T. Agnew since he resigned as Vice President.

The recent European Common Market offer of minor trade concessions to "compensate" the United States for the impact of adding three new members is regarded as unacceptable, informed Administration officials said today, but the Government is in a dilemma over what to do about it.
Canadian and American negotiators have worked out an agreement on charter flights that wraps up air negotiations lasting four years, Michel Dupuy, head of the Canadian team, said today.

George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, received the American Jewish Committee Democratic Heritage Award at a dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

With a swipe at city officials and a kiss from a wellendowed brunette, Weeb Ewbank began his new duties as vice president of the Jets yesterday. At the same time, Charlie Winner assumed his new job as coach and didn't knock anyone, especially the football team.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board made it a matter of policy today that savings and loan institutions may no longer discriminate against women or families dependent on a working wife's income in making mortgage loans.

In defense of sugar, a reader in New Brunswick, N. J., notes its use in many Chinese dishes and comments: "It appears that when the Chinese add sugar to their food, they achieve the height of delectation,

Following is a list of survivors of the explosion of the Pan American World Airways jetliner attacked at Rome's international airport by Arab guerrillas yesterday. The airline, which issued the list in New York, said it would not identify the dead until today.

A state report held yesterday that "baseless" outcries over welfare and Medicaid computer-study contracts to a company headed by H. Ross Perot had grown, in part, from "sloppy administration" by the State Department of Social Services under Commissioner Abe Lovine.
The British Government abandoned its goal of economic growth today and chose instead a policy aimed solely at economic survival.
Maggie Morgan spent a year getting ready: sewing tablecloths and place mats, painting trays and tables, mixing potpourri and searching out unusual decorative objects.

The Supreme Court took the following actions today: ADVERTISING Declined to review a decision prohibiting the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company from contending that its super sports wide oval tire "stops 25 per cent quicker" without conducting adequate scientific tests under typical road and weather conditions

Northeast utilities, which supplies electricity to most of Connecticut and to part of Massachusetts, today asked for permission to burn even dirtier fuel than has already been allowed because of shortages.

Three persons, including the state purchasing agent, were indicted today on charges of defrauding the Alabama Highway Department. The scandal has become a major political issue for Gov. George C. Wallace.
Many of the major news gathering organizations say that they would discharge immediately any correspondent who was also found to be working for the Central Intelligence Agency.

It was bad enough that Gilles Villemure, the New York Rangers goaltender, was injured in that 6-1 battering the team took from the Chicago Black Hawks Sunday night at Madison Square Garden. Getting home was worse.
The Supreme Court agreed today to determine whether a disability benefits insurance program that does not include maternity benefits discriminates unconstitutionally against women.
Discharges from an El Paso, Tex., smelter are responsible for abnormally high lead levels in residents of a four-square mile area, according to the National Center for Disease Control.

Some of the 1,371 Texans who are in prison for marijuana offenses will be freed under executive clemency, a spokesman for Gov. Dolph Briscoe said today, but how many depends on a case-by-case review by the State Board of Pardons and Paroles.

Prosecutor Joseph P. Lordi of Essex County said today he was considering the empaneling of a special grand jury to investigate a number of what are believed to have been gangland murders in recent months.

The Senate approved today an $80-million appropriation for the reorganization of six bankrupt Eastern railroads, including the Penn Central. The money is to be used when Congress approves a separate bill setting up the reorganization plan. This bill is now in a House-Senate conference committee.
House and Senate conferees, after reaching a compromise with the Administration, approved today a multi-billion dollar comprehensive manpower act that includes an emergency public employment program.

Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne tonight effectively killed plans for the New Jersey Turnpike Extension through the center of the state, declaring that it represented a danger to the environment and that the fuel shortage had reduced the need for the road.
Washington, D. C., for which Congress acts, in effect, as city council, could have a limited self-government under compromise legislation passed by the House today.

A dairy industry executive testified today he was told that corporate funds paid rents for two Washington apartments used by company employes to help the Presidential campaign of Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas.

Tom Hammer, a mechanical engineer who developed highvacuum metalizing equipment and was product director of John Dusenbery Company, Inc., in Clifton, N. J., died Saturday of lung cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital.

Le Duc Tho arrived here today for another round of Vietnam negotiations with Secretary of State Kissinger.
In a quick and friendly proceeding, the Senate voted tonight to confirm Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, as Attorney General.

The Palestinian commando leadership today condemned the guerrilla action that began with an armed attack on the Rome airport, describing it as an operation that was against the interests of "our people."
The season's first snowstorm has blanketed much of the Northeast's ski country with sizable depths, setting the stage for what many area operators believe is going to be a happy Christmas season.

State and local offices have been unable to substantiate reports that sewage sludge has moved closer to the South Shore beaches, and state, country and town environmental agencies have called for further samplings to attempt to substantiate the reports.
Filling stations in South Vietnam will operate only nine instead of 19 hours a day to conserve dwindling fuel supplies.
Egypt's Foreign Minister, Ismail Fahmy flew to Damascus today, apparently to urge a reluctant Syria to participate in the proposed Geneva peace conference, according to informed diplomatic sources.
About 250 South Korean Christian students, holding a "prayer service for national salvation" here tonight, urged the Government to amend the Constitution to restore democracy.
The Martha Graham Dance Company will embark on its first European tour in, seven years, appearing at the summer Spoleto and Avignon Festivals and London following a threeweek season here in March.
It was bad enough that Gilles Villemure, the New York Rangers goaltender, was injured in that 6-1 battering the team took from the Chicago Black Hawks Sunday night at Madison Square Garden.
In its final report on the state of the nation's colleges and universities, the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education has painted a gloomy picture of grave trouble on the entire education front.

A South Vietnamese military spokesman said today that 97 Communist soldiers had been killed by Government soldiers, backed by artillery and planes, in heavy fighting in the Mekong Delta southwest of Saigon.
Finance officials from major oil-exporting nations met under tight security today to draft proposals for new and higher petroleum prices.
Stephen C. Wiesenfeld, who sued for and won his "widow's" rights in Federal court, said today that he expected to begin collecting his monthly Social Security payments of $248.30 nextMarch.
The war and the queasy ceasefire have brought building and beautifying to a temporary halt here, but Jerusalem's ebullient Mayor, Teddy Kollek, is still full of plans and hopes.
George Foreman, the world heavyweight champion, has agreed to defend his title against Ken Norton, Norton's manager said today.

New Jersey schoolboy basketball suffered a major setback in Middlesex County because of the energy crisis with the announcements that the Perth Amboy Christmas Tournament and the Colonia Classic have been canceled.

The General Motors Corporation said today that it was notifying nearly 22,000 owners of 1974 model cars of safety defects that could cause the rear wheels to lock or result in the loss of rear wheel braking.

A hijacked Lufthansa jet took off from Athens today at the end of a night of negotiating between Arab hijackers and the Greek Government over the release of two guerrilla prisoners during which the hijackers reportedly killed five of 14 hostages.
Kentucky's Dan Issel continues to lead New York's Julius Erving in the American Basketball Association scoring race, averaging 28.4 points to 27.5 for Erving.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and many prominent and middle-echelon officials in the five previous national Administrations donated their papers as gifts on which they presumably claimed tax deductions, the Scripps-Howard News Service reported today.
Alice Faye and John Payne--together again! The two movie stars who shone in the early nineteenforties as a musical comedy couple made their last movie together 30 years ago.
The Senate approved today a foreign aid appropriations bill that provides $2.2-billion in emergency aid to Israel, but drastically reduces military aid to other countries.
The Board of Education will ask the State Legislature to prohibit teachers and other school employes here from serving as elected members of the decentralized community school boards.

John H. Glenn, the former astronaut, whose two previous tries for the United States Senate were marked by accident and amateurism, surrounded himself last week with political professionals and embarked on a fresh start.

Never mind what his fellow Connecticut Republicans say, Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has nothing but the highest regard for Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, a Democrat. Mr. Weicker criticized members of his own party, among them the Republican state chairman, J. Brian Gaffney, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill and Representative Robert H. Steele, for saying that Mr. Ribicoff, at the age 63, is "too old" for his job.
An Iberian Airlines jumbo jet carrying 167 persons clipped a landing light pier and crashed on landing in fog and rain at Logan International Airport today.

Fragued by stalled trains, frozen power rails and myriad equipment problems, the Long Island Rail Road first threw out its schedule and then threw in the sponge yesterday and shut down virtually its entire operation.

Dean Witter Co., Inc., brokers, reported yesterday that net income for the quarter ended Nov. 30 had risen 20 per cent from year-earlier levels. Unaudited consolidated net income for the company's first fiscal quarter was $1.7million, or 40 cents a share, compared with $1.4-million, 34 cents a share, for the first quarter of last year, the company said.

Amleto Giovanni Cardinal Cicognanl, dean of the Sacred College of Cardinals who for 25 years served as Apostolic Delegate in Washington, died today in the Vatican. He was 90 years old.

Tonight at 9:30, the Columbia Broadcasting System is, almost surreptitiously, easing into its schedule a 90-minute drama that gently and movingly turns out to be one of the most effective television presentations of the holiday season.

Steel production for the week ended Dec. 15 rose by 0.7 per cent to 2,926,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This raised the weekly production index to 119.9 from 119.2 in the preceding week when production totaled 2,907,000 tons.
Three inmates at Walpole State Prison were arraigned today on charges of conspiracy in the Nov. 25 stabbing death of Albert DeSalvo, the selfproclaimed Boston strangler.

The battle to take over Airco, Inc., became more intense yesterday as both contenders for Airco changed the terms of their tender offers for its stock.

The West German government will shortly lift restrictions on corporate investment, reflecting fears that the energy crisis will cause mounting unemployment and social unrest unless deflationary policies are eased. according to responsible officials.
One of Queen Elizabeth's aides lost a hand today when a letter bomb exploded as he opened it, Scotland Yard said.
Leonard F. Black Sr., who retired in 1961 as director of book and mail order advertising for Puck, the comic weekly, died today in Lawrence Hospital. He lived at 294 Bronxville Road.
The Senate voted today to extend for one year the 1975 interim standards for pollution controls on automobiles.

The New Jersey Turnpike Authority hopes to take bids in two or three weeks for a bus company to operate an express bus service between a 950automobile park-and-ride lot under construction here and midtown Manhattan.

The Buffalo Braves' center, Bob McAdoo, raised his scoring average to 29.4 points last week to maintain his National Basketball Association lead.

General Mills, Inc., a leading producer of packaged foods and other consumer products, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the second quarter ended Nov. 25.

When President Nixon names a successor on the Federal Communications Commission to H. Rex Lee, who resigned last week, he will have appointed six of the seven members of that regulatory agency.

Specialists in international law in and out of the Government have concluded that the oil embargo against the United States imposed by Saudi Arabia violates a little-known 1933 treaty between the two countries.

In presenting his anti-Inflation budget to Parliament, Chancellor of the Exchequer Anthony Barber echoed Prime Minister Heath's warning of last week that Britain faces its gravest economic situation since the war.

President Nixon plans a postChristmas -trip to Florida by whatever mode of transportation uses less energy but, because of the fuel shortage, he has ordered that no press plane be chartered by the White House for the trip.

The General Accounting Office, reporting on its review of Federal spending on President Nixon's private residences, called today for Congressional action to provide closer control over and greater public disclosure of such expenditures in the future.
Senate-House conferees agreed today on a $73.75-billion defense appropriation bill. The total is $3.5-billion below President Nixon's military budget for the year.
Larry Christenson will undergo surgery for the removal of bone chips from his right elbow, the Philadelphia Phillies announced today.
A White House tape turned over to a lawyer for Ralph Nader last week was played at a cocktail party last night, the lawyer has confirmed.

"France," says Germaine Bree, "is a country that has prided itself on a long tradition of successful women writers dating back at least 800 years." Yet its contemporary women writers seem to be having a harder time than ours in overcoming masculine prejudice.
Whenever a major labor dispute hits Britain, one that affects the national life and economy in some significant way, a mild political tremor passes through this normally placid country..

The New Jersey Turnpike Authority refused today to accept as final Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne's rejection of a planned expressway link between the turnpike and East Brunswick and the Garden State Parkway and Toms River on the shore.

The Senate Watergate Committee voted unanimously today to subpoena over 200 White House tapes and documents related to its investigation. The committee acted less than 15 hours after winning statutory authority from Congress to seek help from the Federal courts in obtaining the material.

Karl Cordin of Austria, who hadn't won a World Cup race since 1971, recorded a convincing victory today in a downhill race.
The Cliff Keuter Dance Company presented four new works by Mr. Keuter Sunday night at the Broome Street Theater, 330 Broome Street, to open a three-weekend series this month.
The largest credit reStvrting company in the country has been using unfair and deceptive tactics to gather its information, the Federal Trade Commission said today.
A compromise five-year, 375-million bill to encourage group health plans was passed by the House today and sent to the Senate.
Bella Freeman, one of the city's 700 women cab drivers, was honored at City Hall yesterday for outstanding service to the riding public-helping the police to capture a man who had stolen a taxi.

A Cuban narcotics ring, operating between the Miami area and northern New Jersey, was identified by law enforcement officials today as "the prime source" of cocaine for the New York metropolitan area.

Official tabulations today showed that Jim Garrison lost to former United States Attorney Harry F. Connick by 2,221 votes in the controversial district attorney's bid for a fourth consecutive term in the Democratic primary.
Richard J. Hughes, the 45th Governor of New Jersey, took the oath of office today as the fourth chief justice of the modern State Supreme Court, which came into being 25 years ago.

Numbed thousands of residents of the tristate region awaited an end to their ordeal by ice yesterday despite dogged efforts to restore power and heat, telephone service and transportation to normal in the frigid aftermath of the storm that enveloped the area.
First-period goals by Claude Larose and Frank Mahovlich led the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-1 victory over the California Golden Seals tonight.

Spiro T. Agnew asked Maryland's judiciary today to suspend rather than disbar him, giving him a second chance at the practice of law-a chance, he said, to "resume a useful place" and, perhaps, "attempt to bring credit" on his state and his profession.

Secretary General Waldheim informed the representatives of Israel, Egypt, Syria and Jordan today that he would convene the Middle East peace conference in Geneva at 10:30 A.M. Friday at the United Nations' European headquarters.

Mattel, Inc., the nation's largest toy producer, announced yesterday it had signed a letter of intent to sell its wholly owned subsidiary, Ringling Bros.-Barnum Bailey Combined Shows, Inc., to a major United States industrial corporation, which it did not identify.

Cesar Cedeno will spend Christmas in jail, according to the district attorney who charged him with voluntary homicide in the shooting death of 19-year-old Altagracia de la Cruz.

Faced with a party split over the indictment of Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea, Governor Wilson, former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, Mr. Duryea and other top Republicans joined in an often-emotional display of party unity yesterday.

The Italian Interior Minister told Parliament tonight that the murderous Arab guerrilla raid at Fiumicino Airport near here yesterday might have been carried out by members of the same faction. that was responsible for the killings at Lydda Airport in Israel in May, 1972.

If Bill Kilmer cannot attend practice today, the Washington Redskins will turn to Sonny Jurgensen as their quarterback for Saturday's playoff game against the Vikings at Bloomington, Minn. Hundreds of intercollegiate sports events that were originally scheduled for .the next six weeks throughout the Northeast are being postponed or canceled because of the fuel crisis.
A 21-year-old man was shot to death by a gunman who fired from a speeding car last night. It was the 12th slaying on the island of St. Croix this year.

Consolidated Edison began making final arrangements yesterday to burn coal for the first time in more than two years after the city, as expected, gave its formal approval for the burning of the dirtier, but more plentiful, fuel during the energy crisis.
Finland has agreed to help the Russians develop a large iron-ore deposit to bolster the raw-material supply for the Soviet Union's expanding steel industry.

Pete Maravich bounced back from a 2-point performance in his last game to score 34 points tonight and lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 98-91 victory over the Capital Bullets in the National Basketball Association.
Senate-House conferees agreed today on a $73.75-billion defense appropriation bill. The total is $3.5-billion below President Nixon's military budget for the year.

Arab terrorists who attacked Rome's international airport Monday and hijacked a West German airliner to Athens, flew to Kuwait - leaving behind 31 dead in Rome and one in Athens - where they released the hostages aboard their commandeered Lufthansa jet in exchange for "free passage" to an unknown destination. Discussions on the automation issues between Typographical Union No. 6 and the city's major daily newspapers are scheduled to begin on Jan. 7, Theodore W. Kheel, mediator, said yesterday.
Stock prices made a brisk Technical bounce yesterday as Wall Street entered its "holiday phase." Only eight trading days remain in 1973.

David N. Dinkins, Deputy Mayor-designate for Planning, told members of the Alliance for a Safer New York yesterday that Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame had "set an immediate goal" of remedying "some of the most obvious gaps in the city's ability to deter crime.
An official spokesman said today that President Nixon "cant remember" if he paid any state income taxes when he served as Vice President and as a member of Congress from California.

To the Editor: In the face of the current shortfall between U.S. energy demand and supply, the seeming prejudgment in The Times editorial pages against the generation of power from the heat of nuclear fissioning is disturbing.

The United Nations General Assembly last night recessed a session that was marked by the admission of the two Germanys to membership.
The Chicago White Sox sent a left-handed pitcher, Jim Kremmel, to the Chicago Cubs today as the fourth and final player in the deal that moved Ron Santo, the third baseman, to the White Sox.

Housing starts leveled off, at least temporarily, in November after a steep decline that began last spring, the Commerce Department reported today. At an annual rate of 1,698,000 units, housing starts last month were a little above the October rate of 1,636,000, which was revised slightly upward.

The British pound held firm today and managed to eke out small gains in the foreign-exchange markets following the British Government's latest proposals to narrow the nation's trade deficit. The pound's strength indicated that currency speculators had decided to cast at least a temporary vote in favor of the Government's decision to cut $2.76-billion from the budget in the fiscal year starting next April 1.

Valery Panov, one of the Soviet Union's best-known ballet dancers, was told today that he could finally emigrate to Israel, but that his wife would have to stay in the Soviet Union. Mr. Panov said he refused the offer.
The Rev. Theodore Pitcairn, a clergyman and multimillionaire art collector and philanthropist, died Monday at his home in Bryn Athyn, Pa. He was 80 years old.
Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that an "environmental sellout" would not ease the energy crisis but would only jeopardize public health.
The largest credit reporting company in the country has been using unfair and deceptive tactics to gather its information, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

A potpourri of poems, puns, planets and people from around the world in new books and recordings can be found among the 800 titles in the 63d edition of The New York Public Library's "Children's Books and Recordings."
Mrs. Margaret Court is pregnant with her second child and has withdrawn from the Australian team in the $30,000 Bonne Bell Cup tennis competition against the United States starting Friday at Sydney.
Egyptian and Israeli forces exchanged fire on the Suez Canal front today, but there were no Israeli casualties, an Army communique said.
The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 2,437 applicants, a record number, had passed the written examination for admission to the bar at the examination held last July 25 and 26.

Charles O. Finley, owner of the Oakland A's, sought a court order today to prevent Dick Williams from managing any team other than the A's, as a coast-to-coast tangle involving three American League teams became more tangled.

Malcolm Wilson was sworn in today as New York's 50th Governor and immediately promised he would be no "caretaker," but rather show himself to be "progressive in meeting human needs and conservative in handling the people's tax dollars."

The Soviet Union, which has privately been pressing for a world gathering of Communist parties, today opened a conference of ranking party officials from its inner circle of allies in the Communist movement.
More than 100 Americans die daily because of adverse reactions to prescription and legal nonprescription drugs, Ralph Nader told a Senate health subcommittee today.
Prime Minister Heath today canceled a scheduled trip to China next month because of the "difficult and grave" situation arising from Britain's industrial strife and the energy crisis.

When the stockings are hung by the chimney with care, there are some that will simply not hang there. They kick up such a fuss, these socks. Hot Socks, Wild Socks, Outrageous Socks, Totally Outrageous Socks. Teenage girls have many names for the socks they are now wearing but not always showing.

The Soviet Union today indicated concern that yesterday's massacre by Arab terrorists at Rome's international airport might jeopardize the Middle East peace conference slated to begin later this week in Geneva.

The nation's most costly energy-research project -- aimed at developing a commercial version of a "breeder" nuclear power plant by the mid-nineteen-eighties -- is suffering delays and large cost overruns that have forced re-examination of the effort's pace and scope.

The United States and South Vietnamese delegations walked out of a meeting today of the joint military team looking for missing soldiers after flinging onto the conference table the bloodstained jacket of an American officer killed during a search last Saturday.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday sizable gains in all phases of its operations for the three months and year ended Nov, 30.

Trans World Airlines cabin attendants ratified today a new three-year labor contract, ending a 45-day strike and paving the way for resumption of T.W.A. flights in the morning.
Four bombs exploded here today in what police officers believed were reprisal attacks for the jailing of Irish Republican Army terrorists who bombed the Old Bailey last March.

The State Department of Social Services announced yesterday that 200 state auditors would visit local welfare departments, including 150 in New York City, to set up procedures to reduce errors.

Retail food prices may rise over the next three months as beef and pork supplies shrink again, an Agriculture Department food economist said today.

Two 300-year-old Rembrandt paintings, valued at $330,000, were stolen from the Taft Museum today by two masked gunmen.

The transfer of the governorship from Nelson A. Rockefeller to Malcolm Wilson was accomplished efficiently and without ostentation-in a style characteristic of the two men. Mr. Rockefeller's unsentimentally matter-of-fact last day as Governor in office was matched in understatement by yesterday's brief and simple swearing-in ceremony of the new Governor in the Capitol's Red Room.

The Group for Contemporary Music, the new-music ensemble directed by Charles Wuorinen and Harvey Sollberger, unleashed something of a spectacular at its concert Mondy night at the Manhattan School of Music.

George Bucci had 21 points and Bill Campion 18 tonight as Manhattan defeated Hofstra, 77-51. Campion scored all his points in the first half, leading the Jaspers to a 39-28 half-time lead.

Jury selection in the second bank robbery trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton, reputed members of the Black Liberation Army, began yesterday in Federal Court here. The proceedings were disrupted by frequent attempts by Evelyn Williams, Mrs. Chesimard's attorney, to be relieved of her duties in the case. Miss Williams said she disagreed with her client and with the attorney for Mr. Hilton, Robert Bloom, over the nature of the defense.

Despite the recent steep decline in American stock values, many European portfolio managers still see Wall Street as the best place to invest, and some have been accelerating purchases in recent days.

The Knicks announced last night that Willis Reed, their first-string center and captain, would be discharged today from St. Anthony's Hospital in Oklahoma City.

Norman A. Levy, former president of the City Tax Commission, denied from the witness stand yesterday that he had ever been involved in a scheme to fix 2,000 parking tickets. He attributed the scheme to a man who had turned state's evidence to testify against him.

Samuel D. Dorn, who in 1948 founded the Dorn Manufacturing Company, manufacturer of lamps, and had been its president since then, died in Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday. He was 75 years old and lived at 1050 Fifth Avenue.

The beautiful agony of Chekhov's "The Three Sisters," with all its humors and sighs, arrived at the Billy Rose Theater last night at the opening of a Christmas repertory season by the City Center Acting Company.
When the Internal Revenue Service gives a taxpayer two years' grace to protest some action that it tales, it means precisely that--two years. Not an instant more.

A jury of seven men and five women was chosen in Federal Court yesterday to serve in the second trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton on bank-robbery charges. Almost 60 persons were excused as prospective jurors before the 12 were selected. The first trial ended last Friday in a hung jury.
A proposal by union militants to call an emergency congress of the labor movement to organize opposition to the Government was turned down today by the General Council of the Trades Union Congress.

When his Habitat, a modular, systems-built housing complex, was erected as part of Expo '67 in Montreal, Moshe Safdie was hailed as the architect who had found the answer to our urban housing problems.

Egypt will sell $200-million of long-term securities in the Eurobond market, most likely within the next six weeks, to raise the money to pay its share of the Suez-to-Alexandria oil pipeline on which work is scheduled to start next year.

Gerald A. Downs, Mayor of Cinaminson, was indicted by a Camden County grand jury on charges of assault and battery on a police officer and resisting arrest. The grand jury returned the indictment in connection with a Dec. 8, 1972, scuffle that Mr. Downs reportedly had with a state trooper, Richard Humphreys.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala. -- Planned obsolescence is as old as man. Nature built into us a few thin-walled shock absorbers and a finite number of matted cushions, useful, for a predictable period, against the mad sorties of fortune. And of all man's absorber warpers, the most damaging is a wife's fortieth birthday.

During a visit to friends a year ago, Frank Bara began to doodle with their electric jigsaw. The result? An ingenious, if elementary, jigsaw puzzle that, when assembled a half hour later, spelled "Mary", the first name of his hostess.

Nobody can say New York's racehorses aren't doing their part to conserve heating oil. Warmed by blankets, sunlamps and the equine equivalent of hot oatmeal, hundreds of thoroughbreds are digging in for a heatless winter at Belmont Park.

Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of the Bronx, said today that he had introduced legislation to allow mass-transit riders to deduct up to $800 a year in commuting expenses from their taxes.
New offerings in the corporate and tax-exempt bond markets were generally well received yesterday in otherwise rather lackluster trading activity.

Winston Hill, the Jets' offensive tackle, was the only player from the two New York teams named yesterday by league coaches to the conference all-star squads that will meet in the annual Pro Bowl game at Kansas City on Jan. 20.

Basketball is a strange sport. No matter what happens in the earliest stages of a game or the season, virtually all pf the excitement, intensity and suspense is jammed into the closing stages. Rallies and counter-rallies add to the turmoil of tumultuous, tempestuous finishes and give the dribble diversion its extra emotion appeal.

The energy crisis has spawned a new regional self-interest in the major oil and natural gas producing states where, for the first time since World War II, fuel for local industry, homes and farms is running short and getting expensive.

The Delaware River Port Authority voted today to increase commuter bridge tolls on the Benjamin Franklin and Walt Whitman Bridges to 40 cents and create a special 25-cent carpool rate. The new toll sched.

The axiom that it's the little things that count was amply illustrated by several of the smaller of the 192 individual contributions acknowledged yesterday by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
Texaco, Inc., the nation's third largest oil company, now estimates that investment for capital improvements and exploration will reach $1.6-billion in 1973 and next year will go to $1.8-billion.

Nassau Coliseum was the toughest place in pro basketball tonight to make a basket. Luckily for the New York Nets, it was a point tougher for their opponent, the Kentucky Colonels, who dropped an 83-82 verdict and fell into a virtual tie with the Nets, though they lead them by 16 percentage points for second place.

Susan Zwanger cannot hide the heredity. It radiates from her father, a doctor, and her mother, a lawyer.

Nine major electric utilities and the Pratt Whitney Aircraft division of the United Aircraft Corporation have embarked on a $42-million program to develop a large-scale fuel cell to generate electric power.

The new 25-story, $160-million Bellevue Hospital Center, which formally opened only a month ago and began treating out-patients, yesterday solicited bids for a $1-million "modernization" of portions of the building that have yet to be used.
Prices on the Americar Stock Exchange and the over the-counter market continued early in the day the rally started on Tuesday but fel back markedly later in the session to close lower.

A nationwide study of 29,000 blood donors by a team of Wis consin researchers has led to the conclusion that American are regularly exposed to th potential. dangers of excessive amounts of carbon monoxide.
President Nixon released today $1.1-billion in education and health money that he had been refusing to spend in a major dispute with Congress.over the level of funding.

The Department of Health, Education and Welfare is planning a new policy under which it will pay for drugs covered by Medicare and Medicaid only at the lowest price for which the drugs are generally available, Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today.

Clay T. Whitehead, director of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy from its inception in 1970, said yesterday that he would resign within two or three months and that he desired to leave Government service.

The Matshushita Electric Industrial Company, pointing in1 part to the oil crisis, disclosed in Japan yesterday that it would raise prices of color television sets by an average of 13 per cent and washing machines by an average of 20 per cent, both effective Jan. I.

Representative John Melcher, Montana Democrat who heads the House Subcommittee on Public Lands, apparently violated Federal regulations by leasing 40 acres of land from the Government, The Great Falls Tribune said yesterday.

The chairman of the State Public Service Commission, Joseph C. Swidler, was named yesterday by the State University of New York to head its new Institute of Policy Alternatives, a research arm that is expected to draw on the resources of the 72-campus university.
Johnny Majors, who turned the Pitt Panthers into a respectable and exciting football team this season after a 1-10 won-lost mark a year ago, reaped his reward yesterday.
The axiom that it's the little things that count was amply illustrated by several of the smaller of the 192 individual contributions acknowledged yesterday by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
Parkview-Gem, Inc., a discount department store chain, filed a petition yesterday in the United States District Court in Kansas City, under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

The Nixon Administration will announce tomorrow that it will ask service stations to limit gasoline sales to 10 gallons a customer per purchase. This was disclosed tonight by William E. Simon, President Nixon's chief energy adviser,

Judge John J. Sirica sided with President Nixon today and ruled that nearly all of two of the tapes sought in the Watergate case and part of a third were covered by executive privilege and thus would not be turned over to the special Watergate prosecution.
President Nixon released today $1.l-billion in education and health money that he had been refusing to spend in a major dispute with Congress over the level of funding.
The Nixon Administration set in motion today a general increase in oil and gasoline prices and proposed that Congress levy a novel "windfall profits" tax on oil producers.
A new blood test capable of diagnosing pregnancy even before a menstrual period has been missed was described here today.
The Board of Higher Education yesterday submitted a $628-million operating budget for 1974-75, an increase of $99.5-million over the current year.
Executive Airlines, once the biggest commuter airline in New England, was sold today to Air New England, its major competitor.

Governor ana Mrs. Wilson will give back to former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller "as soon as possible" the dozens of pieces of modern painting and sculpture from his collection with which he had turned the Executive Mansion virtually into a modern art museum during his administration.

A $225-million plan to develop the Hudson River waterfront in Yonkers along the lines of the terraced cities of the Italian Riviera was disclosed yesterday by the administration of the outgoing Mayor, Alfred B. Del Bello.

The Mayor-elect of Atlanta has discussed appointing Jule M. Sugarman, New York City's Human Resources Administrator, as Atlanta's chief administrative officer-a city-manager type of post scheduled to be strengthened next year.

Even though there was more than the filet mignon for a coach to drool over when the 1973 black college all-America team was announced yesterday, Charley Winner of the Jets could relax and concentrate on his food.
At least nine people were killed and 53 were injured when a commuter train crashed on the western outskirts of London tonight and four of the packed cars overturned.

Newell Jenkins, music director of Clarion Concerts, has a passion for resurrecting the works of secondary composers that results in a roulette game for the listener: Some turn out to be winners, others are losers. His program on Tuesday night in Tully Hall fortunately turned up a winner.

Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne today nominated William F. Hyland, a former chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, to be Attorney General in the Democratic administration taking office here next month.

The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled that the city must continue its controversial maximum-baserent program, which permits rent increases of up to 7.5 per cent a year in many rent- controlled apartments.

Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Education Commissioner, said yesterday that he favored a complete overhaul of election procedures for the community school boards here, including the establishment of an independent commission to handle the school elections.

Alexander Alekhine, world champion from his victory over Jose Raul Capablanca in 1927 until his defeat by Max Euwe in 1935 and again from his victorious rematch with Euwe in 1937 until his death in 1946, expressed his romantic approach not only by his extraordinarily dazzling speculative attacking play, but also by his novel theoretical pronouncements.

Syria is prepared to join the Geneva conference on a Middle East peace settlement whenever Israel shows that she is prepared to negotiate "in good faith on the fundamental issues," a high Syrian Foreign Ministry official said today.
The House voted today to consolidate all energy research and development programs under a single agency, the Energy Research and Development Administration.
Bob Lanier scored 30 points and the Detroit Pistons held off a second-half Chicago rally tonight in scoring an 89-87 National Basketball Association triumph over the Bulls.

Only six jurors-half the normal number-will hear a gambling case in United States District Court here this week. The reason? Most of the potential jurors called asked to be excused because they could not see anything wrong with gambling.
An administrative assistant to the State Controller has been indicted on charges of attempted bribery, conspiracy and grand larceny.

For Gough Whitlam, Australia's first Labor Prime Minister in twenty-three years, there can be no doubt about it: his Government, he is convinced, has been one of the most productive and constructive in Australian history. In closing the 1973 session of Parliament and his first year in office, Mr. Whitlam reported that the Government had passed 203 bills by keeping the House of Representatives sitting for 908 hours, a fifty-year record.

A nationwide study of 29,000 blood donors by a team of Wisconsin researchers has led to the conclusion that Americans are regularly exposed to the potential dangers of excessive amounts of carbon monoxide.
The Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration yesterday warned skaters not to skate on the city's ponds and lakes because the ice still was not thick enough.
The Kuwaiti Government said today that it had no plans "at the moment" to bring to trial the five Arab hijackers of the Lufthansa jetliner that landed here last night.

Charles G. Rebozo, President Nixon's friend, said in a television interview today that he had taken $100,000 from agents of Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire industrialist, because he "didn't want it to get mixed up or lost."

" Birds," the pet store owner was saying, "go chirp, chirp, chirp." She was trying to explain why buying a pet as a holiday gift poses an unusual problem. The gist of it was that an animal is not a cowboy suit, to be hidden until the appropriate time in a drawer in the master bedroom (you know, where junior never looks, except when he's being real sneaky).

Nearly 90 per cent of all Americans support the current restrictions on the use of energy favored by the Federal Government, and also four out of 10 people would like to see even stricter controls, according to the Gallup Poll.
A transcontinental management shift at R. H. Macy Co. confirmed yesterday problems with the New York operations of the giant retail concern.
Indiana's George McGinnis tallied 15 of hs gamehigh total of 31 points in the first quarter tonight and the Papers rode their lead to a 104 88 victory over the Utah Stars.

Puccini's youthful and ever-attractive "Manon Lescaut" returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night after an absence of some five years. This always has been one of the Metropolitan's nicer productions-modest yet evocative, tasteful and smoothly directed.

The "emergency windfall profits tax" on producers of crude oil proposed by President Nixon today is unlike any tax used before in the United States. The aim is to tax away some of the sheer "windfall" that oil producers may get because of the suddenness of the oil shortage and the resulting possible huge price increases without impairing incentives to explore and drill for more oil.
The dramatic improvement in the United States balance of payments continued in the third quarter, with the "basic" balance showing a surplus of $2.5billion, the Commerce Department reported today.
An authoritative Soviet journal has indicated that Moscow's proposal for a new strategic arms agreement with Washington calls for reductions in some parts of both countries' strategic arsenals.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., the 77-year-old legal scholar and raconteur who gained national prominence this year as chairman of the Senate Watergate investigating committee, announced today that he would not run for re-election next year.

The Committee for the Re-Election of the President has gone out of existence without public notice, but its finance committee, which hardled an estimated $60-million in campaign funds, was still in operation today.

A new method of ending an unwanted pregnancy, developed by a psychologist, promoted by women's groups and surrounded by intense medical controversy, is now being studied carefully by physicians throughout the world.
Xavier University officials announced tonight the school was dropping intercollegiate football because of the "spiraling costs."
Pope Paul VI expressed fears today that the murderous guerrilla attack on Rome's international airport this week might adversely affect the Middle East peace conference opening in Geneva on Friday.
The trial of John D. Ehrlichman and two other former White House aides in the breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel J. Ellsberg's psychiatrist was postponed today until April 15.

Industry spokesmen urged today that Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne "actively cooperate" in the development of a deep-water oil port off New Jersey and in the drilling for oil and gas in the Atlantic undersea shelf.

Mayor - elect Abraham D. Beame yesterday appointed a new Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, who said he would demand that any museum receiving money from the city make detailed financial reports.
The Nixon Administration set in motion today a general increase in oil and gasoline prices and proposed that Congress levy a novel "windfall profits" tax on oil producers.
An agreement was reached to end a wildcat warehouse strike that had touched off heavy grocery shopping in the Detroit area, the food industry negotiating team said today.
A sudden political thunderstorm has broken in France, with open demands from influential Gaullists for the removal of Premier Pierre Messmer.

One tall agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation darted out of a crowd and wordlessly yanked Eddie McNally, a 23-year-old Army deserter, into an awaiting Government car.
