Ranking ideological specialists from nine countries Communist parties today concluded a private meeting that signaled a more co-ordinated counterattack to Western pressures for freer human contacts and a freer flow of people and ideas as part of East-West accommodation.

NICKEL MOUNTAIN. By John Gardner. 312 pages. Illustrated by Thomas O'Donohue. Knopf. $6.95. So far, John Gardner's writing career has been like the progress of a meteorite. We spotted him first on the distant horizon, retelling Greek history in a somewhat remote novel called "The Wreckage of Agathon," published in 1970.
A House-Senate conference committee agreed today on legislation to restructure bankrupt railroads east of the Mississippi under a new Government rail corporation.
Abraham Krasne, who founded in 1915 the wholesale grocery business that is now Krasdale Foods, Inc., died yesterday at his home, 11 Sound Road in Rye, N. Y. He was 88 years old.
Shooting incidents erupted in the Lebanese city of Tripoli yesterday and today, leaving one soldier and one policeman dead and two civilians seriously wounded.
The Texas Railroad Commission continued today for January the 100 per cent oil producing rate with expectations that actual production would be in the range of 3,450,000 barrels a day.
The European Common Market, because of its many internal problems, has deferred serious consideration of an American proposal for international collaboration to resolve the energy crisis.
Joe Cronin, president of the American League, took under advisement today the dispute between the Oakland A's and New York over the Yankees' hiring of Manager Dick Williams.

The Nixon Administration will announce tomorrow that gasoline stations will be asked to limit sales to 10 gallons. The latest conservation move was disclosed tonight by William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, to Senate and House conferees just before they reached final agreement on a compromise emergency energy bill.

The late Jimmy Cannon observed in a Christmas column, reprinted by The Village Voice last week, that reporters work on holidays, and celebrate them when and if they can. He would not have found it incongruous that one newsman's family ate Christmas dinner--or rather the first of four Christmas dinners it will have eaten this yearon Dec. 7.

The Pentagon, which has reduced training flights to conserve jet fuel, said tonight that it might make further reductions in its fuel consumption "in order to divert some fuel to the airlines for the holiday period."

Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut and County Executive Ralph G. Caso of Nassau appealed yesterday to President Nixon for emergency action to help ease the impact of the ice storm that has spread hazard and hardship through the tristate region.
Michael J. Dontzin, counsel to Mayor Lindsay, will be appointed a Criminal Court judge by the Mayor, City Hall sources said yesterday. The judgeship has an annual salary of $30,750.

Valter Despalj, a 26-year-old Yugoslav cellist who has studied here (with Leonard Rose at Juilliard) and in Moscow (with Galina Kozolupova at the Mosnow Conservatory), made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night n the Carnegie Hall-Jeunesses Musicals series.
Cargill, Inc., announced yesterday it was offering to buy any and all of the outstanding common shares of the Missouri Portland Cement Company for a net $30 cash each.
Governor Wilson dealt with the issues of political probity today by calling for tighter election campaign controls and by disclosing several details of his income.
New York said farewell to its most popular bridge expert last week when Bill Root moved to Boca Raton, Fla.

Bill Campbell, an assistant football coach and an outstanding recruiter at Boston College for the last six years, is expected to be named head football coach at Columbia University today.. The 33year-old bachelor will return to his alma mater where he captained Columbia's only Ivy League champion football team in 1961.

Although most Arab terrorists responsible for hijackings, kidnapping and the seizure and execution of hostages over the last few years have been captured or have given themselves up, few have suffered meaningful punishment. Following, in chronological order, is the eventual fate-as best can be determined--of Arab terrorists who preceded those who, surrendered 'Tuesday in Kuwait.

The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled that the city must continue its controversial maximum-baserent program, which permits rent increases of up to 7.5 per cent a year in many rent- controlled apartments.
Shaheen Natural Resources, Inc., said today it planned to build a $225-million oil refinery and petrochemical complex at Bantry on the Atlantic in southwest Ireland.

Mayor Lindsay, in a speech yesterday reviewing his record in labor relations, said that it was important for the city to continue to build on the foundation he had established and to keep labor relations "out of the back room."

A giant incinerator disguised as a 60story skyscraper, the tallest building in Japan. A vast garbage dump turned into a children's playground. A swimming pool and a home for the aged heated by burning refuse.

With Judge "Maximum John" Sirica being talked about as the likely "Man of the Year" for 1973, with "law and order" no longer denounced as code words for repression or racism, and with widespread approval of the way society finally moved to protect itself against crime of all sorts, only a spoilsport would complain that the rights of the accused are being stolen away.

Two state police unions said today that they had urged Governor Cahill to order the expulsion of the State Police Superintendent, Col. David B. Kelly, from the pension fund.

Third-period goals by Errol Thompson and Ron Ellis paced the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 5-3 victory over the California Golden Seals tonight in a game celebrating the 57th anniversary of the National Hockey League.

The giant neon signs atop Jakarta's new skyscrapers that used to beam "Sanyo" and "Toyota" and other Japanese messages into the Indonesian night have recently fallen dark, and it has nothing to do with any energy crisis, for there is no such crisis in oil-rich Indonesia.
PACE CHANGERS Contrast is the watchword up at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle (5812311), where two exhibitions are in contrapuntal display.
Reports that the Administration would impose an excise tax on crude oil products eroded a stockmarket rally yesterday.

Judge John J. Sirica sided with President Nixon today and ruled that nearly all of two of the tapes sought in the Watergate case and part of a third were covered by executive privilege and thus would not be turned over to the special Watergate prosecution.
Despite a doctor's opinion that he is "critically ill," W. A. Boyle, the deposed former president of the United Mine Workers of America, was ordered to Federal prison today for a threeyear term.
The only known American prisoner of the Vietcong was freed at a remote hamlet in the Mekong Delta today, two and a half months after he was captured in a Communist ambush.

President Hafez al-Assad of Syria told Secretary of State Kissinger in Damascus on Saturday that he could inform Israel that all Israeli prisoners held by Syria were being "well-treated," a senior American official said today.

Attorney General Kingsley Cheney of Vermont said today he believed that any refusal by gasoline station operators to sell fuel to "out-of-staters" was illegal. He said he had learned of "isolated cases" where skiers from other states were denied gasoline. Cheney said Vermont's Consumer Protection Law and Federal regulations specify equitable distribution of all petroleum products.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has material in its files casting doubt on the legality of a key transaction in 1969 that made possible the takeover of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, according to informed sources.
G. Mennen Williams says he claimed a major tax deduction when he gave papers on his 12 years as Michigan Governor to a university: library.
Howard M. Metzenbaum, a 56year-old Cleveland lawyer and businessman, was named today by Gov. John J. Gilligan to succeed Attorney General-designate William B. Saxbe in the United States Senate.

The regional administrator of the Federal Energy Office said yesterday that if all owners of New York City apartment buildings kept temperatures at 68 degrees, no one would be without fuel during January.

The Government of Kuwait said it had no plans "at the moment" to try the five Arab terrorists who hijacked a jetliner from Rome to Kuwait in the guerrilla operation that left 31 dead in Rome and one in Athens.
Annemarie Proell won her 10th straight World Cup downhill ski race, took over the lead in the cup standings and was named Austrian athlete of the year today.

The net working capital of United States corporations rose $4.1-billion in the third quarter, the Securities and Exchange commission reported. Working capital jumped $6.5billion in the preceding previous quarter and $3.9-billion in the third quarter of 1972.

A Senate-House conference committee agreed today on a compromise foreign aid appropriations bill, whose funds would include $2.2-billion in emergency military aid for Israel and $200-million for Cambodia.
A British tourist has been charged by the Soviet authorities in a recent Leningrad Hotel fire hi which at least one person died, British officials said today.

Representative Peter W. Rodino, Democrat of New Jersey, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said today that he had selected a man with "a Republican background" as special counsel to head the panel's consideration of impeachment proceedings against President Nixon.

United by the fear that the energy crisis will jeopardize the very existence of the performing arts in this country, 85 representatives of dance and concert organizations, arts associations, managers and unions formed an emergency coalition yesterday to present their plight to the Federal Energy Office and to fight for their collective lives.

Prentiss M. Brown, a former United States Senator who was regarded as the father of the Mackinac Bridge connecting Michigan's two peninsulas, died today of a heart attack at his home here. He was 84 years old.

Hanukkah, the eight-day Jew ish festival of lights, began at sundown yesterday with ceremonies that in many cases drew a parallel between the current Middle East situation and the ancient event that the holiday commemorates.

A Federal jury found the General Motors Coporation and the Ford Motor Company today not guilty of criminal antitrust charges.

The Government of Kuwait said it had no plans "at the moment" to try the five Arab terrorists who hijacked a jetliner from Rome to Kuwait in the guerrilla operation that left 31 dead in Rome and one in Athens. Kuwait's Interior Minister said the attack was still being investigated and suggested that the hijackers might be turned over to the Palestine Liberation Organization if it asked for such a move. Just a bit after nine yesterday morning, Dick Lord arrived in the all but deserted offices of Lord, Geller, Federico, Peterson. He's the president there. He's also the creative director. His ensemble, all muted browns and beige, leaned toward the creative rather than the corporate.
Witnesses at a hearing on hard drugs today linked organized crime to lucrative heroin and cocaine traffic in northern New Jersey and New York City.

United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern, who gained a reputation by prosecuting corrupt public officials, was confirmed today by the Senate as a Federal judge.

Norman A. Levy, former president of the City Tax Commission, ran a night court for political favorites in an apartment in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn to get their parking tickets fixed, an anticorruption state prosecutor charged yesterday.

Ed Mather is his name and cross-country is his game as rivals of Bernards High School have learned over the past 10 years. In that time the 43-year-old coach, a graduate of St. Joseph's College, has guided his team to six state titles, placed second three times (including the recently ended season) and was third the other time. He predicts the 1974 team will be his best.

Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of the Bronx, said today that he had introduced legislation to allow mass-transit riders to deduct up to $800. a year in commuting expenses from their taxes.
Two young drifters who are charged with killing nine persons in the small community of Victor, Calif., were manacled and brought into court yesterday but delayed entering pleas.

To the Editor: On the same day, in a recent Philadelphia paper, were the following headlines: "Dow-Jones in Greatest Decline Since 1972" and "Earnings of Publishing Firm Enjoy Sharp Increase." The stock market decline that day was attributed to "herd instinct," which implies a psychological or mood reaction to current negative news.

Nearly 2,300 Thais voted today to elect 299 of their number to a new national assembly. It appeared likely that the vote would give farmers, students and village officials more weight in national politics.

The State Supreme Court today reinstated $750,000 bail for a member of the Campisi family who has been indicted, along with seven relatives, on charges of committing five murders and more than 100 armed robberies.
A House-Senate conference corn mittee agreed today on legislation to restructure bankrupt railroads east of the Mississippi under a new Government rail corporation.
For a short time when he was a student at Stanford University in the late nineteen-thirties, Walter John Stoessel Jr. played polo and rode in what he termed "the last cavalry R.O.T.C. unit."
Francis A. Cox resigned yesterday as vice president and chief financial officer of The New York Times Company.

Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame was presented yesterday with the Maccabean Service Award, a plaque given annually by the New York Board of Rabbis to "public servants who have manifested outstanding public service."

The Senate completed Congressional action today on legislation to create a Federal financing bank to coordinate all direct Government borrowing in the private markets and sent the bill to Preisdent Nixon for his signature.

The Irish Republic's ban on importing contraceptives was held unconstitutional today by the Supreme Court, the highest of Irish courts. The laws against contraceptives were passed by Parliament nearly 40 years ago.

An expanded schedule of meets, increased funds and new blood, including Steve Smith, the pole vaulter, are signs of growth for the International Track Association,. which begins its second pro season on Feb. 15 at Nassau Coliseum.
The first liquidation payments on four main mutual funds of the Investors Overseas Services group could be within six months, Albert Dondelinger, Luxembourg's banking commissioner, said today.

Dan Wilson told the judge he could study a lot better in prison than out so he wanted a five-year instead of a three-year term In order to complete work on his degree.

Judge William Sherman Greene Jr., general counsel for United World Films in New York from 1945 to 1965, died Monday at the Boston University Medical Center. His age was 72 and he lived at Deer Isle, Me.

Several leading steel companies appealed to the Cost of Living Council today for an end to price controls in their industry. The council is holding hearings on the requests of 32 steel makers for price increases.

William E. Simon, the Federal energy director, called on the New Jersey Conference of Mayors to spearhead a nationwide effort by chief executives of municipalities to spur public cooperation in meeting the energy crisis.

Johnny Majors, who turned the Pitt Panthers into a respectable and exciting football team this season after a 1-10 won-lost mark a year ago, reaped his reward yesterday. He was named coach of the year by the Football Writers Association of America.

The Mayor-elect of Atlanta has discussed appointing Jule M. Sugarman, New York City's Human Resources Administrator, as Atlanta's chief administrative officer-a city-manager type of post scheduled to be strengthened next year.

The financial information released by President Nixon has raised one especially puzzling question among tax specialists. It relates to his $576,000 "gift" of papers, allegedly made in March, 1969, and used thereafter as the basis for large tax deductions.
The much-delayed Middle East peace conference finally began to take shape here today with the arrival of the Egyptian and Soviet Foreign Ministers.
Mickey Cochran, head coach for the United States Ski Association's Alpine team, confirmed today he would resign the post following the 1974 InternationalSki Federation championships.
Soviet authorities have turned to shock tactics to curb the rising tide of interest in mod fashions, especially among Soviet young people.

American Airlines and Trans World Airlines showed improved results in November, according to their reports yesterday. At the same time, Eastern Air Lines plunged further into the red and National Airlines, which operates on a fiscal-year basis, showed slightly lower earnings for November.

A five-alarm fire engulfed the 76-year-old Church of St. Joachim and St. Anne in a childcare compound on southern Staten Island early yesterday destroying all but the granite and brick walls and 150-foot steeple.

Coach Red Holzman was platooning his Knicks like a crazed football coach tonight, but all his line-up changes were not enough to overcome a damaging personal-foul situation that. allowed the Atlanta Hawks to post a 107-105 victory before a crowd of 7,308 at the Omni.

Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut and County Executive Ralph G. Caso of Nassau appealed yesterday to President Nixon for emergency action to help ease the impact of the ice storm that has spread hazard and hardship through the tristate region.

Of the four teams in this weekend's American Conference playoffs, the Oakland Raiders are the most familiar with post-season play, the Miami Dolphins have been the most dominant and the Pittsburgh Steelers became the most exciting with their miracle finish last season. Then there are the Cincinnati Bengals.
The Soviet Union issued tonight a delayed announcement that its manned Soyuz 13 spacecraft had shifted into a new, more circular orbit, similar to that used in the past for linking up

The Senate sent to president Nixon tonight a $375-million bill designed to encourage group health plans. The vote was 83 to 1, with Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, casting the only negative vote.
Spinoni Italiani is neither an ice cream nor a vintage wine. It's a big, squarely built long ears. If a rare breed in the United States means one or two, this is it.
Bad weather in the Middle West and the imminence of a Government report or hogs, due after the close of trading Friday, had an impact on both hog and cattle futures prices yesterday.
David Selden, president of the American Federation of Teachers, refused today to bow to a demand by the union's executive council that he resign.

Discussions on EastWest trade cooperation have become more and more academic, as many U.S. corporations and banks have already made decisive moves toward expanding ties, and the yearly trade turnover between the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. has almost doubled every year in the last three years, bringing it to over $1.5 billion for 1973.

The recording on paper of dance and other highly nuanced body movements has been facilitated by a small, ball-shaped typing element, which, when attached to an electric typewriter, permits the printing of Labanotation symbols, a widely used method of lance notation.

Melvin R. Laird resigned today as President Nixon's chief domestic adviser and said that he believed the House of Representatives should vote no later than March 15 on the question of impeaching the President.

With Congress pushing to adjourn by this weekend, the chairmen of the fiscal committees of the Senate and the House of Representatives agreed today to try to salvage an 11 per cent increase in Social Security benefits for 29 million retired Americans.
The Senate today confirmed the nomination of Walter J. Stoessel Jr. to be United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

A Federal judge agreed today to restrict the public disclosure of documents in a suit against the Nixon Administration for alleged favors to the milk industry after a lawyer for Ralph Nader acknowledged that he had played a subpoenaed White House tape recording at a cocktail party.

Vice President Gerald Ford has conducted himself since his nomination and confirmation with dignity and amiable good sense, but he is not being given the sort of assignments that would prepare him for the Presidency.
President Nixon said today that he would nominate G. McMurtrie Godley, former Ambassador to Laos, to be the United States Ambassador to Lebanon.

A man accused as an underworld "hit" man was shot to death today in a hallway of the apartment building where he lived in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. The victim was identified as Ralph Gallione, 37 years old.

Secretary of' State Kissinger and North Vietnam's chief negotiator, Le Duc Tho, met for four and a half hours today and exchanged complaints about the ineffective Vietnam cease-fire. They also agreed to keep in touch for possible future meetings.

A Kuwaiti official said today that his Government was considering allowing the Palestine Liberation Organization to try the five Arab hijackers who killed 32 people this week at the Rome and Athens airports.

There were spectacular increases in ridership on the subway system, city buses and the Long Island Rail Road during last Sunday's two-rides-for-theprice-of-one experiment, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority reported yesterday.
The State Commission of Investigation said today that it had found "an urgent need" for improved law enforcement tools if traffic in hard drugs in the state were to be curtailed significantly.
Sandy Hawley, the holder of the world race-winning record, ran his total number of victories for 1973 to 507 today when he brought home two winners at Laurel Race Course.
American Airlines and Pan American World Airways announced agreement yesterday, subject to Government approval, on the most far-reaching exchange of routes ever proposed.

Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis will submit to its stockholders on Jan. 14 a plan to restructure its organization through the formation of a holding company, to be known as Paine Webber, Inc., the firm announced yesterday.
In a turbulent special session of Parliament, Premier Golda Meir today explained and defended Israel's decision to participate in the Geneva peace conference opening tomorrow.

The General Motors Corporation announced today the recall of 843,000 of its automobiles and trucks of the 1974 model year because a key part of the suspension could work loose and cause tires to squeal and the steering to pull to the right or left.

ABBY-Milton D. Beloved husband of Adrienne. Devoted brother of Pearl Tayer, Lillian Rosenbloom, Hanlet Edwards, Florence Lipton, Charlotte Paget, Albert, Walter and Buddy Abby. Services today, 1:45 P.M. "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the expatriate Cambodian leader, contends that the insurgent movement in Cambodia has "affirmed to me energetically its confidence, its affection even, and insisted that I remain the uncontested leader of antiimperialist Cambodia."

Premier Luis Carrero Blanco of Spain, who had been governing in the name of Spain's aging chief of state, Francisco Franco, was assassinated in a violent explosion that lifted the Premier's car five stories into the air as he was being driven from a Madrid church.
John D. Baker, who was named general manager of General Motor's Oldsmobile division on Nov. 5, died yesterday at the Methodist Hospital. He was 56 years old.

A long-time observer of hockey in Madison Square Garden said yesterday, "One team [Groton] played on guts, the other [St. Paul's] on talent." Talent, coupled with experience and a game-long aggressiveness, won out, 6-5.
John Cappelletti and O. J. Simpson, this year's premier running backs in the college and professional ranks, were named today as recipients of the Maxwell Football Club's Players-ofthe-Year Awards.

A Senate-House conference committee has agreed on an $800-million mass-transit bill that would give New York State $76-million less in Federal operating subsidies than it would have received under the House version.

The British Oxygen Corporation has almost won its battle for control of Airco, Inc. The Curtiss-Wright Corporation, British Oxygen's rival in the pursuit, reached an understanding yesterday to turn over its Airco shares to B.O.C.
American Airlines and Pan American World Airways announced agreement yesterday, subject to Government approval, on the most far-reaching exchange of routes ever proposed.
United States airline pilots decided today not to strike over Christmas after receiving Nixon Administration assurances that increased supplies of aviation fuel were forthcoming.

E. J. (Ted) Crosby, brother..of Bing Crosby, died in a Spokane hospital yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 73 years old. Mr. Crosby worked for a time for The Spokane Daily Chronicle and the Washington Water Power Company.

The Cathedral School, a private, elementary school that has admitted boys only since its founding in 1901, will become co-educational next September, according to Bishop Paul Moore, the school's board chairman.

Two members of the militant Jewish Defense League were arrested yesterday as they demonstrated at the Egyptian Mission to the United Nations at 36 East 67th Street, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

A Tocal issue in the negotiations on Middle East peace will be Resolution 242, adopted by the United Nations Security Council on Nov. 22, 1967, after the six-day war that June. Following is the text of that resolution.

Tile Federal Reserve added a massive $3.7-billion of securities to its holdings of Government securities during the week ended Wednesday, an action that injects reserves into the banking system and makes it easier for banks to lend money.

Israel and the Arab states today begin the task of negotiation, of finding a way together to terminate the hostility of a generation past. Not for a quarter of a century--the entire history of modern Israel's existence--have the belligerents of the Middle East entered upon a solemn and direct encounter such as is now about to open in Geneva.

Is it possible that Manhattan's falering postal service would be improved by a Christmas present from he Postal Corporation to itself? It would arrive long after Christmas, of ourse, but we're- all used to that. The present would simply be a change of cene for Post Office personnel, and might work wonders-it did once before.

" With great reluctance," Governor Cahill of New Jersey signed a controversial measure yesterday allowing the State Banking Department to raise the existing 8 per cent ceiling on conventional home-mortgage loans. The new rate, to be announced today, is expected to be near 9 per cent.
City-based Government officials dominated the returns today in the election of the new National Assembly, sinking the hopes of rural delegates for a strong voice.
Mayor- elect Abraham D. Beame yesterday named as his press secretary Sidrey J. Frigand, public-affairs director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

The Northrop Corporation said in Los Angeles yesterday that. it had filed suit against the Canadian Government for more than $17.5-million in damages and payments in connection with the CF-5 aircraft built in Canada under license from Northrop.

A man suspected of running a $1.35-million-a-year policy scheme was. kidnapped outside his Brooklyn home yesterday morning, driven in his own car to 'a deserted street and robbed and shot four times by two gunmen.

Adm. Luis Carrero Blanco, the Premier of Spain, who died yesterday in an explosion that shattered his car, had stood for years in the shadow of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, firmly attentive and unfailingly devoted.

A great eve-of-winter storm battered the eastern Midwest yesterday with record snows and marooned thousands of travelers, all but paralyzing many cities and hamlets between the Ohio Valley and the Great Lakes. At least 21 deaths were attributed to the storm.

Stocky man of 51 years with fondness for cigars and habit of neat attire...In diplomatic service since 1946 and known as skilled negotiator...Protege of Dr. Mahmoud Fawzi, longtime Foreign Minister, now Vice President...Studied law and

Gen. Raffaele Cadorna, who commanded Italian volunteer troops fighting at the side of the Allied forces during the last stage of World War II, died today of a heart attack at his home in Pallanza in northwestern Italy.

President Hugo Banzer Suarez announced today that he would hold elections and restore constitutional civilian government in Bolivia on Aug. 6, 1975, when the nation celebrates the 150th anniversary of her independence.
President Nixon's close friend, C. G. Rebozo, arrived in a driving rainstorm this afternoon to answer questions about political donations to the President's 1972 campaign.

Heavy accumulation of ice have caused extensive damage to trees throughout New Jersey, particularly in the shore and southern regions, where the losses are apparently running into the millions of dollars.

Charles O. Finley, elated over the "good news," said yesterday he was "proud of Joe Cronin" for ruling that Dick Williams still belongs to Oakland. He also said he was no longer sure whether he would accept any compensation from the Yankees for his manager.
John J. Kenny, a former Hudson County Freeholder and Democratic leader, was acquitted along with two codefendants today of conspiracy to use county park land for a private garbage dump.
" Neither snow, nor rain, nor heat, nor gloom of night stays these couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds"--except if they run out of gas.
Robert F. Carroll, deputy administrator of the city's Human Resources Administration, was appointed yesterday a vice president of the City College of New York.

The countries involved in the Middle East conflict have tended, publicly at least, to state their demands in the most sweeping terms. Their real positions are known to be somewhat more flexible. Following are the basic negotiating stances as described by correspondents of The New York Times, of the three main participants in the Geneva conference and of Syria, which has thus far refused to send a delegation to Geneva.

Premier Souvanna Phouma said today that the current meeting between Secretary of State Kissinger and Le Duc Tho of North Vietnam could lead to the imminent formation of a coalition government in Laos by the Royal Laotian Government and the Communist-led Pathet Lao.

To the Editor: Your Nov. 30 editorial "Energy Revolution" is most timely. We have become a nation of energy hogs because energy has always been cheap and unlimited, and the construction industry has contributed more than its share to energy waste.

Miss Coral Beverly Vange, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Vange of Seoul, South Korea, was married here this afternoon to William Worthington Scranton 3d, son of William Worthington Scranton, former Governor of Pennsylvania, and Mrs. Scranton of Dalton.

AN AMERICAN VERDICT. By Michael J. Arlen. 196 pages. Doubleday. $6.95. Does anyone remember the Black Panthers now? Yes, there was Huey P. Newton (last heard from rapping with Erik H. Erickson in "In Search of Common Ground") and Eldridge Cleaver (Algiers?) and Stokely Carmichael (Guinea?) and, of course, Bobby Seale (aspiring politician). But now?
Israel and the Arabs open a conference here tomorrow designed to bring peace to the Middle East after four wars and 25 years of hostility.

In what is considered a test case on the right of broadcasters to engage in investigative journalism, the National Broadcasting Company has gone to court to appeal a decision of the Federal Communications Commission that a documentary expose on private pension plans last fall was in violation of the F.C.C.'s fairness doctrine.

W. A. Boyle, the 72-year-old former president of the United Mine Workers, suffered a mild fainting spell today, delaying his departure from a Washington hospital to begin a threeyear Federal prison sentence for embezzling union funds.

At first glance, the energy crisis looks like an ecological disaster. It is not uncommon these days to hear hard-nosed, practical men of business say knowingly, as it vindicated, that now the ecologists will have to show a little common sense.
Former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally and two partners want the state to build a road to Lake Amistad that would open their ranch for real estate development.

Eli Goldston, who once identified himself as a "knsher dill pickle at. a Yankee pot roast," has been named chairman and chief executive officer of one of the nation's most prestigious research and consulting concerns, Arthur D. Little, Inc., effective May 1, 1974.
A team of 20 Chinese Nationalist pilots, recruited recently by the Cambodian Air Force, began active service this week, according to informed sources here.
The reaction of the crowd, such as it was, at Yonkers Raceway tonight was one of almost complete indifference. to the indictments.
One of the world's leading enthusiasts for toy trains is the designer Charles Eames of Venice, Calif.
Premier Luis Carrero Blanco, who was governing Spain in the name of the aging chief of state, Francisco Franco, was assassinated this morning.

The director of the Cost of Living Council, John T. Dunlop, held out today the possibility that price controls might be reimposed on the fertilizer industry. In an interview, Mr. Dunlop noted that each time the
The New York Rangers combined 45 shots on goal, a dozen or so crunching body checks and "fundamental" hockey last night to overpower the Detroit Red Wings, 5-2, at Madison Square Garden.
A Brooklyn police officer was found not guilty yesterday of selling marijuana to a fellow policeman. The jury in State Supreme Caurt in Manhattan deliberated only an hour.

" Most of these drivers are earning more than $100,000 a year," said George Morton Levy yesterday in the president's office at Roosevelt Raceway. "Is it possible they'd fix races for a few thousand dollars? The probabilities weigh so heavily against it."
Israel and the Arabs open a conference here tomorrow designed to bring peace to the Middle East after four wars and 25 years of hostility.
Adrian Dantley, a freshman, scored 21 points tonight in pacing Notre Dame to an easy 99-59 victory over Denver University, the Irish used reserves for the last 11 minutes of the basketball game.

The city's tax collector, Frederic S. Rice, was formally accused yesterday of filing "false and fraudulent" state income-tax returns that understated by more than $20,000 his true income for 1970 and 1971.

The quality of medical care given Medicare and Medicaid patients would be monitored by professional groups in 182 geographical areas covering the entire United States under a proposal published today by the.Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

Two Columbia College students, both varsity wrestlers and fraternity officers, have been indicted for the sale of cocaine. If convicted, they could be the first campus drug dealers to be sentenced to life imprisonment under the state's new narcotics laws.

Senator Phillip A. hart, Democrat of Michigan, told the State and Justice Departments today that his antitrust subcommittee would investigate negotiations between major United States oil companies and oil-producing countries.
Hanni Wenzel, a 19-year-old German skiing for Liechtenstein, won her first World Cup ski race today, the giant slalom.

The nation's energy crisis is putting a crimp in Broadway theater lighting, but not enough to dim the Great White Way drastically. At 16 Shubert theaters here, at the Music Box and at least one Off Broadway house, marquee lights have been reduced by about 25 per cent.

Joseph Rosentover, who helped to form and served as Commissioner of the original American Football Association, the nation's oldest professional football minor league, diedyesterday at Passaic General Hospital. His age was 70.
Ever since the Mesopotamians argued the merits of one skin-covered chariot over another, some three thousand years B.C., the horse-andwagon sport probably has courted some degree of suspicion.

A controversial measure that will enable the state to raise its ceiling on interest rates on conventional home-mortgage loans in New Jersey was signed "with great reluctance" today by Governor Cahill.
The Boston Bruins, held scoreless for half the game by Jim Rutherford, the Penguin goalie, broke loose for four goals within four minutes in the second period and beat Pittsburgh, 6-5, tonight.
Tonight, from 10 to 11, the subject and thesis of the American Broadcasting Company's news "Close - Up" series is "Food: Green Grow the Profits."
The Whitney Museum of American Art has a generally good roundup of 14 short film subjects titled "Animation," a new program opening yesterday for two weeks.

The pretax book profits of United States corporations held virtually unchanged in the third quarter at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $129billion, according to revised estimates published today by the Commerce Department.
The bluegrass was high as an elephant's eye at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening, when four top bluegrass groups got together to pick and sing what was called a "Strictly Bluegrass X-Mas."

John M. Doar, after being selected to direct a Congressional inquiry into the possible impeachment of President Nixon, pledged today to see that "justiced is done, that the Constitution is preserved and fairness occurs.''
Eleven members of what was described as one of the city's largest heroin operations were arrested in predawn raids in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday.

Bill Raftery's cigar was annoying, but his smile, jokes and encouraging words about his Seton Hall basketball team were refreshing. Naturally he was happy with Chris Rzonca's selection by the New Jersey college basketball writers as the university player of the week, but more than that he was happy with the victory over San Francisco.

President Nixon's accountant said today that a ruling by the Treasury Department on the treatment of Mr. Nixon's annual $50,000 expense account had the apparently unintended effect of saving the President taxes during his first four years in office.

Duane Thomas, a Washington Redskin running back, has been sued for $12,264 by the San Diego Chargers, who charged that the controversial star borrowed that amount from them between Oct. 27, 1972, and July 25,

Joe Cronin, the president of the American League, made two rulings yesterday that left the New York Yankees without a manager for 1974 and, in effect, increased pressure on them to pay whatever Charles O. Finley of the Oakland A's required to release Dick Williams.

The Associated Press moved today to block a tariff revision sought by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The news service said that the proposal would discriminate against the press and would significantly impair the widespread dissemination of news.

Work and utility crews labored for a fourth day yesterday to restore full electrical power and clear the remaining debris-clogged roads in areas of the tristate region crippled by Sunday night's storm.
A bomb exploded and wounded three persons in downtown Beirut today, the police said. The blast was the second in 12 hours as antiGovernment riots took place in Lebanon's main cities.

ST. LOUIS-An old story of this region tells of a boy who took a shortcut across a graveyard one dark night and fell into a freshly dug grave. He shouted for help and struggled for hours trying to climb out, to no avail. Finally he shrank into a corner to wait for daylight.
Three of the nation's four top money-winning harness drivers were among 28 persons indicted by Federal authorities yesterday on charges of fixing superfecta races at Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways.

A fire that officials termed suspicious destroyed two floors of a three-story firehouse on West 161st Street in Washington Heights last night while the firemen normally stationed there were responding to an alarm a block away.
The New York State weekly lottery drawing scheduled for yesterday was postponed until today because of the beginning of the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah, a lottery spokesman said.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday formally endorsed the Financial Accounting Standards Board as the organization in the private sector of the economy that will set accounting principles and standards to be followed in writing corporate reports.

The Exxon Corporation announced yesterday a record $6.1-billion capital budget for the company and its affiliates for 1974. The total represents a 73 per cent increase over the 1973 capital budget of about $3.5-billion, the company's previous record.

Wheat futures prices declined a little in dull trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Traders apparently wanted to even out their positions before the holiday weekend and they were wary about the crop report due after the close of trading today.
Columbia University gave Bill Campbell a three-year contract and a one-month extension on this winter's application date for athletes yesterday when it signed him as head football coach.
There were only half as many accidents on the New Jersey Turnpike in November. when slower speed restrictions went into effect, as in October.

Bobby Darin, whose combination of brashness, good looks and talent made him one of the nation's leading singers of popular songs, died today at the age of 37, the victim of heart ailments that had shadowed much of his life.
A long-time observer of hockey in Madison Square Garden said yesterday, "One team [Groton] played on guts, the other [St. Paul's] on talent."

Joanne D. Chesimard. the suspected Black Liberation Army member who was ousted several times for courtroom outbursts during her first trial for bank robbery, was ousted again yesterday for her outbursts.
-Political parties and canaldates will have to start paying income tax on money they make from contributions, but not on the contributions themselves, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

Frederick L. Ehrman, former chairman of the board of Lehman Brothers, Inc., died of a heart attack in his sleep early yesterday at his home, 480 Park Avenue. He was 67 years old and also lived in Armonk, N. Y.

Some of yesterday's contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund were good things that could not be hurried. One of them took three months in the making, and another represented the fruits of eight weeks' labor.
Vice President Ford defended today his plan to use an Air Force jet to take him and his family to Colorado for Christmas, a trip that the Air Force estimates will use 22,000 gallons of jet fuel.

In its package of moves to deal with the oil shortage, the Administration is loading enormous burdens on consumers, seeking to abandon the idea of an equitable rationing system, and providing huge profits to the oil companies. In presenting a program of such design,

Below are menus suggested for a Hanukkah meal and the traditional French midnight supper served on Christmas Eve after mass. The Christmas pie, incidentally, is French-Canadian. Those dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
A city inspector who was sent yesterday to check on compliance by city agencies with Mayor Lindsay's energysaving directives found the resuits spotty.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange slipped yesterday to their lowest level for this year. However, prices in over-thecounter trading advanced slightly.

A calm-looking man walked into the restaurant on the top floor of the Gulf Western Building before it opened yesterday morning, asked the manager for a drink and then, for no apparent reason, began firing shots at the bar and at a large picture window overlooking Central Park.
Governor Wilson yesterday named L. Richard Guylay, a public relations specialist for the Eisenhower, Goldwater and early Nixon campaigns, as his special assistant for policy planning.

Equipped with novel cushioning devices to enable the ship to drill smoothly into the bottom while afloat on the heaving sea, the ship Glomar Challenger is to sail from Tahiti today on a voyage beginning a new phase of deep-sea exploration.
Judge Jacob T. Zukerman of the Family Court, a prominent figure in Jewish labor union circles, died Wednesday at his home, 815 Avenue J, Brooklyn. He was 66 years old.

The International Herald Tribune is planning to divide printing between England and France, rather than continue printing solely in Paris. The purpose is to improve the newspaper's circulation pattern,
The scheduled American Basketball Association game between San Antonio and the Virginia Squires was postponed tonight because none of the Spurs' equipment arrived.
William E. Simon, the Federal energy chief, asked American motorists today to practice doit-yourself gasoline rationing so the mandatory variety will not be necessary.
Congress passed major defense and foreign aid appropriations bills and a compromise manpower bill today as it struggled to adjourn tomorrow.
On 40th Street the other day, a man who was on his way to work was stopped by a bulky man, who called out, "Say, you went to Hotchkiss, didn't you?" In fact, the man had gone to Andover,

CANDIDE, a musical. Book adapted from Voltaire by Hugh Wheeler; music by Leonard Bernstein; lyrics by Richard Wilbur; additional lyrics by Stephen Sondheim and John Latouche; setting by Eugene and Franne Lee; musical director, John Mauceri; orchestrations by Hershy Kay;...
In their third day in space, the crew of the Soviet spacecraft Soyuz 13 reaped today the harvest of the first nutritive protein mass ever grown in space, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

ESSEX, Conn.-Unless drastic steps are taken soon the present chaos of the petroleum industry will bring our economy to a halt and will ultimately erode the economic basis of our society. The following actions by the U.S. Government are, I believe, essential:
Columbia University gave Bill Campbell a three-year contract and a one-month extension on this winter's application date for athletes yesterday when it signed him as head football coach.

The Court of Cassation, Italy's highest tribunal in all cases not involving constitutional questions, today annulled a sentence by a lower court that had found Bernardo Bertolucci's film "Last Tango in Paris" obscene.
It was 19 degrees outside the other day, and the shoppers who trudged through the slush in front of Macy's looked frozen and grim. But Diane Chesney was smiling. She smiles a lot this time of year.
In an unexpected turnabout, City Council committee yesterday rejected in closed session controversial bill to ban discrimination against homosexuals in housing, employment and public accommodations.

The power of television, and perhaps the indirect influence of the Watergate scandals, have helped to make "Alistair Cooke's America" the No. 1 non-fiction best-seller, a number of book industry executives have concluded.

" I know I'm batting my head against a brick wall trying to beat those trotters," said a baker who lives in Brooklyn. "So what? If you're a gambler, you've got to take chances even if the wheel is crooked."

Britain should withdraw from international sports competitions where opponents persist in drug taking. That was one of the suggestions made by the British Association of National Coaches after a conference in which the whole question of doping in sports was discussed by 40 coaches, representing a variety of British sports.

The Board of Estimate, seeking to wind up a number of matters before the Christmas holidays, voted yesterday to give final approval to a special zoning plan intended to preserve the scale and character of Madison Avenue between 61st and 96th Streets.

On the day that John Mack Carter, chairman, submitted his resignation to the board of Downe Communications, Albert S. Traina, president and chief operating officer, did the same with the board of Bartell Media, of which Downe holds 40 per cent of the stock.

Christmas in the record world simply isn't what it used to be. Time was when the disk companies, the music publishers, the singers and the song writers all got together and produced the Christmas records that would be smash sellers during the six- or seven-week preholiday period.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.
Corporate bond prices declined yesterday, reflecting what several dealers suggested were year-end portfolio adjustments by institutional investors.

Two city officials charged with scheming to fix 2,000 parking tickets for friends and political cronies were convicted last night on htree charges by a jury of 11 men and one woman in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

The Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation, an independent producer of data-processing peripheral equipment which has had deficit operations for the last year, went further into the red, according to its company report issued yesterday for the six months ended Oct. 31.

New guidelines for children's masses, issued by the Vatican today, establish that the central rite of the Roman Catholic faith may be shortened and enlivened with special songs, gesturing and pictures when celebrated for congregations made up mainly of preadolescents.

Bud Goode, the noted sports computer analyst from Los Angeles who picked all seven of the National Football League's playoff games correctly last season including the point margin in the Super Bowl game, got his head together yesterday and made his decisions for this year.
The City Council voted yesterday, 33 to 3, to raise the pay of the eight members of the Board of Estimate by $10,000 each.
The five-month sit-in of Mrs. Barbara Mandel, the estranged wife of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland, came to an end yesterday at the Governor's Mansion in Annapolis.

The city was swamped with tenant complaints about in adequate heat during the last week as many apartment buildings ran out of fuel and others curtailed heating periods to conserve existing oil reserves.

New out- t breaks of heavy shooting erupted last night along the EgyptianIsraeli front, endangering Finnish troops of the United Nations Emergency Force. The fighting brought an angry protest to both Egypt and Israel today from the United Nations commander, Lieut. Gen. Ensio Siilasvuo.
Premier Luis Carrero Blanco, who was governing Spain in the name of the aging chief of state, Francisco Franco, was assassinated this morning.

In an unexpected turnabout, a City Council committee yesterday rejected in closed session a controversial bill to ban discrimination against homosexuals in housing, employment and public accommodations.

CARNIVAL Carnival time is a riotous interlude in springtime Brazil, but the spirit of noisy musical abandon is warming things up currently at the wintertime Top of the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (GR 5-5120).

Operators of ski areas throughout the Northeast received two new rebuffs yesterday. One was that William E. Simon, the nation's new energy chief, had asked Americans to reduce gasoline consumption to 10 gallons a week.

A planned offering by Burlington Northern, Inc., of $60million of consolidated mortgage bonds, due 1999, now is scheduled for marketing next month, according to a preliminary offering circular issued yesterday by the underwriters for the issue, led by Morgan Stanley Co.

More than 30 per cent of families receiving cash assistance under the program providing aid to families with dependent children were ineligible or overpaid, according to a study made public today by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

A Senate-House conference committee has, agreed on an $800-million mass-transit bill that would give New York State $76-million less in Federal operating subsidies than it would have received under the House version.

The Hughes Tool Company announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Byron Jackson, Inc., a producer of specialized tools for oil-drilling rigs that also provides oil-well cementing and well-stimulation services.

Three of the nation's four top money-winning harness drivers were among 28 persons indicted by Federal authorities yesterday on charges of fixing superfecta races at Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways.

Two Columbia College students, both varsity wrestlers and fraternity officers, have been indicted for the sale of cocaine. If convicted, they could be the first campus drug dealers to be sentenced to life imprisonment under the state's new narcotics laws.

In a goodwill gesture for Christmas, the British today freed 65 of the 662 persons detained without trial near Belfast. Some had been held as long as two and a half years.

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, made a new appeal today for nations to accept refugees from Chile.

Robert L. Cizek, an insurance executive who specialized in aviation, died yesterday at his home here. He was 71 years old. The Soviet Union today pledged to fulfill commitments to deliver oil and natural gas to Western countries but ruled out production increases to compensate For the fuel crisis.

The resignation of Archbishop Ieronymos of Greece has been unanimously accepted by the Greek Orthodox Church's ruling Holy Synod, a church spokesman said today.
The biggest score ever recorded in a national championship was 78 per cent, by Eric Murray of Toronto and the late Agnes Gordon of Buffalo, in 1963.
Short interest increased to.. 17,621,538 shares at the close of business on the settlement date of Dec. 14, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday.
The Department of Labor, citing the failure of two voluntary programs, announced today that it had "imposed" on the Chicago area's construction industry a plan to increase minority employment.

Top executives of the American coal industry said today that their mines could produce 50 million more tons of fuel for electric-generating plants during 1974 than was earlier estimated, freeing for other uses millions of barrels of oil now burned by the electric utilities.
Representative William V Alexander Jr., Democrat of Arkansas, was arrested at National Airport. today on charges of assault after what he described as a run-in with an officer directing traffic.

To many Jewish parents, it's "the December dilemma"-the question of what to do about Christmas in a land that reveres the holiday not only at the altar, but in the marketplace, the office, the classroom, in every lobby, on every street corner.
The American Motors Corporation announced today specific retail prices increases, averaging $119, on its 1974 compact and sub-compact cars.
The Shell Oil Company yesterday raised crude oil prices by $1 a barrel. It took the step, retroactive to Dec. 19, only 24 hours after the Cost of Living Council authorized the immediate increase.
An international agreement to regulate world trade in textiles was concluded here today by a 50-nation conference.

Dr. Sigmund L. Wilens, professor of pathology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, died yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. His age was 68, and he lived at 100 Haven Avenue.
The Senate adopted a resolution today calling for the observance next April 30 of a "national day of humiliation, fasting and prayer."

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation warned its stockholders yesterday that "several persistent problems" would cause lower earnings for 1973. The statement was issued after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

The latest war in the Middle East could stimulate sluggish programs to improve the quality of front-line equipment in Europe, according to officials at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Brussels.

Reggie Jackson of the world champion Oakland A's was named officially today the American League's 1973 slugging king. Jackson compiled a slugging percentage of .531. Leftist demonstrators machine-gunned a government building in Tripoli and barricaded highways and tore down traffic lights in Beirut in the fourth day of anti-Government rioting today.

Peachy Kellemeyer, the captain of the United States team, hoped her players could regroup after they fell behind Australia, 2-1, in the opening round today of the Bonne Bell Cup women's tennis competition.

Martin J. Hodas, the reputed "porno king," has been acquitted of charges of fire-bombing two competitive "massage parlors" on West 42d Street.

The Cost of Living Council ordered today a delay in increases of some steel prices, but, in a surprise move, allowed some other steel prices to go up immediately. The council said steel companies may increase prices at once to reflect higher costs of scrap steel, noting that the cost of scrap has nearly doubled in the last four months.
Bowing to intense White House pressure, the Senate approved tonight, 52 to 8, a modified emergency energy bill that was stripped of a section designed to limit windfall profits by the oil industry.
The alligator, which was considered an endangered species a few years ago, has made so strong a comeback in this region that Louisiana is offering to give some of the reptiles away.

The Aluminum Company of America said today that despite drought-induced hydroelectric curtailments in the Pacific Northwest, domestic aluminum smelters produced a record amount of primary ingot in 1973.
The proposed move of the Padres' franchise from San Diego to Washington was dealt a setback tonight when the new owners failed to meet a deadline on the provisions for transferring the baseball team.
The conviction of Army Lieut. William L. Called Jr. for the murder of at least 22 Vietnamese civilians at My Lai was upheld today by the United States Court of Military Appeals.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said to day that he had claimed Federal tax deductions of $199,153 on the donation of his Vice-Presidential papers to the Minnesota State Historical Society.

The nation's most serious peacetime inflation in the modern era continued in November at an unabated pace, Labor Department statistics disclosed today.

Weisl Jr. to the sensitive post of Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, for which he has little discernible qualification, is disappointing.

Ligon, director of the Office of Oil and Gas, said the plan had been "postponed indefinitely" after the Acting Attorney General, Robert H. Bork, ruled the oilmen might face conflict-of-interest charges over decisions they would make involving their own companies.

A record 18.5 per cent rise in the costs of fuel oil and coal combined with sharp increases in food prices to drive the regional Consumer Price Index for November to a new high, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.

Rudolf Forst, musician, composer and teacher, died Wednesday at Grasslands Hospital, Valhalla. His age was 73, and he lived here.

Arthur E. Poole, president and chief executive officer of the Hallen Construction Company, Inc., Island Park, L.I., died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at the South Shore Division of Long Island Jewish Hospital in Far Rockaway. He was 60 years old and lived at Hewlett Harbor, L.I.
Robert T. Jones 3d, son of Bobby Jones, died last night in a hospital here of a heart attack. He was 47 years old.
President Juan D. Peron announced an ambitious three-year economic plan for Argentina today that he said would raise the gross national product by 7.8 per cent a year, the highest rate ever.
Yields on United States Treasury bills fell for threemonth bills and rose for sixmonth bills in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

A young man who entered the United States Public Service Health Hospital on Staten Island more than four years ago for the repair of a minor eye injury and emerged a quadraplegic and unable to see or speak, agreed yesterday to a $1-million settlement by the Federal Government.

The business of wine predicting becomes rather silly at times. The air is filled with prognostications almost before the grapes are in the vats. There are even people who will tell you all about next year based on the condition of the vines right now.
The first quarter-horse meeting in New York State will run from April 18 through Nov. 30 next year, Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., chairman of the State Racing and Wagering Board, announced yesterday.
New orders for durable goods rose a marginal 0.3 per cent, or $127million, in November to $44.2-billion, compared with an upward revised $44.04billion in October.

Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan declared a state of emergency this morning to deal with the current oil shortage and inflation. He ordered an immediate 20 per cent cutback in oil and electric power to major industries.
The Atomic Energy Commission says the Dow Chemical Company has failed to report two leeks of radioactive materials in the last five years.

Consumer Affairs Commissioner Betty Furness announced Thursday that the American Film Theater had promised to pay refunds to customers whose prepaid subscription tickets never arrived or came too late.
John M. Doar, the special House investigator, said today that it might not be necessary to show that President Nixon had committed criminal offenses as a prerequisite to impeaching him.
John Harold Brislin, Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter for The Scranton Tribune and The Scrantonian, died yesterday after a five-month illness. He was 62 years old.

On the way from his bank to an office Christmas party, Ernst Rothstein, a 59-year-old chemist for the Union Wire Die Corporation, was shot dead on a Queens street yesterday afternoon in what the police believe was an abortive holdup.

Walter Kennedy, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, yesterday cleared the Seattle SuperSonics of charges they had thrown a game in order to get their coach dismissed last season. The Ford Motor Company expects a sharp decline in earnings in the last three months of 1973 and also looks for lower sales in 1974 to have an "adverse effect" on operating results next year.

The United Nations Emergency Force today reported continuing outbreaks of shooting along the EgyptianIsraeli front lines, and Cairo commentators asserted that full-scale war would erupt if the peace conference in Geneva failed to bring results.

Jerome S. Hyams, who resigned on Oct. 1 as senior executive vice president of Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., has been named to the new post of chairman of the executive committee of the Prudential Building Maintenance Corporation.

Dr. Paul C. Witt, professor emeritus of chemistry at Abilene Christian College, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 74 years old.
A plan to redesign the Central Park Mall, using a $150,000 gift from Bloomingdale's department store and matching city funds, has been dropped by mutual agreement.

A City University faculty women's group yesterday filed a sex-bias suit against the uni versity in Federal Court here charging that "women are dis criminated against in every possible aspect of employment" in the university system.
Japan raised her official discount rate today to 9 per cent from 7 per cent, a record high, as part of a major effort to curb inflation.

The first Arab-Israeli peace conference opened today with strong pleas by the United States and the Soviet Union for a permanent settlement that would avoid another Middle East war and break what Secretary of State Kissinger called "the shackles of the past."

A legal inquiry has been opened in France after suspicion that a horse race in which bettors must forecast the first three finishers was fixed. Old-crop wheat futures rose a little yesterday and new crop months declined. The divergent trends told the story of traders' thinking about what the Government's latest figures on wheat exports meant and what they guessed the Government's first estimate of the winter wheat crop would be.

Spain's assassinated Premier, Luis Car.rero Blanco, was buried this afternoon after a tense funeral procession that extreme rightists turned into a political demonstration.

Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel met tonight with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, in the first high-level session between Israel and Russian officials since the Soviet Union severed diplomatic relations during the 1967 war.

WASHINGTON-In city after city thousands of housing units--abandoned but structurally sound-have been given over to rats and vandals. Yet in those same cities large numbers of people are wretchedly housed. The combination of those two facts has led to the idea of urban homesteading, based on a strategy devised a century ago when we were trying to open up the West and encourage settlement on the frontier.

The House killed a modified emergency energy bill early today. The vote was 219 to 34. By a vote of 171 to 74, the House also rejected a motion by Democratic leaders to adjourn, and will meet again today at noon.

Middlebury College officials, in Middlebury, Vt., have found a solution to a budding campus controversy--they hope. The issue involves two important facilities, the campus library and the Snow Bowl, a well-known ski resort owned by the school.

When a lawyer for Ralph Nader and consumer groups who are challenging the Nixon Administration's dealings with the dairy industry played portions of a copy of a subpoenaed White House tape before friends at a cocktail party, he committed what he himself accurately described as "a very foolish mistake."

The first Arab-Israeli peace conference opened in Geneva with strong pleas by the United States and the Soviet Union for a permanent settlement that would avoid another Middle East war and break what Secretary of State Kissinger called "the shackles of the past."

The major United States stock exchanges will operate on normal schedules Monday, Dec. 24, but will be closed on Tuesday, Christmas day. Canadian stock exchanges, the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange will be closed both Monday and Tuesday.

The Committee for a Unified Newark said today that it was calling off its protests against radio station WNJR because of the recent hiring of a black station manager who had been working with community groups on programing.
Caroline D. Emerson, an author of children's books, died at the Harrington Memorial Hospital in Southbridge on Wednesday. She was 82 years old and had lived here for many years.

A Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute hockey game scheduled tonight was canceled because its opponent was snowed in, in Canada. A storm prevented the Waterloo (Ontario) University team from making the trip.
Irvin Wayne Wasson Jr., a public-relations executive, died Tuesday after a brief illness. He was 47 years old and lived at 145 East 15th Street.
The Vietcong today walked out of a negotiating session with South Vietnamese representatives in a fresh clash over South Vietmna's political future

Administrators of some private and municipal child-care agencies say that the spirit of giving seems less in evidence this year, and that this may mean a subdued holiday for several thousand under privileged children in the metropolitan area.

Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, has gone to the Bahamas and a penthouse complex in the Xanadu Hotel at Freeport, apparently to prepare a refuge from Federal indictments expected to be returned against him next week in Las Vegas, Nev.

A Federal judge here ordered the Government today to turn ver a number of documents to jack up its contention that certain information must be deeted from a book about the Central Intelligence Agency before the book may be published.
Erwin Stricker of Italy won a World Cup special slalom ski race today with two runs of 52.42 seconds each.

Pope Paul VI voiced hope today that the Arab-Israeli peace conference in Geneva would lead to a lasting Middle East settlement, and said that he expected to be consulted on the future of Jerusalem.

The New Yorker Theater, the revival and art-film house at Broadway and 88th Street, has been purchased for an undisclosed sum by the Walter Reade Organization, owner and operator of 81 theaters across the country.
Canada's Parliament, which is considering Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's proposed Energy Supplies Emergency Act, reached an agreement today to recess until Jan. 3.

Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, has gone to the Bahamas and a penthouse complex in the Xanadu Hotel at Freeport, apparently to prepare a refuge from Federal indictments expected to be returned against him next week in Las Vegas, Nev.
With a defense that forced many turnovers, St. John's stunned 10th-ranked Alabama, 72-67, in the opening round of the Connecticut Classic at the Veterans Memorial Coliseum tonight.

Defense was expected to dominate the Tangerine Bowl football game tomorrow night between 17th-ranked Miami of Ohio and the University of Florida. The game is rated a toss-up. Miami led the nation's colleges in defense, allowing 177 yards a game in rolling over 10 opponents for a perfect season.
Glen Satner and Larry Giroux set up both St. Louis goals tonight to give the Blues a 2-1 victory over the Atlanta Flames in the National Hockey League.

Peachy Kellemeyer, the captain of the United States team, hoped her players could regroup after they fell behind Australia, 2-1, in the opening round today of the Bonne Bell Cup women's tennis competition.

In a move reflecting Tokyo's emergence as a major international financial center, six foreign companies had their shares listed this week on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the first time foreign concerns have been allowed to have their shares traded in Japan.
Harsh sounds, joyous sounds, provocative sounds are giving tonal life to two current exhibitions of handcrafted vintage instruments that are just about as exciting to see as to hear.
Three children and their mother were killed today when a flash fire and explosion, possibly caused by leaking gas, flattened their home and burned like an "inferno," according to the police.

An increase of nearly onethird in Federal funds for antipoverty efforts in New York City-$6,219,031 to add to an earlier $20-million-for the year started last July 1 was announced yesterday by United States Senator Jacob K. Javits.

The Skylab 3 astronauts studied the streaking comet Kohoutek through their solar telescopes today to learn more about the make-up of its icy core, which is slowly melting away as it nears the sun.

To many blacks standing in the long ticket lines at the Port Authority Bus Terminal yesterday, juggling luggage and keeping an eye on restless children, going home for Christmas meant traveling south.

A prestigious Park Avenue law firm has sued Aristotle Onassis to collect legal fees and costs stemming from its defense of his wife, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, in a suit involving Ronald E. Galella, a freelance photographer.

Melinda Reed, actress, and Kennett Love, author and correspondent, both of New York, were married here today beside the Pyramid of Kefren at Giza. The Rev. Dale Comption of St. Andrew's Church here officiated at the Episcopal ceremony.

President Nixon has assigned Bruce Herschensohn, who was the subject of controversy when he made films for the United States Information Agency, to be a full-time White House contact for persons wishing to express their support for the President.

A spokesman for President Nixon said today that the Senate Watergate committee's 60-page subpoena asking for hundreds of documents and tape recordings was "incredible" and raised the possibility that Mr. Nixon might not honor it in full.

The Public Service Commission ordered all electric utilities in New York State yesterday to cut voltage 3 per cent around the clock, in a move it said would save 2.5 million to 3 million barrels of oil a year while having "only minimal effect on the consumers of the state."

The Signal Companies, Inc., has agreed to sell for $480million its wholly owned subsidiary, the Signal Oil Gas Company, of Houston, Tex., to Burmah Oil, Inc., the United States subsidiary of the Burmah Oil Company, Ltd., of Britain.

Disappointing news on the inflation front and on 1973 earnings prospects for Westinghouse Electric-a big Wall Street blue chip-combined to send stock prices lower yesterday. Westinghouse, the volume leader, plunged 7 7/8 points to 24 3/8 after trading at its lowest price since 1967. Management said that "several persistent problems" would cause lower earnings for this year.
BOSTON-In what may be an indication of things to come, the giant, downtown Jordan Marsh store here has apparently become the beneficiary of the fuel pinch.
Egypt and Jordan today laid on the conference table basically identical blueprints for peace in the Middle East based on total withdrawal by Israel from the Arab territories she occupied in 1967.

Dr. Vincent H. Gillson, pathologist and director of clinical laboratories at the Pascack Valley Hospital here and at the Riverdell Hospital in Oradell, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Washington Township. He was 52 years old.
A former official of the state's Democratic party won acquittal yesterday on charges of conspiracy, fraud and transportation of stolen securities worth more than $500,000.
The Senate and the House gave final approval today to an 11 per cent increase in two steps in Social Security benefits for some 29 million retired persons.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, in its answer to an antitrust suit filed by the Justice Department in April, 1972, asserted yesterday that the legal action by the Government was an act of reprisal against the network for exercising its First Amendment rights in covering news of the Nixon Administration.
The Panama Canal Company is seeking the first increase in tolls since the waterway was opened in 1914, it was announced yesterday.
Four Lindsay administration officials, including Simeon Golar, a Liberal party stalwart, were appointed yesterday to fill vacancies in the Family and Criminal Courts.

The General Electric Company has received two additional orders for boiling-water nuclear reactor electric generating systems, it was learned yesterday. Mexico's Federal Electricity Commission and the National Institute for Nuclear Energy has ordered its second 660-megawatt unit with initial fuel and five reload fuel batches.

Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident nuclear physicist, declared today that his place was in the Soviet Union and that he intended to return here if he were allowed to accept an invitation to lecture in the United States.

With its second basketball upset in two nights, St. John's defeated Jacksonville, 68-60, to win the first Connecticut Classic at the Veterans Memorial Coliseum tonight. The Redmen had beaten the Dolphins previously in the season's opener for both teams.

The Middle East peace conference ended its first round with a quick agreement on moving "forthwith" toward talks on separating Israeli and Egyptian forces now tangled along a jagged front on both sides of the Suez Canal.

If the Arab-Israeli conference is to accomplish its proclaimed goal of peace in the Middle East, there won't be a sign of any positive action for at least a month. Not that Israel's forthcoming elections and subsequent creation of a new Cabinet comprise the stumbling block; simply that complex modern negotiations take ages to progress. Vietnam is an example.

The fate of the San Diego Padres was just as uncertain today as it had been 2 1/2 weeks ago, pending another meeting of the National League club owners, a meeting that may not take place until January.

The Soviet Union has agreed to let a dozen American mountain climbers try to scale its third highest mountain, the 23,405foot Lenin Peak. The mountain climbers are the first Americans ever allowed to undertake a major ascent here.

An assassins' bomb killed Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco last week, eliminating the man who has been running the country on behalf of the durable but frail Generalissimo Franco and placing unexpected stress on the continuity of leadership.

Miss Jean SinclairWolff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Wolff, was married at home here this afternoon to John Taylor Stevens Jr., a civil engineer and son of Mr. and Mrs. Stevens of Falls Church, Va.
The marriage of Miss Stephanie Sommer to Michael Allen Mayhew took place in Grace Episcopal Church here this afternoon. The Rev. James H. Clark performed the ceremony.
Two Queens businessmen on their way to make bank deposits yesterday afternoon were robbed at gunpoint of a total of $27,500 in cash in two separate incidents, the police reported.

HACKENSACK-How can you clear your sidewalk or driveway of snow without risking a heart attack? How do you keep steps and walks free of hazardous ice? And how do you get to work safely at least within an hour or so of your usual driving time? These are only a few of the worries that beset suburbanites at this time of year.

" Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances."--First Amendment to the Constitution The First Amendment guarantees the people of the United States what economists call "a free market in ideas."

An appeals court has reversed a ruling against the in-flight entertainment chief of Air France, who had been fined for allowing the screening of an adult film aboard a plane in which a 10-year-old girl was a passenger.
The Detroit Red Wings rode the strength of two powerplay goals in the second period tonight to defeat the Boston Bruins, 4-2, in a National Hockey League game.
