Mr. and Mrs. Robert Allen Arny of Upper Montclair and Shelter Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Pauline Arny, to Howard Ross Pywell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pywell Jr. of Canton, Mass.

The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2: "Newsmakers": The guest is Representative Hugh L. Carey, Democrat of Brooklyn, Channel 2, noon.
Mrs. Polly Brooks Howe, who in 1948 leased her estate in Locust Valley, L.I., to the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, died yesterday at her home, 20 Sutton Place South. Her age was 72.

O. J. Simpson was everyone's hero in pro football this season. The talented 26-year-old running back for the Buffalo team set a season record by gaining 2,003 yards in 14 games, of which the otherwise unexceptional Bills won nine.
Tom Weiskopf, who won the British Open title last summer and compiled $243,155 in official earnings for 1973, was named today male golfer of the year by the Golf Writers of America.

Harry and David, a fruit business in Medford, Ore., has sent 1 1/2 million Christmas presents this year, grossing between $15-million and $17-million. It is part of the growing mail-order food industry whose sales will reach $1.5billion this year, according to an "educated guess" by Ruth Shea, a specialist in the Direct Marketing Advertising Association.

As the Laotian neutralists, rightists and Communist-led Pathet Lao struggle toward the formation of a coalition government, it seems clear that whatever structure they produce will still be within the Kingdom of Laos and that the kingdom will have a King.

Miss Marguerite Whittlesey Felt, an assistant fashion editor with Mademoiselle magazine, plans to be married Jan. 19 to Michael Cary Bowen, a vice president of the Goldman Sachs International Corporation, investment bankers.

A partial eclipse of the sun may be seen Monday. The best spot to view the eclipse will be at the mouth of the Amazon River. But viewers in Central and South America, northern Africa and the eastern part of North America will be able to see it, weather permitting.
EAST MEADOW, L. I.--In what may become a trend for hospitals, the Nassau County Medical Center released its full accreditation report Wednesday and held a public meeting to invite comments.

Ernest G. Brown, who retired in 1960 as a vice president of the United States Rubber Company (now Uniroyal, Inc.), died here yesterday. He was 77 years old and lived in Darien and Pine Orchard.

Concern has been growing among ecologists and others that the energy emergency might erode the national movement for environmental reform. A canvas last week disclosed that there have indeed been some setbacks, but most experts felt they would only be temporary. And some even expected benefits to accrue from the shortage. What follows is an examination of the effects so far of the emergency on pollution control.

Another section of the West Side Highway - from 23d to 46th Street - was closed to traffic yesterday evening by the Department of Highways. The action by the Department of Highways followed by one week the closing of the northbound and southbound lanes of the road from the BrooklynBattery Tunnel to 23d Street as the result of a collapse of part of the roadway involving a 30ton, trailer truck.

For United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), Tickets, $40, $20 and $10, from Little Angels Holiday Performance Committee, 18 East 71st Street.

The engagement of Miss Elaine Nash McHugh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Nevin McHugh of Larchmont, to Luis Emil Rinaldini, son of Dr. and Mrs. Luis Maria Rinaldini of Mendoza and Maipu, Argentina, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

Julie Heldman scored a 6-3, 1-6, 6-3 upset victory over Evonne Goolagong of Australia today, sparkling a comeback that moved the United States into a 3-3 tie with the Aussies in the Bonne Bell Cup tennis series.

He's in a wheelchair now and he always will be, but Karl Kassulke hasn't surrendered to being a paraplegic. "I want to coach high school football next season," he says. "I can do it from a wheelchair. No problem."

Dr. Edmund de Schweinitz Brunner, a specialist in American rural sociology, died Friday in the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Wilton, Conn. Dr. Brunner retired in 1955 as professor of education on the Schiff Foundation of Teachers College, Columbia University, and in 1963 as professor of sociology at Columbia and as chairman of its Bureau of Applied Social Research.

Homosexuals probably have more social freedom in New York than in any other American city, but they have yet to gain official city recognition of their rights against discrimination in housing, employment and public accommodations.

The 93d Congress adjourned its first session today after abandoing efforts to pass major legislation giving President Nixon sweeping powers to impose gasoline rationing and take other emergency steps to conserve energy.

Something of a stir was caused last February with the publication of "The Rocksburg Railroad Murders" by K. C. Constantine. The book attracted a good deal of attention for its middle-class ambience, its realism and the author's infallible ear for blue-collar patterns of speech and thought.

Frank Lane tells of suing Charles 0. Finley when he was dismissed as general manager of the A's, when they were in Kansas City, after working less than nine months on an eight-year contract: "It was pretty obvious, in view of all the evidence, the jury was going to find for me, which it did, but that didn't seem to bother Charlie when we were left alone by the judge in his chamber.
Nick Weatherspoon, a rookie, came off the bench in the third quarter to lead the Capital Bullets to a 9889 victory over the Houston Rockets, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
ALMA de MAJORCA, Spain-Mid night mass on Christmas Eve is celebrated throughout the Chris tian world with almost universal conformity to the prescribed ritual.
Contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are often deceptive. Sometimes the amount of a donation does not reflect the effort that went into collecting it.

Miami of Ohio's defense throttled Florida tonight and the Redskins wrapped up a perfect season with a 16-7 Tangerine Bowl victory. David Draudt's three field goals and the running of Chuck Varner at fullback accounted for Miami's scores.

TRENTON-In an effort to save gasoline and to relieve the heavy congestion of traffic leading toward the Benjamin Franklin Bridge to Philadelphia, a bill was filed in the Assembly last week that would allow southern New Jersey riders on the Lindenwold rapid transit line to travel free during noprush hours.

7:30 A.M., WABC-AM: Message of Israel. A report by Rabbi Richard G. Hirsch on conditions in Israel. 8:30-8:55, WNYC-FM: The Singing Lady. With Ireene Wicker. A musical dramatization of the "Night Before Christmas" and "The First Christmas."

Four bombs exploded in London today, injuring five people. The blasts were the latest in a wave of explosions that has been attributed to Irish Republican guerrillas. One of the devices exploded in a police station, wounding a detective in the hands and legs.

The Rhodes scholarship application specifies that candidates possess four essential qualities: intellectual attainment, character, leadership and physical vigor. The fellowship committee at La Salle College in Philadelphia decided that Ada Steinmetz fit the bill.

The Pentagon has grounded all Air National Guard and Air Reserve training flights as the result of a Federal Energy Office order diverting 1.5 million barrels of military jet fuel to civilian airlines. That amount was reduced yesterday to 900,000 barrels. Military forces said yesterday that the grounding went into effect Friday night and would last indefinitely.

THE seriousness of the current energy crisis makes it imperative that every homeowner do everything possible to conserve fuel and avoid wasting heat-and the most effective weapon in this battle is adequate insulation in all walls and ceilings (under the roof) of the house.

ENGLISH cinema seems to be enjoying a sudden burst of creativity. In the last few years, England has produced three extraordinarily talented filmmakers-John Boorman, Ken Russell and Nicolas Roeg. They have little in common except for their visual flair, their rejection of the literary conventions that still dominate most films, and their desire to experiment with a purely cinematic vocabulary.

Seymour B. Durst, a major assembler of land for new construction in midtown Manhattan, has allowed mortgage holders to foreclose on about a dozen properties just east of Times Square. Mr. Durst had in recent years taken control of 30 or more parcels in the area, which is between Broadway and Avenue of the Americas and 42d and 46th Streets. It had been his hope to construct a coordinated office and commercial complex there.

Miss Mary Tait Seiberg, a candidate for a doctoral degree at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, was married here this afternoon to Harvey Jerome Goldschmid, a professor of law at Columbia.
Archbishop Molloy, the Catholic High School's Athletic Association champion, posted four victories yesterday in the League's annual indoor relay carnival at the 102d Engineers Armory.

In Australia 20,000 to 30,000 years ago, there were predators: marsupial lions and Tasmanian wolves. There were rhinoceros-sized quadrupedal herbivores. There were hopping herbivores: kangaroos and wallabies.
Five men were killed by soldiers when they tried to blow up an electrical supply line to the Chilean capital, the military authorities announced today.

The custom of wishing one another a simple "Merry Christmas" seems to be dying out. All of a sudden, perfectly nice people are unwilling to commit themselves wholeheartedly on this point. They will only say: "If I don't see you, have a Merry Christmas." Which is fine, but what happens if they do see you? Will your wassail taste bitter? Will you find a lump of coal in the old holiday sock?
The merging of two of its publications, New South and South Today, into a bimonthly general-interest magazine to be known as Southern Voices was announced today by the Southern Regional Council.

PONTIAC, Mich.-A concept called community education is rapidly gaining converts across the country. At its simplest, the concept Involves a conscious effort to take fuller advantage of school buildings by actively encouraging and coordinating their use by community groups and giving the community some voice in the program.
Sylvan Lawrence, the builder and real estate investor, has purchased the 23-story building at 71 Broadway from the U.S. Steel Corporation for $6,500,000.

What happened on the ground all last week was clear enough-from subfreezing to almost spring, from ice on everything to water gushing everywhere to subfreezing again-but what produced it was less obvious. According to meteorologists, the extraordinary week was the work of several local weather variants, a warm breath from the Atlantic and one large, unfriendly contribution from Canada.

Dancealot pranced into the lead at the start and stayed there all the way to win the $57,300 December Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct. Representing the Mill House interests of the family of the late James Cox Brady, and ridden by Eddie Maple, Dancealot beat nine rivals in the 1 1/8-mile test for 2-yearold fillies.

Anyone who lives in the South, who pays more than passing attention to its political, social and cultural life, cannot fail to be impressed by the persistence of a Southern identity--indeed, a Southern sensibility.

It was a super year for super golfers. Jack Nicklaus achieved one goal by winning his 14th major championship. This came with his Professional Golfers' Association victory at Cleveland as he scored 277 to beat Bruce Crampton of Australia by four strokes. It enabled the 33-year-old professional to eclipse the record of 13 major titles set by the late Bobby Jones in 1930.

THE recent request by the United States mint for "standby" Congres sional authority to switch from copper to aluminum in cent production, widely and often sensationally reported in the daily press, could hardly have caught too many members of the numismatic hobby by surprise. Over the past several months the hobby press has been full of speculation about how the Mint might react to the steadily rising price of copper.

A PRICE INCREASE of $1 a barrel for crude oil has been authorized by the Cost of Living Council. It estimates this will add 2.3 cents to the price of a gallon of gasoline and heating oil . . . William E. Simon, Federal energy chief, has asked for a voluntary 10-gallon-a-week limit on consumption of gasoline.

TO THE EDITOR: I THOROUGHLY enjoyed the Rev. Robert E. Laudher's article, "Will TV Ever Get Religion?" (Nov. 25), about the version of Brian Moore's "Catholics" which I produced for CBS "Playhouse 90." His general comments concerning the lack of religious drama during prime-time television were well taken.
WOODBRIDGE-The New Jersey Highway Authority will offer free nonalcoholic drinks to its Garedn State Parkway patrons on Christmas and New Year's.

ALHAJI BAI KONTE (Rounder Records 5001)--the title "Alhaji" designates his status as a marabout or holy man of Islam-performs African music on the kora, a harp with 21 strings. Konte's music is classical in that it consists of a repertoire of set pieces and stems from a tradition which emphasizes instrumental virtuosity. But it is equally a folk art, since Konte's subject matter recalls the deeds of kings and heroes of the Senegambian Mandinke tribe.

Joseph Curran, who retired as president of the National Maritime Union last March, was paid $419,663.79 in salary and severance pay during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1973, according to the union's annual report filed with the office of Labor Management Reports here.

American consumers were officially asked to buy less gasoline last week but told they were going to pay more for whatever they bought - and for heating their homes with oil as well. The request and the edict were the latest moves in the Administration's effort to conserve fuel and avoid gasoline rationing.

Dr. Walter Hetherington Durfee, former president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges, died last night. He was 84 years old. A Hobart alumnus of 1908, he had been dean emeritus, professor of mathematics emeritus, former provost and, in 1947-48, acting president of the colleges.

It is one of the simplest of all the great and enduring stories. The Roman governor of Judea ordered everyone to go to his native village and register, so a poor carpenter named Joseph and his young wife, Mary, who was large with child, made the journey to Bethlehem. There was no room for them at the inn so, as humble folk often did, they turned to the stable for shelter.

Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations said today that he was "very happy" with the opening phase of the Middle East peace conference. It showed that the United Nations "is still a useful instrument if it is used in the right way and if we do our share," he said in an interview.

The Japanese Cabinet today approved what it termed an "austerity" budget for 1974, calling for the smallest annual increase in spending in four years, as part of the Government's intense new effort to combat inflation and the oil shortage.

WASHINGTON - David Ben-Gurion died recently, during the very struggle which he foresaw in March, 1957 as Premier of Israel. NEW BURLINGTON. On began after Thanksgiving. By Christmas it was deep and bitter. In New Burlington, Ohio, where two streams bent around the tiny farming village like a wishbone, men sat in their kitchens with their overcoats on. It was a Christmas like many other Christmases, but a winter such as no one could remember. The wind blew, ice sheathed the village, and the snow drifted over buggy tops.

Ronan, the M.T.A.'s chairman and chief executive officer. Premier Golda Meir of Israel has been named the "most admired" woman of 1973 in the annual poll taken by the Gailup organization. She won more than twice as many votes as the woman with the next highest total, Mrs. Pat Nixon, who headed the list of the 10 most admired women last year.

Negotiations for a new contract to replace the current Off Broadway pact, which expires Jan. 6, will be resumed Wednesday at 1 P.M., it was announced yeserday.

The Human Resources Administration yesterday requested an increase of $220-million in its expense budget for 1974-75, despite a projected decline in welfare rolls and the Federal assumption of responsibility, as of Jan. 1, for the categories of aid to the disabled, aged and blind. The agency is seeking a total of $2.578-billion.
Spanish newspapers accused French authorities today of harboring the killers of Premier Luis Carrero Blanco. One newspaper said that the Government here would request extradition.
In the menus below, the dishes marked with an as"terisk are followed by a recipe. Enchilada casserole Marinated chick pea salad Pumpkin chiffon cake

Walter W. Heller, incoming president of the American Economic Association, warned today that the energy shortage would not soon go away and that the United States was in for a "fairly profound change" in its way of life.

In preparing tor Manns American Conference championship game with Oakland, Larry Seiple knows he'll punt against the Raiders, but he also wonders whether he'll play tight end and the Raiders wonder whether he'll play running back.
Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt left here today, the last of the foreign ministers to leave after opening the Middle East peace conference last week.

Forty women employes of Newsday, including reporters and editors, filed charges yesterday with the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission charging that the Long Island newspaper "maintains a pattern and practice of employment discrimination against women employes."

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that there was nothing in the law that required Governor Wilson to have filed statements of his financial holdings during his 15 years as Lieutenant Governor. What was filed by him "was a purely voluntary act on his part;" Mr. Lefkowitz said.
Henry Willcox, founder and president of the former Willcox Construction Company of New York, which specialized in public housing, died here today. He was 83 years old and lived here.

After 10 days of alternating snow, sleet and fog, activity In the city swelled like the season's first crocus yesterday as the temperature rose to 61 degrees, two degrees short of the record for the day, set in 1936. The high was recorded at 1 P.M.

Alex Webster approached Jim Garrett on the sidelines at Yale Bowl during the first half of the New York Giants' game against the Dallas Cowboys this year. "Put Jake in," the Giants coach said to his defensive coordinator, referring to Larry Jacobson, a defensive tackle.

James Earl Ray, convicted of assassinating the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., is being transferred from a state to a Federal prison for "security reasons," the Justice Department said in Washington yesterday.

The Indiana Supreme Court blocked a newspaper today from obtaining a copy of a birth record that might show whether Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, was listed as the father of an ililegitimate child.

In Tulsa, Okla., yesterday, where the Minnesota Vikings are practicing on the Tartan turf of Skelly Stadium, Fran Tarkenton was asked if the Vikings would be handicapped, on Sunday in the National Conference champion ship game at Dal las because the Cowboys were so much more accustomed to artificial turf.
A 31 - year- old equipment repairman is being held in $100,000 bail in connection with the death of a Boston woman whose charred body was found in his burned-nut apartment. The man,

Dr. J. Pearce Mitchell, a former professor of chemister and registrar at Stanford University, who also was a former Mayor of Palo Alto and a member of the City Council, died at his home here today. He was 93 years old.

Three young women were presented at the ninth annual debutante ball of the Metropolitan Club last night. They were the Misses Liza Skouras Fowler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Anderson Fowler of Sharon, Conn.; Carol Ann Maytag, daughter of Mrs. Kerrvn King of New
The Soviet Union today announced the commissioning of the first wharf of a major new Pacific port on Wrangel Bay, being built with Japanese help and an $80-milln credit from Tokyo.

William E. Simon, the Federal energy director, announced today the establishment of a stand-by gasoline-rationing system but said he was "personally optimistic" that rationing could be avoided "if the American public continues to cooperate."

In making Roger Starr his chief housing adviser, Mayor-elect Beame has picked one of New York City's best-qualified experts on the economics of housing-a thoughtful, articulate analyst of problems that have contributed so drastically to the decay of neighborhoods and the shortage of good housing for middle-class and poor families.

The Administration is still trying to "keep its options open" on a program for dealing with the energy crisis. The announcement by Federal energy chief William Simon of a stand-by rationing scheme for gasoline is really a way of deferring the tough decision on whether or not to ration.

All 15 prison guards on the day shift, reportedly disgruntled over concessions made to inmates, staged a "sickout" yesterday at the minimum-security Mercer County Corrections Center in nearby Hopewell Township. Spokesmen for Local 107 of the Mercer County Corrections Officers were unavailable for comment, but guards belonging to the union said the action involved alleged partial treatment of prisoners.
Don Pierce rode Woodland Pines to a length victory today in the 22d running of the $34,300 Palos Verdes Handicap, the traditional opening-day feature of the Santa Anita winter thoroughbred meeting.

The systematic extortion of bribes by groups of New York City police officers has been substantially reduced in recent years, but allegations of illegal involvement in narcotics by individual officers has increased, according to a police corruption study.
New Israeli complaints of Egyptian troop advances along a sensitive sector of the cease-fire lines were reported today by the headquarters here of the United Nations Emergency Force.

The chief executives of two of the nation's leading companies, the RCA Corporation and the Xerox Corporation, in yearend statements yesterday acknowledged problems but expressed confidence in both their companies and the nation's economic performance for 1974.

Herbert Stein, chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, predicted today that inflation would continue at a "pretty high" rate early next year but that it should drop below a rate of 5 per cent in the latter half of the year after the worst of the impact of energy and food prices is over.

Jorge velasquez, the slar 27-year-old jockey from Panama, made the 20,807 fans at Aqueduct yesterday forget all about Ron Turcotte and Angel Cordero. Velasquez, one of the most dependable riders on the continent, rode four winners on the nine-race program, and only a disqualification out of a first place finish took a fifth triumph away from him.

Miss Nancy Browning, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Prentice Browning of Holmes Beach, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Walter E. Afield, professor and chairman of the department of psychiatry at the University of South Florida College
William Haines, a film comdian of the nineteen-twenties and thirties died of cancer yesterday in St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica. He was 73 years old and lived in Brentwood.
Aristotle Onassis said yesterday that his wife, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, would pay the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton Garrison $235,000 today to settle a claim against Mr. Onassis.
A funeral service will be conducted here Saturday for Harold B. Lee, 11th president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, in the Tabernacle on Temple Square.
Two thousand Jewish youngsters filled the Lubavitch Synagogue in Brooklyn yesterday with joyous music and song as candles glowed on two large candelabra.

Seymour Terry, who was being investigated by the city's Board of Ethics over a possible conflict of interest, asked Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame yesterday to drop him from a key job in the administration, and Mr. Beame instantly agreed.

In years past, the Metropolitan Museum's holiday week concerts presented in front of its glorious Christmas tree in the Medievel Sculpture Court have had a distinctly festive air that made them seem Christmasy even when some of the music

The United States registered its third consecutive monthly trade surplus in November, although the surplus was sharply reduced by higher costs of imported petroleum and other fuels, Government trade figures showed today.

Aeroflot, the Soviet national airline, has recognized that it has a safety problem. After at least 17 air crashes, the journal of the Civil Aviation Ministry devoted its main editorial this month to "increasing flight safety."

The systematic extortion of bribes by groups of New York City police officers has been substantially reduced in recent years, but allegations of illegal involvement in narcotics by individual officers has increased, according to a police corruption study.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago and the General Electric Company announced yesterday the successful completion of settlement discussions covering outstanding issues under the turnkey contracts for construction of four 800 megawatt nuclear power plants entered into in 1965 and 1966.

Gen, Chatichai Choonhavan, Thai Deputy Foreign Minister, left today after a week-long stay in Peking, the first official visit by a Thai delegation to mainland China since the Communist Government was established in 1949.

The City Commission on Human Rights opened a campaign yesterday to end the realestate concerns' practice of "racial steering," or sending white home buyers to all-white neighborhoods and blacks to mixed or all-black areas.

Austrailia could be without most of its top players in its quest this year to retain the Davis Cup. Four members of previous teams, Colin Dibley, Ross Case, Geoff Masters and Bob Giltinan, announced today they would be unavailable for early-round matches because they would be playing on the World Championship Tennis circuit.
A technique of screening human semen has been developed that, the experimenters believe, can increase sharply the likelihood that a couple desiring to produce a boy rather than a girl can do so.

New Jersey college basketball teams are invoies In tournaments from Trenton to Oklahoma. Rutgers is in Oklahoma City for a tournament that also includes Southern California, Oral Roberts, Southwestern, Weber State, Houston and Virginia Tech. Princeton is in the Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden, while Seton Hall is in Orlando, Fla., for the Tangerine Bowl and St. Peter's is in Springfield, Mass., for the Hall of Fame tournament.

TALLINN, U.S.S.R.-"I don't know the statistics, but from the young people I know it seems that more marriages are taking place between Russians and Estonians," said a young Russian teacher and housewife.
Heavy fighting was reported near Phnom Penh today as Cambodian Government troops pushed into an area used by the rebels to aim rockets at the capital.

If you're looking for an experienced account man in the $35,000 salary class you'll have no trouble finding one. If, however, you have in mind an assistant account executive with two years' experience in the $18,000 to $25,000 variety you will find slim pickings.

The Bank of Greece announced today a devaluation of the drachma.. The new exchange rate set by the central bank put the dollar at 293 drachmas, devalued from 28 to the dollar Sand close to the 30-drachma level it held two months before a 10 per cent upward revaluation of the Greek currency.
Prof. Peter Schickele, the world's foremost authority on the life and music of P.D.Q. Bach, opened an engagement on Wednesday night at Town Hall, where he will be appearing through Sunday.

To the Editor: There are about a million long-haul trucks operating on our highways today. These tractor-trailer rigs move about 22 per cent of our freight. They do so while consuming almost ten billion gallons of diesel fuel and gasoline-about 10 per cent of that sold commercially.
Salvage crews, environmentalists and the Coast Guard joined today in efforts to clean up a major oil spill in the Delaware River between Pennsyl[vania and New Jersey.
Miss Donna G. Israel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Israel Df West Orange, was married here this evening to David C. Berliner, a freelance writer, in Congregation Oheb Shalom.
Where are the sleds of yesteryear? Parents, with fond memories of zooming down frosty hills on their Flexible Flyers, found themselves rethinking their children' Christmas lists this year.
The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday chargd the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and its chairman, Dr. Armand Hammer, with defrauding the public in connection with the sale of securities.

Tamara Melcher and Larry Rothschild have been co-operating for a year or more in designing and mak-clothes of velvet applique, but in opening Tamala/Design Works, a craft studio in SoHo, they have widened their scope considerably. Here they are combining their falents with those of other craftsmen.
A sonar-type device was used in the New York Aquarium yesterday in an unsuccessful effort to pick up fetal heartbeats from a pregnant white whale.

The comet Kohoutek, which is to whip around the sun tomorrow, is losing its glow as a postChristmas spectacular for the average neck-craner, but it still ranks as the probable comet of the century for scientists.

A spokesman for Blue Shield conceded yesterday that there was some validity to charges by the State Insurance Department that Blue Shield had failed to make prompt and fair settlements of claims in which its liability was clear.

Plans were announced here tonight for a $250-million shoppingrecreation-residential center on the Palisades. The 16-acre site is just south of the George Washington Bridge and would adjoin Lemoine, Main and Central Avenues.
Eight local political committees, seven organized by supporters of Senator George McGovern and one by supporters of President Nixon, were cited today for failing to file 1972 campaign reports.

President Nixon's declaration that he now favors use of Federal funds to subsidize mass transit operations offers some hope that Washington may yet offer help to City Hall and Albany to save New York's 35-cent fare. However, the Administration's change of heart on operating subsidies falls far short of providing an adequate answer to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's $300-million deficit problem.
Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that he had been threatened by Arab terrorists but that "I personally am not going to be blackmailed."

A tentative agreement was reached last night on a one-year contract for police officers after an all-day mediation session yesterday between Herbert L. Haber, the city's Director of Labor Relations, and officials of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

Mrs. Heien (Penny) I weedy, owner of Secretariat, 1973's Triple Crown winner and Riva Ridge, a former Kentucky Derby winner, said today the only reason the two horses had not completely passed their fertility tests was because of the large sums of insurance money resting on the outcome. Secretariat, the first horse in 25 years to win the Triple Crown, is insured for $6,080,000 and Riva Ridge, his stablemate, is covered for $5.6-million.
Eugene J. McNeely, who served as president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from Aug. 16, 1961, until he retired on Dec. 31, 1964, died today at his home here. He was 73 years old.

The Champion Home Build ers Company said in its company report issued yesterday that a severe cost-price squeeze and gasoline problems were the reason for an 81 per cent dedine in profits and 35 per cent in sales in the third fiscal quarter ended Nov. 30.
Like directors at a board meeting of a giant corporation, the great luxury boats of Florida's winter fleet sit rail to rail in the slips of marinas and yacht clubs in sun-splashed, protected bays.

The year that brought an end to the massive United States war effort in Vietnam brought no end to the doubts and tragedies that fell upon some twenty young men and their families far away. These men went to Southeast Asia voluntarily; they were unarmed-except for pencils, notebooks and cameras, the tools of their profession.
The marriage of Miss Roslyn Fay Braeman, a vice president with Eastdil Realty, Inc., an affiliate of Blyth, Eastman, Dillon, New York investment bankers, was married at noon today to Lisle D. Payne,
In its first decision regulating the quality of rail travel, the Interstate Commerce Commission issued today detailed rules requiring nationwide

For the second time this month the bank-robbery case against Joanne Chesimard and Fred Hilton has gone to a Federal jury. Neither Mrs. Chesimard nor Mr. Hilton, identified by authorities as members of the Black Liberation Army, was present yesterday during Judge Arnold Bauman's 40-minute charge on the law applicable to the three-count indictment.

The size of a donation sometimes does not reflect the thought and effort behind a gift. This was demonstrated by several of the 190 contributions acknowledged yesterday by The Times's Neediest Cases Fund.

Dr. Dau-Lin Hsu, former personal secretary to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and professor of Asian languages and literature at the University of Washington, died Monday at his home here. He was 67 years old.

PPG Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that lack of petroleum - based feedstocks would keep the Puerto Rico Olefins Company closed for an indefinite period and would continue to cause "a severe curtailment" at PPG's wholly owned chemical complex at Guyanilla, Puerto Rico.

The chief executives of two of the nation's leading companies, the RCA Corporation and the Xerox Corporation, in yearend statements yesterday acknowledged problems but expressed confidence in both their companies and the nation's economic performance for 1974.

There was a time when Pearl Woods, a mother of six living in a downtown area scheduled for redevelopment, was always the first on her feet at public hearings, asking indignant questions about relocation.
The former head of the Suf folk County narcotics squad was indicted today on charges of stealing $48,000 of police money.

Rate attorneys representing the public interest said today that they would ask the courts to enjoin the implementation of a Public Utilities Commission order permitting the New Jersey Bell Telephone to pass part
Dr. F. Theodore Reid, who named had practiced medicine in this city for 53 years. died yesterday at Columbus Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 211 West 138th Street.
The Government estimated today that 400,000 workers were being laid off because of the fuel shortage, nearly doubling the national unemployment total.

New York State's new commissioner of Environmental Conservation charged yesterday that the energy crisis had been "overblown and exaggerated," and said he saw no need to extend the emergency variance granted Consolidated Edison to burn dirtier fuel oil and coal.
In a winter of discontent, New Yorkers are preparing to celebrate a New Year's Eve marked by the energy crisis, higher prices in nightclubs and less money for the annual party in Central Park.

The 96-91 victory that the Knicks posted over the Pistons in Detroit on Wednesday night was gratifying, since it came over the team with the fourth-best record in the National Basketball Association. But it may have been costly.
Secretary of State Kissinger said today that improved American relations with the Soviet Union were possible only so t long as Moscow maintained a "responsible course" in the Middle East.
Food prices in the city rose 8.3 per cent from May to the second week in December, according to figures compiled by the Consumer Affairs Department for its weekly Market Basket.

SEOUL. South Korea-Last summer a shy student from a conventional middle-class family in Seoul worked in a factory as part of a program organized by the Christian churches here. The experience suddenly radicalized the student, Lee lung Ae-that is not her real name-and when she returned this fall to Ewha Women's University,
Former Gov. Christopher Del Sesto of Rhode Island, who was an associate justice of the state's Superior Court since 1966, died today at his home. He was 66 years old.

Iraq's revenue from oil after the latest rise in the price of Persian Gulf oil will be $8.337-billion a year, the Iraqi newspaper Al Taakhi said today. Iraq has refused to join other Arab oil countries in cutting production as pressure on the West.
Marlene Dietrich, who injured her leg in a fall last month, briefly entered Santa Monica Hospital in California last Sunday for what her agent here said was a skin-graft operation on her left leg.

One hardly knows whether Hamlet would have minded, but with the second new work the New York Shakespeare Festival is presenting at its Vivian Beaumont Theater, the play is very definitely not the thing.
Wall Street's year-end rally continued yesterday as the how-Jones industrials added 45 points to Wednesday's vance of 22.75 points.

The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit today against Mid-America Dairymen, Inc., one of three big Middle Western milk marketing cooperatives that made heavy contributions to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

It Is a common habit with nations that they seldom think much about economic warfare until it is turned against them. This is a subject worth thinking about some night if you run out of heating oil or gas, and it is certainly a topic that will have to be considered in the forthcoming talks on world trade.
Phil Ochs appears singlehandedly to be trying to keep the protest song alive, if his Wednesday performance at Max's Kansas City, Park Avenue South at 17th Street, is to be judged.

Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne said today that the New Jersey Turnpike Authority has assured him it would not award any additional contracts for construction of a turnpike route to Toms River, which he has opposed, until his office had completed further "exploration" of several areas of disagreement he has with the authority's commissioners.

The second National Black Political Convention will be held in Little Rock, Ark., beginning next March 15, according to Imamu Amiri Baraka, one of the leaders of the convention's assembly. The first, in 1972, drew 8,000 blacks to Gary, Ind.

Three Jews who are former colonels in the Soviet Army said today that they were subject to "continuing reprisals" for seeking to emigrate to Israel and two of them said that they were formally renouncing Soviet citizenship.

With no intent to violate the season of good will, it has to be asked why the State of Maryland should make further exception in the case of Spiro T. Agnew and suspend rather than disbar him from the practice of law. He has already been shown more favor than would have been granted
In the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Michael Ellen O'Callaghan, daughter of Thomas A. O'Callaghan of Montclair and the late Mrs. O'Callaghan,
China's venerated leader, Mao Tse-tung, turned 80 years age yesterday, but his birthday received little or no public attention in his own country.

Seymour Terry, who was being investigated by the city's Board of Ethics over a possible conflict of interest, asked Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame yesterday to drop him from a key job in the administration, and Mr. Beame instantly agreed.

Scoring their biggest advance in more than five months, prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to rise yesterday for the second straight session. Prices in the over-the-counter market also rose.
Comedy of Errors romped to an eightlength victory today in the Irish Sweeps Hurdle and rewarded 12 Irish Sweepstakes ticketholders around the world with prizes of $120,000 each.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn. -It is unprecedented and unbelievable that Richard M. Nixon's papers donated to the National Archives were appraised as a charitable gift valued at $576,000.
Corporate bond prices recovered some of Wednesday's losses in light trading yesterday. Dealers attributed the improvement to short covering accompanied by the reduction announced
Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, two of his top aides and two other associates were named today in a nine-count criminal indictment by a Federal grand jury here.
Most futures prices rose yesterday on commodity exchanges around the country as a result of the announcement on Wednesday that the Arabs were easing their oil Cutbacks for Europe and Japan.
Federal Judge Julius J. Hoffman, who presided over the tumultuous "Chicago seven" conspiracy trial of 1969-70, has been called back to the bench in Illinois.

Administration officials indicated tonight that it was highly unlikely that either transcripts or summaries of tapes of President Nixon's Watergate conversations would be released to the general public.

Outstanding performances for the year continue to be recognized with awards: yesterday, they were announced on both sides of the Atlantic. Winner of the Eclipse Award as the outstanding thoroughbred horse trainer was H. Allen Jerkens, who sent out Onion and Prove Out to upset Secretariat, horse of the year.
The First Pennsylvania Corporation, holding company for the First Pennsylvania Bank and other financial services companies, announced a series of top management realignments yesterday.

Secured loans of the Kassuba Development Corporation, a large national real estate company that has filed for an arrangement with the creditors in the United States District Court in Chicago totaling well over $125-million have been reported by a growing number of mortgage investment trusts.
The liquidation of Weis Securities, Inc., this year has pointed up important deficiencies in the three-yearold law designed to protect investors in brokerage-house failures.
The nation's six largest manufacturers of gypsum board, a major component of home construction, were indicated by a Federal grand jury today on price-fixing charges.

Miss Sandra-.Jeanne Fascell, daughter of United States Representative Dante B. Fascell and Mrs. Fascell, was married here this evening to Frank Berry Diamond Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Diamond of Lower Merion, Pa.

The stronger position of the United States, relative to other industrial countries, in the wake of recent sharp increases in the price of crude oil, was translated today into sharply higher values for the dollar against leading currencies.

In., a move called unusual by many officials, the City Council of Long Beach, L. I., prohibited persons requiring "continuous" psychiatric, medical or nursing care from living in the many old hotels of this seaside resort.
Two substantial upsets marked the early rounds of play in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Double Knockout Team Championship for the Von Zedtwitz Trophy, in which 53 teams are entered.
Last month SKl area operators in the Berkshires were wondering whether this was going to be an early winter. Today they were wondering whether spring was here.
Secretary of State Kissinger said yesterday that improved American relations with the Soviet Union were possible only so long as Moscow maintained a "responsible course" in the Middle East.

William E. Simon, the Federal energy director, announced today the establishment of a stand-by gasoline-rationing system but said he was "personally optimistic" that rationing could be avoided "if the American public continues to cooperate."

At Charles Regini's Exxon station in the middle of Bloomfield, the pumps were barricaded tonight by a wrecker, a blue Buick, a panel truck, a purple Jeep, a red Volkswagen, a blue and white Scout, two garbage cans, two oil drums and a saw horse.

The Rhinechem Corporation, a subsidiary of Bayer, A.G., the West German chemical company, announced yesterday that it had extended to Jan. 18 its offer to purchase at $18.50 a share all the outstanding class A and class B common stock of Cutter Laboratories, Inc.

United States officials hailed today the new international textiles trade agreement, signed last week in Geneva, as a "good portent" for success in the broader trade negotiations due to begin next year.
John Calvin Hill, a career Foreign Service officer, died today of cancer in the Georgetown University Hospital. He was 52 years old.

Violent crime rose 3 per cent in the United States in the first nine months of 1973, the Fed- Ch eral Bureau of Investigation reported today. Over all, serious crime-encompassing murder, rape, robbery, aggravated assault and far more numerous cases of burglary, larceny and auto theft-rose I per cent, compared to the same period in 1972.
The pro-Communist Pathet Lao forces have appointed an envoy to negotiate with the Laotian Government on all matters, a Government spokesman said today.

A week-long Kwanza festival, the African-oriented celebration that is gaining favor among many American blacks, was begun here by the Committee for a Unified Newark this week with musical and dramatic events, including a new play by Imamu Amiri Baraka satirizing Newark politics.
Following are questions and answers about the Government's stand-by gasoline rationing plan: Q. When will it go into effect? A. Not before March and perhaps not at all.
A bistate task force on commuter service said yesterday that construction of a new rail tunnel under the Hudson River at 48th Street should be deferred.

In a move called "highly unusual" and "blatantly discriminatory" by critics, the outgoing City Council today banned persons requiring "continuous" Psychiatric, medical or nursing care from residing in hotels and boarding houses here.
St. John's, offensively aggressive, and Princeton, with a tempered offense, advanced to the semifinal round of the Holiday Festival basketball tournament last night at Madison Square Garden.
Two of the most prominent figures in the broadcast consumerist movement in Washington are joining forces as the new heads of the National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting, which is reorganizing.

The stronger position of the United States, relative to other industrial countries, in the wake of recent sharp increases in the price of crude oil, was translated today into sharply higher values for the dollar against leading currencies.
Secretary of State Kissinger said today that improved American relations with the Soviet Union were possible only so long as Moscow maintained a "responsible course" in the Middle East.
Irving H. (Larry) Larom, who from 1915 to 1969 ran Valley Ranch, a dude ranch near here, acting as host to many socially prominent New Yorkers, died Sunday at the age of 84.

New York State's new commissioner of Environmental Conservation charged yesterday that the energy crisis had been "overblown and exaggerated," and said he saw no need to extend the emergency variance granted Consolidated Edison to burn dirtier fuel oil and coal.
In its first decision regulating he quality of rail travel, the Interstate Commerce Commistion issued today detailed rules requiring nationwide

The Rev. Daniel Berrigan has rejected the Gandhi Peace Prize. The directors of the organization that was going to make the award - Promoting Enduring Peace - were reconsidering it in light of a recent speech by Father Berrigan that had been criticized as antiIsrael and anti-Jewish.
President Nixon began a post-Christmas vacation at his San Clemente estate today convinced, as one aide said, that his trip across the country by commercial jet had "scored points with the public."

The director of the Southern California region of the Veterans Administration, Gordon Elliott, has been replaced following delayed payments to thousands of student veterans for months, incurring the anger of President Nixen.

Federal and state legislation will be sought to bar public utilities from turning off power or heat to residential customers for nonpayment of bills without first notifying police or welfare officials, several legislators said yesterday.
A technique of screening human semen has been developed that, the experimenters believe, can increase sharply the likelihood that a couple desiring to produce a boy rather than a girl can do so.

Scoring their biggest advance in more than five months, prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to rise yesterday for the second straight session. Prices in the over-the-counter market also rose.

Miss Charlotte Anne Leidy and Wilhelmus Bogart Bryan 3d, both of New York, were married here yesterday afternoon in the Side Chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Kenneth 0. Jones.

The Akron Chamber of Commerce announced today that it was ending all financial and admnistrative responsibility for the AllAmerican Soap Box Derby. It said the event had been killed by "cheating, faud and hoax."

In "Dos Mundos," the exhibition by 12 Puerto Rican photographers now on view at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle, the point is too rigorously and too easily driven home--the point being the contrast of life-styles in the Caribbean island and in the barrios of New York - but the show is a forceful and interesting documentary nevertheless.
C. Arnholt Smith informed the National League today that he had sold the Padres baseball club to a Los Angeles group without the league's blessing. The group intends to keep the team in San Diego.
Bob Lanier and George Trapp led a fourth-quarter rally tonight that helped the Detroit Pistons to 10 consecutive points and a 102-93 National Basketball Association victory over the Capital Bullets.
Three young Americans convicted of smuggling 225 pounds of hashish into Turkey from Syria were sentenced to death by a Turkish court today. The court then commuted their sentences to life in prison.

The Walker Chapel of the First Congregational Church here was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Mrs. Florence Wheeler Everson of Pine Orchard to Walter Frank Denton of Waterbury. The Rev. Roger Manners performed the ceremony.

The Power Authority of the State of New York said yesterday that it had asked the 42 municipal and rural cooperative customers who are wholesale purchasers of its power to reduce their voltage by 3 per cent to consrve energy. The action was taken in cooperation with statewide voltage-reduction measures undertaken by other utilities.

The Justice Department made public today examples of how it puts a stop to corporate activities it objects to. The department released a Collection of letters it had sent to various companies over the last six years.

The fact that the Columbia Broadcasting System's respected news omnibus, "60 Minutes," must hibernate each year for the duration of the professional football season illustrate the priorities of the television business.

Two Roman Catholic priests from this northern Spanish town have been sent to monasteries for a month's detention after failing to pay fines imposed on them for assisting a strike last October, informed sources said today.

The financially troubled Kenton Corporation, which operates a chain of 33 discount stores and Cartier and several other prestige stores in New York, announced yesterday that it would file a petition under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act early next week.

Opening a rugged eightday stretch during which they play six National Basketball Association games, the Knicks expect to have Dean Meminger and Phil Jackson available for service this afternoon when they face the Philadelphia 76ers at Madison Square Garden.
As motorists formed lines as much as six blocks yesterday at gasoline stations that remained open in the metropolitan area, Federal and state officials warned of increased measures against gasoline
Three sleeping cars of the Coast Starlight Amtrak train, carrying 400 holiday travelers at 60 miles an hour, jumped the tracks and overturned today, injuring 80 persons.
The Defense Department announced today plans to testfire Minuteman missiles without nuclear warheads from an Air Force base in Montana over five Western states into the Pacific Ocean.

Campus radicals of the nineteen-sixties were the offspring, literally and figuratively, of the campus radicals of the nineteen-thirties, and the large number of common traits suggests that radical movements may be a recurring pattern, a professor at Michigan State University said today.
Rickie Hawthorne, a sophomore, made two free throws with 12 seconds remaining tonight, enabling California to edge Penn State, 64-63, in the semifinal round of the Quaker City basketball tournament.

The United States Court of Appeals here ordered today that E. Howard Hunt, Jr. and Bernard L. Barker be released from prison without bail pending the appeal of their conviction in the Watergate case. The court gave no reason for its decision.

If someone had asked Ely Culbertson, in his heyday four decades ago, to suggest his most likely successor at the top of the bridge ladder he would not have named Charles Goren, then a littleknown protege of Milton C. Work.
A basketball game between St. John's and Manhattan, the first since the 1962-63 season, will be played tonight in the final of the Holiday Festival Tournament at Madison Square Garden.

United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern said today that his office. would follow up on the new disclosures of alleged extortions by New Jersey political figures that have been unveiled by a special Philadelphia grand jury.

Not for six years, and perhaps not for 25 years, has Israel found itself in such a state of political convulsion and uncertainty. Monday's quadrennial election will almost certainly not set a decisive policy for the nation's future, but the government that emerges will have the responsibility for negotiating the peace settlement that has eluded Israel for so long.
A passer-by on the ChampsElysees was short to death today during a gun battle between policemen and robbers who had held up the newspaper Le Figaro.

Despite rumors that he is being considered by the New York Giants to be their next head coach, Darrell Royal of the Texas Longhorns said yesterday in Austin, Tex., that he had not heard from anyone connected with the football Giants.
The stock market's year-end rally sputtered a bit yesterday, but some leading gold issues traded at their highest prices on record.
The General Assembly Hall of the United Nations had never been opened to the public for a cultural performance before Thursday.

Secretary of State Kissinger went to some pains in Brussels and London this month to assure the "European Community" and its chief new member, Britain, that the United States still favors West Europe's evolving union. He gave special welcome to the Common Market's enlargement from six nations to nine.

Ice jams on the Mohawk River created a flood threat yesterday for the low-lying communities of Cohoes and Waterford, near Albany. Concern centered on two ice jams that merged late Thursday under twin bridges of the Adirondack Northway.

The State Court of Appeals ruled 4 to 3 today that the widow of a state employee held hostage during the 1971 rebellion at tile Attica Correctional Facility and killed when troopers quelled the rebellion with gunfire could sue the state.
A salesman was shot and wounded shortly before midnight last night in his home Here when he tossed a coffee pot at one of two burglars he surprised when the family came home.
The nation's six largest manufacturers of building supplies say they will put a vigorous defense against Government charges that they have fixed prices on gypsum board since 1960.

The new 72-foot sloop Helsal from Sydney was 140 miles from the finish in the Sydney-to-Hobart yacht race tonight and seemed headed for a race record. The United States yacht Ondine set the record in 1962-3 days 3 hours 46 minutes 16 seconds.

A collection of speeches, conversations and directives of Mao Tse-tung, printed for limited circulation in China, has come into the hands of scholars here. The documents provide intimate glimpses into the personality of Chairman Mao, and as scholars study them, they are expected to shed light on doctrinal disputes within the Chinese Communist party.

A state appeals court yesterday upheld the conviction of a state trooper for misconduct in office in connection with the alleged branding of an Ocean County man. The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 206.6 from 205.4 last week. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 131.6 on Dec. 26, 1972.
Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of those short-term securities.
The latest closing of a thoroughbred racing season in this state will occur today when the New York Racing Association presents its final 1973 card at Aquaduct.

Paul H. Hedrick, former president of Hedrick Johnson, a now-defunct New York advertising agency, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 75 years old and lived at 7 Spruce Hill Road.

Army officials are trying to find out whether a recent upturn in recruiting was spurred by fears of economic recession. The Recruiting Command has been told to gather information on this from new volunteers entering the service, sources said.

Ashby Lee Biedler, president of the Ashby Lee Biedler insurance agency in New York City, ( a business founded by his fatheir in 1894, died yesterday at his home, 20 Church Street. He was 76 years old.

Dr. Melitta Sperling, a former clinical professor of psychiatry at the Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn, and a Freudian psychanalyst, died yesterday at her home, 960 Park Avenue. She was 74 years old.
The General Motors Corporation announced today that it planned to lay off 86,000 workers because of the drop in sales of its standard-size cars resulting from the energy crisis.
Norman J. Marsh, who retired as a New York stockbroker in 1970, died Wednesday in Pawling. He was 79 years old and lived here.
Mayor Lindsay, in the waning hours of his administration, announced yesterday that new one-year contracts had been negotiated with the city's policemen, sanitationmen and correction officers.

John Newcombe, Evonne Goolagong, Jimmy Connors and Chris Evert continued the Australian-American domination of the Australian Open, the first of tennis's Big Foui tournaments, today. But a weary Bjorn Borg and a weakened Peggy Michel were ousted.
The Oakland Raiders could boycott Sunday's American Conference championship game with Miami and picket the Orange Bowl with signs proclaiming, "Dolphins Unfair to Visiting Teams."

Frank S. Hogan, who on Wednesday announced his resignation as Manhattan District Attorney after nearly 32 years in the office, has been admitted again to St. Luke's Hospital, where his condition was reported as serious yesterday.

The Pacific Lighting Corporation announced yesterday that its subsidiary, the Pacific Lighting Marine Company, had contracted with the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Chester, Pa., for the construction of two liquefied natural gas ships and an option for three additional vessels.
A lawsuit seeking access to the Vice-Presidential papers donated by President Nixon to the National Archives was filed today in United States District Court here.
An inmate at the Trenton State Prison was found scalded to death in his cell today, prison officials reported.

Frank Bagolie, Western manager in Canada for the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union for the last 12 years, covering the provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Winnipeg. He was 64 years old and made his home in Winnipeg.
Egypt said today that her troops shot down an Israeli plane that intruded over Egyptian lines this morning near the city of Suez at the southern end of the Suez Canal.

A West German industrialist who is also his country's honorary consul here was kidnapped from his home last night.

Heavy fighting broke out yesterday in South Vietnam's Central Highlands near the Cambodian border, after a lull of more than two weeks, the Saigon command said today.

Pierre Plante' two goals in the second period tonight gave the St. Louis Blues a 3-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

Some 900 members of Local 1150, Communications Workers of. America, walked off the job yesterday morning in a dispute with the American Telephone Telegraph Company over the suspension of a shop steward, the company said.

Government figures covering all Christmas shopping days except last Monday showed today that, except for a big decline in sales of autos and related items such as gasoline, this was a fairly strong though not sensational Christmas season for the stores.

New mortgage loans made by the state's savings banks in November amounted to $447-million, the Savings Banks Association of New York State reported yesterday. The ever-bolder critics of the government of President Park Chung Hee of South Korea have been warned that they had better not go too far. Premier Kim Jong Pil warned protesters, particularly a group of civic, educational and religious leaders, that restriction of some democratic freedoms was needed to insure political and social stability for continued economic growth, and to maintain security against a serious threat from North Korea.

WHEN the new year bows in at midnight tomorrow, there is bound to be a note of hopeful optimism sounding in the toasts raised by investors and those who labor in the vineyards of the various security, financial, foreign-exchange and commodity markets.

Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Holmes Hathaway have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laurie Ann Hathaway, to Robert Lloyd Lawrence. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Tharp Lawrence Jr. Both families live here. A June wedding is planned.

Mrs. Evelena Stevens Kenworthy and James Lowell Oakes of Brattleboro, a judge of the United States Circuit Court, were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride by the Rev. Fred H. Miller, retired Minister of All Souls Unitarian - Universalist Church in Brattleboro.

The state's Court on the Judiciary voted unanimously yesterday to remove Supreme Court Justice Joseph Pfingst of Babylon, L. I., from office. Mr. Pfingst was convicted in Federal Court in July, 1972, on three counts of a nine-count indictment involving conspiracy in the concealment of assets in a bankruptcy case.

The head of the State House of Representatives' special committee investigating state leases has labeled as a "sweetheart contract" a $4.2-million state lease on a building purchased with a $100,000 investment by two men close to Gov. Milton J. Shapp, a Democrat.

Charitable organizations throughout New Jersey were deluged with unprecedented demands for food and clothing at Christmas, and officials attribute the growing requests for aid to mushrooming unemployment, inflation and the energy crisis.

The United States became the first signer yesterday of a treaty that aims to protect diplomats from terrorist attacks and threats. The treaty was completed at the recent General Assembly and will go into effect 30 days after ratification by 22 governments.

Three scientists working at a laboratory in Germany have apparently come close to eliminating the major mystery of human birth - Will it be a boy or a girl? FOR most sober Americans, mere are three central problems: national politics, world politics and Richard Nixon. The first two meet. interact and come together in a thousand important ways. Using the city of Chelm as his locale this famous Yiddish storyteller recounts a series of anecdotes about government by fools. A 61-year-old woman who had reportedly been suffering from depression apparently jumped to her death early yesterday from her Park Avenue apartment, the police 'said.
David M. Daynard, a business broker specializing in properties in publishing, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 55 Centrial Park West.

And now to conference play. With the holiday tournaments behind them, most of the college basketball teams will start playing league games Saturday.
Efforts were made today to clean up a 12mile trail of oil spilled in the collision of a Navy cargo ship and a Liberian freighter off California's coast.

The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.
James B. Moore Jr. moved into the Inter Club class lead today by finishing third in the 43d annual frostbite regatta on Manbasset Bay. The one race held was won by Randy Bartholomew.

The marriage of Miss Deborah Joy Garber, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. Harry Douglas Garber, to Douglas Walker MacKelcan Jr., director of admissions and an instructor in history at the University-Liggett School in Grosse Pointe, Mich.,
The owner of a marina here last night shot two men he said were breaking into his storage facilities, critically wounding one and killing the second, the Suffolk County police said today.

On the eve of a new administration w in New York City, some top members of Mayor Lindsay's cabinet have warned that the impact of Federal policies on the life and destiny of the city is equal to, and possibly greater than, that of City Hall.
As a New Year begins, members of Congress are finding that the home folks are not necessarily more interested in impeaching Richard Nixon than they are in the shortages of gasoline and fuel oil.

Governor Wilson yesterday appointed Harold A. Stevens and Samuel Rabin, who are the Presiding Justices of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court in the First and Second Departments, as associate judges of the Court of Appeals.

America's tennis sweethearts, Chris Evert and Jimmy Connors, each reached the finals today in the $74,500 Australian open tennis championships. Chris Evert and her fiance, Jimmy Connors, defeating their respective opponents, Julie Heldman and John Alexander, in the semifinals of the Australian open tennis championships yesterday in Melbourne.
Police Commissioner Robert diGrazia said yesterday that the way statistics were reported caused distortions in American urban crime rates announced recently by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

In another challenge to the male-only policies of the service academies, Representative William J.. Hungate, Democrat of Missouri, said today that he had nominated an 18-year-old girl to the Air Force Academy.
Steve Kuberski squeezing between Tom Van Arsdale, front, and Steve Mix of the 76ers yesterday to shoot for Celtics at the Boston Garden. The Celtics won, 106-97.

Christopher William Coates, retired director of the New York Aquarium, at Coney Island, who helped make it one of the city's major attractions with strange and fascinating creatures from the sea, died Sunday in a hospital in East Stroudsburg, Pa. He was 74 years old. Christopher W. Coates

In a modest two-minute ceremony in his rented apartment in the Belle Harbor section of Queens, Abraham D. Beame was sworn in last night as the 104th Mayor of New York City, six hours before he officially took office at midnight. Abraham D. Beame being sworn in as Mayor in his apartment in Queens by Surrogate Nathan R. sobel

Harry Vann says he drove into this city from Montezuma, Kan., on a sunny Monday afternoon last August, walked into a flashy strip joint on Main Street and for one night in his life was a high-rolling spender.

As the old year slipped away, President Nixon signed today 19 pieces of legislation, including a widened program of Federal flood insurance. Working at his oceanside villa at San Clemente, 10 miles south of here, the President also conferred with Secretary of State Kissinger, who flew to California last night on a commercial airliner.

In the Orange Bowl where the No. 1 collegiate ranking is not at stake, Penn State, undefeated and untied, is about a onetouchdown favorite to beat Louisiana State University tomorrow night. Joe Paterno, left, Penn State coach, and Tom Shuman, quarterback, at workout last week in Miami.

Sandy Hawley closed his record-setting year at Laurel Race Course today with one winner for a total of 515. Hawley rode Third Law in the sixth race for his final triumph of the year. George Cusimano piloted George E. Clark Jr.'s Son O'Fancy to victory in the $29,200 Monumental Handicap. A crowd of 11,826 turned out in the rain for the next-to-last program of the meeting.

SEN. SAM J. ERVIN JR. Democrat of North Carolina My main objective is to wind up the investigation of Watergate, to make a report to the Senate and to make recommendations about some new legislation that would prevent future Watergates or punish adequately the people who are responsible for them.

Ohio State, bent on restoring the Big Ten's prestige, seeks revenge tomorrow against Southern California in the 60th Rose Bowl game. The Buckeves (9-0-1 wonlost tied record) are rated 2point favorites over the Trojans (9-1-1). A near-capacity crowd of 104,700 is expected for the nation's premier bowl attraction, dating back to 1902.

The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine has claimed responsibility for yesterday's attempt on the life of one of the most prominent members of the Jewish community in Britain, Joseph Edward Sieff.

The search for possible victims or carriers of an infectious ty phoid outbreak traced to a church supper in Burlington on Nov. 4 has narrowed down to six unknown individuals whose existence may be only "theoretical." The typhoid bacillus
William L. Day, a banker who was chairman of the board of trustees of the University of Pennsylvania, died here today while on vacation. He was 66 years old and lived in Devon, Pa.

Conversation in the Gagg household is strictly sports and the decor tells why. In the living room of the home in Butler, N. J., there are 95 trophies for sports, most of them awarded to the four oldest sons.
The General Assembly's Public Health and Safety Committee has drawn up a number of bills dealing with the fluoridation of public drinking water.

A student kidnapped from a birthday party was found today, locked in an automobile trunk. The officials said 20year-old Kathy L. Morris was in good condition. She was found after someone heard her cries, the police said.

Premier Golda Meir's Labor party appeared to have suffered a slight setback in Israel's crucial parliamentary elections, but appeared likely to retain its dominant position in the Government. In heavy balloting, Labor lost votes to smaller parties on the right and left, and to the Likud, the rightist alliance that was the principal opposition group.

Volume on the American Stock Exchange reached a record for the year of 6,546,000 shares yesterday as prices rose sharply. Trading was the heavies since 10,306,000 shares were sold on Dec. 29. 1972. Prices also rose in the over-thecounter market.
Senegal's chief delegate to the United Nations said today that he and his mission had been targets of "various hostile acts" by the police and people in New York.
A law firm filed a $270-billion lawsuit today charging 12 major oil companies with artificially creating the fuel shortage in order to raise profits.
James H. McDonald, holder of the Medal of Honor, died Saturday at Charles Cole Memorial Hospital. He was 73 years old and had been retired from the Navy after a 33-year career.

Two leading steel executives said yesterday that the nation's steel, industry might work at close to capacity levels for the second consecutive year in 1974. Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said in a year-end statement: "It is an odds-on possibility that 1974 could be another year of steel production at a level close to the maximum-output of the industry." Edgar B. Speer

" It's very mean today," said tile small middle-aged man pumping gasoline. "They want more than their $3 worth anti they get mad and yell at you and treat you like a dog. They're worse than animals. Crude-oil prices in some producing countries rose by 60 to 80 per cent to record levels effective today as Libya, Indonesia, Nigeria and Bolivia adjusted their export prices following a pattern set by the major Persian Gulf producers a week ago.
The Manchester Union Leader today printed a front-page retraction of charges that President Nixon's long-time associate, Murray Chotiner, organized the Watergate bugging incident.
Robert E. Mercer has been named president of the KellySpringfield Tire Company. He succeeds J. Carson Dowell as head of the company, a subsidiary of the Goodyear Tire Rubber Company.
The Soviet Union ended 1973 on a wave of confidence, playing up its own gains against the disarray of the Western alliance and exulting in the chaos caused by the energy crisis in the West.

In an atmosphere of good cheer and fellowship, the City Council yesterday overrode Mayor Lindsay's veto and gave the eight members of the Board of Estimate salary increases of $10,000 each. The vote was 31 to 3, with 25 votes needed for the override. Thomas J. Cuite, City Council majority leader, calling for a vote to override Mayor Lindsay's veto on raising the salaries of Board of Estimate members.

To the Editor: Without even the consolation of news coverage, a quiet tragedy is taking shape. The World Food Program, already crippled this year by skyrocketing food prices, is preparing to play a diminished role in the fight against hunger.

The Chilean Government has guaranteed safe-conduct out of Chile to 191 people taking refuge in the French Embassy in Santiago, but the fate of 29 others there remains in doubt, the French Ambassador to Chile, Pierre de Menthon, said today.

James E. Morrow. the Conservative party candidate in one of last year's disputed Assembly races, swore in a notorized statement filed with the Board of Elections here today that he had received a total of $3,300 from former Assemblyman Stanley Harwood, a Democrat.

Citing the growing Importance of community boards in the city's government, the Board of Ethics has set forth some general principles to guide members of Community Boards in areas where there may be potential conflicts of interest.

The New York City Ballet will revert to repertory next Tuesday after 31 performances of "The Nutcracker" at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center with "The Goldberg Variations" and the "Irish Fantasy" as the opening program.

Premier Fidel Castro has told Cuban troops that the nation still faced the danger of military aggression from the United States. "On several occasions we have been in real danger of a direct aggression by the armed forces of the United States," Premier Castro said in a speech to the troops yesterday.

Miss Helga-Luise Zimmermann, daughter of Mrs. Wilhelm Zimmermann of Munich, West Germany, and the late Mr. Zimmermann, was married here this afternoon to Thomas Forrest Thurston of Bryant Pond, Me., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Ralph Thurston Jr. of Smoke Rise.

The police said a youth walked away from a state school yesterday and stole a mobile home and new police car before he was apprehended. Authorities said the 13-year oll boy, whose name was not disclosed, fled the state Agricultural and Industrial School at nearby Industry.

Dr. Leander H. Shearer, former president of the medical board of Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, died yesterday at the Princeton Medical Center. His age was 97 and he lived here.

The driver of a New Jersey charter bus was arrested on the Cross Westchester Expressway last Sunday and was charged with speeding and driving ,with a revoked license. The bus was carrying 39 passengers.

A 74-year-old woman who had worked since childhood in a dry-goods store in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn was found beaten to death there yesterday, an apparent robbey victim.

Dr. Carl T. Parsons, an entomologist who taught at the University of Vermont and more recently did private research here, died, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday at the Dorset Field Club in Dorset. He was 59 years old.
The 15-man Northern Ireland executive was sworn in here today. It will take over much of the administration of the troubled province tomorrow after 21 months of direct rule from London.

The passing of the old year has more than transient significance for Americans this New Year's Day. With 1973, an era died, an era of profligacy unprecedented in human experience when most Americans embarked on an orgy of consumption, following the lean years of the Depression and World War II.

Dark shadows cling to the snowfringed mountains at 3 in the afternoon. By 5 P.M. this valley is dark and silent except for the bells on Buddhist temples tinkling in the icy breeze, the temple drums tapped by lamas and an abrupt, lonely jeep horn carried on the wind.

A group of 15 elder politicians, religious leaders and prominent intellectuals today sent a letter to President Park Chung Hee asking for the restoration of a "genuine democracy" guaranteeing people's basic rights, and requesting a meeting with him.

An Egyptian writer on military affairs appeared today to confirm reports that a route for delivery of military supplies had been opened to units of Egypt's Third Army, cut off in the Sinai Peninsula in October by an Israeli thrust west of the Suez Canal.

The great majority of East Jerusalem's Arabs boycotted today's municipal election, setting back Israeli hopes for advancing the integration of the city under Israeli rule. Jerusalem was divided between Israel and Jordan until the 1967 war.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, following 'other major producers, announced yesterday that it would apply a scrap surcharge on some of its products in accordance with a recent Cost of Living Council decision permitting price increases to reflect higher prices for steel scrap.

Employment reached a record high in New Jersey in November and the number of unemployed workers was also up, according to the State Department of Labor and Industry. Labor and Industry Commissioner Ronald Heymann noted, however, that the record November employment figure did not reflect the latest developments in the energy crisis. He said that if the crisis intensified, the employment picture could take a downturn.
