Nearly 200,000 aged, blind and disabled poor people in the city move today from the welfare system to the new Federal Supplemental Security Income program, but the transition has run into problems.

Joanne D. Chesimard and four others suspected of being members of the Black Liberation Army were indicted yesterday on charges of attempting to shoot and kill two Queens policemen from ambush last Jan, 28.
Henri Bus ser, a French composer and former director of the Paris Opera died at his home last night, 1 days before his 102d birthday

A high Soviet health official has criticized his country's pharmaceutical industry for delays in bringing newly developed drugs to the consumer. The criticism of the Soviet Union's state-controlled prescription-drug industry, published in the Government newspaper Izvestia, comes at a time when profit-oriented American industry is under attack by Congress and consumer groups for high prices charged for drugs.

Premier Golda Meir's Labor party lost ground in Israel's crucial parliamentary elections, but appeared certain of dominating the next coalition Government. In heavy balloting, Labor lost votes to smaller parties on the right and left. The Likud, the rightist alliance that was the principal opposition group, gained at Labor's expense.

A key Government official predicted today that the prices of gasoline, heating oil and diesel fuel would rise by 10 cents a gallon in January and February. Charles R. Owens, Federal Energy Office spokesman, at his news conference yesterday in Washington.

Dr. J. Salwyn Schapiro, emeritus professor of history at City College, where he led four decades of students through the intricacies of European politics, died Sunday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 45 Christopher Street.
The new Federal income tax forms that 81 million Americans are beginning to receive in the mail have been shortened in some categories, according to the Internal Revenue Service.

The United States Government, which has been holding secret talks with the Peruvian Government on amumber of issues, is not expected to apply economic sanctions against Peru because of the nationalization of the Cerro de Pasco Corporation today.

Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said last night that he would ask the M.T.A.'s board of directors to extend indefinitely the Sunday half-fare bargain and exapnd it to include other holidays and even some weekdays.
Cesar Cedeno, the Houston Astro center fielder, was freed on bail today to await trial for involuntary manslaughter in the fatal shooting of a 19-year-old woman in a motel room here.

The three-day work week arrived in Britain today, sharply reducing industrial output and cutting the wages of millions in the most drastic program yet undertaken by any nation to cope with the energy crisis.

Wakening in the night now and hearing the silence, it seems impossible that this was such a busy, noisy world only a few months ago. The summer birds have gone south, The summer insects have lived their brief lives and died or hibernated. The winter animals are silent as starlight. This is the time of the New Year.

Skylab 3's astronauts had a day full of New Years today. The three--Lieut. Col. Gerald P. Carr of the Marines, Lieut. Col. William R. Pogue of the Air Force and Dr. Edward G. Gibson, a civilian scientist passed back and forth between the new year and the old 16 times as their orbiting space station crossed each of the world's time zones once every 93 minutes.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and the Midwest Oil Corporation, 95 per cent owned by Indiana Stahdard, said yesterday they had settled, subject to court approval, a lawsuit filed in Denver in 1971 by present and former Midwest shareholders.

The United Brands Company announced yesterday that it would close its Revere Sugar Refinery in Charlestown, Mass., but meanwhile the company is trying to find a buyer for the facility, an employer of 503 persons.

Gold ended the year at a new four-month high on the London bullion market to-, day. The dollar finished the year marginally up in Frankfurt but slightly down in London and Amsterdam. America's tennis sweethearts, Chris Evert and Jimmy Connors, each reached the finals today in the $74,500 Australian open tennis championships. Chris Evert and her fiance, Jimmy Connors, defeating their respective opponents, Julie Heldman and John Alexander, in the semifinals of the Australian open tennis championships yesterday in Melbourne.

Rebel gunners pressed their dry-season offensive against the Government of President Lon Nol today with rocket and hand-grenade attacks against Phnom Penh, killing two women and seven children, according to official reports.

Consolidated Edison said yesterday that it expected to be burning coal at its Arthur Kill No. 3 plant on Staten Island by Feb. 1. A spokesman said that the utility already had more than 15,000 tons of coal on hand but needed a 20-day stockpile 60,000 to 70,000 tons - to make sure the plant would not run out of fuel.

In a modest two-minute ceremony in his rented apartment in the Belle Harbor section of Queens, Abraham D. Beame was sworn in last night as the 104th Mayor of New York City, six hours before he officially took office at midnight.

The crash last Oct. 2 of a police helicopter in which two policemen were killed was caused by mechanical failure in the drive shaft, not by bullets from a sniper's gun, as the police had previously thought, according to the National Transportation Safety Board.

A serpentine road rises perilously from Phuntsholing, on the Indian plains, to the Thimphu Valley. It is a bumpy six-hour jeep ride deep into the Himalayas, a trip over lofty ranges marked with glacier-fed streams and deep glens. Nepalese laborers in Thimphu, Bhutan. Brought in as itinerants to build the 127-mile road from Phuntsholing, they are poorly paid, live in squalid conditions and are multiplying more rapidly than the native Bhutanese.
Starting next July. all Federal departments and agencies housed in Government-owned buildings maintained by the General Service Administration will begin paying rent to tile administration.

Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne's plan to call a special legislative session to deal with school finances and tax reform drew a mixed reaction today from legislative leaders.

Wheat futures prices rose 15 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Trading closed at noon because of the holiday today. In the soybean pit, beans, meal and oil prices were down, but in the other pits corn and oats were irregular. Iced broilers were unchanged to about half a cent a pound higher in extremely light trading.

Wall Street sources said yesterday the American Financial Corporation, a Cincinnati-based holding company, was engaged in negotiating for a major infusion of capital into Shearson, Hammill Co., Inc., a large Wall Street securities firm.

Rutgers University overcame a New York Athletic Club lead in the last 500 meters yesterday and won the featured eight-oared race of the New Year's Eve Regatta on the Orchard Beach Lagoon in the Bronx.

That seems fair enough. The Dolphins are an imperturbable crowd going into their third straight Super Bowl. Dairy cattle on a farm in the Cobleskill area of New York. Outlook for dairy farmers in the state in 1974 is good.

A new 650-acre Federal wildlife refuge will be created at the mouth of the Salem River in South Jersey as soon as the land can be deeded over to the Government by Philadelphia Conservationists, Inc. Marshland at the mouth of the Salem River, part of a 650-acre wildlife refuge to be established when the land is deeded to the Government by Philadelphia Conservationists, Inc. The bargain Sunday fare on the Long Island Rail Road has more than doubled Sunday ridership, according to the latest count, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

Former Mayor John V. Lindsay, his wife, Mary, and their son, John Jr., left by plane for Puerto Rico yesterday afternoon to begin his first rest without official cares since 1965, when he was elected Mayor.

A three-judge Federal panel has struck down Georgia's election law, which bars married women from voting in the state when their husbands legally reside elsewhere. The lawsuit was filed in United States District Court here against state election officials in behalf of Mrs. Patricia Kane of Albany.

When James J. Braddock was an unemployed longshoreman on relief, he knocked out Corn Griffin in a semi-windup. "I did that on hash," he told his manager, Joe Gould. "Get me a piece of steak and see what I can do." Gould got him a piece of steak and he whipped Max Baer for the heavyweight championship of the world.

Charles E. Bohlen Ambassador and Mrs. Charles E. Bohlen at a ceremony in Red Square in Moscow in November, 1954. With them was their son, Charles E. Bohlen Jr.

Auto racing in France has been given a New Year's reprieve and all Le Mans is celebrating. A survey of 15,000 executives by an employment agency showed today that fat executives received less pay than lean ones did. "By exploiting the overweight, too many American companies are literally living off the fat of the land," said Robert Half, president of a New York-based company that finds jobs for financial and computer executives.

" Gulag Archipelago," Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's new history of Soviet police terror and the sub-human prison camp network, is less important for what it says than for what it leaves unsaid. This horrifyingly detailed account of repression in the Soviet Union from 1918 to 1956 takes on its real importance from the suggestion that the police system it describes continues to this day.

Premier Golda Meir watching the election returns being recorded at Labor party campaign center in Tel Aviv.

A television drama based on the 1951 trial of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, who were convicted as atomic spies and executed, will be produced for the American Broadcasting Company by the noted film maker Stanley Kramer.

Gabriel Tichi, a fire marshal, was to have retired this year after 25 years with the Walla Walla, Wash., fire department. But Mr. Tichi was killed early yesterday when the wall of a turningg two-story building colapsed.

For the ninth consecutive New Year's Day, the members of the Aquaholics, a local water skiing club, demonstrated their self-proclaimed cure for a hangover by water skiing in the 42-degree water of the Toms River. "If you have a pounding headache and you hit that water," said Edward F. O'Toole, a member of the club, "you have a new and more immediate problem to worry about-to get warm."
Mrs. Elizabeth Kuhn Blum, widow of Alexander Blum, a stockbroker, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived at 1112 Park Avenue.

An ominous new rise during the last two months in prices of "commodities" - things grown on the earth or dug from the earth-has increased prospects for inflation in 1974, in the view of private and government economists.

Owen Adrian, left, and Richard Sirois, plant manager, at work in the boiler room of the Lawrence Park Heat, Light and Power Company in Bronxville, N. Y. BAN PAK-OU, Laos-The people in the Government-held areas of Luang Prabang Province have accepted the presence of the Communist-led Pathet Lao as calmly as they accept the silver-gray mist that floats down from the mountains and chills the towns until about 10 o'clock on most winter mornings.

The Colombian Davis Cup team is depending heavily on the altitude of this city and the coaching help of two Chileans, Jaime Fillol and Patricio Cornejo, to beat the United States team in the Davis Cup American Zone final.

The Pakistani Government today nationalized all Pakistani banks, shipping lines and leading oil distribution companies. Foreign banks were not affected except that they will no longer be permitted to establish new branches. Finance Minister Mubashir Hasan said the nationalization of the banks would lay a solid foundation for the balanced economic growth of the country.

PLAINVIEW, L. I. - An unusual public survey sponsored by thie Plainview .School District has produced some contradictory findings, according to results released this wePk. :
Jan. 1-Randy Bartholomew won four of today's six races to capture Interclub class dinghy honors as the 43d annual New Year's Frostbite regatta ended a three-day stand on Manhasset Bay.

Joseph Edward Sieff, the prominent British Zionist and chainstore executive shot by an Arab guerrilla two days ago, continued to make good progress in a hospital today and was removed from the intensive care unit.

The Labor party today is like a person who has come through a terrible automobile accident with only a broken arm," a senior party official observed today. Menahem Begin, leader of the Likud, the major opposition group in Israel, getting a report yesterday.

An Orient Point, L. I., ferryboat that ran aground with 43 persons aboard New Year's Eve was refloated at high tide early yesterday, but not before a Coast Guard cutter also was damaged in a rescue attempt. The Coast Guard said no one was injured.
Maybe it was what Coach Ara Parseghian had felt all along-that this Notre Dame team, despite its youth, was just loose enough, just cool enough to pull off anything under pressure. Anything.
Economists, like inveterate horse players, cannot kick the forecasting habit, no matter how badly they have been doing lately. It was indeed a penitent and humble band of economists who
Two persons - an 8-year-old girl and a 17-year-old youth were killed by gunshots fired joyfully in the streets of Naples last midnight. More than 100 people were injured during the celebration.
A South Korean Army sergeant shot upa tea room in Taegu last night, seized about 30 hostages and still was holding off 200 policemen and military policemen this afternoon, the Defense Ministry said.

Quick Fare gave her owner, E. Gay Drake, a surprise New Year's Day present today at Liberty Bell Park when she rallied from off the pace to register a head victory in the fifth running of the $27,950 New Hope Stakes.

The opening today of the Internationally controlled yellowfin tuna fishing season in the eastern Pacific found the American tuna fleet immobilized at its berths here by a deadlock over the price that canneries will pay for the fleet's catch in 1974.

A pollster asks 3,000 people whom they favor for Mayor and then predicts that Abraham D. Beame will get such and such per cent of the vote, John Marchi so much, Albert H. Blumenthal so much and Mario Biaggi so much. How many long-distance phone calls will be made? Telephone people seek probabilistic answers to this question, and they keep detailed records in their quest.
Seatrain Lines, Inc., has sold its 225,000-ton supertanker, "Brooklyn," to the General Electric Credit Corporation, one of the nation's largest leasing companies.

Gunmen assassinated a local leader of Prime Minister Mujibur Rahman's party last night and wounded the Premier's political secretary. The dead man was Zuhurul Islam Chowdhury, secretary general of the local branch of the ruling Awami League in Bhola, about 70 miles south of Dacca, where the shooting occurred.

About 55 inmates of the maximum security section of the Adult Correctional Institutions in Cranston refused to return to their cells after supper tonight. The men, all awaiting trials, demanded more recreation time.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer semifinals get under way at the Orange Bowl in Miami tonight, with Brown meeting St. Louis and Clemson taking on the University of California, Los Angeles. The winners will meet for the university division title on Friday night.

Sandy Hawley, who established a world record by riding 515 winners during 1973, opened the new year at Laurel Race Course today with three winners. Hawley rode Mrs. Jay Newmeyer's Jane Lacey in the Happy New Year race, the featured eighth race, to an $18.60-for-$2 triumph.

The Nassau County Executive, Ralph G. Caso, who started his second term in office today, is hinting that he might not complete his new term if an appropriate Federal office became available in a new Republican Administration.

Queen Elizabeth's New Year's honors list today awarded recognition to the Government's troubleshooter, William Whitelaw; a leading trade unionist, Victor Feather, William Whitelaw, top left, Victor Feather and Bobby Chariton, right, were honored by Queen Elizabeth.

1-President Nixon's appointment of his wife to serve on a national advisory council was illegal, the White House said today. A Presidential spokesman said that the law prohibited the President from appointing his wife to a Governmenl position, and therefore Mrs. Nixon could not serve on the new 25-member National Voluntary Service Advisory Council.
Sam McBride, who owns the first gasoline station to be closed down for energy-crisis price violations, says he will not abide by court orders because neither does President Nixon.
Columbia University announced yesterday the appointment of 50 editors and writers as jurors for the 1974 Pulitzer Prizes in journalism.

A court security program featuring intercom systems for judges to summon help during disturbances and the experimental use of metal detectors to keep weapons out of courtrooms-will be instituted here this month.
Six Spanish Basque refugees were rounded up in the French Basque country before dawn today and sent under police guard to live in northern France, far from the Spanish border.

A 12year-old girl who defied her teacher in primary school is the latest hero of China's growing campaign against so-called reactionary tendencies-a campaign that bears some similarity to the one that launched the Cultural Revolution in 1966.
To the Editor: The House has moved to extend 1975 "interim" Federal emissions standards for an additional two years to cover 1976- and 1977-model passenger cars.

In a move of major| political import, the Chinese leadership has put into effect a sweeping reshuffle of positions among the nation's top' military leaders, a dispatch, from Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency, revealed this morning.
Despite snow and gasoline shortages, this Adirondack village's officials turned in a major effort to stage the East's first three major skiing events yesterday and today.
The soviet union, moving ahead with an active nuclearpower program, has started up the world's northernmost reactor, in a remote corner of Siberia facing Alaska.

A state commission said yesterday that the controversial vacancy - decontrol law had not only "failed to spur" landlords to make major improvements in existing housing here, but had, in fact, been accompanied by a significant decrease in such improvements.

It's over now--the adventure that was the Lindsay years. John Vliet Lindsay's election in 1965 was something of a political miracle. He appeared so young; he was so full of hopes and ideas. Besides, who had ever supposed a Republican would win in New York City?
A justice of the peace says the marriage business boomed last weekend and yesterday, thanks, in part, to Federal tax laws.
Fires in the United States in 1973 killed about 11,900 people, nearly the same number killed in fires in 1972, the National Fire Protection Association said yesterday.
Northern Ireland's new power-sharing executive took over the day-lo-da running of this British province today amid incidents of gunfire and bomb blasts.

Pope Paul VI urged Italians today to shun a "mafia-style mentality" of cunning, violence and vendettas. "This hurts our prestige as a nation and our honor as a people," the Pontiff told a congregation of 1,500 in the parish church of St. Anthony in the
Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira left Tokyo today for a four-day visit to Peking to sign a new Chinese-Japanese trade treaty, and try to negotiate a start of air service between the two countries.
A justice of the peace says the marriage business boomed last weekend and yesterday, thanks, in part, to Federal tax laws.
Fires in the United States in 1973 killed about 11,900 people, nearly the same number killed in fires in 1972, the National Fire Protection Association said yesterday.
Northern Ireland's new power-sharing executive took over the day-lo-da running of this British province today amid incidents of gunfire and bomb blasts.
New rules were announced yesterday to protect consumers in the state against unexpected gross overcharges by household movers and to set time limits in which loss and damage claims must be settled.

The police in Miami Beach and nearby Fort Lauderdale Beach used tear gas early today to break up rowdy crowds of young New Year's revelers who had spilled onto the streets and began blocking traffic and smashing car windows.
One of the warmest ovations at Mayor Beame's inauguration was accorded to the All City High School Chorus, made up of youngsters from all parts of the city and of various ethnic groups.
The opening of the trial of Joanne Chesimard and Clark E. Squire on murder and assault charges was delayed here today for 24 hours to permit the defendants to confer with their attorneys.

Likening New York City to a man who takes out a loan to buy a car and then floats additional loans to cover each interest payment as it comes due, a member of the City Planning Commission delivered a sharp criticism of the city's budgeting process yesterday.
Dave Wottle, the Olympic 800-meter champion and one of the world's top milers, said yesterday he was "thinking very strongly" about running as a professional this year.

The merger agreement between the American and National Basketball Associations, worked out more than three years ago but stillborn because Congress has not granted the antitrust exemption needed to make it possible, will expire officially on Friday.
Seven bombs exploded during the night at Larnaca, in southeast Cyprus, wrecking several cars and damaging houses. No one was hurt, the police said.

This article is the second of a series on the military factors in the Middle East conflict by the military correspondent of The New York Times, who recently concluded a tour of the battlefields and capitals in the area.

President Nixon signed today a bill requiring states to limit highway speeds to a maximum of 55 miles an hour as a condition for continuing to receive Federal highway trust funds.

Agreement to end a six-day partial walkout of long distance operators and craftsmen in New York was announced late yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. A management spokesman said the agreement had been reached when each side won the right to insert its own version of a dispute in the personnel file of a suspended shop steward.
George G. Montgomery, former board chairman of the Kern County Land Company here, died yesterday in Mills Memorial Hospital in San Mateo. He was 79 years old.
The city's two Culture Loop bus routes, continuing to grow in popularity, attracted 3,837 passengers at $1 each on the last weekend in 1973, the Transit Authority said last night.

Ralph Block, who was a screen producer, writer and critic, died today at a nursing home in Wheaton, Md. He was 84 years old. Mr. Block produced and wrote films in the nineteentwenties and thirties and was associated with W. C. Fields, the comedian, for whom he helped produce films, and with Carole Lombard, whom he employed on several pictures.

Chief Air Marshal Konstantin A. Vershinin, former commander of the Soviet Air Force, died Sunday in Moscow. He was 73 years old. A peasant's son and a shipyard laborer in his youth, Marshal Vershinin joined the air force in 1932 after graduation from the Zhukovsky Air Force Academy. He rose through staff

Treasury Officials met yesterday with New York City bank officials and leaders of the American Bankers Association, and broached a Federal proposal to ease check-cashing problems for recipients of Federal benefits.

The appointment of Howard Bishow as director of industrial relations of The New York Times was announced yesterday by John H. Mortimer, senior vice president for industrial relations. The 43-year-old Mr. Bishow, who has been director of personnel at The Times, will also be an assistant to Mr. Mortimer.

KENSINGTON, Callf.-The Western consumer has no access to oil-industry cost or oil-reserves data and only scant access to supply data. Nowhere has he sought legislation to insure that he will get this information-not in the United States, Canada or Western Europe. As a result, he is saddled with an oil-industry crisis; he is unaware that the world has been awash with crude oil this year.

Defense Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel will meet Secretary of State Kissinger in Washington on Friday, with the Nixon Administration reasonably certain that the results' of the Israeli election will not impede the current Middle East negotiations.

Courageous is back in the America's Cup picture, even though the syndicate behind the new aluminum 12-Meter insisted yesterday it would not make a final decision on the yacht's future until next Tuesday.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit ruled today that radio and television stations could broadcast winning lottery numbers in drawings conducted by states because they are "hot news." The unanimous decision overturned a lower court ruling that had upheld an order of the Federal Communications Commission.
The Skylab 3 crew reported today feeling changes of "almost a spiritual nature" in their views of themselves, of other humans and of the possibility of life existing elsewhere in the universe.

Neither rain nor snow, but a missing or incorrect address can keep Benjamin Meyerson from speeding mail to its destination. He is monarch of all he surveys, proud manager of the "Claims and Inquiry and Undeliverable Mail Section" - the dead letter office at the New York Post Office, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street.

James Saunders's "Next Time I'll Sing to You," which opened yesterday at the Billy Rose Theater, is a rare contemporary excursion for the City Center Acting Company. I mean the word "rare" in two senses, which is several senses fewer than Mr. Saunders means most of his words.

Drawings by member countries from the International Monetary Fund in 1973 were at their lowest level in 10 years, the fund reported today. Total drawings, or borrowings, last year amounted to the dollar equivalent of $884-million, the lowest since the $333-million figure of 1963. Drawings in 1972 had been more than $1.9-billion.

When the White House was in power, one of the most mean-spirited and petty abuses it was fairly accused of perpetrating was "the freeze-out"-a stern direction from on high to cut off some reporter or publication from all communication with White House aides, after a critical or unfair article or commentary appeared.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund reaped a $10 windfall yesterday. It was prompted by an unexpected act of kindness to Joan Walsh of Brooklyn, causing her to double her contribution this year.

Willie Mosconi, considered the leading pocket billiards player in modern history, and Rex Williams of Britain, holder of the world's professional snooker championship, will engage in an unusual series this month.
The easing of the great New Year's gasoline drought in the metropolitan area yesterday was marked by new deliveries of fuel and new warnings of shortages from service station operators.

Nine of the 16 seeded players were upset in the men's singles in the New South Wales open tennis championships today. And the top-seeded player, John Newcombe of Australia, withdrew because of a bruised heel. Newcombe's

Potato futures prices rose sharply yesterday with the May contract hitting $10.94 a hundredweight during the day and closing at a record of $10.77 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The previous high was $10.60 per hundred pounds reached last Friday.
A.C. Israel Co. and the Louis Dreyfus Corporation, both leading commodity trading houses, yesterday dissolved their joint venture, ACLI International, Inc.

Chessie System, Inc., the first major company to issue calendar 1973 results, reported yesterday the second highest 'fourth-quarter earnings and the highest annual net ever achieved by the Chesapeake Ohio-Baltimore Ohio Railroads.
The Internal Revenue Service announced today that it was "reexamining" President Nixon's tax returns, but it would not say which ones.

Long before the bicentennial rolls around, it will be possible to dine from patriotic plates etched with 24karat gold eagles, to sit on George Washington chairs, to fire a blast on ersatz 1776 cannons, to douse oneself with Historic Charleston cologne and to decorate living room windows with the sort of floral print that Thomas Jefferson might have viewed while penning the Declaration of Independence.

The Bombay docks were silent today. Along Mahatma Gandhi Road, the center of the city, children idly played soccer as policemen stood in small clusters near locked-up banks and shops. By mid-afternoon,

Mayor Beame, after original- s ly deciding to turn the city's handling of the energy problem over to a Deputy Mayor, has left it with the Municipal Service Administrator, as it was with former Mayor John V. Lindsay.

Government officials in charge of energy policy expressed fear today that the latest oilprice increase by Libya would lead to another round of increases by countries on the Persian Gulf. Libya yesterday raised its price from $9 to $18.76 a barrel, and the officials predicted the posted price would soon reach $20. In Libya,
Egyptian and Israeli military negotiators announced today that they had reached "an important stage" in their discussions on how to separate their forces on the Suez front.
The Skylab 3 crew reported today feeling changes of "almost a spiritual nature" in their views of themselves, of other humans and of the possibility of life existingg elsewhere in the universe.
An American family of five was among the 39 persons killed in yesterday's crash of an Italian airliner at Turin, the police said today.

The Staten Island community of Rossville has a distinction most of its residents would gladly relinquish: almost every building is within what has come to be known, by them as the "absolute kill zone" around a controversial liquefied natural gas tank farm being built here for the Distrigas of New York Corporation.
Earl J. Silbert, the prosecutor of the seven Watergate conspirators, was sworn in today as Acting United States Attor ney for the District of Columbia.

TALLINN, U.S.S.R. - This Estonian capital, a city with a reputation in the Soviet Union of architectural distinction, is planning to pioneer an innovation for urban highways by sinking arterial roads in deep underground trenches intended to muffle sound, contain pollution and provide more safety for pedestrians.
The Government announced today that anyone who sought refuge here in the Irish Republic while accused of murder in neighboring Northern Ireland would face trial in the republic's courts.
American Airlines announced yesterday that it would ground 10 of its 16 Boeing 747 jumbo jet airliners, effective Monday, because of the fuel shortage.
William E. Simon, the Federa energy chief, would like to consolidate in his new agency the energy research mission that the White House believes should he assigned to a new, independent agency.

President Nixon's California tax attorney said today that full details of Mr. Nixon's state income tax status would be made public. "Some place along the line we're going to have a complete disclosure of anything and everything that anybody wants to know," said Dean S. Butler of Los Angeles.
The Federal Reserve Board reduced today from 65 to 50 per cent :he required "margin," or cash payment , for purchasing or carryingg stocks on credit.

Producers and performers resumed negotiations yesterday in an effort to avert an Off Broadway theater strike of actors and stage managers.

On Jan. 3, 1749, as the Age of Enlightenment was beginning to flourish across Europe, Ernst Henrich Berling of Copenhagen founded a newspaper. From that day to this, his Berlingske Tidende has survived in continuous publication under the continuous ownership of the founder's family, spreading its solid influence across Scandinavia and the rest of Europe.

The voting habits of the baseball writers in the annual election for the Hall of Fame are not especially predictable. Researchers have found it much easier to chart the mating patterns of the goony bird. Some of the brighter minds have even studied the election returns and reached the conclusion that the first appearance of a superstar on the lists means that he commands so much attention as to brush aside lesser mortals.

TEANECK, Jan. 2-Athletically inclined girls would be wise to consider a career in physical education. That's the opinion of Mrs. Helen Connolly, a teacher for many years in New Jersey schools. Chairman of the girls physical education department at Teaneck High School, Mrs. Connolly predicts a boom in girls varsity sports. "We'll need all the qualified teachers and coaches we can get," she declared.

The Midland-Ross Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed to sell most of its Midrex operations for the direct reduction of iron ore to the Midrex Corporation, an American company controlled by the Korf Group, a West German steel producer.
Several major oil companies announced yesterday that they were raising prices of gasoline and other products, effective immediately.
The easing of the great New Year's gasoline drought in the metropolitan area yesterday was marked by new deliveries of fuel and new warnings of shortages from service station operators.
Congressional investigators have found that United States Army troops and equipment were used to clear land for a private golf course in West Germany, Senator William Proxmire said today.

Following, in translation by The New York Times, is the text of a commentary distributed in Russian today by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, on Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's book "The Gulag Archipelago, 1918-1956":
A tractor-trailer overturned here today, dumping 500 gallons of fuel oil into the Croton Reservoir, which supplies a portion of New York City's water needs.
Carlos Arias Navarro was sworn in today as Spain's Premier, succeeding Adm. Luis Carrero Blanco, who was assassinated almost two weeks ago.
The United States Steel Corporation said last night that it would make some changes in its stainless-steel product lines, but that it had no plans for quitting the stainless-steel business.

Potato futures prices rose sharply yesterday with the May contract hitting $10.94 a hundredweight during the day and closing at a record of $10.77 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The previous high was $10.60 per hundred pounds reached last Friday.

On Oct. 20, 1972, amid the symbolic panoply of Independence Hall in Philadelphia, President Nixon signed a bill that he later described as the first step in "a new American Revolution" designed to "restore power to the people."

The New York Public Library, whose crumbling stone facade has not been attended to since its completion on the building at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street 63 years ago, will receive $200,000 as a long-delayed safety measure.

Defense Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel will meet Secretary of State Kissinger in Washington on Friday, with the Nixon Administration reasonably certain that the results of the Israeli election will not impede the current Middle East negotiations.

About 3,000 workers at two General Motors Corporation assembly plants in New Jersey are to be laid off indefinitely this month and 5,000 more in New Jersey and Westchester County are to be laid off for two weeks. all because of the drop in sales for standard-size cars, a company spokesman said yesterday.
Judge Arthur A. Salvatore in Mercer County Superior Court denied a motion today to dismiss murder charges against Colin C. Carpi, a Princeton investment consultant.
News that the Federal Reserve Board has reduced margin requirements was greeted happily in Wall Street, where any factor that promised to encourage stock purchases is regarded as positive.

The Board of Estimate has passed legislation that for the first time extends the city's zoning power underground. The legislation is designed to control development around stations on the new Second Avenue subway line, with the specific goal of eliminating crowded mid-sidewalk stairways that are the only means of entrance and exit for most existing lines.

A fire raged today in a group of Israeli-operated oil wells off the coast of the Sinai peninsula, a Government spokesman said. He said there had been no injuries in the blaze, which erupted last night.

"There've been no fights today--people are patient--but I just hope all these people have good reason to drive," said Officer Frank Alberti, watching the three block line of cars inching their way into the Central Service Station at 42d Street and 11th Avenue.
Rumors and joKes about another possible national shortage-this one of toilet paperhave struck the second major metropolitan area in less than a month.
Tex Ritter, the country music star, died of a heart attack here tonight. The 67-year-old singer, guitar player, actor and politician was visiting a friend at the county jail when he was stricken.

Pennsylvania's Insurance Commissioner has issued a "Shopper's Guide to Health Insurance" in which he rates the 25 largest health and accident insurance companies in that state and finds that 15 of them "do not rank as good buys" for the consumer.

Mayor Lawrence Cohen said today that 30 city agencies were coordinating their efforts to prevent problems during trials of the leaders of the 71day siege of Wounded Knee, S. D., last spring. "I say it's a lot easier to prevent trouble than to resolve it after it has happened," Mayor Cohen said.

The Watergate revelations are thought by audience research experts to have been the significant factor in the sudden upturn in television network news ratings during 1973, after several years of steady decline in the viewing levels.

A 16-year-old boy who was beaten when he asked several youths to keep quiet the night before the Tournament of Roses died today from head injuries. It was the second homicide of this year's parade and only the third in the 85-year history of the tournament.

Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan, who had planned, after the firemen's strike last Nov. 6 to press "neglect-ofduty" charges against all firemen who took part in the walkout, has decided riot to bring such charges.

The "revival" of radio drama attempts to get considerably more serious this Sunday evening with the debut of "C.B.S. Radio Mystery Theater," which will offer a complete and different 52minute story to listeners seven nights a week. Because WCBS-AM in New York will continue as an "all news" station, the series will be carried on WOR in the metropolitan area - at 7:07 P.M. Monday through Friday, 8:07 P.M. Saturday and 5:07 Sunday.
Omega-Alpha, Inc., said yesterday in Dallas that an agreement extending debt maturities of about $20-million due Dec. 31 had been reached with its banks.
The Justice Department moved today to force newspaper publishers in St. Louis and Des Moines to give up their interests in local broadcast stations.

Syria reported new fighting today with Israeli forces on the Golan Heights. A Syrian military spokesman said that in two incidents involving machine-gun and artillery fire, one Israeli soldier had been hit and a number of enemy construction vehicles destroyed.

Byron Dyce, the former New York University star who now competes for the Florida Track Club, won the fastest 1,000-yard race ever run on a 220-yard flatboard track last night at the 168th Street Armory.

Broadcasts of entire text of Alexander I. Solzhenitsyn's new book on the Soviet prison camp system are due to be beamed into the Soviet Union by the American-sponsored Station Radio Liberty.
The State Department of Transportation said today that it would make computerized assistance available to communities that want to set up car-pool systems or expand mass transit.

Edward P. Parker, chairman of Parker Brothers, the games manufacturers here founded by his great-uncle in 1883, died of cancer yesterday in Salem Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in nearby Beverly Farms

Daniel J. O'Conor Jr., former executive vice president and director of the American Cyanamid Company, died today at his home here. His age was 57. A probationary police officers was stabbed and seriously' wounded in an East Harlem school yesterday, allegedly by a distraught father of a student there.

Tim Ecclestone came back to haunt his former team by scoring two goals tonight and Inge Hammarstrom scored a goal with 5 minutes 35 seconds to play to help the Toronto Maple Leafs overcome a three-goal deficit and defeat the Detroit Red Wings, 4-3.
Real Note, a multiple stakes winner owned by Roland Aristone, won the $22,300 Southern Maryland Handicap today at Bowie Race Course as the track opened a 60-day meet ing.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics identified 15 industries today that are heavily dependent on petroleum and could suffer severe unemployment if fuel supplies were cut back sharply. The information was given to the Federal Energy Office for guidance in planning fuel allocation programs.
The Soviet Union has accused Peking of backtracking on its longstanding claim on the island of Taiwan to curry favor with the United States.

The Soviet Union ridiculed Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's new expose of the Soviet prison system as a "blanket slander of the Soviet people," born of the author's "impotent rage" against Communist achievements. In the first authoritative Soviet comment on Mr. Solzhenitsyn's "Gulag Archipelago," the official Soviet press agency gave no hint of what actions might be taken against the author or the book's foreign publishers.
Amtrak reported yesterday that patronage of its nationwide rail passenger system was up substantially in November and December, with Metroliner passengers up 30 per cent.
Jimmy is four years old and has keratoconus, an eye condition sometimes described as a bulging of the window of the eye. One thing that seems to help him is contact lenses but he keeps losing them.

President Nixon signed into law today the Regional Rail Reorganization. Act of 1973 to restructure seven bankrupt railroads in the Northeast section of the country into one Federally backed private corporation.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 2The stage had been set before dawn. Across from the Nassau County Veterans Memorial Coliseum here, the supporting players were in the wings. The police were on hand to direct traffic. Reporters and photographers were present to record the event. But the principal players failed to make the curtain raising.
CARACAS, Venezuela--The view of Caracas from the slum dwellings that infest the surrounding green hills and ravines is one of movement, growth and hope.
Joseph F. Whittington, a 26year-old patient at the Northport (L.I.) Veterans Hospital, was held in $100,000 bail yesterday on charges of murdering a hospital attendant Tuesday night.

Prices of raw farm products rose 1.5 per cent from midNovember through mid-December after declining for three consecutive monthly periods and edged toward 1974 an average of 34 per cent higher than a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

One of the most sensible comments to come out of the United States Government in a very long time was made the other day by William E. Simon, the energy administrator. If and when the Arab oil embargo is lifted, he said, his major concern will be "not letting the American people go to sleep again."
President Nixon signed today a bill requiring states to limit highway speeds to a maximum of 55 miles an hour as a condition for continuing to receive Federal highway trust funds.

"I have bad news for you, you have an ineligible player." When any Public Schools Athletic League coach hears those words, he shudders. When those words may mean forfeiting three games and a shot at a basketball title, the shudder gets worse. With the coaches at New Utrecht, which lost the chance for its football division title because of a forfeit, the shudder may become shattering.
A pessimistic economic outlook that included a prediction of a 10 per cent unemployment rate in Suffolk County was offered today by County Executive John V. N. Klein.

The Turbodyne Corporation has received a letter of intent from the Houston Lighting and Power Company to purchase six Turbodyne industrial gas turbine generators. The order, which the company said was worth $26-million, raises Turbo. dyne's backlog to $228-million. Last week, the company received an $81.2-million order from the San Diego Gas and Electric Company.
The police today arrested a 53-yearold journalist on the staff of ly daily newspaper Figaro and aid he was the mastermind of he $75,000 holdup at the pater's offices last week.
The Conference Board, an independent business and economic research institution, said yesterday that the Government might have overstimated the petroleum shortage in the United States.

The General Accounting Office has been asked to investigate the possibility of collusion between the Navy and a Texas concern that produced $16-million worth of communications buoys that were too large for United States submarines.

REEL THING The Film Forum is a place for people who will go to see movies that are not likely to be proclaimed in big ads or bright lights. The Forum, which works out of its neat little 50-seat house upstairs, at 256 West 88th Street (3620503) fashions its season from films by folk you may not have heard of-yet-and from reels that may not make it to your neighborhood house.
Jim Pappin scored his 10th and 11th goals of the season to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 5-1 victory over the New York Islanders in a National Hockey League game tonight.

With the Federal Reserve exerting a downward push on short-term interest rates, the Department of Housing and Urban Development sold notes; yesterday at the lowest rate it has incurred since last May.

Sources in the Cahill administration said tonight that the outgoing Republican Governor had prepared a $2.5-billion state budget for the next fiscal year that does not include any new taxes or any new programs.
The Interior Department opened today 7.7 million acres of California's ocean shelf. some of it just off Los Angeles and its beaches, to oil and gas exploration.
The Japanese Foreign Minister, Masayoshi Ohira, said here today that he would discuss the question of a civil aviation agreement with Chinese leaders during his visit to Peking this week.
President Nixon authorized today the import of an additional 100 million pounds of cheddar cheesemostly from New Zealand and Australia-to meet a current shortage in this country.

Three New Jersey women enlisted in the Army today to become members of a special American company being formed to mark the first peace-time opening of a basic-training center for the Womens Army Corps.

Mrs. Sally Longo Murray, who had been secretary to the Boa had been secretary to the Board presidents, William Hefferman, James P. Powers and Maurice J. O'Rourke, died yesterday at New York University Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived at 3518 12th Avenue in Brooklyn.

Britain's three-day work week has begun with a vengeance. Three-quarters of a million workers were thrown onto the unemployment rolls yesterday, on top of the nearly half-million already there. If the abbreviated week long continues, unemployment could climb to six million, a level of joblessness the British have not experienced since those years on the dole before World War II.

The Soviet Union ridiculed Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's new expose of the Soviet prison system as a "blanket slander of the Soviet people," born of the author's "impotent rage" against Communist achievements. In the first authoritative Soviet comment on Mr. Solzhenitsyn's "Gulag Archipelago," the official Soviet press agency gave no hint of what actions might be taken against the author or the book's foreign publishers.

Construction contracts in November rose to $7.9 a billion, up 11 per cent from November, 1972, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday. Contracts in the first 11 months of 1973 totaled $94.4 billion for a gain of 12 per cent over the comparable period in 1972.

The trial of two former Cabinet officers that was scheduled to start next Wednesday was postponed yesterday in Federal District Court here because defense lawyers remained tied up with another trial that could continue until late next month.

Erich Leinsdorf has agreed to replace Riccardo Muti as conductor of the New York Philharmonic concerts this week. Mr. Muti is ill in Italy with influenza and bronchitis. Mr. Liensdorf agreed to take over the concerts late, Tuesday night.
The opening session of 1974 proved a bonanza yesterday for gold, silver and other precious metal issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

The state plans to rent space in a hotel near the Bronx County Courthouse to free enough space in the building for six more courtrooms, officials said last night. The target date for the move is June, according to Gerald Stern, director of administration of the courts in the First Judicial Department.

A three-day inaugural celebration in honor of Detroit's first black Mayor, Coleman Young, got, under way. yesterday with a- blunt challenge from another black, United States District Judge Damon Keith, to all blacks to help the police in their fight against crime.
A.C. Israel Co. and the Louis Dreyfus Corporation both leading commodity trading houses, yesterday dissolved their joint venture, ACLI International, Inc.

The food industry has been advised by market analysts that the typical consumer is, like his diet, unbalanced. Much of American food merchandising is based on that assumption. Dietary behavior abounds in evidence of neurosis: divorce from reality, guilt feelings, masochism, a profound sense of inferiority and insecurity.

The New York Times Company and the Kimberly-Clark Corporation have signed an agreement to purchase all of the stock interest in the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, Ltd., held by The Evening Star Newspaper Company of Washington, D.C.
A woman whose automobile insurance policy was canceled because she was living with a man "without benefit of wedlock" is seeking damages in Federal Court here.
A military police sergeant who held about 30 people hostage in a railway station tearoom in Taegu, in south-eastern Korea, surrendered to-night after 30-hour siege, radio reports said
Senator J. W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, announced today that he would run for a sixth Senate term this year.
The Vietcong urged the Saigon Government today to release all military and civilian prisoners before Tet, the Lunar New Year, on Jan. 23. The South Vietnamese said they would try to comply.

E. Howard Hunt Jr., looking frail and wan after sering more than 10 months in a Federal prison for his part in the Watergate bugging conspiracy, was released without bail today to await a decision on his appeal of his conviction.

Mayor 'Beame has refused to reappoint a judge in Queens Criminal Court despite urgings by the Queens County Bar Association and Matthew J. Troy Jr., the county Democratic leader, that the judge be retained.

Miami, Jan. 2 John Priestes, one of the first builders to implicate Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, in alleged corruption involving the Federal Housing Administration, surrendered today to United States marshals to begin serving a one-year sentence.
The 105th college football season approached its end in the Rose Bowl yesterday as Ohio State excited and surprised fans who thought Coach Woody Hayes knew only the flying wedge style of football.

As the Government of Kuwait continues to resist worldwide demands for a proper trial of the five Arab terrorists who murdered 32 innocent persons in recent criminal acts of air piracy, an international agreement to deal with such obstruction of justice becomes more urgent than ever. The absence of an effective pact is an invitation to the kinds of outrage which have been haunting international air traffic for the last several years.
The Federal Reserve Board reduced today from 65 to 50 per cent the required "margin," or cash payment, for purchasing or carrying stocks on credit.

St. Louis University and the University of California, Los Angeles won their National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer semifinal games at the Orange Bowl tonight and will meet for the championship Friday night.
Judge Arthur A. Salvatore in Mercer County Superior Court denied a motion today to dismiss murder charges against Colin C. Carpi, a Princeton investment consultant.
The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, which has had difficulty showing earnings in recent years, announced a profit and record sales yesterday in the third quarter.

To the Editor: Several members of Congress and others have made the statement recently that, had import controls not been imposed, this country would not be confronted with an energy crisis. The exact opposite is the case.
The American people expect 1974 to be a year of economic difficulty and rising unemployment, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

A total of nearly $1.5-billion in Federal general revenuesharing funds has been funneled into the tristate New York metropolitan area since the program became law on Oct. 20, 1972, according to the Office of Revenue Sharing in Washington. D.C.

Neither rain nor snow, but a missing or incorrect address can keep Benjamin Meyerson from speeding mail to its destination. He is monarch of all he surveys, proud manager of the "Claims and Inquiry and Undeliverable Mail Section" - the dead letter office at the New York Post Office, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street.

Mayor Paul T. Jordan established his control of Hudson County's governmental apparatus today when the 59-year-old grandmother he had picked for the post was selected to be director of the Board of Freeholders.
Cuba's Armed Forces Minister, Raul Castro, warned his countrymen today that the energy crisis might have serious consequences for the nation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--The Food and Drug Administration is planning to require batch-by-batch certification of the important heart drug digoxin because some samples have failed to meet standards in the rate at which the drug dissolves.

Edgar I. Williams, an architect who had played an influential role in his profession as president of the National Academy of Design, the Architectural League and the Municipal Art Society, died Tuesday at his home in New Milford, Conn. He was 89 years old.

The Sun Oil Company denied today charges of price gouging made by two oil distributors. "The key to the transaction is that this was a sale from Puerto Rico Sun Oil, which operates out of Puerto Rico and is not subject to Cost of Living Council price regulations," a Sun spokesman said.

The Carolina Cougars continue to miss Billy Cunningham. As the American Basketball Association's most valuable player recuperates from surgery for a kidney blockage at Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital in Manhattan, the Cougars have turned from the powerful Eastern Division leaders to a struggling team.

Gerald L. Warren, White House deputy press secretary, spent a substantial portion of this morning's regular news briefing attempting to disentangle the White House from the problem of Mrs. Richard M. Nixon and the new 25-member National Voluntary Service Advisory Council.

The Nixon Administration enters the New Year under siege from four different lines of attack. * The special prosecutor's office organized by Archibald Cox is persevering relentlessly (under leadership of its new chief, Leon Jaworski) in its inquiries into possible Administration malfeasance. According to Mr. Jaworski, major indictments against former Administration officials are likely to be forthcoming from one of three grand juries before the month is out.
A state appeals court upheld today the conviction of a man charged with conspiring to burn a cross in front of the home of a black community leader in Asbury Park.

Billy Isaacs testified today that his older brother Carl Isaacs and two other accused killers had shot five male members of the Ned Alday family one by one as they entered a trailer on the family farm.
The Internal Revenue Service announced today that it was "reexamining" President Nixon's tax returns, but it would not say which ones.

American Airlines announced yesterday that it would ground 10 of its 16 Boeing 747 jumbo jet airliners, effective Monday, because of the fuel shortage. In a similar but less sweeping move, Trans World Airlines said it would take two of its 19 jumbos out of service on the same day.
Mayor Beame, in his first full day of work at City Hall, issued an executive order yesterday that virtually forces a commissioner to choose Civil Service aides from the very top of the list.
Andre Lacroix, the team's star center, said tonight that the Jersey Knights' players have been informed that the franchise would be moved to Baltimore for the 1974-75 World Hockey Association season.

The gray squirrels (sciurus carolinensis) of Washington and other major cities within the range of the species, which extends east from the Mississippi River Valley, are showing the effects of segregation forced upon them by heavy vehicular traffic, according to the Massachusetts Audubon Society.

The city's major landlord groups accused a state commission yesterday of "deliberate distortions" or "serious omissions" for having said that major housing improvements had decreased here since enactment of the controversial vacancy decontrol law.

Ron Swoboda, the popular 29-year-old former New York Met and Yankee outfielder, signed with the Atlanta Braves as a free agent yesterday. He had been released by the Yankees after having batted .294 for their Syracuse club in the International League last season.

Amtrak reported yesterday that patronage of its nationwide rail passenger system was up substantially in November and December, with Metroliner passengers up 30 per cent.

Judge Charles B. McCormick, a bankruptcy referee in the Federal Court in Chicago, extended yesterday a temporary restraining order protecting the assets of Walter J. Kassubas' real estate interests from assaults by creditors until Feb. 5.

Leber Katz Partners has two assignments from the Netherlands National Tourist Office, a client for the last three years. First, attract conventions from the land of the perpetual business and association meeting. Second, bring in those tourists.

Bing Crosby is sidelined, but the tournament that bears his name will open the 1974 professional golf tour here tomorrow. The singer has been hospitalized by pleurisy and whether or not the doctors will permit him to trod the fairways this week as a spectator or participate in the national telecast is still uncertain. Meanwhile,

J. David Parkinson has been named president and chief executive officer of the Thomas Betts Corporation. He succeeds Robert McK. Thomas Jr., who died last month at the age of 64. Mr. Thomas was a son of a cofounder of the electrical and electronics manufacturer.
Negotiations to settle the wage disputes involving Britain's coal miners and railway engineers remained at an impasse today as workers began lining up for unemployment benefits.
An official spokesman for the Persian Gulf oil producers said today that the price of oil would be reduced if industrialized nations lowered the cost of their exports.

On the first harness program of the year, the Filion brothers won five of the nine races tonight. Henri, normally overshadowed by his older brother, Herve, the national driving champion, proved to be a long-shot bettor's delight.
Continuing the year-end rally into the first day's trading of the new year, prices close higher yesterday on the Amer ican Stock Exchange and ib the over-the-counter market Volume declined.

The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a divorced Roman Catholic woman who had intended to remarry her former husband but had been told by a priest that a ceremony was unnecessary was entitled to workmen's compensation benefits through her late husband.

In the midst of Governor Wilson's move to consolidate his new power, State Senator John J. Marchi yesterday recommended reorganization of the state executive branch, citing what he called its "vast and pervasive" growth during the administration of Nelson A. Rockefeller.
Bob Lanier scored 25 of his 34 points in the second half tonight and the Detroit Pistons rallied for a 106-92 National Basketball Association victory over the injury-riddied Milwaukee Bucks.

New York City's major landlord groups accused a state commission yesterday of "serious omissions of deliberate distortions" for having said that major housing improvements had decreased here since enactment of the controversial vacancy decontrol law.
John Lucas scored 25 points and Tom McMillen set a school career scoring record, leading third-ranked Maryland to a 96-60 rout of Richmond in college basketball tonight.

Anatoly Karpov. crowding in one last competition before his world championship quarter-finals match with Lev Polugaevsky begins Jan. 14 in Moscow, captured first prize in the Madrid International tournament. His impressive score was seven victories, no losses and eight draws.

Treasury officials met yesterday with New York City bank officials and leaders of the American Bankers Association, and broached a Federal proposal to ease check-cashing problems for recipients of Federal benefits.
Mrs. Helen (Penny) Tweedy, who managed the racing careers of Secretariat and Riva Ridge, was named today as winner of the Big Sport of Turfdom award by the Turf Publicists Association.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today that he had ordered his staff to investigate allegations in Nassau County by a Conservative party Assembly candidate that he had received funds last year from a Democrat to draw votes that normally would have been expected to go to the Republican candidate.

Several million Americans who are aged, blind or disabled and also poor are a bit better protected against the ravages of inflation as a result of the introduction this week of the first broad Federal guarantee of a floor under income for the needy.

The post-New Year's sobering process has started in earnest at the network news departments. Last night at 10 o'clock, the National Broadcasting Company examined the soaring costs of education in "The College Money Crunch."
A high Justice Department official conceded today that there was little hope of extraditing Howard R. Hughes from his Bahamas refuge to stand trial in a Las Vegas, Nev., stock fraud case.

The United States has withdrawn 3,700 troops from Thailand since September, a top Thai defense official said today. Gen. Kriengsak Chamnand, deputy chairman of the Thai Joint Chiefs of Staff, said the number of United States servicemen in Thailand would go below 35,000 by the end of the week.

Christmas and post-Christmas business surged in many stores around the country as consumers turned out in large numbers, according to December sales results posted by some of the nation's largest retail chains yesterday. Although the monthly results were not among the year's best, most of the chains reporting yesterday, including Sears, Roebuck Co., Chicago, the largest merchandiser, had gains well above the year's rise in consumer goods prices.

President Pompidou of France predicted today that the Geneva talks on the Middle East would probably produce "a prolonged armistice rather than a real peace."

The bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company announced yesterday that it reduced its loss in the month of November to $11.4-million from a deficit of $20.6-million in November, 1972.

Officers of the National Bank of North America, a large New York-based institution, allegedly solicited and received payoffs from a financially troubled shipping company in return for approving more than $7-million in apparently illegal loans, according to documents filed in United States District Court here.

The dormant controversy about a possible deep-water oil port off New Jersey may be revived by legislation filed by the Senate President-designate, Frank J. Dodd. It would establish a state agency to build and operate an offshore oil facility.
Prison sentences of 12 to 18 years were imposed yesterday on four narcotics dealers who were permitted to spend Thanksgiving at home after their conviction last Nov. 21.

Communist-led insurgents killed 8 people and wounded 37 in a rocket attack on the Cambodian capital yesterday and today, according to official reports. Eight rockets were fired into Phnom Penh, making a total of 29 since the rebels began a rocket campaign 12 days ago. A total of 22 people have been killed and 61 wounded, police sources reported. An armed man raped a 20year-old part-time student yesterday morning in the Bowery station of the BMT subway line, the transit police reported. The assailant is believed to have been the same person who last Nov. 28 unsuccessfully tried to rape another young woman in the same station.

William H. Simon denied reports today that oil tankers were waiting off the United States coast in hopes of new oil price increases. The energy chief said the Federal Maritime Commission had reported "no signs of unusual activity" off United States coastlines.

Although not abandoning the idea of hiring Dick Williams eventually, the New York Yankees named Bill Virdon, dismissed by the Pittsburgh Pirates late last season, as their manager yesterday for the 1974 season. Virdon signed a one-year contract. George Steinbrenner, general partner of the Yankees, during yesterday's announcement.

Spain's new Premier today produced a Cabinet in his own image--politically conservative and strong on authority and order. Premier Carlos Arias Navarro, catapulted into leadership by the bomb that killed Premier Luis Carrero Blanco two weeks ago, made sweeping changes that left the Spanish political world stunned.

Bond-rating houses are expected to make their decision today or early next week on the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority's application for a rating of the $295-million bond issue to finance the Hackensack Meadowlands sports complex. Two earlier attempts to have bond issues rated by Standard Poor's Corporation and by Moody's Investor Service were unsuccessful.

A panel truck containing 5,343 cartons of cigarettes was seized by the police last night in Astoria, Queens, and the operator of the truck was arrested and charged with possession of untaxed cigarettes, a felony.

A United Nations spokesman said today that Israeli troops obstructed the movement of nonmilitary supplies yesterday to elements of the Egyptian Third Army that are cut off on the Sinai Peninsula, on the east bank of the Suez Canal.

Tri-Star Development, Inc., has purchased two major office buildings in Detroit for approximately $20-million. The buildings are the 28-story Fisher Building and the 11-story New Center Building, both about three miles north of the city's downtown area.

The controversy between commercial menhaden fishermen and sport fishermen, which flared last summer in Long Island Sound, will be aired at a meeting sponsored by the Southern New York Fish and Game Association Jan. 17 at 8 P.M. at the Little Theater, Westchester County Center, in White Plains.

Wheat prices swung sharply higher and then retreated yesterday, closing virtually unchanged on the Chicago Board of Trade. Brokers spoke of nervous trading that resulted in some selling late in the session.

Canada's House of Commons adopted tough new rules today to govern the financing of election campaigns. The legislation, the product of years of study, sets limits on how much candidates may spend, requires full disclosure of contributions over $100, and provides that some campaign expenses be paid out of the Federal treasury.

Mayor Beame held his first reception at Gracie Mansion late yesterday "just to say hello" to about 200 legislators of both parties, their wives and members of his new administration.

A controversial proposal to construct a housing development in a wooded undeveloped tract near the Palisades Interstate Parkway has been rejected by Tenafly's Planning Board as "totally contrary" to the density concept in the borough's master plan.

The Rheingold brewery in Brooklyn, one of the two breweries left in the city, faces imminent closing, Richard I. Ahern, Rheingold's president, said last night. The company's directors will meet tomorrow to vote on discontinuing brewing operations after nearly 40 years.
Roman Catholic Church here yesterday Miss Paula Siebs Vogelsang, a fashion designer, was married to John D. In St. Paul the Apostle Leonard, a freelance writer.

President Nixon signed into law today a two-stage, 11 per cent increase in Social Security payments that will augment the incomes of 30 million Americans. Seven per cent of the increase will take effect in March and be contained in checks received in April, and 4 per cent will take effect in June and be contained in checks received in July.

As a result, they say, Kuwait has delayed handing the men over to the Palestine Liberation Organization for trial before a Palestinian "revolution ary court."
A Presidential advisory committee on the environment told Americans today that they "must accept - and ultimately demand - energy conservation and make it a way of life."

Assistant Attorney General Maxwell B. Spoont has been selected to head the state's Organized Crime Task Force, succeeding Robert E. Fischer. Governor Wilson and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced the appointment today.

The Knights, formerly the New York Golden Blades, were taken over by the league, renamed and moved to Cherry Hill, N.J., last Nov. 20 when the Blades owners couldn't meet financial obligations.

Michael Kan, curator of primitive art at the Brooklyn Museum, has been named the museum's acting director. While the search for a new director proceeds, he will hold the post vacated by Duncan F. Cameron, who resigned under fire Dec. 18.

Governor Wilson intends to seek emergency authority to deal with the energy shortage, including optional power to allocate limited fuel supplies if necessary, the assignment of state inspectors to combat price gouging and the purchase of 1,200 smaller cars for the state's use.

To the Editor: Nuclear power reactors have not been proved safe. The oft-cited fact that there have been about thirty reactors producing power for an average of almost five years without calamitous accident does not prove they are safe but only that if we are to have a thousand or so reactors in the future we will probably not have more than a few calamitous accidents per year.

Warning that the oil shortage could lead to a worldwide depression, Secretary of State Kissinger said that President Nixon would make a personal effort to persuade major oil-producing and oil-consuming nations to band together to ease the crisis. Spread out before him on the top of an Eero Saarinen table was the eclectic accumulation of a man less interested in acquiring conventional antiquess than in owning vintage objects worthy of design study.

A squatter in a colony beside railroad tracks in Jakarta. People in the area have no water supply, and the passing trains rattle homes, often so hard that they collapse.

Mr. Salazar, of The Los Angeles Times and television station KMEX, was killed Aug. 29, 1970, when he was struck in the head by a tear gas shell fired into a bar by a deputy sheriff.

Clifford Irving was transferred yesterday.. from the Federal prison at Danbury, Conn., to a halfway house here, and within an hour after checking in, was granted a weekend pass that gave him his first taste of freedom since he entered prison in August, 1972. It rolls and hurtles through space, driving through many directions simultaneously at breakneck speeds, except that it doesn't break our necks because, because, well, it's very scientific-go see the show.

Most forecasters now agree that the American economy will suffer a marked slump in 1974. Estimated increments in the gross national product (in real terms) range from 0 to 2 per cent. The index ended the week at 880.23, showing a net gain of 32.21 points.

The spectacle of eight bluechip corporations admitting in court that they had illegally contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars in company funds to President Nixon's re-election has chipped away at business's already eroded image.

Dr. Maurice Lenz, an internationally known radiotherapist, who was professor of clinical radiology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, from 1941 to 1955, died Friday in Englewood (N. J.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 1375 River Road, Edgewater, N. J.
City and state housing officials are pressing ahead with plans for 10 electrically heated housing projects despite charges that electric heat wastes the city's energy-generating capacity.

One way of reading this is to assume that more good films weremade here in 1973 than in any recent year. Or one can be blunt and say simply that foreign films were worse, even though we usually receive the best of the lot.

Two young French ecologists, determined to dramatize the fate of whale species they say are threatened with extinction, plan to draw up a blacklist of whale products in France and to join the crew of a ship planning to sabotage whale hunts.

In the apparel industry, where 20 per cent of knit capacity remains idle, a move is under way to combat one of the biggest complaints about double-knits-their tendency to snag. Irving Howe has had a long, admirable and increasingly enviable career. An academic who is never musty and a journalist who is never merely quick or content with flash, he seems to have grown over the years, and his prose is sharper, his insights more precise and flexible. Of course he loves polemical situations too much, and a taste for battle born in the days when the Old Left was new has never left him.

TRENTON - It costs New Jersey taxpayers at least $300,000 a year to provide religious services for the 11,000 inmates in state prisons, hospitals and reform schools. The cost will probably increase to $350,000 this year because many of these services are no longer performed free by volunteers.

In an old brick church in the South Bronx parish he has served for more than 12 years, the Rev. Louis R. Gigante celebrated mass yesterday, took an oath of office as the new Councilman from the district and, standing before an altar in white vestments, pledged to remain in the streets to work on local problems.

Steve Craig of Northwestern University catching pass for a North touchdown in the American Bowl all-star game in Tampa, Fla., yesterday. North defeated South, 28-7.
Sterilization of a 14-year-old mentally retarded girl, requested by her parents because she is "overly friendly" to strangers, was held up yesterday by an appeal filed by the Legal Aid Society.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday that he planned to add 1,000 uniform officers to street patrol by taking them off clerical details and similar duty.
The San Diego Dilemma, however it is handled on Wednesday when the National League club owners meet in Chicago, may hasten another expansion of the major leagues.

J., was shot to death early yesterday at a Bronx intersection after he and two passengers in his car got into a street brawl over a traffic dispute with two men in another car, the police reported. About 400 cheering, pennantwaving fans greeted the American Football Conference champion Miami Dolphins today when they arrived to begin final drills for next Sunday's Super Bowl game against Minnesota.

Prospects for a fourth commercial television network in the United States in the next few years "are not very bright" despite the impetus given the idea by a recent White House study, according to a Rand Corporation report released here recently.
A 60-year-old man was killed and three families were made homeless early yesterday when fire swept through four twoand-a-half-story homes in the Woodhaven section of Queens.

School Chancellor Irving Anker has begun plans to create between five and 10 special elementary schools across the city next year, each stressing a "theme" decided by the local community and attended by pupils whose parents have chosen to send them there.

As the city, along with most of the nation, switched over to Daylight Saving Time yesterday, forbidding skies yielded barely enough light to be worth saving. The sun lined up with the moon and earth in an unusual pattern, modifying the Twelfth Night post-holiday return to normalcy on the first Sunday of the new year.
Long Beach State was placed on indefinite probation for not less than three years by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today for basketball and football violations.

Phil Chenier scored 31 points tonight in leading the Capital Bullets to a 90-88 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks. Chenier scored 8 points in each of the first three quarters, as the Bullets stayed ahead all the way.

When the three-man Township Committee organized here Jan. 1, Wesley K. Bell was routinely made chairman of the police committee, although he was under indictment on charges of interfering with a police investigation last year to protect a friend.

The Emergency Medical Service Division of the Health and Hospitals Corporation has 142 ambulances to serve the needs of city residents. But only about 120 are in service at any one time. In addition, the voluntary hospitals have 38 ambulances on duty.

The political leader of the Zulus and a leader of the white Parliamentary Opposition, the United party, have signed a declaration of faith in South Africa's future as a peaceful, multiracial society with equal opportunity for all.

The Dover Township Police Department has filed juvenile-delinquency charges' against three teen-agers in connection with vandalism inside the 115-year-old First Presbyterian Church of Toms River. More youths may have been involved, the police said. They declined to identify those arrested.

Percy Winner, a former foreign correspondent who had recently been director of foreign-area studies at American University, died of cancer yesterday in George Washington University Hospital. He was 74 years old.

Robert W. Neumann, a consultant on the foreign money market, most recently to the Cummins Engine Company of Columbus, Ind., died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 154 West 71st Street.
Vandals broke into Intermediate High School 2 last night in Staten Island and set fire to about 50 books after dumping them into two garbage cans in the school library, authorities reported.

According to authorities on agricultural production, something like that may be happening in their field right now. Her success was attributable to a rare combination of technical skill, determination, concentration, and being pleasant to partners.

Lucille and Ronald Fields, both teachers in the New York City school system, couldn't find anyone who lived up to their admittedly high standards to take care of their infant son.
