Temple goes into the Big 5 basketball game against Pennsylvania tomorrow without the services of Joe Anderson. The 6-foot-4 forward was suspended last night for leaving the Owls' lockerroom at half-time Saturday night and not returning. The Owls lost to Manhattan, 68-66.

Thousands of poor people--some aged, some disabled, many of them drug addicts--jammed the city's 23 offices of the Social Security Administration yesterday as chaos attended the transfer of 200,000 New Yorkers from welfare rolls to a new Federal assistance program.

Although a Federal District Court's challenge to Congressional and Legislative districting in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx is not final, the court's ruling in Washington last week exposes shameful electoral practices in this city that should long since have become intolerable.

The company, that hasunderwritten malpractice insurance for almost all New York State physicians for the last 25 years will stop doing so next year, leaving the state medical society in search of a company to underwrite the growing, though unprofitable, business.

A seven-man, five-woman Federal jury was chosen in Newark yesterday to hear the cocaine smuggling trial of Peter Richard Campisi, a reputed mobster, and five others. They were among 20 persons named last May in a three-count indictment that alleged they had conspired to smuggle in at least five and a half kilos of cocaine from South America. Judge James A. Coolhan is presiding in District Court.
Harold A. Stevens and Samuel Rabin were sworn in as associate judges of the state Court of Appeals in brief ceremonies today in the court's 130year-old building.

Leonard Slatkin, associate conductor of the St. Louis Symphony, will make his New York Philharmonic debut this week replacing Riccardo Muti, who canceled his Philharmonic engagement because of illness.

Mrs. Genevieve Ludwig Maxwell, wife of James A. Maxwell, a writer who is now a senior editor in the general books division of Reader's Digest, died of cancer yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 63 years old and lived at 300 West 55th Street.

The Arien Realty ana Development Corporations, which operates the Korvette chain of department stores as well as commercial and residential properties, reported yesterday sharply lower earnings for the quarter and nine months ended Nov. 30 although revenues were little changed.

The groundwork was laid for an early test of impeachment sentiment among returning Congressmen when the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee said today that a vote of the full House was needed to give subpoena power to the committee's impeachment inquiry staff.
Consumers are facing sharply increasing food prices if the usual barometer of the city government's advance purchases remains as accurate as it has been in the past.

The Democratic minority leaders of the Legislature issued a "state of the state" message today, urging tighter controls on campaign spending and reform of legislative procedures to counteract what they said was the public's "growing frustration and. deep mistrust" of government.

Representative Clarence J. Brown, Republican of Ohio, announced today he would seek re-election to represent the seventh Ohio district. He had been considering seeking the nomination to rthe United States Senate to succeed William J. Saxbe, now Attorney General.

J. Edwin Carter has been named president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., effective Feb. 1. He succeeds J. Edward Grubb, who was elected chairman of Inco, the world's largest nickel producer, and remains its chief officer. (Inco does not use the title of chief executive officer.)

Commuter trains from New Jersey were delayed, many school children missed their free breakfasts, some workers walked to subways and buses with trepidation, and many people felt strange yesterday as the day began an hour earlier for most in an eerie darkness.

Darryl Sittler scored three goals to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 6-2 victory over the Atlanta Flames tonight. The Leafs' Victorv moved them into a tie with the New York Rangers: for third place in the National Hockey League's ,East. Division.. The Flames are in fourth place in the West.

The Defense Department has agreed to curtail bombing practices on Matagorda Island off Corpus Christi, Tex., where the world's 46 known whooping cranes spend their winters, Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

Steel production last week totaledd 2,847,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Insti:ute reported yesterday. This was up 2 per cent from the preceding week's 2,790,000 tons and raised the index of production to 116.7 from 114.4.

A White House spokesman said today that President Nixon would fly back to Washington aboard a commercial plane, the same way he flew out here.

An interest in jewelry led Robin Orban to an entanglement with four alleged student extremists and resulted in a weekend of questioning by the English police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, she told reporters today.

Theodore W. Kheel, mediator in the contract negotiations between Typographical Union No. 6 and the city's three major daily newspapers, said yester. day that discussions of the key issue of automation would begin next Tuesday.

Maynard Holbrook Jackson Jr., the greatgreat-grandson of a former Georgia slave, became tonight this city's youngest Mayor ever. He will be 36 years old in March.

Under cloudy skies but good flying conditions, a reserved-seat, scheduled Eastern Airlines aircraft took off from Newark Airport for Boston at 7 A. M. today, and 20 minutes later a similar flight headed for Washington.

A Jewish woman charged here with complicity in the killing of an Arab waiter described today how she had eavesdropped on a conversation in a swimming pool between the victim and his friend.
Joseph M. Wafer, who retired in 1966 as a vice president and a director of the Westvaco Corporation, died today. He was 72 years old and lived here.

Sy and Stephanie Rosenfeld, their daughter and their dog set sail here today for the Caribbean aboard a 35-foot racing sloop they bought with the proceeds from the sale of their suburban home and all its furnishings.
A number of new offerings in the corporate and tax-exempt bond markets received a good initial response yesterday on the second day of a lively week.

Bjorn Borg, the 17-year-old Swedish star, and Evonne Goolagong of Australia won second-round matches in the Auckland open tennis championships today.

Ronald Dante, nightclub hypnotist who was the seventh husband of Lana Turner, the actress, until their divorce in 1972, was arraigned today on an extradition warrant from Arizona where he has been chargedd with attempted murder.

With food and fuel prices both racing uphill, the defenses against inflation are fast collapsing. The wholesale price index went up last month at a rate that would cut 25 cents out of the 1974 consumer's dollar if fully translated at the retail level.
Charles G. Bond, who retired in 1971 as chairman of the New York City Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, died yesterday at the Somerset Valley (N.J.) Nursing Home. He was 96 years old.
A Legal Aid Society lawyer who is also a Roman Catholic priest has been told by a Brooklyn judge he may not wear his clerical collar while defending his client before a jury.

What has been described as the second best legislature in the country convenes in Albany today for a session that has the potential of making it number one. A preliminary poll of members by the Citizens Union has revealed broad support among both Republicans and Democrats for a program of legislative priorities that places heavy emphasis on reforms in such key areas as the courts, prisons, consumer protection, education, welfare and campaign financing.

Premier Fakuei Tanaka of Japan told the Philippines today that the Japanese Government would exercise "administrative guidance" over Japanese businesses here and elsewhere in Southeast Asia to harmonize them with the needs and ways of their host nations.

Tung Group, left Los Angeles Dec. 7 with 250 passengers, and her scheduled ports of call included places in the Far East, Africa and South and Central America.
A Cuban diplomat says that Havana would be willing to hold political talks with Wash ington if the United States lifted its economic blockade of the island.

The battle for control of Pergamon Press, Ltd., escalated today as the company's institutional shareholders disclosed that they were considering separate proposals from the Reliance Group and Robert Maxwell, Pergamon's former chairman.

State Department officials said today that Secretary of State Kissinger might soon visit the Middle East again to help work out an agreement between Egypt and Israel on separation of their forces along the Suez Canal.
William P. Hurley, who retired in 1963 as professor of physics at Fordham University after 40 years on the faculty, died Monday at Union Hospital in the Bronx. He was 78 years old.
Bill Walton of U.C.L.A. sustained only a back bruise after taking a hard fall last night in a game against Washington State at Pullman, a school official said today.
President Nixon is expected to propose to Congress this month a national health insurance program for all Americans that would cost about $37.5-billion next year.

The National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing (NASCAR) and Winston announced today an increase of $20,000 in the Winston Cup Grand National awards for 1974. The total prize money will be $140,000.
A gun battle between state troopers and local policemen and a gunman here this afternoon for almost an hour resuited in the capture of the badly injured man and injuries to four other persons.
A permanent problem in standard bidding methods is the moderate four-five hand, with a four-card suit just outranking a five-card suit.
A student athlete may turn professional in one sport but retain his amateur status for other intercollegiate sports, the National Collegiate Athletic Association ruled today.

A Federal judge issued a stern warning yesterday to the United States. Attorney and Federal law enforcement officials here against any repetition of a case last spring in which on-the-spot news coveragewas permitted of a roundup of suspected narcotics dealers.

States Representative Ella Grasso said today that she was a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Connecticut this year. She is the first woman to seek the gubernatorial nomination of a major political party in Connecticut.

The Alleghany Corporation is assuming a greater interest in the shoe machinery business through its increased acquisition of stock in the USM Corporation, formerly the United Shoe Machinery corporation, Alleghany acknowledged yesterday that its holdings in USM stock had climbed to 900,500 shares, or about 22 per cent, from about 5 per cent held a year and a half ago.
Tommy Prothro, dropped by the Los Angeles Rams in his first job as a pro football coach, was hired today as head coach of the San Diego Chargers.
Bud Grant, the Minnesota coach, said today he had been threatened with a fine by Commissioner Pete Rozelle should he continue to complain about the inadequacy of the Viking practice facilities here.

Paul Methuen, one of the most prolific painters of his generation, died yesterday in a hospital in Bath. He was 87 years old.

Against a background of concern about merchandise shortages and uncertainty because of the energy crisis, representatives of the nation's retail industry are finding reasons to be optimistic about this year's prospects for sales of youth apparel, food services and leisure-time goods.
Despite rare astronomical conditions that caused higher than normal tides, no serious flooding was reported yesterday along the New York, New Jersey or Connecticut coasts.
Sweden today began more than seven weeks of rationing oil and gasoline. Many service stations ran out the first morning. The rationing of heating oil also took effect today.

Henry Weitz, former director and senior vice president of Loehmann's, the women's dress store chain, died here today of a heart attack. His age was 72 and he lived in Hollywood.

Lawyers representing the public challenged today the legality of a Public Utilities Commission order allowing the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company to pass increased operating costs directly on to consumers without a formal rate hearing.

Ron Santo moved across town from Wrigley Field to White Sox Park, yesterday and gained a salary increase. "I received a raise," said Santo, who was paid a reported $110,000 to play third base for the Chicago Cubs last season.

The Chicago Cougars and Cleveland Crusaders skated to a scoreless tie in overtime tonight-the World Hockey Association's first overtime contest to end with a 0-0 score.

March wheat futures prices rose to a record for any month's contract of $5.92 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade. Yesterday's soaring price erased the former high of $5.78 registered by December wheat in mid-December before it expired.

After five disastrous years of declining rainfall that culminated in drought, desolation and death, the tragedy of the sun-scorched region of former French West Africa has come to public attention. It is a tragedy that could have been avoided.

Christa Zechmeister, a 16-year-old Bavarian, won her second major international slalom race in succession today and became a top contender for World Cup honors.

Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan, asserting that "working people are entitled to a fair share of the spoils," said today that inflation was likely to create a demand for substantially higher wages In 1974.

Governor Cahill urged the new Democratic legislative majority that took office here today to approve a state income tax as part of a sweeping reformation of what he described as New Jersey's unjust and regressive revenue system.

Two Washington, D. C., men who had pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in the shooting of a United States mail guard were sentenced yesterday to serve 25 years in prison.

Marvin Glass, a well-known toy designer and the founder of Marvin Glass Associates here, died last night at his home in suburban Evanston, of complications following a stroke he suffered last summer. He was 59 years old.
Two accidents involving school buses carrying retarded children occurred yesterday in Brooklyn and Queens. None of the children was seriously injured.

SAILING TODAY Trans-Atlantic FRANCE (French), Around-the-world Cruise; sails 1 P.M. from W. 44th St. ATLANTIC CINDERELLA (Atlantic Container), Goteborg Jan. 18; sails from Port Newark, N.J. Letter mails for Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden.

Emphasizing the "moderate, middle way," Governor Wilson delivered his first message to the Legislature today and promised there would be "no extravagant ventures" by the state in this time of inflation and fuel shortage.
A special envoy of the 19-nation Arab League opened a threemonth cross-country campaign today to tell the Arab side of the Middle East conflict to as many Americans as possible.

Maxmilian Egon Raym, who retired in 1966 as public-relations representative for Press Wireless at the United Nations, died, apparently of a coronary attack, yesterday at his home, 1192 Park Avenue. He was 71 years old.

Stock prices dropped on a broad front yesterday. Recent market favorites and old-line glamour issues were hit particularly hard. The Dow-Jones industrial average, with none of its blue-chip components showing a gain, sank 26.99 points to 834.79.

Minister Masayoshi Ohira said today that Japan expected to conclude a civil aviation agreement with China soon, apparently removing the obstacle that has stalled, improved relations between the two countris for over a year.

The city Correction Commissioner, Benjamin J. Malcolm, asserted yesterday that conditions at the Manhattan House of Detention, also known as the Tombs, were "not as bad as critics would have you believe."

A 21-year-old inmate who died slowly by scalding in the Trenton State Prison was regarded as a key witness against state officials in the death of a fellow prisoner, it was disclosed today by lawyers and a penal reform organization.
Twelve members of the American Nazi party were attacked last night during a Board of Education meeting Called to consider the integra tion of the city's junior and Senior high schools.

The Pentagon says the attempt to locate more than 1,100 United States servicemen missing in Indochina will continue, despite a temporary halt after an attack last month on a helicopter engaged in the search.

Major oilexporting nations, after quadrupling their prices in the last three months, today promised stability over the next quarter but warned that future price decisions hinged on the industrial countries' ability to control both inflation and the profits of oil companies.
For the second week in a row, record costs were reported yesterday for the 38-item Market Basket survey of food for a family of four as monitored by the City Department of Consumer Affairs.
George Dungee, a 36-year-old fugitive from a Baltimore prison, was convicted today of six counts of murder and sentenced to death in the mass slaying of a South Georgia farm family.
Mrs. Gwen Broadley of Warwickshire, England, has judged in many parts of the world, including Australia, Africa and Europe.

Air Products Chemicals, Inc., said yesterday it had been awarded "multi-million dollar contracts' by Pertamina, the Indonesian state oil and gas enterprise. The contracts call for Air Products to supply its patented MCR process and coil-wound liquefied natural gas heat exchangers for what is expected to be the largest base-load LNG project ever undertaken at a total cost of more than $3billion.

Two goals by a aerenseman, Mike Pelyk, propelled the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 6-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight and into sole possession of third place in the National Hockey League East Division.

New York University faculty members and librarians began voting in the university's runoff collective-bargaining election yesterday and will continue the balloting until this evening. The runoff choice between the American Association of University Professors and the "no agent," or no union, position, were ordered by the National Labor Relations Board in November, when neither side got the necessary majority in a three-sided race in which the United Federation of College Teachers was eliminated. Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, said yesterday that he might announce some decision earlier than usual on his political future. Mr. Aiken, 81 years old, is completing his sixth term. If he decides to seek a seventh term, he will face re-election in November.

The American Petroleum Institute reported today another substantial drop in refineries' stocks of crude oil as criticism mounted that. the Government was wholly dependent on unverified industry data for information essential to policy-making.

The White House explanation of President Nixon's decision to raise milk price supports apparently contradicts a recent declaration by Mr. Nixon that he refused all information about campaign contributions prior to the 1972 election.

A group of black students and educators has accused the History of misrepresenting African history and asked that a black curator be hired "to supervise all activities and presentations of African history and culture."

George Morris, a former United States Equestrian Team rider from Pittstown, N. J., and Carlene Blunt of Delray Beach, Fla., were named today horseman and horsewoman of the year for 1973 by the American Horse Shows Association.

Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea will introduce on Monday a bill to suspend the state's 2.5 per cent income-tax surcharge for another year, his office announced today.

Dorsie W. Willis, an 87-yearold retired shoeshine boy who was dishonorably discharged from the United States Army by President Theodore Roosevelt, received a tax-free Government check today for $25,000 as a sort ,of payment for services not rendered. Dorsie W. Willis, only survivor of the Brownsville Incident, during ceremonies in Minneapolis yesterday. Representative Augustus F. Hawkins, left, of California applauds as Maj. Gen. DeWitt Smith Jr. reads I.R.S. letter saying check is tax-free.

Governor Wilson submitted to the Legislature today a deficiency budget in which he requested $26.6-million in spending authorizations, the lowest such request since 1965, to meet expenses not anticipated when the 1973-74 budget was approved last April.

The war against potholes is one the city can't win for losing. The Detroit Pistons have designated Feb. 1 as "Dave DeBusschere Day" honoring the former Pistons' player coach and Al-Star forward of the New York Knicks on his last appearance in the Motor City this season. Dave DeBusschere, retiring as player, is to be honored Feb. 1 in Detroit, where he coached Pistons.

Secretary of State Kissinger today urged all countries-producers and consumers of oil alike-to work for long-term multinational agreement to solve the energy shortage, rather than seek short-term advantages in country-by-country deals. Secretary of State Kissinger and William E. Simon, head of the Federal Energy Office, at a news conference yesterday before Mr. Kissinger left for the Mideast.

Iran has reportedly accepted a United States offer to sell 30 Grumman F-14A fighters at a total cost of $900-million, including spare parts. The decision by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi was conveyed to American officials yesterday, according to highly reliable aviation sources.

Dick Williams, the phantom manager of the New York Yankees, retreated from baseball's legal wars yesterday and took a temporary job as an assistant to John D. MacArthur,. the wealthy Florida businessman and developer. Dick Williams telling about his new post. At left is John D. MacArthur, for whom he'll work.
Richard F. Clevand, the oldest son of President Grover Cleveland and a lawyer and civic leader, died at his home here today. He was 76 years old.

RICHARD II, a play by William Shakespeare, Directed by John Barton; setting by Timothy O'Brien and Tazeena Firth; lighting by David Hersey; music by James Walker. The Royal Shakespeare Company, presented by the Brooklyn Academy of Music, at 30 Lafayette Avenue. Ian Richardson playing the title role..

The Brunswick Corporation said yesterday that an admission by the Internal Revenue Service to the United States Tax Court that Brunswick's tax liability for the years 1962 through 1969 was $22-million less than the Government claimed confirmed the company's position that the I.R.S. had made inconsistent determinations for later years.

William E. Simon, the Federal energy chief, said today that investigators from his Federal Energy Office and the Internal Revenue Service would audit the price, profit and supply records of every petroleum refinery in the nation.

The soaring price of gasoline may do little to drive consumers away from the pump this year. Instead, Americans seem inclined to pay more to fill up the car--and to spend less of their money on other things.

The Interdepartmental Fuel and Energy Committee, which soon will become Governor Wilson's emergency coordinating group, has urged broad changes in the state's transportation system for the more efficient use of fuel.

Gov. Ronald Reagan proposed today a record $9.81-billion state budget that envisions a $272-million surplus as a possible cushion against the energy crunch. The proposed budget was the biggest in the nation but the second tightest Governor Reagan has submitted.

Remarks by Cuba's Ambassador to Mexico about the possibility of resuming contacts with the United States are of more than passing. interest, especially since for once the State Department did not dismiss the comments out of hand but promised to "weigh everything."

The State minority leader, Allen Jones Cook, died today at the Wilmington General Division. A downstate, conservative Democrat, Mr. Cook began his public career in 1949 at the age of 28, when he was elected to the House of Representatives.

Onny Parun of New Zealand and Ross Case of Australia advanced to the semi-finals of an international tennis tournament today. Parun defeated Syd Ball of Australia 7-5, 5-7, 4-6, 6-2, 6-4, and Case beat another Aussie, Allan Stone, 6-7, 2-6, 7-5, 6-1, 6-2.

John D. Ehrlichman, the former adviser to President Nixon, was offered a deal by the special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, in return for his cooperation in Watergate-related prosecutions, The Los Angeles Times reported in its Friday editions.

Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States and Panama had made "substantial progress" toward a "statement of principles" on their negotiations on a new treaty regulating the American-owned Panama Canal.

The Health Department is conducting a major campaign against health violations in the city's schools, and has summoned the principals of three elementary schools and one junior high school to hearings on "unsafe and hazardous" conditions in their buildings.
Banking and credit statistics released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday seemed to indicate a continuing trend toward making it easier to borrow money.

The 64th National Boat Show, which opens tomorrow at 10 A.M., has its fingers crossed. So does nearly everybody connected with the annual spectacle at the Coliseum. Boats on the second floor of the Coliseum. In foreground is the bow of the 34-foot Grampion Marine craft..

The American Electric Power P System and the General Atomic Company announced yesterday a joint program to develop a series of 1.5-million-kilowatt standardized nuclear power plans. The plants would be of the high-temperature, gas-cooled reactor type in contrast to the light-water reactors now generally in use. They would also have the largest capacity of any units yet ordered. dered.
The Rev. Dr. J. Pius Barbour, pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church here, died of gastroenteritis following a cerebral hemhorrage at Lankenau Hospital in Philadelphia on Saturday. He was 79 years old.

Senator John C. Stennis of Mississippi, who was critically wounded during a robbery outside his Washington home almost a year ago, said yesterday that his health is "good with no complications" and that he definitely would be a candidate for re-election in 1976. Senator John C. Stennis

Japan is to invest in a 500,000-barrel-a-day Iranian oil refinery, it was announced here today. The output of the $2-billion refinery, which will also feed a chemical refinery, will go to Japan, officials disclosed after the departure of the Japanese Minister of International Trade and Industry, Yasuhiro Nakasone.
President Nixon soon will suspend wheat import quotas as a hedge against possible domestic shortages, an administration source said today.
The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said yesterday that it planned to raise prices on tin-mill products about 8 per cent, effective Feb. 16.
Colt Industries, Inc., which makes specialty steel through ts Crucible Steel division, reported yesterday record sales and earnings in the fourth quarter and all of 1973.
The Encyclopaedia Britannica is abandoning its current design and coming out in a radically new form--its first major innovation in more than 200 years of publication.

The Export- Import Bank approved today, as expected, a combined loan and financial guarantee of $100-million to finance United States equipment and services for building an oil pipeline in Egypt running from the Gulf of Suez to a terminal west of Alexandria.

A White House explanation that political considerations and Congressional pressures contributed to President Nixon's decision to raise milk price supports in 1971 seemingly conflicts with a sworn statement by the Secretary of Agriculture at the time, Clifford M. Hardin.

With an eloquent plea for reform of one of the nation's most unjust tax systems and for enactment of a state income tax, Gov. William T. Cahill has delivered a timely and relevant swan song to the New Jersey Legislature.

Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the United States had begun re-targeting some of its strategic missiles so they could strike at Soviet military installations as well as cities.
" There's so much prejudice in New York-I think they're afraid of it." The speaker was the country music singer Buck Owens, and the subject was country music.

The World Cup organizing committee said today there had been no agreement between Chile and the Soviet Union over compensation for the Russians' refusal to play a qualifying soccer match in Santiago. Chile demanded that the Soviet Union make up gate losses incurred when the Russian team refused to play a match with Chile on the ground that the detention of prisoners in Santiago's stadium-where the match was to be played-made it "a concentration camp."

Secretary of State Kissinger yesterday urged all countries--producers and consumers of oil alike--to work for long-term multinational agreement to solve the energy shortage, rather than seek short-term advantages in country-by-country deals. Secretary of State Kissinger and William E. Simon, head of the Federal Energy Office, at a news conference yesterday before Mr. Kissinger left for the Mideast.
George R. Wadleigh, who retired 28 years ago as managing director of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company, died Tuesday at Dobbs Ferry Hospital. He was 98 years old and lived here.
Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea will introduce on Monday a bill to suspend the state's 2.5 per cent income-tax surcharge for another year, his office announced today.
Copper futures showed some strong price rises yesterday at a session during which traders learned that the Government would soon sell copper from its stockpile of about 251,000 tons.
New York was sodden, slushy, soggy, splashy and sloppy yesterday. It was also raw and rotten. In other words, it was a perfect day to sell hot soup.
Ten Protestant and Roman Catholic organizations and leaders have joined the Minneapolis-based American Lutheran Church in a court test involving clergy confidentiality.
The Cambodian Air Force, in a day-long battle, struck repeatedly today against rebel positions west and north of Phnom Penh, reportedly with napalm.

Confident, even magistral in his command of the keyboard, the 25-year-old Cubanborn pianist Horaclo Gutleryez blazed his way through Beethoven, Liszt and Prokofiev in his Carnegie Hall recital on Wednesday evening.

Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne appointed two more cabinet members of his incoming Democratic administration today, nominating Joseph A. Hoffman to be State Commissioner of Labor and Industry and James J. Sheeran as Commissioner of Insurance. Gov.-elect Brendan T. Byrne with James J. Sheeran, left, his choice for Insurance Commissioner, and Joseph A. Hoffman, right, nominee for Commissioner of Labor and Industry.
A 225-year-old copper weather vane stolen last week from the roof of Faneuil Hall was recovered tonight from a hiding place in the Revolutionary War meeting place.

The Greek Government invited the Orthodox Church's Assembly of Bishops today to vote for a new primate Saturday but disqualified 34 of the 66 prelates from participating.

Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson opened his campaign for re-election today, vowing to run independently of candidates for other offices and promising to avoid the "negativism" of racial hostilities in the political race. Mayor Gibson launching his campaign for re-election at Newark's City Hall

Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan met here today with representatives of students who had been denouncing his visit as symptomatic of "economic imperialism." Chants in English of "Jap, go home!" were heard yesterday shortly after he arrived. Premier Kakuei Tanaka, left, of Japan meeting yesterday with Sanya Dharmasakti, Premier of Thailand, in Bangkok during a visit to Government House.

A man free on bail on two felony charges shot and killed three persons today, wounded three others including a woman hostage, and then apparently killed himself and his girlfriend after his car crashed as he fled from the police, the Delaware State Police said.

As signaled in advance by weekly figures, retail sales in the Christmas season and for December as a whole were strong except for the sharply slumping automobile sector, Commerce Department figures disclosed today. Holiday shoppers at Macy's at Herald Square. Christmas season sales were reported up.

Frank Mahovlich marked his 36th birthday with a power-play goal and Guy Lafleur added two others tonight to spark Montreal to an 8-3 victory over the New York Islanders at the Forum.

The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation said last night that a branch of Canada's National Research Council in Ottawa was really an intelligence agency working closely with the Central Intelligence Agency of the United States.

ARBEIT-Arnold A., Dr., of 116 Fox Meadow Road, Scarsdale, N.Y. Listed in "Who's Who in America", Col. of U.S. Army, retired. Architect, artist, professor. Survived by wife Amelia Feibush and son Stewart of same address. Services at Riverside Memorial, 76th St. Amsterdam Ave., N.Y.C., 12:00 noon Friday, Jan. 11, 1974.

In the West Country town of Hereford the president of a women's club told a yearend meeting that the January bingo game would be canceled to save electricity. Then she proposed a New Year's resolution.

Eleven persons have been indicted in connection with an alleged multimillion-dollar loan-sharking ring in Manhattan's garment area whose profits are said to have gone toward the buying and selling of stolen property and smuggled and jacked cigarettes. Joseph Winograd, right, and his wire, Sylvia, leaving the District Attorney's office yesterday. In the background be are Fred Russell, face covered, and John Savino, also named in loan-sharking indictments.
A member of the United States liaison office here is leaving because of a car accident in November in which a young Chinese cyclist was fatally injured.
Hundreds of enthusiasts who try to improve their game by taking lessons felt a sense of personal deprivation recently when the country's No. 1 bridge teacher, Bill Root, moved to Florida.
The Independent Investor Protective League filed a class-action antitrust suit yesterday against Time Inc. asking damages of $1.37-billion.

A resident of a Boston suburb looked at the comet Kohoutek through binoculars for the first time Tuesday night, saw a fuzzy blur in the heavens and said, "Watergate, then the energy crisis, and now the comet."

Responding angrily to Mayor Beame's sudden postponement of the appointment of State Senator Joseph L. Galiber to the last remaining Deputy Mayor's slot, a group of 14 black ministers yesterday sent a telegram to the Mayor charging "racism which imputes misbehavior towards black leaders even when there is no basis for the charge." People at City Hall to see Joseph L. Galiber sworn in linger uncertainly after being told of postponement Mr. Galiber Mayor Beame

MADRID-No one doubted the outcome of the trial of the "Carabanchel Ten," who have been sentenced to twelve to twenty years in prison for their labor activities-attempts to organize workers to improve wages and working conditions, conduct that is protected by civilized governments.

President Nixon's invitation to major oilconsumer nations to coordinate policies at a Washington meeting on Feb. 11 has drawn a generally positive response although the Common Market countries: - including France. the least enthusiastic among them -- said they would have to discus the matter further.

Despite two days of free immunizations and widespread publicity, this city still has a serious outbreak of measles cases. And in Newark, health authorities report a sharp upsurge in measles since Dec. 1.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over the-counter market declined for the third consecutive session yesterday as investors' concern over the inflationary trend and possible recession continued to weaken most issues.

One of nine students wounded in the 1970 Kent State University shootings appeared today before a Federal grand jury. Donald S. MacKenzie, who was wounded in the. neck in the shooting that killed four other students, said he had appeared before the jurors, but he refused to say anything else.

The Nassau County District Attorney's office is under Federal investigation for possible grand-jury tampering in a case involving Republican politicians, sources close to the investigation disclosed yesterday.

The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has proposed new rules to control the costs and quality of hospital and nursing-home care for elderly and poor people whose medical bills are paid by the Government.

If 1973 was unkind to shareholders in general, it was doubly so to owners of shares of closed-end trusts. As a result of market setbacks plus persistent and deepening discounts in trust shares, there is talk of combinations with well-managed mutual funds, talk that has resulted in merger in at least one case.

Additional pollution of the Hudson River, possible air pollution and heavy truck traffic all came in for discussion tonight as the New Jersey State Environmental Protection Agency opened public hearings into the proposed construction of a new heating-oil storage depot on the waterfront here.

The New York Civil Liberties Union intends to enter the election conspiracy case of Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea and argue that the charges against him should be dismissed because they are unconstitutional.

The Buffalo Sabres went on a scoring binge in the third period tonight, knocking in five goals to shatter the New York Rangers, 7-2, at Memorial Auditorium. Three goals were scored in the first 1 minute 52 seconds of the period, and two were only 10 seconds apart.

A fire broke out just before noon on the top floor of the Carnegie Hall building. Thirty-five firemen raced to the scene in seven trucks, disrupting traffic in the area for about an hour. The concert and recital halls at ground level on 57th Street were not affected. Firemen reported, however, that three photo studios on the 12th floor were damaged by smoke. .

Forty persons were killed last night when a twoengine turboprop plane of a national military airline crashed in flames on the Andean foothills in southern Colombia.

Don Doll, Green Bay Packers' defensive backfield coach who helped mold one of the National Football League's stingiest pass defenses in 1972, resigned for personal reasons.

This season, for the first time in its history, the Metropolitan Opera has had an official music director working in tandem with the general manager. But Schuyler G. Chapin, the manager, said yesterday in an interview in his office, "I must always take the final responsibility." Rafael Kubelik

How do you cope with the fact that profound social change - whether it's progressive or reactionary - is often accompanied by violence? And can you untangle the concepts of "necessary" and "negative" violence, or determine the moment when resistance becomes aggression! Before having to answer in 25 words or less, students of these subjects should see and ponder "When the People Awake" and "Tupamaros!" at the First Avenue Screening Room today and tomorrow.

Street crime has increased in Peking and some other Chinese cities to the point where neighborhoods are being patrolled day and night by militia units. These patrols are backed by a poster campaign urging public support for the fight aganist "hooliganism."

Joseph A. Kaplan, a 26-year-old Israeli citizen, was arrested on murder charges this morning in the fatal shooting last week of Maurice Salvia, an Atlantic City Boardwalk auctioneer for whom he worked as a chauffeur.

President Kennedy told a reporter in a private conversation in November, 1961, that he was under great pressure from intelligence advisers to order the assassination of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba, according to an article in the February issue of Esquire magazine.

Half a dozen banks - large but not giant-sized - reported their earnings for 1973 yesterday with four showing gains and two, declines. They include: the United States Trust Company, up 29 per cent; the Arizona Bank up 18 per cent; the Bank of New York, up 11 per cent; the First National Bank of New Jersey, up 8 per cent; the Citizens and Southern National Bank.

Cario, Jan. 10-The United Nations today reported restraints on the movement of its patrols to oversee the cease-fire between the Egyptians and Israelis, and said that tension at the city of Suez "again has heightened" because of an advance of Egyptian troops to a new position.

Phil Esposito, the National Hockey League's leading scorer, beat his younger brother, tony, with his 38th goal with 45 seconds left tonight, giving the Boston Bruins a 2-2 tie with the Chicago Black Hawks.
Cast Upon the Breakers, by Horatio Alger Jr., forward by Ralph D. Gardner (Doubleday, $6.95). Book edition of a story that appeared serialized in Argosy magazine in 1893.

A 19-year-old upstate college coed on her first visit to the city was kidnapped from a Queens street corner Wednesday night by three men who repeatedly raped her as they drove about for more than five hours, the police said yesterday. y.
Prices eased slightly, in the secondary corporate bond market yesterday, but the pace of new offerings remained brisk and acceptance ratios continued to be generally favorable.
Commission on Status of Women, working group on discrimination--10 A.M. and 3 P. M. Signers of convention on elimination of racial discrimination--10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

Indian and American scholars announced today a broad effort to spur academic exchanges and research in both countries. A joint statement, after a four-day meeting of scholars, made it plain, however, that the Indian Government was placing restrictions on the flow of students and limiting their subjects of study.

Stock prices continued to plummet yesterday amid fears of a recession in 1974, huge increases in energy costs and high inflation rates. Trading volume was relatively light. The stock market made a half-hearted rally at midsession, then grew progressively weaker.

Governor Wilson said yesterday that he was "disappointed" that more drug addicts had not applied for treatment in the wake of the state's stringent anti-drug laws, which took effect last Sept. 1. Ghezzi, left, acting New York Secretary of State, swearing in Anthony Cagliostro yesterday as chairman of the Drug Abuse Control Commission as Mr. Cagliostro's wife, Monica, and Governor Wilson observed.

The New York Nets completed a sweep of a three game road trip by beating the San Antonio Spurs, 105-93, tonight at the HemisFair arena. The victory was the 25th in the last 32 games for the Nets, Eastern Division leaders of the American Basketball Association.

Ten years ago today, the Surgeon General of the Public Health Service issued a momentous report citing cigarette smoking as a major hazard to life and health. Alpha Portland Industries, Inc., said yesterday that a subsidiary was successful low bidder as a coventurer in a $54.3-million contract to build a portion of the New York subway system. After a series of injuries that limited the sure-handed Miami Dolphin receiver to only two pass receptions during the regular season, Twilley was named to start in Sunday's game against the Minnesota Vikings if Paul Warfield is not sufficiently recovered from a pulled hamstring muscle. Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. proposed today a broad liberalization of the state's "right to know" laws that would make it easier for private citizens to gain access to government information.

Dr. Donald B. Thorburn, an osteopathic physician in New York from 1923 until his retirement in 1971' and a member of the New York State Board of Medical Examiners from 1938 to 1952, died yesterday. He was 78 years old and lived here.
The 47 Chinese paintings in "The Colors of Ink," a new exhibition at Asia House, 112 East 64th Street, are, by literal definition, colorless, since all are in black ink with its gray variants.

Dr. John O. Theiss, who was perhaps one of the last of the old-time physicians who thought nothing of making a house call in the middle of the night, died today. He was 77 years old, and, while his home was in this mountain community, his practice ranged all over the state and beyond its borders.

If the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera both perform "Madama Butterfly," why cannot both the New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater perform Balanchine's "Apollo"? It is an interesting question.

The distinctly precisionist elan of the sculptures of Michael Steiner now on view at the Mailborough Gallery, Inc., 40 West 57th Street, is the most remarkable feature of these recent works by the 29-year-old American artist.

Too much snow and not enough gasoline severely handicapped the start of the Tristate Regional Championships here Thursday. Attendance for the first of the four days of play was about 40 per cent below previous years.
The bankrupt Penn Central Railroad lost an appeal today seeking the increase of an award of $2.-million for the sale of property and air rights in Journal Square in Jersey City.

The 31-year-old mother of three young children was found slain in her $75,000 home here today. Edward F. Curran, the Nassau County chief of detectives, said that the victim, Mrs. Barbara Waldman, the wife of Dr. Gerald H. Waldman, a dentist, had been found by her 5-yearold son, Eric, lying next to her bed on the second floor of the Colonial style home at 3917 Sally Lane.

Two former officials of Associated Milk Producers, Inc., pleaded guilty today in Federal District Court here to charges that they conspired to donate illegally $22,000 in corporate funds in 1968 to the Democratic Presidential campaign.

The Rev. Joseph P. McCormack, a Maryknoll missioner, died Tuesday of cancer at St. Teresa's Residence. He was 80 years old.

The Wall Street community is stirring with speculation that the major New York City bank pension trusts will show abysmal performances for 1973 as a result of their commitment to the so-called "nifty-50" stocks, which have suddenly and dramatically fallen out of favor.
A convicted narcotics dealer won a reversal yesterday of his conviction on a Federal civilrights charge that he had killed a Manhattan model to prevent her from testifying against him.

Greece's military regime, faced with a $900-million bill for oil imports in 1974, tonight imposed strict fuel economy measures, ranging from a 65 per cent price increase on gasoline to alternate-weekend motoring. Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market rebounded yesterday after two days of declines and closed slightly higher in light trading.

Henry Lionel Williams, author of more than 70 books covering a wide range of subjects, died Wednesday in New Milford Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived here. Mr. Williams, a native of England, came to the United States in 1923 and later became a citizen.

Marty Liquori, who has not run an indor mile race under 4 minutes, started off with every intention of doing so tonight. But halfway through his first indoor mile of the winter, the former Villanova star decided to settle for just a victory.

Tony Lama Sr., who in 1911 founded the Tony Lama. Company, now a publicly owned manufacturer of Western boots and accessories, died here today at the age of 86. Mr. Lama joined the cavalry in the early part of the century and took part in action along the Mexican border.

The wedding of Miss Anne de Lapeyrouse-Vaucresson and Franklin Reginald Forbes Singer, a great-grandson of Isaac Merritt Singer, inventor of the Singer sewing machine, took place in the chapel of St. Louis-des-Invalides today.

Shortly before Thanksgiving, one of the older players on the Minnesota Vikings approached Chuck Foreman. "Rookie," he said, "be sure to get your free turkey." "What free turkey?" the rookie running back asked. The older player told him about a supermarket where it was traditional for members of the Vikings to receive a free turkey. Other rookies also were told about it.

A mistrial was declared yesterday in the misconductconspiracy trial of former Stafford Township Mayor Wesley K. Bell, charged with trying to alter drunken-driving charges for an associate. The mistrial was declared by Judge William Huber of Ocean County after the jury failed to reach a verdict on one misconduct count. Earlier in the day, the panel found Mr. Bell not guilty of conspiracy, eliminating that charge.

People's Revolutionary Army guerrillas said today that the Esso Argentina Oil Corporation had agreed to donate $10-million worth of food, clothing, tools and medicine to the poor if the guerrillas would free Victor S. Samuelson, an Esso executive kidnapped Dec. 6.

American automobile company subsidiaries in Argentina are negotiating with Cuban officials for the sale of thousands of cars and trucks over the next few years. Technically, it would be part of a large trade agreement between the Governments of Argentina and Cuba.

In Moscow, chauffeur-driven Chaikas line up in Red Square, waiting for high members of the Soviet Government. Top Kremlin officials may keep these cars, but many lowerranking bureaucrats must surrender the less luxurious vehicles assigned to them.

RAPID CITY, S. D.--During the months that have passed since the first hint that "peace is at hand," I have been haunted by two phrases from Lincoln's Second Inaugural Address: "to bind up the nation's wounds and "to care for him who shall have bone the battle." These are among the few humane and hopeful sentiments that can come out of war.

SUMMIT - Mrs. Irene Krugman, whose works are the subject of a one-woman show at the Summit Art Center, is what is known as a "gestural" artist. That is to say that she is as concerned with the gesture of making art-the means and the ideas behind it - as she is with what the end result looks like.

Joey Newton Kagebien of DeWitt, sentenced three years ago at the age of 15 to die in the electric chair, may be a free man in a few years. In a new trial here last Monday, he was convicted of second-degree murder and received a 21-year prison sentence, with 12 years suspended. Under Arkansas law, the youth would be eligible for parole in about two and a half years.

Fire bombs destroyed two homes owned by Roman Catholics in a Belfast suburn during the night in a new spate a street violence by Protestants, the police said today. Irish Republican Army bombers matched the Protestant action by blowing up two shops in Newry and Dungannon, policemen added.

Now Ice becomes the wedge that can level the hills. The slow seep of midday melt creeps into the rocks, into those hairline cracks, and when darkness comes with its deep cold, the seep freezes and opens the crack a little wider. Eventually the root of spring will find a place to grow there, and another winter will pry again, and again, until a whole ledge totters.

LAGUNA BEACH, Calif.-Inadvertently, the White House has added to the textbooks on American government chapters and verse on exactly how political considerations influence Federal policy. The intent has been to place the actions of President Nixon in the most defensible light; the accidental result has been to describe the machinery of government as the prize of contending pressure groups-a description not new but newly documented.

A debate began among historians, journalists, sociologists and politicians on the causes of Israel's refusal to face facts, which were all too clear in retrospect.

HOUSTON, Jan. 13-The Miami Dolphins aren't perfect after all. Their quarterback, Bob Griese, and their fullback, Larry Csonka, each forgot the snap count today at the Minnesota Vikings' 2-yard line in the third quarter. In the huddle, Griese had ordered the ball to be snapped "on one," meaning the second "hut" in his call at the line of scrimmage.

At AAA Galleries here shoppers seek less expensive works. Art sales here last year were about $150 million.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13-A sense of deep uncertainty, even bewilderment, pervades the top economic officials of the Government over the financial "atom bomb" represented by the huge increase in the world price of oil.
The first week of winter Daylight Saving Time has prompted many school districts across the country to delay starting times so children do not travel to class in the dark.
That vague and often mysterious term "jazz singer" is no closer to definition after a concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening that was called "The Jazz Singers."
Is there really an energy crisis? Or even a genuine shortage? Is it all a contrivance of the oil industry? Or just a honest but ghastly miscalculation by the Government?
A Congressional staff study, made public today, concludes that most people are correct in their belief that any increased income they had in 1973 was more than offset by higher prices.

The marriage of Miss Katherine Elliott Buck to David Michael Miller, a vice president of the American Express Company, took place here last night in All Saints Episcopal Church. The Rev. James De Wolfe performed the ceremony.

Football's Super Sunday brought to an end yesterday the National League's championship season amid the sounds of jingling cash registers and the happy wails of football widows who reclaimed their husbands. Larry Csonka of Dolphins smashes off tackle at Houston. Roy Winston (60) and Nate Wright (43) defend for Vikings. Bud Grant, Vikings' coach, sees the Dolphins move downfield against his team in the first quarter.

Fifteen years after the first American combat troops entered South Vietnam, the American intelligence community is telling the President that the question is still when-not whether --North Vietnam is going to launch a major offensive against the South.
A new bail system that allows defendants in criminal cases to. post with the court only as much money as they would normally pay a bail bondsman has passed its first court test.

Douglas Newton, curator of the Museum of Primitive Art since 1960, has been named its director, it was announced yesterday by former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, founder and president of the museum. Mr. Newton will fill the vacancy left last March by the death of Dr. Robert Goldwater.

A special bipartisan advisory committee on the state's election laws is expected to recommend this week the creation of a salaried, four-member commission to oversee the financing of election campaigns in the state.

AXELROD-Fannie. Beloved mother of Arthur and Phillip. Dear sister of Sessle Jenkins and Lily Escott. Loving grandmother of Gary, Robert and Mark. Adored greatgrandmother of Ira, Craig, Matthew, Kimberly and Jodi. Services at the Boulevard Chapels. 312 Coney Island Ave. at Prospet Park, B'klyn, Tuesday at I P.M.
Despite the energy crisis and the widespread money crunch, the art market last year enjoyed the biggest sales in its history, according to several New York art dealers.
HOUSTON, Jan. 13--"It's the most well-coordinated offensive team I've ever seen," Jack Patera said today in a tribute to the Miami Dolphins and their 24-7 Super Bowl victory.

President Nixon returned to Washington today after an 18day California vacation, prepared to plunge into a new round of government activity that his aides hope will divert some attention from his Watergate troubles and enhance his chances of continuing in office for the three years remaining in his term.

The Safe Return Amnesty Committee, which seeks exoneration of all war resisters, will hold meetings around the country aimed at renewing interest in the future of returning exiles, deserters and those already severed from the military with less than honorable discharges.

The revival of active political dissent in South Korea after more than a year of repression and stunned silence has triggered a new crackdown by the Seoul regime. President Park Chung Hee seemed to be moving toward some liberalization last month to contain the protest movement.

The series of articles starting today in the The New York Times measuring the attitudes and perceptions of New Yorkers is based on interviews .by Daniel Yankelovich, Inc., a leading public opinion research organization, with 1,341 residents 18 years or older during the last two weeks of November.
Red Christmas, by Patrick Ruell (Martin Dale Book: Hawthorn Books, $5.95). International intrigue and violence. The French Inheritance, by Anne Stevenson (Putnam, $6.95). Romance and suspense.

HOUSTON, Jan. 13-Bob Kuechenberg of the Miami Dolphins summed up today the basic ingredient in their Super Bowl victory. "Man for man," said the left guard, whose primary assignment was to block Alan Page of the Minnesota Vikings, "I thought we whipped 'em." Don Shula, Dolphins' coach, watching as his team led, 24-7, with 1 minute 25 seconds left in the game

Just two years ago, President Nixon signed - to the warm praise of conservationists--an Executive order that was intended to put an end to the horrid practice of poisoning prairie dogs and predatory birds and animals on the public lands. Of all man's intrusions on nature's order, the wholesale use of poison in the United States has been among the most reckless and indefensible.

INDIAN ROCKS BEACH, Fla.-Dogs used to be fine back in the old days, before they took obedience courses and vocational training and learned how to parody human skills in their clumsy way. But they've become a pain in the neck.

Clovis Ruffin isn't one of your staid, uptight designers. Not by a long shot. But the way the ,girls came gyrating down the runway of the Gotham Hotel's ballroom the other afternoon, chiffon flying and all that, you could see that even he had loosened up. Clovis Ruffin makes terry cloth look sexy in pajamas with jacket worn open, from his first loungewear colelection for Keyloun.
The city's school principals will soon join their students in getting report cards that will show how well-or how badly-they are doing in school.

Using a helicopter to break the ice of Prospect Park Lake, police emergency crews worked into the night grappling for the body of Daron Pritchard, a 13-year-old boy who fell through the ice while playing with a friend.
The corporate and tax-emept bond markets face another busy week as the heavy January calendar continues to move along at a brisk pace.
Raoul Jobin, a tenor who appeared in opera and on the concert stage in Europe, Latin America and the United States, died today of cancer. He was 67 years old.

The Administration will propose spending about $1.6-billion for energy research and development during the next fiscal year, with the heaviest new emphasis on greater use of coal, according to Government officials.

As Britain prepares to begin the third of her three-day work weeks, Prime Minister Heath is coming under pressure from mempers of his Cabinet to call a general election next month in an effort to win fresh public support in his fight against inflation and the nation's coal miners.

Miss Laurie Pellman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul N. Pellman of Oceanside, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Allan Daniel Rosenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Rosenberg of Garden City, L. I. Rabbi Abraham Moseson, assisted by Cantor Irving Rogoff, performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton.
Slowly, the teen-age girl approached Larry Csonka for an autograph. Noticing her cautious manner, the 238pound full-back of the Miami Dolphins smiled. Off the field, a quite different image.

The Arab world reacted with skepticism and some polite official statements to the announcement by Libya and Tunisia yesterday that they plan to merge into one nation. Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, left, the Libyan chief of state, and President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia during their meeting on unification Saturday in Tunis.

Makiko Lanaka is not like most Japanese women-demure, retiring, deferential to men. The daughter of Premier Kakuei Tanaka knows her own mind and speaks it often-and usually a mile a minute, like her father. She is poised, self assured and frank, qualities that have won her considerable attention from the press and public in the Southeast Asian nations she is currently visiting as her father's official hostess.

Mrs. Susan Rosenkowitz today handled all six of her babies in their incubators, and although all of the sextuplets are still suffering jaundice, a medical bulletin reported that the disease was under control.

The Government of Israel today approved a specific proposal for the separation of Israeli and Egyptian forces along the Suez Canal and authorized Secretary of State Kissinger to present the plan to the Government of Egypt. U.S. Ambassador Kenneth B. Keating trying to attract the attention of Secretary of State Kissinger during conference with Ephraim Evron, left, Israeli Foreign Ministry official, and Deputy Premier Yigal Allon on Saturday In Jerusalem.

Miss Jean Bloch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sam E. Bloch of Rego Park, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Menachem Z. Rosensaft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Josef Rosensaft. Dr. Gerson D. Cohen, chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, and Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein, chancellor of the Bar Ilan University in Israel, performed the ceremony at the Rosensaft home.

Henry C. McMullen, former president of the Union County Bar Association and municipal magistrate here from 1948 until 1960, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 78 years old and lived at 41 Mountain Avenue.
(AP)-Denis Hulme of New Zealand drove a McLaren to victory today in the 196-mile Argentine Grand Prix, the first Formula One race of the 1974 international circuit.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (Reuters)-The English Football League gave its 92 clubs permission today to play league matches on Sundays for the first time in the 85-year history of the league. Alan Hardaker, secretary of the league, announced the decision after a meeting of the management committee. He said Sunday league matches would be permitted from next Sunday as long as the current three-day working week in Britain continued.

HENRIETTA, N.Y., - "I know you have a lot of questions, just as your parents do," Representative Barber B. Conable Jr. told his audience of about 700 children at the Gates-Chili Middle School near here the other morning. Indeed, they did.
A Government spokesman today rejected a suggestion that President Lon Nol step aside to facilitate peace negotiations between the Government and the insurgent guerrillas.

In its current issue, Time magazine lists its choices for the "10 best newspapers" in the nation and, comparing the list with one drawn up 10 years ago, points out that half of them are new selections.

The $500-million American Reinsurance Company will contest the New York State Insurance Department ruling permitting the $1.2-billion American International Group of New York to acquire additional shares of American Reinsurance stock.
More than 100 young rightists have received court notices that they may have to stand trial on charges of attempting to subvert the democratic system in Italy.
Miss BarbaraEllenAtkinson,daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Atkinson of Yonkers, was married here this afternoon to Allan Richard Bobbe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Bobbe of Denville, N. J.

Ian Fleming immortalized 007. Joe Namath made the number 12 a fixture on thousands of T-shirts.. But one number that most people have never heard of is 2503 (c), a section of the Internal Revenue Code that deals with gifts to minor children.

VILLAGE VIBES Now that the Super Bowl has come and gone, and the basketball and and hockey playoffs and the opening of the baseball season remain, like the comet Kohoutek, dim and distant, maybe it's time for all the chairbound to stop watching and start doing.
WASHINGTON--A world unabashedly hooked on symbolism has-mistakenly, as we shall see - looked upon the two happy, healthy pandas as the symbol of detente between the great powers.

After being deluged with students for more than a decade, all but the most prestigious educational institutions suddenly find themselves with an excess of places in their substantially overexpanded facilities. Enrollments in 1973 increased at only half the rate of previous years and the private colleges showed a slight decline.
The New York Rangers posted their second victory in two days under the latest coaching regime of Emile Francis as they defeated the California Golden Seals tonight, 7-2, before a crowd of 5,231.

GREAT SOVIET ENCYCLOPEDIA. A Translation of the Third Edition. Volume 1. 678 pages. Macmillan. $50. Publication of the entire 30-volume set of the English translation of this major national Russian reference work is to be completed in 1979, but the purchaser of the first volume already gets information on the Soviet Union and other areas from A to Z.

The English Football League gave its 92 clubs permission today to play league matches on Sundays for the first time in the 85-year history of the league. Alan Hardaker, secretary of the league, announced the decision after a meeting of the management committee. He said Sunday league matches would be permitted from next Sunday as long as the current three-day working week in Britain continued.

The International Telephone Telegraph Compa ny, which probably has been involved in more controversy than any company in recent years, is increasing its corporate advertising budget by about 115 per cent over last year's and will use television for an image campaign for the first time
Lady Patricia Ramsay, a granddaughter of Queen Victoria who broke several court traditions, died yesterday at her home in Windlesham, Surrey. She was 87 years old.

As an agreement with Israel for disengagement of troops on the Egyptian front seemed to draw near, Egypt's Foreign Minister, Ismail Fahmy, assured fellow Arabs today that Cairo would not accept a "separate peace" with the Israelis.

The latest "explanations" from the White House reveal that President Nixon still has no conception of the precarious realities of his position. A press secretary, releasing lengthy statements about Mr. Nixon's role in the I.T.T. antitrust case and the raising of price supports for the milk producers, asserts that these accounts "will lay to rest the allegations against the President."

David R. Young Jr., a member of the White House "plumbers" group, concluded in a report submitted in early 1972 to President Nixon that Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had received secret National Security Council documents taken from the office of Henry A. Kissinger, well placed sources said today.

Dr. Martin Schreiber, a.psychiatrist who had written on the measurement of personality change in people undergoing psychoanalysis, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital, where he had served for many years on the psychiatric staff.

Helen Morgenthau Fox, who wrote and lectured widely on horticulture, died yesterday at her home in Mount Kisco, N.Y. Her age was 89. Mrs. Fox was the widow of Mortimer J. Fox, an architect, banker and landscape artist; a daughter of Henry Morgenthau Sr., United States Ambassador to Turkey from 1913 to 1916, and a sister of the late Henry M. Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury under President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The Government has begun to slip back after having reached the brink of success in dissolving large land holdings, distributing them to poor tenant farmers and thus eliminating one of the Vietcong's most potent political issues. Bui Van Bay, a farmer, knew of the land grant program but asked for none: "It would not have been honest."

Gifts from faraway places are no novelty to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. One eye-catching contribution came from Gail Hochman, a student at Oberlin College, in Ohio, who is spending her junior year at the University for Foreign Students in Perugia, Italy.

David Thompson, at his best, was too much for Maryland to handle yesterday. Thompson did everything that could be asked of a forward as his North Carolina State team defeated Maryland, 80-74, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game between two of the nation's top-ranked college basketball teams at Raleigh, N.C.

By his performance as Special Prosecutor, Leon Jaworski has quieted early questions about his ability to be independent from the President who appointed him. He has held together the staff picked by Archibald Cox; he has pressed the investigations; he has kept his distance-and his freedom-from the White House.
The conviction is growing among Soviet dissidents and Western diplomats here that for the present the authorities do not plan to take direct action against Aleksandr I.

Time continues to stand still for Artur Rubinstein. The great pianist strode onstage at Avery Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon for his latest recital here, sat at his instrument as straight - backed as ever and plunged into Chopin's Scherzo in B flat minor, oblivious to the fact that he will be 88 years old on Jan. 28.

The Government of Israel approved a specific proposal for the separation of Israeli and Egyptian forces along the Suez Canal and authorized Secretary of State Kissinger to present the plan to Egypt's Government. Teams of American and Israeli officials worked through the night to complete the draft. The plan was approved by the Israeli Cabinet yesterday morning.

The widow of the founder of Walston Co., has sued duPont Walston, Inc., the New York Stock Evchange, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation and H. Ross Perot and others to undo the realignment of Walston and duPont Glore Forgan, Inc., last July.

The office of Investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scarpetta is reviewing the payroll time sheets filed by Raymond Gerson, director of the city's Noise Abatement Bureau, who also teaches a college chemistry course three mornings a week.

There is no shortfall of threatening talk in Washington about the resumption of bombing, if necessary, in Vietnam. The Soviet Union made a major attack upon Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn today, charging that his new book on the nation's penal system was "stuffed with cynical falsifications, concocted to serve the forces of imperialist reaction."

Monika Kaserer of Austria, a 22-yearold seasoned skier on the teen-age-dominated international circuit, won a grueling giant slalom today and surged back into the front ranks of the World Cup standing.

At his first cabinet meeting at City Hall, Mayor Beame told 50 top city officials yesterday that he expected them to carry out his campaign commitments, More than half the top administrative posts have not yet been filled by the Mayor.

The city's Commission on Human Rights opened a hearirig 'yesterday into a complaint that The New York Times practices racial discrimination by publishing advertisements for employment in South Africa, where separation of the races is official policy. The advertisements sought personnel for faculty positions in South African universities, as well as for executive jobs in industries there.

The Mcintosh Foundation, a charitable organization whose assets are mostly shares in the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, has sued the troubled food chain for the right to see its books and records, the foundation announced yesterday.

City investigators studied State Senator Joseph L. Galiber's financial records yesterday while politicians put two conflicting interpretations on the lengthening delay in swearing him in as the city's first black Deputy Mayor.

Kirk Nurock's Natural Sound Workshop, which appeared Saturday night at the WBAI Free Music Store, 359 East 62d Street, is built on an engaging idea. The 20-member group makes sound entirely independent of instruments or amplification, mostly vocal and mostly avoiding fixed pitches and words.

The selection of residents interviewed in The New York Times survey of the city conducted by Daniel Yankelovich, Inc., a leading public opinion research organization, was done in a way that New York's population reproduces as broken down by borough, age, marital status, race, voter registration and other categories in the 1970 census.
