Until his desk and chair were moved from the State House to his new Princeton law office last Friday morning, Governor Cahill gave the appearance of a man determined to be in control of the executive branch of the state government through his final days in office, even while he was departing it.

Representatives of 161 citizens groups today challenged members of the Federal Conmunications Commission to explain how the public interest would be served by the F.C.C.'s efforts to re-regulate radio and re-examine the broadcast fairness doctrine for possible modification or even its repeal.

Allison Thompson, 18 years old of Santa Barbara, Calif., and two men friends were ordered held without bail today for another week on charges thai they were part of a gun-running conspiracy that has beer linked to Arab terrorists. The court hearing in suburban Uxbridge was guarded by armed policemen-a rarity in Britain.

AVON CALLING Gone are the days when Brooklyn used to be good for a laugh as the home of "Dem Bums." These days, it is the residence of the Royal Shakespeare Company, which has crossed the Gowanus under the auspices of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and Brooklyn College.

Jury selection began yesterday in the misdemeanor trial of former Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell shortly after the prosecution disclosed it would summon 30 witnesses to testify in the case.

Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis today called for a Congressional investigation into the pricing and allocation of fuel oils. The Maine Governor was the first witness before Senator Edmund S. Muskie's subcommittee on intergovernmental relations, which is conducting a hearing on the impact of the energy crisis in New England. Mr. Curtis decried the layoff of 2,000 Maine workers because of the energy crisis.
The Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that it expected earnings for 1973 to be substantially improved from unsatisfactoryr" results of the last several years.

After five and a half hours of talks, Prime Minister Heath and Britain's union leaders failed tonight to reach an agreement on ending the dispute with the coal miners. The inability to find a formula for resolving the country's worst industrial crisis in years promptly intensified speculation that Mr. Heath would decide to call an early general election. But there were no signs that he had made up his mind yet.

At noon yesterday, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd pinned a gold badge on Assistant Chief Inspector James M. Taylor and appointed him first deputy commissioner, the second most important post in the department.

Detective Samuel F. Bianco of the Princetown Township Police Department testified under cross-examination today that he had burned a 60-page investigative report the morning of the day he had been subpoenaed to bring in all the records he had on the Carpi murder case for a petrial hearing.
Breathes there a woman, with spirit so dead, who fever to herself has said something unprintable about appliance servicing? Apparently not.
Howard Z. Fuchs, a former city welfare investigator who allegedly ran a multimilliondollar narcotics ring in the metropolitan area, was convicted of Federal drug charges in Brooklyn yesterday.
Senator John C. Stennis, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said today that he planned to begin an informal inquiry this week into alleged military spying inside the White House.
The First inaugural concert in New Jersey's history was staged here this evening for the Governor-elect, Brendan T. Byrne, members of the state's cultural community and the public.

More than $1.6-billion was bet on horse races last year in the state, of which New York look $175-million in pari-mutuel taxes, the State Tax Department reported today. The state's revenue collection in 1973 was $12.5million higher than in 1972.

Clothilde He Sakharoff, formerly one of Europe's best-known ballet dancers, died here Friday at the age of 80. Mrs. Sakharoff studied ballet F and cello in Munich as a child and made her professional debut as a dancer in 1910.
Howard Z. Fuchs, a former city welfare investigator who allegedly ran a multimilliondollar narcotics ring in the metropolitan area, was convicted of Federal drug charges in Brooklyn yesterday.

With only a 10-day supply of residual oil on hand to generate electricity, instead of a normal 25-day supply, the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday put into effect a 5 per cent round-the-clock, seven-day-a week voltage reduction.

Bill Bradley used the All-Star break to marry Ernestine Schlant of New York today. They were married at the Royal Poinciana Chapel by the Rev. S. M. Lindsay. Bradley's parents, Mr. and Mrs. W. W. Bradley, came from Crystal City, Mo., to attend the ceremony. A marriage license was issued to the couple on Jan. 9.

If the individual is turning away from the stock market, It is not hard to find reasons why. In the first place the market has been unrewarding to all but the most astute investors since 1969, when a sustained bear market began that continues today.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that the promoters of a German investment scheme involving European houses of prostitution have been directed to produce books and records and to testify in Supreme Court for New York County here on Jan. 28.

Haverford College, a men's small liberal arts school in Eastern Pennsylvania, has decided to work toward coeducation through cooperation with nearby Bryn Mawr College, a women's school, rather than becoming independently educational. Haverford's board of managers concluded last night that "the impact of coeducation on Bryn Mawr would be sufficiently negative to threaten relations
The Securities and Exchange Commission today denied a women's rights request for a ruling to prohibit sex and race discrimination in the securities industry.
The White House said today it was a mistake for an assistant to have informed President Nixon in 1970 of plans by milk producers to contribute $2-million to his reelection campaign.

President Park Chung Hee, in a move to cope with economic difficulties facing South Korea, announced a series of financial measures today to reduce the tax burden on people with low incomes, curb spending for luxuries and conserve gasoline. The President's decree was issued under an article of the 1972 Constitution ' permitting him to take emergency action "in time of a grave financial or economic crisis."

Francois L. Schwarz, founder in 1946 and chairman of Francois L. Schwarz, Inc., food and commodity brokers for armed forces commissaries and exchanges around the world, died Saturday while visiting in Miami. He was 75 years old and a resident of New York.
James Silas scored 23 points tonight and led the Sari Antonio Spurs to a 90-81 victory over the Western Division-leading Utah Stars in In American Basketball Association contest.

A strong business performance for 1974 is widely expected by business and industrial leaders, a survey by The New York Times of dozens of leading companies disclosed, although the energy crisis and continuing questions over the Nixon Administration's economic controls program caused much uncertainty in the forecasting.
RALEIGH, N. C.-Having pursued wild quail and woodcock for one day with Frank Barick, I knew that if I was to get my share of the birds on our next hunt, I would have to move faster.
William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, held out hope today to New York City for relief from the long lineups through which gasoline buyers have suffered at service stations.

The Northrop Airport Development Corporation and other partners have pulled out of-a project to build a $125million, second international airport for Thailand, it was announced here today. Dr. Chaiyuth Karnasuta, chairman of the Northrop Thailand Airport Company, set up last month to carry out the project of the American concern, made the announcement at a news conference. It came amid widespread public questioning of the project's viability.

Elbridge Durbrow, United States Ambassador to Vietnam from 1957 to 1961, arrived here with seven other persons on a private fact-finaing tour today. The touring group is part of the conservative American Security Council, a private nonprofit organization.
Don Shula, their coach, said today that the Miami Dolphins "played our best football of the season" in defeating the Minnesota Vikings, 24-7, in the Super Bowl game here yesterday. That assessment

Anheuser-Busch, the big boy of the beer business, sold 11.8 million barrels of beer in 1965 and 26.5 million barrels in 1972. Joseph Schlitz, an aggressive No. 2, leaped 10 million barrels to 18.9-million during that same period.
William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, held out hope today to New York City for relief from the long lineups through which gasoline buyers have suffered at service stations.

The Cambodian command said that guerrilla forces cut Route 4 about 16 miles southwest of the capital yesterday, severing Phnom Penh's link to Kompong Som, Cambodia's only deepwater portl again. Today, Government infantrymen, armored personnel carriers and T-28 fighter-bombers battled the Communist-led insurgents in a wide arc on three sides of Phnom Penh as close as four miles from the capital.

Paul L. Bleakley, a leading trial lawyer here, died yesterday at his home, 50 Abbey Place. His age was 75. Mr. Bleakley, a cousin of the late State Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley, former Republican leader of Westches ter County, served as majority leader of the Westchester County Board. of Supervisors in the nineteen-thirties.

Lawyers for the teen-ager charged in six of 27 sex and sadism murders of young boys tried today to suppress statements the youth gave the police. Judge William Hahen took the motion under advisement. Elmer Wayne Henley, 17 years old, gave the police in Houston and Pasadena, a suburb, oral and written statements on Aug. 8 saying he, David Owen Brooks, 18, and Dean Corll, 33, had killed the youths over a three-year period.

The president of the Women's Christian Temperance Union said today the Nixon Administration should shut down the nation's breweries and distilleries as a belt-tightening step toward improving the nation's economy.

In one of the most significant museum coups of recent decades, the Detroit Institute of Arts has acquired a "lost" ,major work, "The Conversion of the Magdalene," painted in 1598 by Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio, the great master of Italian baroque art. The purchase price was $1.1-million.

Swiss team championships are usually won with a perfect score, but the concluding event of the Tri-State Regionals at Grossinger, N. Y., Sunday was an exception. In a field of 132 teams, the competition was so fierce ?at nobody had a 100 per cent score going into the eighth and final round.
The first inaugural concert in New Jersey's history was staged here this evening for the Governor-elect, Brendan T. Byrne, members of the state's cultural community and the public.
Bargaining talks continued yesterday between Actors Equity and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers covering terms of a new labor contract to replace the one that expired Jan. 6.

The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states can require newspapers to provide free space for political candidates to reply to criticism in editorials or news columns. The high court announced that it would review a decision by the Florida Supreme Court, which upheld as constitutional by a 6-to-1 vote a state "right to reply" law that The Miami Herald had refused to observe in order to precipitate a test case.

A Federal District Court judge denied today Ralph Nader's request for an investigation to determine if President Nixon or other Administration members intervened in the 1971 settle. ment of antitrust cases against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

Sir Alec Douglas-Home, the Foreign Secretary, will pay official visits to Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria from April 21 to 27 for talks on European economic and security questions and other issues. The Foreign Office announced today that Sir Alec would travel to Budapest, on April 21, to Bucharest on April 23, and to Sofia on April 25 and return to London on April 27.
The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania said today it would have construction expenditures this year in excess of $390-million, an increase of nearly $24-million over last year. William S.

As a football content it was dull. But as a demonstration of major event "hype," Super Bowl VIII was fascinating. Although nearly 1,700 members of the press were on hand to record the game and its numerous sideshows, the occasion was created by and for television.

Senator John C. Stennis, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said today that he planned to begin an informal inquiry this week into alleged military spying inside the White House. In an interview by telephone from his office in De Kalb, Miss., Mr. Stennis said, "I certainly want to take a look at this matter and I don't expect them [the White House] to hold anything back."

Federal District Judge Fred J. Nichol has ruled that the Government must pay the cost of defending two leaders of last year's Indian uprising at Wounded Knee, S.D. These costs are expected to be about $5,000 a week. The judge made his ruling after a special defense fund reported in an affidavit that it was virtually penniless and had heavy debts.

Glistening technique is all too often a final goal for dancers when it should only be a resting place for a push into the area of artistry beyond technique. Cynthia Gregory has now made that push, and her "Coppelia" on Sunday afternoon demonstrated her easy assurance as convincingly as anyone could ask.

Of all America's young playwrights few if any have such a firm grasp of myth and legend as Sam Shepard. His new play, "Back Bog Beast Bait," is currently being given by Unit 453 at Exchange for the Arts, 151 Bank Street.

A high official in the Mines Ministry said today that Venezuela would "adjust" her oil prices Feb. 1 despite a price freeze agreed upon by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (O.P.E.C.) in Geneva.

In one of the most significant museum coups of recent decades, the Detroit Institute of Arts has acquired a "lost" major work, "The Conversion of the Magdalene," painted in 1598 by Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio, the great master of Italian baroque art. The purchase price was $1.1-million.

Jules Leger, a 60-year-old career diplomat, was sworn in Yesterday as Canada's 21st Governor-General amid pageantry that included the blaring of trumpet fanfares, the red ermine-trimmed robes of Supreme Court justices, and Cabinet members decked out in morning coats.

State Supreme Court Justice Richard J. Bartlett, a widely respected criminal-law expert, was reported by Capitol sources today as the person Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel was likely to appoint to a newly broadened role as state administrator of the courts.

The stock market couldn't quite make up its mind yesterday and ended mixed in slower trading. The oil issues, which have been under pressure recently, were the weakest group on the New York Stock Exchange. In contrast, the gold mining issues, which have a tendency to move counter to the general market trend, showed the best gains of the day.

The Small Business Administration is investigating allegations that three white North Carolina businessmen set up minority employes in spin-off concerns and then milked them profitless with management fees, officials say. The businessmen and their concerns are known within the Federal agency as being politically potent, with their friends including Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South...

Steel production for the week ended Jan. 12 slipped 0.4 per cent to 2,835,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The production index dipped to 116.2 from 116.7 a week ago when production totaled 2,847,. 000 tons.

The nonprofit Children's Television Workshop has eliminated the jobs of 13 staff mem bears connected with two of its most popular projects, "Sesame Street" and "The Electric Company," because of a 50 per cen cut: in Federal funding. It also has begun cutting back on pro auction and other aspects of it. operations.
Unaware that his mother was riding on the same train, a 13year-old boy was decapitated in the Bronx yesterday when he climbed to the top of an IRT train, the police reported.

Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, has alleged in letters sent to Secretary of State Kissinger and Attorney General William B. Saxbe that "secret" decisions by the Government have shaped the nation's energy policy for 20 years.

A memorial service for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will begin at noon today at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church, 420 West 145th Street, and will be attended by Mayor Beame, who will read a proclamation to commemorate the day.

Monika Kaserer of Austria, a 22-yearold seasoned skier on the teen-age-dominated international circuit, won a grueling giant slalom today and surged back into the front ranks of the World Cup standing.

The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee sought at its Oct. 16 meeting to make sure that growth resumed in the money supply even if its operations meant some decline in short-term interest rates, it was disclosed today.

Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that a "technical shortcoming" in an American-made Hawk ground-to-air missile was responsible for a multimillion-dollar blaze in offshore oil wells in the Gulf of Suez. A rocket from an Israeli battery in the occupied Sinai Peninsula hit the top of an oil rig and started the fire, which still was raging fiercely, on Jan. 1.

A leader in American Reform Judaism appealed yesterday to the Jewish and black communities of New York to make today, Martin Luther King Day, a time for "renewal of their old working coalition" aimed at improving the welfare of minority groups.

Peter H. Pinkernell, a senior partner in the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen Co. and a member since 1966 of the New York State Board of Examiners for certified public accountants, died Sunday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 96 Barkers Point Road, Sands Point, L. I.
There is little wrong with the American stage-although something always seems to be ailing it-that a few more plays like Hugh Wheeler's "Look: We've Come Through" couldn't cure.

A sharp rise in fourth-quarter net operating income as well as new highs in total earnings, deposits and loans for the full year were reported yesterday by the BankAmerica Corporation, holding company of the Bank of America, the nation's largest bank.

President Nixon underwent a brief physical examination today and his personal physician said the President appeared to be in good health. Dr. Walter R. Tkach, an Army brigadier general, said Mr. Nixon's heart was in good condition, his pulse normal and his chest clear.

Whenever a contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund totals dollars and cents, chances are that children had a hand in it.

Western classical music was fiercely atlacked in the Chinese press today, only a few months after several Western orchestras performed here for the first time since the Cultural Revolution. Articles in the Communist party newspaper Jenmin ,Jih Pao, sharply denied that music could be devoid of class significance. "There are some people who until this day are still uncritically introducing these things to our youth," the paper said. "If we go on like this

WASHINGTON-He would have been 45 years old today but he never reached his 40th birthday. So much could have been different had not the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s heart been stilled by an assassin on that infamous day in Memphis, April 4, 1968.

Madison Fund, Inc., a closedend investment company with a diversified portfolio of stocks in various concerns, is seeking to increase its ownership in First National Stores, Inc., a leading food chain with

Federal agency officials are now cautiously confident thai there will be no general short+ age of heating oil this winter if consumers keep their thermostats turned down and if there is no prolonged spell of abnormally cold weather.

Ed (Buzzy) Fox has built a fine reputation as basketball coach at St. Patrick's in Elizabeth. In his 10-year tenure, his teams have collected three state titles and finished as a state runner-up and semifinalist on two other occasions.
The Health Department has released the names of 36 more restaurants and food stores that failed to correct violations when inspected a second time.

The Cincinnati Board of Education decided today "not to implement" a sweeping integration plan that was passed by a "lame duck" board last Dec. 10, to permit any high school student transfer to any other high school if the transfer 'will improve racial balance.

Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano, who has been charged with murder in the death of a patient dying of cancer at the Nassau County Medical Center, went on trial today, with his attorney insisting that the case was one of 'murder- and not a mercy killing.

The chief domestic subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, the world's largest petroleum company, announced yesterday that its crude-oil supplies were slightly larger now than a year ago but that refining operations would be limited in the future by declining imports.

A comprehensive reorganization of the city's health services, involving some decentralization of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, more authority for the Health Commissioner and less autonomy for some departments is quietly being worked out by a special committee that Is advising Mayor Beame informally on health problems.

Thirty-eight Haitian refugees, who were rescued from their foundering wooden boat in the Atlantic Thursday, arrived here last night aboard a Coast Guard cutter. The refugees, who said they left their homeland Jan. 4, were picked up 180 miles southeast of here by two Miami-based fishing boats. They were transferred to the Coast Guard cutter on Saturday.
, director of the Brooklyn College School of General Studies (the evening division), died Sunday at Albert Einstein Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 1662 Glenwood Road, Brooklyn.
The General Services Administration said today that the first in a series of monthly competitive bids for Government-stockpiled copper would be opened Feb. 5 on an offering of 100 million pounds.

Canada's Parliament today limited wiretapping and other types of electronic eavesdropping by law enforcement agencies. The new legislation, which also outlaws bugging by private citizens, still leaves the police here a great deal of leeway, but it sets out for the first time rules on when and how judges can authorize electronic surveillance.
Seymour Scher, the controversial City Manager of Yonkers, announced today that he would resign in a few weeks at the request of the city's new Republican leadership.

Yeoman 1st Cl. Charles E. Radford denied repeatedly today that he was the source of leaks from National Security Council files in 1971. Yeoman Radford is 30 years old, a career specialist in stenography and office procedures who was on the staff of two admirals who were the Navy's liaison officers to the National Security Council.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People lost about 7,000 members last year, dropping to 405,417, according to a report delivered yesterday at the annual membership meeting.

Secretary of State Kissinger spent the day in Egypt with President Anwar el-Sadat, making what Mr. Kissinger said was "very good progress" toward narrowing differences on separating the Israeli and Egyptian armies near the Suez Canal. He returned to Tel Aviv last night, bringing Israelis a detailed Egyptian map and counterproposal for disengagement. [1:8.]

Officials and money experts from 20 countries opened weeklong talks today on international monetary reform.

The Assembly today 'unanimously voted to remove the requirement of corroboration in rape cases from the State's Penal Code--a move that for years has been urged by women'sliberation and civil-liberties groups and law-enforcement officials.

A memorial service for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will begin at noon today at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church, 420 West 145th Street, and will be attended by Mayor Beame, who will read a proclamation to commemorate the day.

A streamlined format and the absence of some familiar figures will mark tomorrow night's 24th annual EastWest National Basketball Association All-Star game here, to be televised nationally by the Columbia Broadcasting System (Channel 2, 9:30 P.M., in New York).

As the anniversary of the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. approached this year, Carole Coleman, who teaches a class in black history at Public School 180 in the heart of Harlem, decided to vary the traditional observance.
A panel of three Maryland judges concluded today that former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew was "unfit" to be a lawyer and that he should be disbarred to "protect the public."
Detectives captured three kidnapping suspects yesterday and freed a 20-year-old student they were said to have seized by taking him from his Elmhurst, Queens, home at the point of a knife.

The city started a training program yesterday aimed at preparing candidates, particularly from minority groups, for the "sanitation man" examination, which 65,000 applicants have said they want to take.

In the farmers' markets of Moscow and other central Russian cities a common lament this winter is that there is almost no succulent fruit from the neartropical orchards around the Black Sea in Soviet Georgia. The explanation has appeared in Pravda.

ABROMET-Jeannette, on January 12, 1974 in St. Augustine, Fla. Born in Elkhart County, Indiana. Associated with Western Electric, pioneer member of The Telephone Pioneers of America and member of Eastern Star Old Glory Lodge #622, Patchogue, L.I., N.Y. Survived by niece Mrs. Jean Alexander of St. Augustine, Fla. Service at the Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, Wednesday 2 P.M.
Delta Air Lines contended today that air-traffic controllers were responsible for the July 31 crash of a Delta jet at Boston's Logan International Airport. All 89 persons aboard died in the crash.
On a day in which one general manager and a coach were dismissed, Larry Popein was standing still. "I'm still thinking things over," he said yesterday, a few days after

Robert B. Mayer, since 1949 a director of Consolidated Foods Corporation and a vice president of the Maurice L. Rothschild Company, clothing retailers, until the chain became part of Botany, Inc., in 1961, died here today at the age of 63. He lived in Winnetka, III.

The first public hearing held by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey ot discuss its $222million Plainfield-corridor commuter project produced an atmosphere tonight of strong support from business and local government officials who testi'ied.

A 53-yearold black American who identified himself as a reporter from New York was arrested Nov. 23 on a charge of espionage for East Germany, West Berlin officials disclosed today. They said that the American, Calvin Williams, was. in the tuberculosis ward of the Plotzensee youth prison here, where he had been placed three days after his arrest after a medical check-up showed that he was

Attorney General William B. Saxbe has been asked to referee a dispute over proposed Federal controls on crime records sent to state and local governments. The issue presents Mr. Saxbe with a conflict between the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which maintains the computerized crime files, and the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, which finances many state and local computer projects dealing with criminal records.

Fiat, S.P.A. Italy's largest motor manufacturer. reported yesterday that sales in 1973 totaled 24-billion lira, or 6.6 percent over the level of sales in 1972. At the current rate of exchange, sales in 1973 came to $3.75 billion, up from $3.37 billion the year before.
J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., parent of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the fifth largest bank in the nation, reported that earnings were up sharply for the fourth quarter of 1973 and for the full year.
The Skylab 3 astronauts set a record today for the longest manned space flight, a world mark that may stand for a decade. At 9:10 P.M. Lieut. Col Gerald P. Carr of the Marines,

"Amici" means "friends" in Italian and the Amici Trio-Michel Debost, flute, Alain Meunier, cello, and Christian Ivaldi, piano-have chosen an apt name for themselves. Both the music and the performances at their New York debut in Town Hall on Sunday afternoon exhibited all the warmth and give-and-take of good fellowship.

secretary of State Kissinger spent the day in Egypt with President Anwar el-Sadat today, making what the Secretary called "very good progress" toward narrowing differences on separating the Israeli and Egyptian armies near the Suez Canal.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that an 'F.T.C. law judge, Alvin L.. Berman had recommended extension of a legal order barring bakery acquisitions by the I.T.T Continental Baking Cornpany, which markets Wonder Bread and Hostess snack cakes.
An autopsy disclosed this afternoon that 14-year-old Daniel W. Ebersole, who was kidnapped last Tuesday in suburban Lakewood, was killed several days ago by a blow on the head.

Kohoutek has failed its promoters. It is a nothing act. It is the biggest flopperoo since "Kelly" hit Broadway at a cost of $700,000 and folded on the first night. It is the Edsel of the firmament. Kohoutek may be brighter than the full moon, space agency people said in November. Now Kohoutek is nothing.
Dr. Louis Gordon Welt, medical educator and research scientist, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his office in the Yale New Haven Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived here.

The town of East Rutherford and its Mayor asked a Federal Court here today to enjoin the sale of a $295-million New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority bond issue on' the ground that underwriters had breached antifraud provisions of the securities laws.

Harriette Hollis McLoughlin, daughter of John T. McLoughlin of Princeton, president of the Vick Chemical Company, was fatally injured Saturday in a one-car accident near Cambridge, Vt. She was 19 years old and had been employed by the Red Fox Ski Dormitory in Jeffersonville, Vt.

Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski has announced that he cannot turn over evidence collected by his office to a House committee studying impeachment. Senator Barry Goldwater said a day later that he would not lead a delegation of Republicans to ask for the resignation of Richard Nixon, whom he described as "probably the best President we've had in this century."

Improbable as any agreement between Libya's unstable Colonel Qaddafi and Tunisia's moderate President Bourguiba may appear, the proposed merger between their two countries has some foundation in logic even if its realization seems remote under present circumstances.

The Mitsubishi International Corporation, a leading Japanese trading company. announced yesterday a joint venture with Abramson Enterprises and Brisbane Management under which Americana Hotels, Inc., would operate its newly acquired Canyon Hotel and Country Club Estates at Palm Springs, Calif. The $22-million agreement marks the
Sidney Finkelstein, retired died music critic and author, died attack Sunday at Maimonides Medical lived Center, Brooklyn. His age was Roch 64 and he lived at 52 Stratford Mr Road, Brooklyn.

"Blue Monday" can just as ptly be called "Mu Monday," according to an analysis of colds and other respiratory illnesses suffered over a six-year period by residents of a Michigan city. Two University of Michigan epidemiologists who conducted the study in Tecumseh, a city considered typical of others in the country, reported in the issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association published yesterday:

The Supreme Court took the following actions today: Reversed the conviction for contributing to the delinquency of a minor of a New Hampshire store operator who sold a button reading "copulation not masturbation" to a 14-year-old girl. The Court said there was no evidence the defendant had made the sale (No. 73-573, Vachon v. New Hampshire). Dissenting: Rehnquist, Burger and White.

Secretary of State Kissinger spent the day in Egypt with President Anwar el-Sadat, making what Mr. Kissinger said was "very good progress" toward narrowing differences on separating the Israeli and Egyptian armies near the Suez Canal. He returned to Tel Aviv last night, bringing Israelis a detailed Egyptian map and counterproposal for disengagement. [1:8.]

The Justice Department declined today to turn over to a former White House official documents related to a 21-month-long wiretap placed on his home telephone. The wiretap was part of.a program, ordered by President Nixon, aimed ostensibly at halting leaks of classified information to the press.

Nicholas F. Brady has been named chairman of the Jockey Club. Brady succeeds Ogden Phipps as head of the organization that occupies an important role in thoroughbred racing in the state and country. It was chartered in 1894.

A county judge delayed today until Feb. 25 a hearing on whether burglary charges should be dropped against John D. Ehrlichman, former chief White House domestic adviser, and others in connection with the 1971 break in at the office of Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist on the ground that they were acting as Federal "police officers."

The Cost of Living Council exempted today domestically produced ferronickel, a major ingredient of stainless steel, from price controls. Although exemption from price controls usually has been coupled with the lifting of wage restraints, the council said the pay of workers in the ferronickel industry would remain covered by the Government's stabilization program. The council offered no explanation for this decision.

As the anniversary of the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. approached this. year, Carole Coleman, who teaches a class in black history at Public School 180 in the heart of Harlem, decided to vary the traditional observance.

The Government of Bangladesh has banned all publid meetings and processions in Dacca from today until Feb. 3 because of a "threat to law and order." The Government said in a statement last night that it was forced to act to "safeguard the greater interests of the people" because a political party was "openly preaching violence."

The Madison Square Garden Corporation reported yesterday that it had a net income of $1.5 -million in the second fiscal quarter ended Nov. 30 in contrast to a $130,000 loss in the corresponding three months last year.

Richard C. Leone, who has been appointed State Treasurer, announced that Clifford A. Goldman of Ewing Township would become deputy state treasurer. Mr. Leone, who takes office today, shortly after Brendan T. Byrne is inaugurated as Governor, said Mr. Goldman would have the special responsibility to find a way to meet the requirements of a'Supreme Court decision ordering a new method of school financing in the state.

The Assembly today unanimously voted to remove the requirement of corroboration in rape cases from the state's Penal Code-a move that for years has been urged by women'sliberation and civil-liberties groups and law-enforcement officials.
Eastern college basketball teams will have to play themselves into the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and no longer depend on a committee to select the teams.
Police threw a tight ring of security around Miami Dolphins' coaches and players upon their arrival at Miami International Airport today because of telephone threats.

Using much of the identical poetry and prose by -who became a literary figure of special inest after her suicide in 1963 at the age of 31-the British Royal Shakespeare Company and the American New York Tea Party, a tiny company that began as a feminist "consciouness-raising group," are presenting separate productions here within a few days of each other.

With only a 10-day supply of residual oil on hand to generate electricity, instead of a normal 25-day supply, the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday put into effect a 5 per Cent round-the-clock, seven-day-a week voltage reduction.
A new organization concerned with the improvement of the theater on a national as well as a local basis is under discussion by a group of theater owners and businessmen in the Times Square area.
Herbert R. Johnson, who retired in 1969 as a senior partner in Orvis Brothers, stockbrokers, died Sunday at his home, 137 Engle Street. He was 96 years old.
Harry Taylor Gherardi, an architect who in 1929 joined what was then the firm of Voorhees, Gmelin Walker, died today in Princeton Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 37 Snowden Lane.

How important is tne Davis Cup to the United States? That question loomed yesterday following the startling 4-1 upset of the United States tennis team by Colombia in the North American Zone final at Bogota.

A United States district judge ruled today that the drug-rehabilitation program of the Army's European command was illegal and told the Army to rewrite the program's regulations. Under the program, a soldier's property and person can be checked and sanctions can be imposed against him if he it deemed a drug abuser.

THE PAST IS THE PAST and-GOING THRU CHANGES, two Plays by Richard Wesley; directed by Lloyd Richards; setting by James Jokulo Cooper; production stage manager, Harrison Avery. Presented by the Billie Holiday Theater, Herbert Scott-Gilson, artistic director, 1368 Fulton Street, Brooklyn.
Larry Fry led a second-half surge tonight as Mississippi State downed Louisiana State, 89-75, in a game that saw the losers finish with only four players.

District Attorney Frank Diaz stunned the courtroom today with a motion to drop charges of involuntary manslaughter against Cesar Cedeno two hours after the trial of the Houston Astros' outfielder began.

Is it a good idea to play in a tournament just before an important match? The practice afforded will not directly bear on the match play, because trying out new opening weapons in the tournament will tip off your match opponent as to what's in store for him.

After quick, quiet stops in Singapore and Malaysia, Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan landed here tonight on the last stop of his Southeast Asian tour and ran immediately into Indonesia's student protesters. Despite a heavy armed guard at the new international airport, some of the 800 students broke through the lines and gathered across the route of Mr. Tanaka and his host, President Suharto.

A soviet shipping official has announced the opening of a big container terminal at the Pacific port of Nakhodka, formally inaugurating a long-planned "container bridge" through Siberia between Japan and Western Europe.

The women will sit at consoles inside bright new offices electronically regulating how much gasoline will go to each pump. The drivers will pump their own gas, then go to the offices to pay with credit cards or cash.

Leasing procedures are now being promoted to open up more EastWest trade. Two West European banksthe Credit Lyonnais of Paris and Morgan Grenfell of London -have gone into partnership with Soviet-controlled banks in recent weeks to promote EastWest lease financing of capital goods.
A panel of three Maryland judges concluded today that former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew was "unfit" to be a lawyer and that he should be disbarred to "protect the public."
Peru's leftist-oriented military leaders are vowing to press ahead with their reorganizing of Peruvian life despite increased opposition at home and a growing feeling of international isolation.

President Habib Bourguiba today dismissed his Foreign Minister, who was said to have played a key role in bringing about the agreement of last Saturday for a merger of Tunisia and Libya. As a result, a senior Foreign Ministry source said, the merger could be postponed.

Investigators for the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection today searched the mile-long Oyster Creek between the Route 9 bridge and the outlet of the creek in the Barnegat Bay near Waretown for fish reported to have been killed by the shutdown of the atomic power plant here of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company.

Until now, when the women's movement talked about "us," what it usually had in mind was the middle-class, college-educated woman. Now this is beginning to change--on both sides. The working-class woman has started to make demands. and some leaders in the movement have begun to recognize that it will take a larger coalition of disparate groups to effect change.

"Our view about detente," Secretary of State Kissinger said recently, "did not indicate moral approval in any respect of the Soviet system." He was replying at a news conference to a question about the effect on United States-Soviet relations of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's book about the Soviet prison system, "The Gulag Archipelago, 1918-1956."

There's nothing like cuddling into a nice mink or sable coat on a chilling, dreary January day. Which may help explain why Mrs. Joshua Logan had little trouble rounding up friends and acquaintances to model some of them at the Museum of the City of New York's 50th birthday party last night.

Although the number of issues showing declines slightly outnumbered those recording advances, prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday in dull trading. Prices in the over-the-counter market also increased, with advances surpassing declines.

Higher prices for gold traded abroad and for gold-company stocks here propelled silver futures to record highs yesterday In active trading on the Commodity Exchange. Silver coins traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange also set highs.

The Federal Government's allocation program for gasoline, which takes effect tomorrow, will give filling stations supplies of about 80 to 85 per cent of their current requirements, an official of the Federal Energy Office said tonight.

Bessie Smith has been used as a source of material by several singers in recent years, almost invariably to the contemporary singer's disadvantage. Miss Smith had such a strong personality. even on the 40-year-old records that are her basic means of communicating with us today, that the mere memory of her overwhelms most of those who try to follow in her footsteps.

Israel has appointed Maj. Gen. Avraham Adan to assume overall command of the tense Suez front with the Egyptians, the military command announced today. General Adan, 47 years old, one of the first Israeli generals to cross the Suez Canal during the October war, will take command Wednesday. He replaces Maj. Gen. Israel Tal, who is also deputy chief of staff.

As Welfare Commissioner in the Wagner administration, James R. Dumpson showed himself a compassionate and dedicated director of the city's relief program. He has added to his reputation in recent years as dean of Fordham University's Graduate School of Social Services. On that basis, he is eminently qualified for the post reportedly preferred him by Mayor Beame as Human Resources Administrator and Commissioner of Social Services.

Speakers at an international[ investment conference yesterday did have some kind words to say about gold and the potential of the Wall Street stock market, but an air of global caution held sway in the, carpeted grand ballroom of the New York Hilton.

Treasure the Miami Dolphins now because they won't be quite the same next season. The best team ever to play football succeeded with a formula of human chemistry that already has been diluted. The constant of the defensive unit, Bill Arnsparger, is leaving to become the New York Giants' head coach. Several variables on offense, meaning players, are uncomfortable.

The Fern Place School got the bad news today. Because of dwindling school population, the little grade school may have to close its doors in June. But Fern Place will hardly be the last school closed in the Plainview-Old Bethpage School District or in other Long Island communities, where school enrollment is dropping after the postwar boom.
Trading was halted briefly yesterday morning on the Midwest Stock Exchange to mark a historic moment: the presence on its trading floor of a woman member.

Detective Samuel F. Bianco of the Princeton Township Police Department testified under cross-examination today that he had burned a 60-page investigative report the morning of the day he had been subpoenaed to bring in all the records he had on the Carpi murder case for a pretrial hearing.

Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, called today for an investigation by the General Accounting Office of a $415,000 loan by a Government bank to finance an American-owned hotel in Haiti. Mr. Aspin said in a statement that the Overseas Private Investment Corporation floated the loan as part of a $1.2-million resort promoted by Oliver Coquelin, a former nightclub owner in New York City.

To the Editor: What fools we be. First, we are told the Arab embargo has caused our energy shortage. But since we only Import 6 per cent of our requirements from them, we are advised that this crisis has been developing for years and despite repeated warnings we have done nothing about it,
Gilbert M. Landy, a city judge here since 1961, died today in Yonkers Professional Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 20 Woodland Terrace.
The bitter, 18-month-long feud between the National Hockey League and the rival World Association will end within a few days.
Charlie Finley, perhaps the only owner in sports ever denounced on the floor of the United States Senate, will sell his California Golden Seals to the National Hockey League this week for $6,585,000.

The shortages of man-made fibers created by the energy crisis and worldwide demand have resulted in a black market for nylon and acetate yarns, according to , president of the Knitted Textile Association.

When the old New York Tribune building near City Hall was dedicated by Horace Greeley's daughter a century ago this month, journalistic mementos of the period were locked into a brass box placed inside the cornerstone.

About 30 South Vietnamese soldiers were back today in a remote border base in the Central Highlands nearly four months after the base was overrun by Communist tanks. A South Vietnamese military spokesman said that a platoon was taken In helicopters to the Le Minh camp, on a hilltop near the Cambodian border in Pleiku Province.

Seven cars of an eight-car Amtrak train carrying 108 passengers derailed in thick fog today, injuring about 30 persons. One was hurt seriously. Police Chief Frank Lindsey said there were no deaths, but that a search had begun for a 6-month-old child separated from his mother. The Oklahoma Highway Patrol said 10 persons had been admitted to hospitals in the area, and others were treated and released.

For some two decades, since the advent of the Soviet H-bomb, the dominant concept in American military planning has been that there could be no winners, only losers, in a strategic nuclear war with the Soviet Union. The central aim of Presidents Eisenhower, Kennedy and Johnson was "deterrence."
Although New York has the reputation as the most liberal city in America, more city residents today consider themselves conservatives than they do either moderates or liberals.

Although New York has the reputation as the most liberal city in America, more city residents today consider themselves conservatives than they do either moderates or liberals. This ideological swing to the right is reflected in strong attitudes among New Yorkers in favor of the restoration of the death penalty, in giving life sentences without parole to drug pushers, in

The spectacular downfall of Spiro Agnew has highlighted the weaknesses in the method by which political parties choose their candidates for Vice President. The Republican party has scheduled a meeting in Washington next month to discuss the problem. House Democrats have named a committee headed by Representative Edith Green of Oregon to submit recommendations for possible legislation to their caucus in March.

Bolstered by increased volume from acquisitions, earnings of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, Inc., climbed to 40 cents a share in the quarter ended Dec. 31, the brokerage house reported today. Earnings were equal to 25 cents a share in the corresponding period of 1972.

The Soviet Union made a major attack upon Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn today, charging that his new book on the nation's penal system was "stuffed with cynical falsifications, concocted to serve the forces of imperialist reaction."

The frozen body of an airman missing for more than a month was found yesterday by a passing soldier near an Army Nike site on Mount Gleason, sheriff's officers said. Deputies said that Peter A. Walt, 17 years old, of Lewiston, N.Y., evidently had frozen to death after he had sat down to rest in the cold and had fallen asleep.

Japan is working on a $280-million program of aid that she recently promised to Egypt for the reopening of the Suez Canal. The aid, which is to take the form of credits, was described in Government circles as evidence of Japan's desire to play a role in restoring peace in the Middle East and to promote friendly relations with the oil-producing countries.

Robert W. Miller; executive vice president and general manager of the United States and Canadian Photographic Division of the Eastman Kodak Company of Rochester, N. Y., died here yesterday of a heart attack. His age was 56 and he lived in Brighton, N. Y., near Rochester.

The Assembly passed rules changes today designed to make the Legislature more effective and open to the public, but the changes were immediately branded as "meaningless" by the Democrats and as "a sham" by good-government groups.

Silver, potatoes and sugar set new highs on their respective commodity exchanges yesterday, continuing their strong showing on Monday. On the Commodity Exchange here silver futures move up to a new record high of $3.56 1/2 in terms of the March delivery, erasing the former high made Monday of $3.54 2-10 an ounce.

From left, Pauline Trigere, Gian Carlo Cicogna Mozzoni, Stephen Birmingham, Mrs. Byron Janis and Mrs. Jaime de Pinics. Chili in silver tureen was served by gloved butler in orange jacket.

The Pentagon has drastically cut funds for the Army' SAM-D antiaircraft missile until tests on its guidance system are finished next year, Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, said today.

A Connecticut organization of independent gasoline-station owners charged yesterday that at least one major oil company was using vacant and closed-down service stations to hoard gasoline as it awaited an expected price increase.
Norbert Cifelli, the nearly blind proprietor of the snack stand in the State House near the Governor's office, thought the inauguration of Brendan T. Byrne was one of the quietest in memory.

The British Navy, its ships short of fuel, is experimentally going back to sail. Only one ship, an 1,800-ton deep-sea diving vessel called the Reclaim, is involved. Like all other British warships, she is under orders to keep her engines at half-speed when possible in the Interest of oil economy.

As a long-time supporter of Federal financial aid for education, I have come to realize with much pain that many billions of Federal tax dollars have not brought the significant improvement we anticipated. There are even signs that we may be losing ground.
Chile, objecting to South Africa's policy of racial segregation, will play the South African tennis team in the Davis Cup only in a neutral country.

A lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union urged the State Court of Appeals today to readmit a former Communist to the bar because he had rehabilitated himself.

SAN FRANCISCO-It appears clear by now that the energy shortage, whatever its causes or consequences, constitutes just one element in the growing national consciousness of limits and in the declining faith in an indefinitely expanding American future.

Four men and four women jurors were selected today in the trial of Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano, former chief resident surgeon at the Nassau County Medical Center, who has been charged with murder in the death of a dying cancer patient.

Jonathan Williams, who dropped out of a two-mile race last month because "I didn't feel like running," redeemed himself in record time yesterday in the fourth annual Martin Luther King Memorial scholastic track meet at the 102d Engineers Armory.

A majority of proGovernment legislators from the two houses of the National Assembly today submitted a draft amendment to the Constitution that would permit President Nguyen Van Thieu to run for a third term.

Two suits seeking a total of $3-billion have been filed against the American Petroleum Institute and eight oil companies, alleging they violated state and Federal antitrust laws, conspired to hoard gasoline and drove up retail prices.

An official of the Writers Union for the Russian Republic proposed that Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn leave the country because of what the Soviet press has described as his treasonous writings. It was by far the most serious threat to Mr. Solzhenitsyn since the Soviet press began to attack him two weeks ago. [1:1.]

The Greek Government was urged by newsmen today to restore press freedom and end the "insecurity" felt by journalists. The call came in the form of a resolution adopted by a special assembly of the 600member Athens Union of Journalists.
The controversial 1974 American tour of Leningrad's Kirov Ballet, the first. in 10 years, was abruptly canceled yesterday, less than six months before it was to have begun.

Tests and examinations have never stood high in students' esteem. But in the last year the examining of examinations was both profound and far-reaching throughout education and industry alike. Students, parents, educators, employers, job applicants - all had urgent questions.
The American Stock Exchange has submitted a plan to the Securities and Exchange Commission for trading in stock options on a trial basis, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

DYEING ART Back in 1907, when a couple of Japanese warships were paying a courtesy visit to the United States, a group of prominent New Yorkers formed a welcoming committee. From that beginning came the impetus for formation of a premanent organization dedicated to the promotion of friendly relations between the two counties and to the fostering here of more accurate knowledge of the people and ways of Japan.

Finance ministers and central bank governors of leading industrial and developing countries are meeting here this week to discuss how to pay for much more expensive oil and whether new monetary structures can be devised to deal with the financial issues of the energy crisis. Dr. Otmar Emminger

When representatives of the non-Communist nations met in Nairobi last September, about all they could agree on was a deadline of July 31, 1974, for world monetary reform. Since then the October war in the Mideast, the Arab oil embargo, the skyrocketing price of fuel and the impending massive money flows from the nations consuming oil to those producing it have shattered any slight hope for reaching agreement on the complicated design presented at Nairobi.

Two former police officers who pleaded guilty to corruption in connection with the Knapp Commission investigation of the New York police were sentenced yesterday as part of a plea-bargaining deal to pay a $500 fine each or serve six months in jail.

After a long day and evening of conferences with Secretary of State Kissinger, the Israeli Government decided last night to defer decision on a formula for separating Israeli and Egyptian troops along the Suez Canal. The decision was put off until Mr. Kissinger could make another visit to Egypt-his third in less than a week.

Senator Carl T. Curtis, Republican of Nebraska, asked today that Howard M. Metzenbaum, Cleveland Industrialist who was appointed to the Senate from Ohio, not be seated when Congress reconvenes Jan. 21.

The Municipal Labor Committee, composed of leaders of city employee unions, asked Mayor Beame to give up the city's opposition to the Cost of Living Council's approval of the recent contract settlement with the Uniformed Firefighters Association. The request was made on the eve of a scheduled public hearing on the contract before the council in Washington. There was no immediate comment on the request from the Mayor's office.

Because of its searing loop around the sun Dec. 28, the comet Kohoutek, now fading from view to the unaided eye, has become enveloped in a cloud of hydrogen atoms three million miles wide. A rocket-borne camera in space over New Mexico photographed this glowing hydrogen cloud enveloping Comet Kohoutek. Cloud is more than three times size of the sun, and is being blown, left to right, by "solar wind."

Josef Smrkovsky, right-hand man of Alexander Dubcek, the former reformist leader, died of cancer here last night. He was 62 years old. Mr. Smrkovsky was chairman of the National Assembly when Mr. Dubcek came to power in January, 1968, beginning the reform era, which ended with the invasion of Czechoslovakia by Soviet troops in August, 1968. Josef Smrkovsky
Gene Williams, the allSouthern Conference safety from Virginia Military Institute, was in fair condition today after removal of a kidneydamaged in theAmerican Bowl football game Jan. 6.

The continued delays in the Middle East negotiations are increasing the pressure or Syria to move away from Egypt and closer to the Arab radical camp led by the Iraqis, who strongly oppose a negotiated settlement with Israel.
A suit asking up to $122.39-million in damages from Heublein, Inc., the successor concern to the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation, has been filed by Col. and Mrs. Harland Sanders.

Murray L. Weldenbaum, a prominent Republican economist and a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in the Nixon Administration, warned yesterday that the Administration's budget figures, to be announced later this month, would understate the size of the deficit facing the Federal Government in the fiscal year 1975, which begins next July 1.

These are hard times for American educators. Money is short, public dissatisfaction is widespread, and the sense of manifest destiny that pervaded the profession a decade ago has all but evaporated. One reason for the current crisis in confidence seems to be the widely. publicized shift in opinion among social scientists about the importance of education in shaping American society.

The American Ballet Theater, the American company most publicly involved in protests against the appearance of the Kirov Ballet from Leningrad at the New York State Theater, is now free to perform in that theater three weeks earlier than scheduled as a result of the cancellation of the Kirov's tour.

An employee of the Howard Hughes organization has told the Senate Watergate committee that President Nixon personally suggested to him before Mr. Nixon's election in 1968 that he should attempt to solicit a campaign contribution from the billionaire industrialist, according to a Senate source.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed yesterday with the Federal Commuriications Commission for changes in interstate rates for its Wide Area Telecommunications Service.

The Federal Energy Office released details of a proposed gasoline rationing plan today while making public formal allocations of fuels that favor public services and industrial use at the expense of private automobiles and home heating. John C. Sawhill, deputy energy chief, discussing fuel needs yesterday.

Calling prospective jurors "these jokers," Samuel H. DeNicola, accused of the slaying of a C. W. Post College coed, suddenly asked today that his right to a jury trial be waived. The court approved the request, and the trial, without a jury, will continue Friday morning.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednes day, Jan. 16-Many thousands of Indonesians took to the streets of Jakarta yesterday in violent demonstrations against the visit of Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan and what they regard as Japanese economic imperialism. A young Indonesian, on shoulders of fellow student, urging soldiers in Jakarta to arrest their generals and not demonstrators. A moment later he was pulled down and led away. Japanese were targets of violence.

High White House officials sought today to minimize the significance of an alleged military spy ring inside the White House and characterized a confidential report on such activi ties filed by David R. Young Jr. as "ludicrous."

The demands on college presidents have changed so abruptly and dramatically since the late sixties that many of us are still in the process of redifining our roles and even our job descriptions.

Once again, just as it appeared that President Nixon was weathering the Watergate crisis, another startling disclosure has aroused suspicions of further criminal acts in the White House and inflicted new damage on the President's credibility.
A furloughed inmate serving a sentence for manslaughter at a state correctional facility was apprehended early yesterday after a high-speed car chase by policemen seeking the killer of a Queens man.

Despite impressive gains in integration over the last five years, the over-all national picture is marked by racial isolation, Nearly two-thirds of all black children attend schools that are majority black. About as many black youngsters go to nearly allblack schools as attend integrated ones.

In this first-grade class Jacob Blank teaching Yiddish at the Workmen's Circle in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.

A United States District Court judge extended a temporary restraining order today on behalf of two Long Beach State basketball players who had been ruled ineligible by the National Collegiate A. A. The N.C.A.A. charged Glen McDonald and Roscoe Pondexter had entered school by having proxies take entrance tests for them. Both men have signed statements saying the allegation is untrue.

It was a quiet Monday in night court. No one knows why, but Mondays in night court are usually quiet. It gets busier during the week, however, and by Thursdays, perhaps 100 cases are heard in night court. It is in the Criminal Court at 100 Centre Street, and on this Monday there were only 40 or 50 defendants.

In his first major initiative in office, Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel announced today that he had created a new post of state administrative judge and had consolidated existing courtmanagement authority in the post to spur statewide improvements in the judicial system.

Video Techniques, Inc., which did the closed-circuit television last January when George Foreman swatted Joe Frazier loose from the heavyweight championship of the world, expects to announce a title match between Foreman and Ken Norton on Friday at a news conference in Los Angeles. The bout is penciled in for March 25, but the site has not been chosen.
Nineteen persons were killed and 28 others were injured today when a farm labor bus missed a turn in predawn darkness and plunged into 10 feet of water in an irrigation canal southwest of here.
John D. Ehrlichman, whose friends have started a trust fund to help pay for his legal expenses, is struggling to reestablish himself with a law practice specializing in environmental affairs.

The order issued by a Federal judge for major reforms in the treatment of prisoners in the Tombs should-but probably will not-mark the end of the subhuman conditions that have long existed at this dismal Manhattan jail.

Linwood Holton, former Republican Governor of Virginia, will be appointed to a high Federal position, probably Assistant Secretary of State for Congressional Relations, according to State Department officials.

The Mississippi River Corporation announced yesterday that it had received about 88 per cent of the 635,696 shares of new common stock of its subsidiary, the Missouri Pacific Railroad, tendered in response tQ its offer to purchase 400,000 shares at $100 a share.

Cesar Cedeno was found guilty today of involuntary manslaughter in the motel-room shooting of a young woman and fined the equivalent of $100, closing the case. "It's an injustice!" cried Felicia de la Cruz, aunt of the victim.

If any clear pattern is discernible in American education, it is a growing shift of responsibility back to the states. This shift, after a decade of rising Federal involvement in the schools, is unspectacular but profound.
A oneday strike of railroad engineers stopped all passenger trains in Britain today. Commuters, especially in southeast England, were hit hard. A few freight trains continued to run.
Former Representative Harold D. Cooley, Democrat of North Carolina, died today of emphysema. He was 76 years old. He leaves his wife, the former Madeline Strickland; a son and a daughter.

Galina and Valery Panov, former principal dancers of the Kirov Ballet, who want to emigrate to Israel.

Members of the Government met today and considered spe cific proposals to eliminate or sharply reduce the espionage and other activities of the United States Central Intelligence r Agency in Thailand.

Nadjari, disclosed yesterday that "some" assistant Queens district attorneys had given contradictory statements to a grand jury about their knowledge of a get-rich-quick scheme and said the "truth would have to be wrung out of them" at the trial of former Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell.
The Tunisian Government backed away today from merger with Libya, delaying a proposed referendum on the union until the Tunisian constitution is revised. The process could take months.

The First National City Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the nation's second and fourth largest banking concerns, reported sharp increases in earnings for the fourth quarter and all of 1973.

Stephen B. Bull, a special assistant to President Nixon, said tonight that a number of persons in addition to himself had had access to the June 20, 1972, tape recording of which a large segment was erased.

Rubey Ayala, who considered the campaign spending scandals caused by Watergate one of his strongest issues, scored a key victory for the state Democratic party yesterday by upsetting Jerry Lewis, a Republican Assemblyman, to win the 20th District Senate seat.
By its choice of counsel, the House Judiciary Committee has made it plain that it intends to look busy for a few months and then recommend the impeachment of the President.

Sylvia Plath was a poet with a vocation for death and a feeling for life. She was born in Boston in 1932, and she committed suicide--almost by accident-in London in 1963. By ancestry she was part Polish and part German, and she found herself waiting in what she called "the incalculable malice of the everyday." But she listened, watched, noticed and lived.

Clarence E. Lovejoy, editor o the series of school and college guides that bear his name and retired boating editor of The New York Times, died today in Riverview Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 80 River' Edge Drive, Little Silver. Clarence E. Lovejoy

Just when everyone thought the Emile Francis spell had been dispelled by the Detroit Red Wings tonight the New York Rangers came back spectacularly to score two goals in the final 2 1/2 minutes and tie Detroit, 4-4. Steve Vickers of the Rangers shooting the puck past Bill McKenzie, Red Wing goalie, in the first period at Detroit last night. The Rangers, down 4-0, pulled out a 4-4 tie.

Twin strikes by 6,000 boiler room and maintenance workers cut off heat and cleaning services at many city schools yesterday, forcing 34 schools with 77,400 pupils to close and prompting many parents to take their children home from cold classrooms. Some pupils at P.S. 129, Brooklyn, put on coats and gloves when the heat went off

The State Department announced today that it had denied a request by the Cuban film director Tomas Gutierrez Alea for an entry visa to accept the award of the National Society of Film Critics in New York Sunday.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will ask its stockholders to approve authorization of an additional 50 million shares of preferred stock at the annual meeting on April 17 at Minneapolis. The giant concern now has 750 million shares of common and 50 million shares of preferred stock for a total of 800 million captial shares. It is the most widely held stock on the Big Board, being owned by some 2,950,000 stockholders.

There was a proud, big-city spirit of can-do and make-do among most of the city school system's principals, teachers, students and chief custodians yesterday morning, but falling temperatures and rising mounds of garbage, plus expressions of sympathy for the strikers, had many of them hoping by day's end for orders to close down.

Thailand today invited the Soviet Union to assume a key role in establishing peace in Southeast Asia. At the same time, the Government indicated strongly that it had no intention of seeking large-scale withdrawal of United States military forces from Thai bases until It was satisfied that war was ended in this part of the world.

Two courtappointed experts have determined that ancient pottery fragments, obtained in the Etruscan tomb country near here last year, did not "seem" to come from the controversial Greek vase by the Greek master Euphronios in the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York,

The Warsaw National Philharmonic, a relatively frequent guest in Carnegie Hall's International Festival of Visiting Orchestras, returned there Tuesday night under the direction of Witold Rowicki. Mr. Rowicki, Poland's most distinguished conductor, helped found this orchestra and also conducted it on its first visit to America about a dozen years ago.

David Frye is. not just a great comedian and impressionist but a political satirist who can wound mortal targets wth deadly accuracy. On Monday night he began a three-week engagement at Jimmy's - his first New York club date in five years.

Tunlsla's new foreign minister said today that his country would never unite with Libya so long as Morocco or Algeria opposed the union. Nevertheless, Tunisia will continue consultations with Libya to work out details of the merger agreement, Foreign Minister Habib Chatti said at a news conference.

Silver futures, which have been setting alltime record prices, surprised the experts yesterday. It was no surprise that a great deal of short covering--buying by traders who had sold--entered the market yesterday causing a significant price decline.

The prosecution in the trial of Colin C. Carpi, a Princeton investment consultant charged with murdering his estranged wife, Laura, in 1971, today introduced testimony designed to cast doubt on the defendant's statement as to when he visited his wife's home on the day of her disappearance.

A private consumer watchdog concern considers the publicworks engineering profession in New Jersey riddled with conflicts of interest and scandals that are costing taxpayers millions of extra dollars and may even threaten health and safety in the state.

In Ambassador Graham A Martin's six months in Saigon he has asserted firm control of the sprawling official American community, established a severely restrictive public-information policy and given almost uncritical support to the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu.

Amid their pervasive preoccupation with crime and violence, New Yorkers share concerns on other matters in which city government has some impact. But their priority list hints some hazards for Mayor Beame's new administration.

The Federal Energy Office said yesterday that it had begun an investigation of conplaints by airline officials who said they had been offered large quantities of scarce jet fuel at prices ranging up to three times the market price.

Nationwide consumption of electricity appears to be running below its normally expected level by as much as 10 per cent, industry figures indicate. Weekly statistics released yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute placed power output in the lower 48 states at just under 36.6 billion kilowatt hours for the week ended Jan. 12.

Cloudy weather will cover most of the Northeast and portions of the Middle Atlantic States today. Rain or snow is forecast for the lower region, while sunny skies will prevail in northern New England. Cloudy skies will spread from Alabama north along the southern Appalachians, and over the middle and upper lake region.

A long-awaited national policy proposal for cable television, released today by the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy, calls for the virtual removal of Government regulation over it, in order to give cable television the same freedom-of-the-press status as newspapers, magazines and books have under the First Amendment.

Brian Faulkner, chief executive of Northern Ireland's government, returned today from talks in Dublin with the Irish Prime Minister and said that he felt reassured that Dublin would not seek the unification of Ireland without the consent of the majority in Northern Ireland.

John J. Graham, who since 1969 had been board chairman of F. R. Schwab Associates, Inc., a New York-based industrial management-consultant organization, died yesterday in Valley Hospital in Ridgewood.

Paul Gibson Jr., an airline executive, was named yesterday to become New York City's First black Deputy Mayor after another black man, State Senator Joseph L. Galiber, withdrew under pressure as a candidate for the job. Paul Gibson Jr.
The General Accounting Office said today that it doubted the Government's ability to meet the 1985 Congressional goal of cleaning the nation's waters because of a lack of needed research.

The desert crowds in close to this city on the Upper Nile, which rises abruptly from the edges of a granite cataract athwart the river. The pervasive mood is solitude, ideal for the sensitive negotiations carried out here by Secretary of State Kissinger in his series of fly. ing visits.

John R. Evans, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, suggested yesterday a tentative deadline of mid-February for the securities industry to move forward on plans for testing a composite stock ticker tape.

With upState objections overcome by the promise of similar aid, both houses of the Legislature passed a bill today authorizing the state to lend New York City $100-million to save the 35-cent transit fare until May 1.

The lobbyist for the Citizens Union said today that business lobbyists here were "not above" providing sexual partners to lure Favorable votes from the legisators. Other lobbyists and legislators immediately called the charge , made by the Citizens Union spokesman, Albert N. ??odell, a "cheap shot" and "ludicrous" rumor-mongering. Upon questioning, Mr. Podell Said he did not speak from First-hand information.

An Internal Revenue Service employe, identified by investigators as the person who gave information about President Nixon's Income tax returns to a newspaper, quit his job under a threat of being dismissed, according to service officials.

A panel of electronics experts will return to Chief Judge John J. Sirica's courtroom Friday to face further cross-examination by White House lawyers. At the center of the discussion in United States District Court is whether three tiny bits of voice-like sound still on the tape mean that the tape was once filled with voices that were erased when the buzzing sound was recorded onto the tape.
An innovation in the posting of prescription-drug prices that will assist consumers in shopping for the best price has been announced by the Walgreen chain.

The American Football Coaches Association, acting on a proposal by United Press International, has voted to permit member coaches to extend their future U.P.I. rankings of the top 10 teams to include results of postseason bowl games. Since their inception in 1950, rankings by the U.P.I. board of 35 coaches-five from each of the nation's seven geographical areas-have ended each year with the final Saturday of the regular season.

The inventions that impound solar energy through sun-reflecting or lensing devices are fascinating to the imagnation but relatively insignificant in potential. In fact, they work only a few hours daily when the sun is at a favorable angle. Even if half of Arizona were turned into a direct-sunlight-energy-converting mechanism, the production would be negligible in comparison with windpower sources.

Paul Gibson Jr., an airline executive, was named yesterday to become New York City's first black Deputy Mayor after another black man, State Senator Joseph L. Galiber, withdrew under pressure as a candidate for the job. Mayor Beame said he would swear in Mr. Gibson, an American Airlines vice president, at 9:15 this morning. He was Mr. Beame's third choice. Paul Gibson Jr.
If it's not an original, and it's not a fake, what is it? It's a Tuli-Latus. And what, you may well ask, is a Tuli-Latus? An exotic fruit, an undiscovered artist, a recherche couturier? Not at all.

Big-time basketball, in the form of recruiters and "interested" college alumni, has hit New Haven, and with it has come big-time problems. Bob Saulsbury, coach at Wilbur Cross High, the defending Connecticut state champion, is fighting back. He has placed a fence around his key man, Bruce Campbell, and tacked on a sign that says in effect: "Keep off! If you weren't there when he was down, don't come around when he's on top."

Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union played P-K4 today to open the second game of his world chess championship quarter-final match against Robert Byrne. Byrne, the chess columnist of The New York Times and former United States champion, replied with P-QB4, setting up a Sicilian Defense, the same defense Spassky used on Monday. After 40 moves, the game was adjourned, and will be resumed tomorrow.

CAIE--Thomas J., 79. Former Vice President of the Groller Society New York Publishers and Executive Vice President of J. G. Ferguson Publishing Company, Chicago. Died suddenly at his home, 3434 Chiswick Court, Silver Spring, Maryland January 13. Mr. Cale was an army veteran of World War 1 and a long time resident of the Chicago area where he spent his entire business life. Memorial services will be held at 2 P.M., Thursday
