The 46 songs of Hugo Wolf's "Italienisches Liederbuch" virtually never turn up in concert as a complete set, and why should they? Though they share a common style (uncommon, really), in only the most tenuous sense are they narratively related.

The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority canceled without explanation today a contract-signing under circumstances that suggested that its $302-million bond issue might once again be in trouble. The authority had been scheduled to sign a contract tomorrow with its underwriters, detailing the terms of the sale. The signing was originally scheduled for today, but had been put off.

Lawyers began efforts yesterday to win a new trial for a man convicted of manslaughter in the 1967 shooting of a Marine sergeant in Greenwhich Village. The lawyers sought to prove that the police and the prosectors had knowledge that a principal witness against their client had a history of mental illness and kept it from the defense

For the first time in more than five years, a major banking bill that has been fought strongly by the banking lobby, one of the most powerful lobbies in the state, will be moved out of committee this year and onto the floor of the State Assembly, sources close to the Banking Committee said today.

The Signal Companies, Inc., of Beverly Hills, Calif., said yesterday that a temporary injunction to enjoin Signal from selling its Signal Oil Gas Company to Burmah Oil, Inc., for more than $480-million had been dissolved. The injunction had been sought by Louis S. Gimbel 3d, a Signal stockholder, in the Court of Chancery of Delaware, which had ordered that a $25-million bond be posted by Jan. 15.
Using a door apparently left open for the benefit of pickets in the twin school schools strikes, about 30 youths ransacked a high school in Cambria Heights, Queens last evening.
Three brothers and their cousin were arrested today in the murder of David Akeman, the Grand Ole Opry comedian known as "Stringbean," and his wife, Estelle, at their home near here Nov. 11.
Expert players can estimate fairly accurately how well they are doing in a pair contest, and the last deal can be a nervous moment for pairs who think they have a chance to win.
William R. Katzell, a former textile mill owner who became a Broadway producer in the nineteen-forties, died today at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck. His age was 68.

A rocket made a direct hit today on the anteroom of the office of the army commander in chief. The commander, Maj. Gen. Sosthene Fernandez, was not hurt, members of his staff said. But a soldier was reported killed and four were wounded.

A landslide roared down a mountain near here tonight, shoving a telephone company building into a creek and burying it, the police said. They said nine persons were missing and believed to be in the building.

Christa Zechmeister of West Germany, the youngest and smallest of the world's top Alpine skiers, captured her third straight World Cup special slalom today in a race that had three Americans and one Canadian among the first 10 finishers. Christa Zechmeister on the way to third straight victory in cup slalom yesterday in Switzerland.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation is preparing to seek legislative authority for reviving counterintelligence tactics in the event of a sudden national emergency, the bureau's director, Clarence M. Kelley, said today.

PARTICIPANTS-The two striking unions are Local 74 of the Service Employes International Union, representing 5,000 maintenance employes, cleaners, matrons and handymen, and Local 94 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, representing 1,000 stationary engineers and firemen. The two groups are actually direct employes of the school custodians, who act as independent contractors and are given allowances by the Board of Education to pay for the schools' maintenance and for labor costs.

The search for the person or persons who erased 18 1/2 minutes of a key Watergate tape recording was narrowed today when the special Watergate prosecution established in court that the erasure must have been made between last Oct. 1 and mid-November. Stephen B. Bull, the President's appointment secretary, who assisted Rose Mary Woods in preparing transcripts of the tapes, arriving at U.S. District Court yesterday.

The White House denied today that President Nixon had personally erased part of a key Watergate tape, but otherwise refused to discuss yesterday's testimony by technical experts suggesting that the tape may have been tampered with.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit reversed today a contempt judgment tha would have sent an American Lutheran Church official to jail for refusing to testify about Indian activities last year at Wounded Knee, S.D.

The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority canceled without explanation today a contract-signing under circumstances that suggested that its $302-million bond issue might once again be in trouble.

The Earl of Cromer, retiring after three years as Britain's Ambassador in Washington, used his farewell address to sound a timely warning about American relations with the nine-natioin European Community. He conceded that forging new procedures for satisfactory consultation with the Community would be "immensely frustrating" for Washington, but added: "I hope that you will not allow such frustration to become the key to your policies toward Europe.

The Administration plans to withdraw all of the Americanfinanced Thai forces from Laos in the next few months, ending a chapter in which the United States recruited foreign troops to fight in Indochina.

WESTWOOD-Sundays at 5:30 A.M., the first pucks are flashing across the ice at the Fritz Dietl rink here. The fledgling Gordie Howes--their ages range from 5 to 12who form the Pascack Valley Peewee Hockey Association, take their sport seriously.

A public hearing on the safety of the New York subway system will be conducted by the Federal Railroad Administration Feb. 13 starting at 9:30 A.M. at the Pace College auditorium across from City Hall on Park Row.
In a surprise discovery, the chairman of the Assembly Codes Committee said today that numerous organizations-the Boy Scouts, church groups and newsmen who cover the capital-had been breaking

A striking election upset by the Communist party in the heart of Bombay has jolted Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's New Congress party. The defeat in the parliamentary election Monday was considered deeply significant in New Delhi because it underlined the restless and angry mood that grips many other cities.
Two more power company issues were marketed yesterday in a corporate bond market still attempting to assess, among other things, fuel-supply factors,

Stephen B. Bull, the President's appointment secretary, who assisted Rose Mary Woods in preparing transcripts of the tapes, arriving at U.S. District Court yesterday.

6-10 A.M., WNCN. Trumpet Concerto in D, Telemann; Sonetto di Petrarca, Liszt; Gigues, Debussy; Rondo for Piano and Orchestra (K. 386), Mozart; Sinfonia in E flat, C. P. E. Bach; Scherzo, Dittersdorf-Kreisler; Overture to La Fiere dl Venezia, Salieri;
Expert testimony that the 18 1/2minute gap in a critical tape recording of White House conversations was caused by five erasures and recordings has

The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange does not have a list this week.

Though generally satisfied with their insurers, the majority of automobile and ,home policyholders believe their companies discriminate against the young, are reluctant to pay claims fully and are quick. to cancel policies after an accident, according to a national survey.

Bowing to public pressure and the threat of legal action, the Hudson County Parks Commission decided tonight to temporarily withhold payment of nearly $40,000 to meet the legal fees of two commissioners who were acquitted of conspiracy and misconduct-in-office charges.

Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson today proposed a $229.2-million operating budget for 1974, with nearly one-fourth earmarked for public schools. The Mayor said the proposed budget was aimed at "increasing and improving municipal services while again reducing the property tax levied on Newark home-owners."

A man shot and killed two police officers and wounded two others today during a gun battle that began shortly after the police responded to a call about a domestic quarrel. The shooting began shortly after 4 P.M., when the man identified by the police as Andrew J. Pantaleo began firing at the officers from his whiteshingled, single-family home on the East Side of Detroit.
Western Union has introduced a service for skiers that provides the latest ski conditions at New England or Colorado resorts. The reports are obtainable by dialing FYI News on
Former Gov. William Guy said today that he would seek a United States Senate seat from North Dakota this fall.

Albert H. Cass Jr., assistant professor of biological sciences at Dartmouth College, died yesterday at his home here. He was 33 years old. Dr. John L. Dunn, deputy medical examiner of Grafton County, called the death a suicide.

Those closely guarded figures telling how well the major New York. City banks have done with their commingled corporate pension accounts have surfaced, disclosing stunning losses for 1973 almost all along the line.

The United States and the Soviet Union today signed an agreement laying out five broad areas for cooperation in transportation this year. The agreement worked out at the first meeting of a joint committee, on cooperation in the field of transportation, which began here Monday, covered railway, air, auto and marine transportation, as well as transportation construction.

The North American Soccer League today announced its 14th franchise for the 1974 season beginning in May would be based in San Jose. Milan Mandaric, a 35-year-old electronics expert from Yugoslavia, was introduced as owner of the franchise and Dick Berg, former Stanford quarterback and more recently promotions director for the San Francisco 49ers, was named general manager.

Suspense, anyone? The oldfashioned kind? Who's for good, clean fun? Two of the quieter Off Off Broadway packages are worth investigating. One is Agatha Christle's 1954 puzzler, "The Spider's Web," tastily staged at Lolly's Theater Club, Lexington Avenue at 62d Street (8327404, admission $4). The other, believe it or not, is good old "Dracula,"

The letter was signed "Chuck." And the envelope was no help either. It bore in fading ink one of those United States Postal Service Imprints that could have been hastily applied in almost any American town. But inside were seven slick $1 bills, along with the following note:

Five seamen died in the Channel today and 11 were saved after a Danish coastal vessel, the Merc Enterprise, capsized south of here in winds gusting up to 100 miles an hour. Seven of the survivors were rescued by British and West German helicopters from a nearby British naval training base and four were picked up by the Soviet ship Leningrad.

The state Democratic party, which saw many powerful trade unions back Governor Rockefeller for re-election four years ago, began a drive yesterday for widespread labor support for its candidates this year. As a step in that direction, the state chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, announced the formation of a Democratic Labor Advisory Council to work closely with his organization on a yearround basis.

JAWS. By Peter Benchley. 311 pages, Doubleday. $6.95. Most of the way through "Jaws," it looks as though Peter Benchley Is going to pull off the rare trick of writing a slickly plotted thriller with substance. After all, Peter Benchley

Howard. M. Metzenbaum; a Democrat appointed to the Senate from Ohio, replied at a news conference today to Senator Carl T. Curtis, Republican of Nebraska, who urged yesterday that the Senate delay seating. Mr. Metzenbaum pending an investigation...

Chancellor Irving Anker, who has seen all kinds of crises during 39 years in the city's school system, began his office day at 8:30 A.M. yesterday by meeting around his oversize, modern desk with a sort of ad hoc "cabinet" on the strike emergency.

Senator James H. Donovan, chairman of the State Senate Select Committee for the Mentally and Physically Handicapped, toured four New York City prison wards yesterday in preparation for his committee's hearings today on the treatment of handirapped inmates. State Senator James H. Donovan talking to inmates in Branch Queens House of Detention for Men in Long Island City during his tour of city prison wards yesterday.

Landlords of apartments throughout New York City said yesterday that they had been confronted with 40 per cent price increases in fuel oil this week compared with a week ago--34. cents a gallon for residual oil, instead of last week's 24 cents.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association, in a step it believes will make college football safer, outlawed today downfield blocking below the waist, on kickoff and punt returns next season.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Communications Workers of America will negotiate their new wage contract on a nationwide basis this year for the first time, the two sides announced jointly today.

A long-awaited national policy proposal for cable television, released today by the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy, calls for the virtual removal of Government regulation over it, in order to give cable television the same freedom-of-the-press status as newspapers, magazines and books have under the First Amendment.
In some dimly remembered Hollywood Western, a frontier woman tells her children that their father has been killed and that the oldest boy, the 10year-old, will have to be the man of the house now.

The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was recalling 159,149 of its current-model cars because of a defect in the suspension system that could result in a loss of steering control. The cars affected include all 1974 Dodge Monaco. Plymouth Fury, Chrysler and Imperial passenger cars built through Dec. 31. A spokesman said about two-thirds were still in dealer stocks.
If south Florida horseplayers truly are creatures of habit, they will be seriously disorientated tomorrow. The action switches from Calder Race Course to Gulfstream and

Nationwide consumption of electricity appears to be running below its normally expected level by as much as 10 per cent, industry figures indicate. Weekly statistics released yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute placed power output in the lower 48 states at just under 36.6 billion kilowatt hours for the week ended Jan. 12.

While the Nixon Administration continues to complain about its "press," particularly television coverage, the news department of the Columbia Broadcasting System seems especially determined to give no indication of retreating under pressure.

Auto insurers are under growing pressure to reduce rates because of the gasoline shortage and the reduction in driving. But so far they are urging patience. They maintain that accidents may be down, but inflation is up and car-pool accidents might even offset any possible saving. But if any saving is possible, they say, policyholders will get them.

An investment company from oil-rich Kuwait has bought 50 per cent of the Atlanta Center, Ltd., and there are reports that it is also interested in financing a South Carolina resort. The company, KIC, Inc., paid an undisclosed sum to become a limited partner in the project being developed.by Crow, Pope Land Enterprises of Atlanta.

Secretary of State Kissinger shuttled back and forth between Tel Aviv and Aswan today, arriving late tonight confident that an agreement was near between Egypt and Israel that would pave the way for the separation of their forces near the Suez Canal.

South Vietnamese sailors and militiamen today fired bursts of machine gun fire at. Chinese who raised a Chinese flag on Robert Island in the disputed Paracel group claimed by Saigon, South Vietnamese military sources said here.

Pocket calculators - products of continued electronic miniaturization that have sold in millions over the last three years - are developing from simple arithmetic devices into general purpose machines with the characteristics of computers.

State Senator Anthony Imperiale, the controversial white militant leader from this city's North Ward, formally announced today his candidacy for Mayor, declaring, "I am the only man capable of bringing this city back together again."

Frank Schiffman, who in 1934 was the co-founder of Harlem's Apollo Theater, died yesterday at his home in Surfside. He was 80 years old. The Apollo had been a burlesque theater when Mr. Schiffman, who already owned several theaters in Harlem, bought it in 1934 with Leo Brecher.

The Navy will spend an average of $3.4-billion a year over the next five years on anti submarine warfare in search of weapons, ships, aircraft and sensors to counter the expending Soviet undersea fleet, according to a leading technological market research organination here.

The city's Market Basket report yesterday showed the sixth straight week of price increases, led by rising meat prices, bringing the cost of feeding a family of four to $57.42-the highest level since the Department of Consumer Affairs began the surveys last May.

Lawyers began efforts yesterday to win a new trial for a man convicted of manslaughter in the 1967 shooting of a Marine sergeant in Greenwich Village. The lawyers sought to prove that the police and the prosecutors had knowledge that a principal witness against their client had a history of mental illness and kept it from the defense
The lobbyist for the Citizens Union said today that business lobbyists here were "not above" providing sexual partners to lure favorable votes from the legislators.

Last July 23, in a letter to Senator Sam Ervin, President Nixon said that the White House tapes would remain "under my sole personal control." When some tapes were subsequently subpoenaed, there was a legal obligation to preserve that evidence even while the subpoena was contested.
" The thing that troubles most of us," Mrs. Ellen McConnell, a retired schoolteacher in Winfield, Kan., told Senator Robert Dole last week, "is that we don't know who and what to believe."

The mounting violence and virulence of the official campaign against Aleksandr Solzhenitsyrn may wind up doing more damage to the Soviet regime than did the publication in Paris of his new book on the prison camp system. If the denunciations are followed by arrest, confinement to an insane asylum, internal deportation or forcible exile, they will set back a decade of Soviet policy abroad in pursuit of detente, trade and technological exchange with the West.

The World Banking Conference in London has attracted many of the big guns in the banking world to hear some of its leading figures talk about problems and prospects in the field. Among yesterday's speakers were:

Rumors that she is breaking up with her husband were termed "a deliberate lie" by Tricia Nixon Cox. The President's daughter authorized the denial of the rumored break-up. The denial was issued in Washington by Mrs. Helen McCain Smith, news secretary to the President' wife.

The Chase Manhattan Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 55 cents a share, payable Feb. 15 to stock holders of record Jan. 30. The payment, five cents higher than the quarterly dividends paid in 1978, reflects the bank's higher earnings, David Rockefeller, chairman, said.
The Ford Motor Company said today that a new survey showing that more than 60 per cent of 1974-model Ford owners use safety belts indicates that air bags may never be needed to protect car occupants.

In a game to perplex the onlookers-both masters and patzers-Boris Spassky and I fought the opener of our quarter-finals candidates match to a draw. Spassky took 2 hours 26 minutes and I 2 hours 37 minutes to arrive at a level rook-and-pawn ending that prompted us to cease hostilities at move 44.

The financially ailing brokerage organization of duPont Glore Forgan, Inc., and duPont Walston, Inc., disclosed financial data here yesterday showing that, despite continuing losses, the two companies were operating well within the requirements of the New York Stock Exchange as of Nov. 30, the latest reporting period.
Ten years ago, Paul Gibson Jr. walked into an emotionally charged parents meeting at Andrew Jackson High School in Cambria Heights, Queens. The issue was busing schoolchildren for

Derek Sanderson scored his second goal of the game with 3 minutes 57 seconds left tonight to give the Boston Bruins a 5-5 tie with the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game. It was the third straight deadlock between the teams this season.

Leo Quanchi, a painter represented in the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York and other public and private collections, died yesterday in the Sharon Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived on Maple Road Extension here.

Although it is in the midst of making strike plans for next week unless "significant progress" is made on a new contract covering Off Broadway actors and stage managers, Actors Equity Association has reached a working agreement with. the Roundabout Theater.

The stock market made its second consecutive advance yesterday as investors were buoyed by the hopes that some progress was being made in the Mideast disengagement negotiations being conducted by Secretary of State Kissinger between Israel and Egypt.

After four days of rest, the New York Nets responded tonight with perhaps their worst performance of the American Basketball Association season. Performing sluggishly on both defense and offense, they were run down by the Carolina Cougars, 131-105, before a disenchanted crowd of 9,048 at Nassau Coliseum. Ted McLain of the Carolina Cougars driving for a layup against the Nets at the Nassau Coliseum last night.

The Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire, through a subsidiary, the zinc smelter and other properties and to assume certain liabilities of the National Zinc Company of Barltesville, Okla.
Archbishop Seraphim, enthroned as Primate of the Greek Orthodox Church in the Cathedral of Athens today, vowed to restore unity and order in the deeply divided church.

The Ingalls Shipbuilding division of Litton Systems, Inc., has received $411-million in additions to a previously awarded Navy contract for 14 destroyers. The company got $236-million to complete funds for seven destroyers ordered last fiscal year and $175-million in advanced funds for the final. seven destroyers of the 30-ship order.

New Hampshire trout anglers no longer have to doze by the hearth in winter dreaming of the time when they can once again go forth to pursue their favorite fish. On Jan. 1, New Hampshire made it legal to fish for lake, brook, rainbow and brown trout, grayling and splake (a lake trout-brook trout hybrid) through natural openings in the ice in streams, ponds and lakes.

The; Co t of Living Council made public today final regulations covering price increases in the' health industry that will permit hospitals somewhat greater flexibility than had been proposed. The regulations also provider additional incentives to emphasize outpatient rather than inhospital care.

" Citibank," the Ralph Nader study group's report about the First National City Bank, has just been expanded and reissued in book form, touching off a deep-seated clash between the authors and the bank's executives over the methods and conclusions of the analysis. Jacket of new book, Left: Ralph Nader, and right: Walter B. Wriston.

The credibility gap created by the energy crisis is threatening to match that of Watergate. The paucity of verified facts has provoked angry complaints from Congress and state governments and led to widespread public suspicion that the oil shortage may be "contrived" rather than "real," in the words of New York State's Attorney General.

An Internal Revenue Service emdloye, identified by investigators as the person who gave information about President Nixon's Income tax returns to a newspaper, quit his job under a threat of being dismissed, according to service officials.

The Boston Herald-American announced today that it would eliminate its afternoon editions beginning. Feb. 11. The newspaper said that the cutback would involve about 60,000 copies of the 375,000 in its circulation.

Unless the sharply higher prices recently imposed by the oil-producing countries are quickly cut to a level that the oil-consuming countries can afford to pay, the end result could be a global depression, according to Walter J. Levy, one of the world's leading energy economists. Walter J. Levy

Arthur F. Flood, a former executive vice president, director and controller of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, now Fairchild Industries, lied yesterday in a convalescent home. He was 66 years old and lived at 166 Foxwood Road.

SEASON OPENER While Brooklyn is monopolizing Shakespeare, Manhattan and Queens are attempting to do justice to that American playwright who made good, Eugene O'Neill. Manhattan, of course, has been making its contribution with productions of "The Iceman Cometh" and "A Moon for the Misbegottent." Gene Krupa

Gov. Francis W. Sargent called today for public regulations "or if necessary public ownership" of the nation's oil companies. In testimony before a United States Senate subcommittee on intergovernmental relations, the Massachusetts Governor said: "The major oil companies were given a free hand. They have used that hand to turn the oil spigot off and on at will and manipulate and gouge the consumer. Such unrestrained freedom must never be allowed again."

The University of Connecticut basketball team fought off a surprisingly stiff Columbia challenge tonight before defeating the Lions, 63-56. The Lions, losers of 10 straight before tonight, were underdogs to the Huskies.

A sharp decline in automobile production, combined with an unusual drop in the output of electric and gas utilities, brought the first significant dip in December in the nation's industrial production in two years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

With upstate objections overcome by the promise of similar aid, both houses of the Legislature passed a bill today authorizing the state to lend New York City $100-million to save the 35-cent transit fare until May 1.
The work of American Kennel Club executive field agents in dealing with the breeding and selling of dogs for the pet market was explored by Roy Carlberg, a vice president of
The Allied Chemical Corporation and the Stauffer Chemical Company reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the final 1973 quarter and the full year.

The pound tumbled to another low against the dollar and some West European currencies today. The dollar also eased marginally. Battered by labor troubles and published reports that Britain may have to seek a massive loan from the International Monetary Fund in the face of growing oil bills, the pound fell to $2.16325.
Nearly all the "national security" questions involved in the Watergate case have now been made public, and in the wake of their disclosure critics are still raising questions about

The state Democratic party, which saw many powerful trade unions back Governor Rockefeller for re-election four years ago, began a drive yesterday for widespread labor support for its candidates this year.

The strikes of furnace tenders and janitorial employes that may force closing of all the city's public schools within a few days falls into a never-never land of exclusion from all the city and state laws prohibiting strikes in municipal agencies. That indefensible exclusion stems from the anomalous position these critically needed workers occupy in the school structure: they are technically not employes of

Elizabeth J. McCormack, the president of Manhattanville College, announced yesterday that she had resigned from the Society of the Sacred Heart and accepted a new post with an unnamed foundation, beginning in June. Elizabeth J. McCormack
Kohoutek is a giant snowball, coated or impregnated with organic matter and displaying an intitail as well as a tail, according to observations from Skylab and a number of ground observatories.

Bo Osten Unden, who was Sweden's Foreign Minister from 1945 to 1962 and was a strong advocate of world peace through international law, died Tuesday in Stockholm. He was 87 years old. Mr. Unden gained recognition as a legal scholar, and came to worldwide attention as a persistent critic of countries that he thought had violated the principles of the United Nations Charter.

Deputy Premier Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria says that there should be a simultaneous disengagement of forces on the Syrian and Egyptian fronts and insists that the disengagement be linked to an Israeli withdrawal from occupied Arab territory.

Eight former topless masseuses are seeking a State Employment Security Commission order giving them their old jobs, back pay and the right to unionize and eat submarine sandwiches. The women contend they were dismissed by the American Massage Parlor in Ann Arbor after organizing in October to fight what they called harassment by management.

Two young men were arraigned in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday in connection with the kidnapping and sexual assault of a 13-year-old girl who was allegedly held captive for four days in a street gang's clubhouse. A 14-year-old girl abducted at the same time is still missing, the police said.

The public knows of Robert H. Bork as the bearded Yale Law School professor whom President Nixon appointed as Solicitor General, and who moved up to the post of Acting Attorney General when Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson resigned, and Deputy Attorney General William D. Ruckelshaus refused to obey the order of his commander in chief to fire Archibald Cox.

Mrs. Hazel H. Johnston of St. Louis today won the 32d New Jersey millionaire lottery drawings. The winner was not present. A $200,000 prize went to Jose and Susan Liebiedz of Irvington, and the Helen Barney family of Paterson won $100.000.

The Charter New York Corporation, the parent company of the Irving Trust Company and thirteen smaller upstate banks, reported yesterday a slight rise in fourth-quarter profits and a substantial increase in full-year results.

Mrs. Johanna Reston, mother of James Reston, a vice president and columnist of The New York Times, died early today. She was 98 years old. Mrs. Reston was born in Stranraer, Scotland, one of eight children of Andrew Irving, a stonemason, and Roseanne Gordon Irving. Her husband, James Reston Sr., a machinist, died here in 1960 at the age of 88.
The Soviet Union has started jamming west German radio broadcasts to prevent Russians from hearing readings from Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's new book, German Sources here said today.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Communications Workers of America will negotiate their new wage contract on a nationwide basis this year for the first time, the two sides announced jointly today.

The First Western Bank and Trust Company disclosed in Los Angeles last night that it had been sold by World Airways, Inc., its owner since 1968, to Lloyds Bank, Ltd., of London, for $115-million. The joint announcement said the 94-branch bank, eighth largest in California, with assets of $1.3-billion, would retain Its present management,
United Natioin supplies for Suez City and for troops of the Egyptian Third Army on the eastern bank of the canal were interrupted yesterday and today, the United Nations reported.

Oil imports dropped sharply last week, resuming their steep decline begun in November, the American Petroleum Institute reported Wednesday. And United States gasoline stocks dropped some 3.6 million barrels to a low level usually reached only in midsummer.

State Senator Anthony Imperiale, the controversial white militant leader from this city's North Ward, formally announced today his candidacy for mayor, declaring, "I am the only man capable of bringing this city back together again." Anthony Imperiale passing out petitions to get his name on the ballot as a candidate for mayor along Park Avenue in Newark yesterday

Columbia Artists Management's cancellation of an American tour by Leningrad's Kirov Ballet this summer is not expected to damage the 1974 to 1976 cultural-exchange agreement between the Soviet Union and the United States, according to the State Department.

Governor Byrne today appointed Anthony J. Grossi, the longtime Passaic County Democratic leader, to be the first full-time president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners. Governor Byrne sitting at the head of a conference table at the State House with members of his cabinet

The Treasury Department is ready to begin a program of paying Government benefit checks by direct electronic deposits into a recipient's bank account. The program begins in March for the 3.5 million or so recipients of the new Fcderal supplemental security income payments for disabled, blind and aged.

In the week since the, arrest of a prime suspect in the slaying of Marcus A. Foster, the Oakland schools superintendent the police have said little, but there are indications that they have begun to unravel the mystery of the Symbionese Liberation Army.

The World Rehabilitation Fund an international, nonprofit organization that helps physically handicapped persons to build new, active lives, honored David A. Morse last night for his "unusually active" years of service to the disabled.

Landlords of apartments throughout New York City said yesterday that they had been confronted with 40 per cent price increases in fuel oil this week compared with a week ago--34 cents a gallon for residual oil, instead of last week's 24 cents.

They had nothing in common except friendship and skill, which were enough to enable them to enjoy doing things together. Mickey Mantle was a quiet country kid who could hit. Whitey Ford was a tough city kid who could pitch. When they were with the New York Yankees, it seemed as if they were in the World Series every year. It also seemed as if they were in the nightclubs every night.

The Rev. Dr. Angus C. Hull, executive secretary since 1962 of what is now the American Baptist Churches of Metropolitan New York, died yesterday in Knickerbocker Hospital after suffering a heart attack at a memorial service for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in Convent Avenue Baptist Church in Harlem. He was 64 years old and lived at 70 Lasalle Street.

Art should change something in our lives, Rilke, the poet, said, and he was right. The problem with Lar Lubovitch's interesting failure of a new ballet is that his "Three Essays" doesn't really tell us anything at any level that we don't already know. Christine Sarry

North Vietnam wants to set up diplomatic relations with the United States subject to certain conditions, according to a Foreign Ministry white paper published here today to mark the first anniversary of the signing of the Paris peace accords.

Twin strikes by 6,000 boilerroom and maintenance workers cut off heat and cleaning services at many city schools yesterday, forcing 34 schools with 77,400 pupils to close and prompting many parents to take their children home from cold classrooms. Some pupils at P.S. 129, Brooklyn, put on coats and gloves when the heat went off

Fighting has again erupted in the last month on Mindanao Island between Philippine troops and small groups of Moslem rebels who have refused to lay down their arms. At least 12 soldiers have been killed, it was reported today, and parts of three towns have been burned down. Some 10,000 people reportedly fled their homes for the safety of urban centers.

For the first time in more than five years, a major banking bill that has been fought strongly by the banking lobby, one of the most powerful lobbies in the state, will be moved out of committee this year and onto the floor of the State Assembly, sources close to the Banking Committee said today.

Defense lawyers in the trial of Thomas J. Mackell, the former Queens District Attorney, yesterday portrayed a former Queens assistant district attorney and a former county detective as having been "taken in" by a get-rich-quick scheme that the prosecution asserts flourished in Mr. Mackell's office for four years.

President Nixon announced today the appointment of Kenneth R. Cole Jr. as special assistant to the President for domestic affairs. Mr. Cole, who is executive director of the Domestic Council, will keep that position as well. Gerald L. Warren, deputy White House press secretary, said at a briefing today that Mr. Cole would be the President's chief adviser on domestic affairs.

Arab spokesmen at a series of high-level monetary meetings here have indicated a willingness to lend funds to industrial, developed countries, as well as developing nations to help them finance higher payments for oil.

" I don't expect anybody to read the book," said F. Beaven Ennis, author, In response to the wise-guy comment, "I'm waiting for the movie." But, he said, he does expect the 188-page opus to be frequently used as a guide, a how-to book, in packaged goods companies that have the product manager system.

Secretary of State Kissinger shuttled back and forth between Tel Aviv and Aswan today, arriving late tonight confident that an agreement was near between Egypt and Israel that would pave the way for the separation of their forces near the Suez Canal.

The Government newspaper Izvestia today called the discussion of an independent defense community in Western Europe "incompatible" with the 19-nation negotiations on the mutual reduction of forces in Central Europe.

The New York Giants confirmed the selection of Bill Arnsparger as their coach yesterday and promised him "total involvement" to rebuild the team. Andy Robustelli, the club's director of operations, followed up the worst-kept secret of Super Bowl VIII with the announcement that the 47-year-old Arnsparger had accepted a three-year contract.

To the Editor: Alexander Hamilton would view today's political scene with sardonic amusement at Jefferson's expense. It is a banality to say that there are bumbling incompetents in Congress; more serious charges can be leveled at many members, There are probably also honorable and competent people in the body, but this is less susceptible of proof.

Amid White House denials, Senate Watergate committee sources elaborated today on their evidence that President Nixon indirectly solicited a contribution from the Howard Hughes, organization during the Nixon campaign for the White House in 1968.

A woman named Luba Harrington returned from her summer home in Sag Harbor, L.I., last fall, and brought with her some flowers from a garden. When she began to arrange the flowers in a bowl in her apartment here, there flew out of them a small fly.
Bobby Clarke scored two goals and an assist tonight and led the Philadelphia Flyers to a 7-2 victory over the Buffalo Sabres in a National Hockey League game.
On a visit here from his native Russia, David Ois-. trakh, the violinist, saw a Chrysler in a showroom, and asked, "how much is that droshky in the window?"
The Nixon Administration was assailed here today for what was described as its failure to support or provide for a comprehensive housing program for the elderly.

The EastWest negotiations on the reduction of armed forces in Central Europe resumed here today, and the Czechoslovak delegate held a news conference afterward to reiterate Warsaw Pact objections to Western proposals.
The Cost of Living Council banned today any increases in automobile insurance premiums for the next two months because of an apparent decline in highway deaths attributed to the energy shortage.
The White House promised today to "cooperate totally" with the Federal Bureau of Investigation's inquiry into the erasure of a key 18 1/2-minute segment of a Watergate tape recording.

The Champion International Corporation realized profit increases of 26 per cent for the final quarter and 46 per cent for all of last year on sales gains of 17 and 18 per cent, respectively, all setting records, the company reported yesterday.

The members of Class 6-405 at Public School 95 in the Bronx have found a way to sweeten the spirit of charity. Their teacher, Mrs. Frances Morrison, said the $12 contribution to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund acknowledged yesterday represented the profit of a "Make Your Own Sundae Party."
A Mercer County Superior Court jury heard testimony today that Colin C. Carpi threatened his estranged wife, Laura, twice shortly before she was murdered.

The Libyan Embassy issued a statement yesterday denying that the Libyan Government had anything to do with an alleged plot by Arab terrorists to assassinate Secretary of State Kissinger in Beirut last Dec. 16.

Jacob Sheinkman, general secretary-treasurer of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, has been elected president of the Jewish Labor Committee, the union announced yesterday. He succeeds the late Jacob T. Zukerman.

In this pop life, where hyperbole is far more common than talent, it's very difficult to distinguish the significant from the flashy event. Yet, it would be hard to overstate the promise inherent in the first concert of the New York Repertory Jazz Company a week from tomorrow at Carnegie Hall.

The first consumer directory of physicians in the nation, containing such information as office hours, fees, willingness to make house calls and medical training, was released today for the Prince Georges County area of Maryland, a suburb of Washington.

Stock-market reform has proved to be a frustrating experience to all hands. The many moving parts that make up the stock market will not sit still long enough for anyone to figure out what the problem is, or was, much less how to make repairs.
The Franklin New York Corporation, holding company for the Franklin National Bank, announced yesterday changes in its agreement relating to the acquisition of 52 per cent
A former student leader, Daniel Cohn-Bendit, was sentenced today to five months in jail for assaulting a policeman and knocking out two of his teeth.

Members and officers of three' major New Jersey labor inions demonstrated for a little movie than an. hour today in front of the Exxon Corpora tion's -research center. on Route 1 to protest what they called a "phony" fuel shortage. The Republican and Democratic parties started a joint search today for ways to finance national political conventions that would be free of scandals and pressures.
The bodies of three young mountaineers killed in an avalanche in northwest Wyoming's Grand Teton Mountain range were taken from the mountain by helicopter today and brought to nearby Jackson.
The bizarre scalding death of a youthful inmate at Trenton State Prison has touched off a broad investigation into the New Jersey penal system, the Mercer County Prosecutor said today.

The Internal Revenue Service is auditing the tax returns of the Richard Nixon Foundation in addition to President Nixon's personal tax returns, Arthur Blech, the President's accountant, disclosed today.

The stock market scored its biggest gain of the week yesterday in heavy trading on news that Egypt and Israel had agreed on a disengagement in the Suez area. The news was officially announced by President Nixon shortly before 3 P.M. after the stock market had moved higher throughout the session on reports that an agreement had been reached, between the two countries.
The executive commission of the Common Market has proposed to the nine member countries an average increase of 7 per cent in the community farm support prices for the 1974-75 season.

Egypt and Israel reached agreement on the separation of their forces along the Suez Canal. The agreement is to be signed today at the tent encampment on the CairoSuez highway where cease-fire talks began after the October war. The announcement of the pact was made simultaneously in Cairo, Jerusalem and Washington, where President Nixon reported the agreement to the nation over television. [1:8; Text, P. 2.]
The completion of the Egyptian-Israeli agreement on the disengagement of their forces along the Suez Canal was announced today to newsmen in Aswan, upper Egypt, by the Government's spokesman.

After a 13-year effort to conserve for future generations the helium that is flowing from wells in the world's only helium-rich gas field, the program has been terminated. The gas is being permitted to disperse into the atmosphere,

Uncollected trash and unclean lavatories became the chief problems for those city principals and teachers still on the job yesterday, while some student rowdiness added to the difficulties of running a school and teaching classes without custodial help. Mark Sofar, of the faculty at Washington Irving High School, using a bullhorn to announce that classes were suspended yesterday

The Financial Accounting Standards Board, responding to the stepped-up rate of inflation besetting the nation, announced yesterday that it had decided to study the effect of general price-level changes on corporate reports.

Senior American officials disclosed this morning that a detailed American proposal limiting what arms both Israel and Egypt could deploy in the Suez area would be signed today by Premier Golda Meir in Israel and by President Anwar elSadat in Egypt, both in the presence of Secretary of State Kissinger.
Growth of the nation's economy slowed markedly in the final quarter of 1973 and housing starts plummeted in December, the Commerce Department reported today.
It is advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices before going to, the show, Most, if not all, theaters accept Theater Development Fund vouchers.
Fifty opposition assemblymen said today that the supporters of a proposal to allow President Nguyen Van Thieu to run for a third term were "annihilating democracy for a totalitarian regime."

Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn became the third major Democratic gubernatorial contender yesterday as he began openly campaigning in Binghamton for the nomination. Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn in Binghamton yesterday.

The agreement on disengagement of Egyptian and Israeli forces along the Suez Canal is a notable achievement for all the parties involved. If promptly and faithfully executed, it will sharply reduce the danger of renewed fighting and significantly enhance the prospects of a comprehensive Arab-Israeli settlement.

The New York City and Newark metropolitan region would get 20 per cent less gasoline than the nationwide standard under the rationing plan proposed by the Federal Energy Office - possibly 33 gallons a month for each driver, rising to about 40 when supplies ease up.

Bill (the Bridegroom) Bradley rejoined his New York Knick teammates today after a 48hour honeymoon and, everything considered, was treated gently by a group whose teasing capability is enormous. Bill Bradley, now a married man

The Federal Reserve did little in the money market this week, and its inaction tended to confirm the view that the central bank likes money-market conditions just about the way they are.

After the bowls are over in football, including the Super Bowl, 'tis the season to play musical chairs with coaches in earnest. A lively game was played yesterday by several teams, including the New York Jets.

Representative H. R. Gross, the 74-year-old gadfly of the House, today announced his retirement. The Iowa Republican, who has been called "Congressman No" for questioning bills and objecting to what he regards as wasteful Government spending, thus joined 10 other Republican Representatives, most of them senior House members, who so far have announced that they will not seek re-election next fall.

The nation's sixth largest banking concern, the Chemical New York Corporation, whose principal subsidiary is the Chemical Bank, reported a sharp rise in fourth-quarter earnings for 1973 of 14.8 per cent. A smaller increase of 8.2 per cent was reported for the full year.

For its third annual fundraising spectacular, the Film Society of Lincoln Center will present "A Gala Evening With Alfred Hitchcock" on April 29 at Avery Fisher Hall. A facsimile of the Hitchcock "signature" that will appear on a flag to be flown over Avery Fisher Hall April 29.
Egypt and Israel reached agreement today on separating their forces along the Suez Canal arid limiting the arms each is to have in the area.

For the ordinary Soviet citizen, the ideological message in his daily newspapers is clear-the United States is a good place to keep in touch with, but no place to live.

It seems unlikely that George Gershwin's music can ever have been in more compatible circumstances than in the "Jazz Portrait of George Gershwin". that was presented Monday evening at New York University's Loeb Student Center.

H. Danforth Starr, board chairman of the Cerro Corporation, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, while on an airplane en route to Florida, where he had planned to-attend a meeting of a company of which he was a director. He was 68 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.
WASHINGTON-The line were brief, and the words could easily have been missed during President Nixon's 12minute radio talk, but they were momentous.
Gales with 100-milean-hour gusts whipped the English Channel into a fury today and swept the European mainland, leaving at least 34 people dead and a' wide trail of damage.

For the second night in a row, the New York Rangers tried to overcome a two-goal deficit in the final period, even removing their goalie in the final frantic seconds for an extra skater. Blues' goalie John Davidson blocking a shot from Pete Stemkowsld of the Rangers in the first period of game in St. Louis last night. The Blues won, 3-2.

The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority announced this evening that a syndicate of New York financial underwriters had sold a $302-million bond issue to finance the construction of a sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands in New Jersey.

The Government said today It had found that racial discrimination still exists in the Topeka, Kan., school system, the defendant in the United States Supreme Court's 1954 decision outlawing "separate but equal" education.

The World'Championship of Tennis and World Team Tennis announced today cooperation in a multi-million dollar pension plan and a format to protect the open events of Italy, France, the United States (Forest Hills) and Britain (Wimbledon).

State Controller Arthur Levitt asserted today that physician faculty members at the state's four medical schools were regularly earning more outside income than permitted under the State University's rules and that the medical schools generally, made little effort to enforce the state regulations.
William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, said tonight that "after the embargo" United States imports of oil would climb to seven million barrels a day, a new high.

The world's scheduled airlines announced today they would investigate measures to give civil aviation a bigger share of available oil supplies.

Two hours before the country got fresh evidence of gross misconduct in the White House-the systematic erasure of Watergate tapes-Vice President Ford chose to describe President Nixon as the victim of "a few extreme partisans" bent on using Watergate to crush him and his policies.

Concentrations of helmeted riot policemen in parts of this ordinarily placid capital gave evidence today of an increase in tension as the country appeared to be backtracking on its proposed merger with neighboring Libya.

The lack of heat and the growing accumulations of gar. bage forced 294 city schools to close yesterday as new efforts were unable to settle the twin strikes by 6,000 boilerroom and maintenance workers. Gerard N. Oak, principal, viewing trash piled up yesterday at Washington Irving High School, one of many schools closed because of strike by maintenance workers.
A Westinghouse Electric Corporation executive said today that the company would pledge its entire assets to back its contention that nuclear energy is the safest available.

About 100 workers fled from a 50-story midtown office building last evening when an hourlong fire in a fifth-floor reception lobby at 810 Seventh Avenue sent smoke pouring up the building'ss air-conditioning ducts and elevator shafts.
A memorial stone was installed today over the grave of former President Harry S. Truman in the courtyard of the Truman Library.

Evidence in the files of the Federal Power Commission indicates that some natural gas -producers in the United States have tried to buy up available deserves, intending to keep the gas off the market and await higher prices.

The chairman of an energy policy group in the Consumer Federation of America contended today that the Nixon Administration had failed to solve energy problems but, had let energy companies' profits run wild.
An ax-wielder killed a 15. year-old girl and critically injured her 25-year-old companion in a South Bronx tenement, the police of the Simpson Street station house reported yesterday.

Acceptance by the European Common Market of President Nixon's invitation to an international energy conference next month is an encouraging step forward, but it leaves still distant the goal of joint action by the leading oil-consuming countries.

Common Cause subpoenaed to-day "Richard M. Nixon, individually and as President of the United States," in search of financial records to determine if Mr. Nixon's backers fully disclosed all expenses and contributions in the 1972 campaign.

Several criminal cases against the managements of companies that are alleged to be marketing hazardous products knowingly are being developed by the Bureau of Compliance of the eight-month-old Consumer Product Safety Commission.
John Lucas and Tom McMillen scored 23 points apiece, leading fourthranked Maryland to a 112-73 basketball victory over Ford.ham tonight.
Darryl Sittler and Lanny McDonald scored third-period goals last night to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 5-5 National Hockey League tie with the California Golden Seals.

Bing Crosby, the singer who underwent lung surgery last weekend, was transferred today from an intensive-care unit at Peninsula Hospital here to a private room. "His spirits are high, he's sitting up and he's on a soft diet now," a hospital spokes man said of the 69-year-old entertainer.

The Communications Workers of America said today that it would demand a "substantial" general wage increase and an improved cost-of-living escalator clause from Bell System telephone companies this year.
The Maine House of Representatives approved the equal rights amendment today by a vote of 78 to 68. Last year, the House approved the amendment by the same vote,

For residents of a city that boasts as many major teams as New York does, adult New Yorkers are apparently not obsessed with sports. Three out of five New Yorkers 18 years of age or older do not follow either basketball or football, according to the Times-Yankelovich survey, and 44 per cent don't follow baseball.
The Brit. ish Government tonight eased the curbs on power for the steel industry and said it would con. sider extending the three-day work week to four days.
Mayor Beame pledged yesterday "to marshal all of the municipal and private sources at our command in an all-out attempt to reduce crime and related problems" in the Times Square area.
Joe Torre, a first baseman who was asked to take a pay cut, was among five players reported today by the St. Louis Cardinals as having signed their 1974 National League contracts.

Governor Byrne announced today that he intended to create a new state public-advocate department and nominate Stanley Van Ness, the State Public Defender, to head it. If nominated and confirmed, Mr. Van Ness would become the first black man in the Byrne cabinet. Stanley Van Ness with Governor Byrne after the Governor proposed he head new public advocate department.

It'll be a little tougher for pitchers to pick up a save from now on. Under the old rule, some persons suggested pitchers were being credited with saves merely for showing up at the ball park.

Soon after his election in November as Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, Charles D. Breitel created a committee to help recruit a new administrator for the entire statewide court system. The man has been found-State Supreme Court Justice Richard J. Bartlett, who brings to the job a helpful background not only as jurist but as legislator and chairman of the commission that revised the state Penal Code.

Hopeful expectations about the successful negotiations to end the Arab-Israeli impasse influenced higher prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The news came, late in the day but the expectation was evident early in the session.

Johnny Miller took a giant step toward his third straight pro golf tour victory today. The United States Open champion set a course record with 10-under-par 62 in the first round of the $150,000 Dean Martin-Tucson open to take a four-stroke lead. Johnny Miller watching a birdie drop on the second hole at Tucson. He made 11 birdies for his record round.

The owner of a boat repair yard in Stony Brook, L. I., became the first person convicted for violation of the state's new Tidal Wetlands Law, the State Attorney General's office announced yesterday. ThomasF. Harrison, an assistant Attorney General, said that Arthur A. Barstow, the yard owner, had been fined $500 for filling and dredging a wetlands area by the Sixth District Court in Patchogue. Mr. Barstow had pleaded guilty to the charge.

John F. Roggenkamp, who retired in 1971 as financial vice president and controller of the Winthrop Laboratories division of Sterling Drug, Inc., died Monday at his home at 166 Bourndale Road North. He was 67 years old.

Clarence Clyde Ferguson Jr., the United States delegate, named Kuwait, Libya,. Qatar, Venezuela, Saudi Arabia, Iran and Gabon, as being "the most obvious examples" of countries whose spurt in oil earnings should enable them to give more money to the United Nations Development Program.
