When the news came out on Monday that the Utah Public Service Commission had ruled against the Mountain Fuel Supply Company, there had already been a market reaction suggesting that someone knew the bad news in advance.

Frederick J. Woodbridge, a partner in the New York architectural firm of Adams Woodbridge and consulting architect to Columbia University, died yesterday at his home, 21 Claremont Avenue. He was 73 years old. Frederick J. Woodbridge

Michael J. Lonergan, a veteran of 27 years in the Police Department, became its chief of operations and highest-ranking officer yesterday when Commissioner Michael J. Codd pinned a four-star shield on the left breast of his uniform. Michael J. Lonergan at ceremony yesterday.

Secretary General Waldheim said today that the United Nations Middle East Emergency Force was prepared to give "all necessary assistance in arranging for the separation of Egyptian and Israeli armies.

The Department of Labor, moving to implement a new manpower training act, announced today that $250-million for state and local public employment programs would be released as soon as possible after Feb. 1.

A former Peekskill, N. Y., City Court judge was fined $5,000 yesterday for evading almost $9,000 in Federal income taxes in 1966 and 1967. The defendant, Jerome J. Hersh, 51 years old, of 1358 Longview Avenue, Peekskill,

The agonizing search for a third Deputy Mayor has ended successfully after a series of embarrassments that pushed aside many of the urgent tasks Mayor Beame had hoped to tackle in his first fortnight in office.
The Soviet press agency Tass issued without comment tonight President. Nixon's announcement of an agreement by Egypt and Israel to disengage their forces on the Suez Canal front.
Troops occupied the University of Indonesia campus today shortly after the departure of Premier Kakuel Tanaka of Japan, whose visit here was disrupted by violent demonstrations.

The fastest -growing major city in the United States--the city with the best highway system -the city with some of the most innovative architecture in the world--is Houston. Houston has no zoning laws.

The State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene deplored what happens to those "not bad enough to go to jail and not mad enough to go to hospitals." A State Supreme Court justwice condemned as "absurd" a criminal-justice system that left him no option but to send mentally ill people to prison.

Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior in the Administration of President Dwight D. Eisenhower and a well-known Midwest publisher, died last night in a hospital after a long illness. He was 64 years old. Fred A. Seaton

Elsie Keene, a stage actress who had appeared with some of the greats of the theater in their early days as well as more recently on the stage, in films and on television, died in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Dec. 29. .

Vice President Ford came back to his home town last night for the first time since being sworn in as Vice President. Vice President Ford speaking at a school he graduated from during hometown tribute in Grand Rapids, Mich.

A psychotic horse with orthopedic shoes" is doing quite well for Dean Watson of Beaconsfield, Quebec. Watson has' a one-horse stable consisting of a 6-yearold trotter named Charon, whom he bought for $1,400 four years ago.
One hundred and twenty firemen with 22 pieces of fire apparatus responded early today to a three-alarm fire in a group of stores in Jamaica, Queens.

Hans K. Lorentzen, a pioneer in the manufacture of venetian blinds in this country, died yesterday at the Bergen Pines Hospital in Paramus, N. J. He was 86 years old arid lived on East Palisades Avenue in Englewood, N. J.
The Phillips Petroleum Company plans to spend $650-million this year to increase its capacity to produce energy supplies, the company announced yesterday in Bartlesville, Okla.

Spiro T. Agnew, the former Vice President, has put his suburban Washington home up for sale for a figure reported to be around $300,000. which is at least $100,000 more than he paid for it a year ago. The home in a Maryland suburb of Washington that Spiro T. Agnew has put up for sale

The Internal Revenue Service is auditing the tax returns of the Richard Nixon Foundation in addition to President Nixon's personal tax returns, Arthur Blech, the President's accountant, disclosed today.

Apartment landlords publicly appealed to the city yesterday for permission to increase rents to cover rising fuel-oil prices and at the same time moved to cancel union contracts in the Bronx and to defer maintenance of tax payments elsewhere to get cash for their oil bills.
Maybe you can't call it the best, but New York surely must be the most interesting place in the world for eating out. It beats even Paris in one respect-variety.

Fruit and vegetable stocks began running low at small grocery stores and the outlets of smaller supermarket chains in the metropolitan area yesterday as a wildcat strike that shut down the sprawling Hunts Point produce market in the Bronx went through a second day with no settlement in sight.

After months of cautiously correct political behavior, Gerald R. Ford assumed the offensive for Richard Nixon's team the other day, and promptly found himself in need of a helmet. There are a couple of useful lessons to be learned from his experience.
Motorists who had to pay 99.9 cents a gallon for gasoline on Christmas Day in Brooklyn must be given refunds, a judge ruled yesterday.
Although December proved to be a poor producer of snow in the East and the news from Washington last month about the gasoline crunch had been
Juan Valdez, the coffeebean picker of advertising fame, and the president of a coffee company, both drinking tea and recommending it to others? Can you believe it? Does this look like a tea drinker?
Gov. Ronald Reagan embarks tomorrow on a national tour that will test his chances of survival as a national political figure after he leaves office at the end of this year.

The price of gold jumped to an all-time high of $132.30 an ounce in Paris today. The dollar made unsteady progress in European exchanges. Gold's record price in Paris was a jump of $4 during the day. Other European bullion markets priced it up, though not that high.

Mr. Wiggins stayed in Washington. Eight months short of finishing his fourth term as the Congressman representing California's 25th District, Republican Charles E. Wiggins did not go home for the holiday recess. Representative Charles E. Wiggins in Washington office.

Gulfstream Park opened a 40-day meeting with its president, James Donn Jr., doing his best to eschew gimmick betting. Donn grudgingly has installed three perfectas (known as the exacta in New York) races on his daily 10race program He would prefer to have none.

To the Editor: In recent weeks nuclear power has been criticized on TheTimes' editorial page. At the same time, your news columns have repeatedly quoted recognized experts on the need for nuclear energy as well as its exemplary record to date. There seems to have been a misreading of fact, especially on dependability, and I would like to set the record straight.

At a warm, family-style ceremony at City Hall, Paul Gibson Jr. was sworn in yesterday as Mayor Beame's third choice to become the city's first black Deputy Mayor. Paul Gibson Jr. and his wife at City Hall yesterday for his induction as Deputy Mayor

Roger Woodward, a 29-yearold Australian pianist who studied in Poland for several years and whose career thus far has centered on London, made his New York debut on Wednesday night, playing Battok's Piano Concerto No. 2 with the Warsaw National Philharmonic.

Marc Neikrug, the pianist-composer who is the son of George Neikrug, cellist, has been creating a body of music or his father that is of more than passing value and should expand the relatively small ?? repertory.

The Walton Gang from the University of California, Los Angeles played without its injured leader, Bill Walton, again tonight, but managed rather easily to extend U.C.L.A.'s record basketball winning streak to 88 games.
After confusing price changes on Wednesday, silver futures opened strongly on the Cormmodity Exchange here yesterday and forged ahead to record highs once again.

The lack of heat and the growing accumulations of garbage forced 294 city schools tb close yesterday as new effbrts were unable to settle the twin strikes by 6,000 boilerroom and maintenance workers. Gerard N. Oak, principal, viewing trash piled up yesterday at Washington Irving High School, one of many schools closed because of strike by maintenance workers.
The Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, today proposed increasing the exemptions on the state personal income tax by $50 a person beginning with income earned in 1974.

Senator Walter F. Mondale of Minnesota, a leader of Democratic liberals through most, of his 10 years in the Senate, took his first formal step toward a Presidential candidacy today with the 'announcement of a fund-raising committee for a "preliminary exploration" of his chances in 1976.
Carl Marion Dice, a mining engineer and tungsten expert who was former president of Teledyne-Wah Chang in Glen Cove, L. I., died here Monday. He was 66 years old and lived in Glen Cove.

Wes Unseld, who had been sidelined by arthritic knees, marked his return to the Capital Bullets line-up tonight by scoring 13 points and grabbing 17 rebounds to lead his team to a 101-86 National Basketball Association victory over Cleveland. Atlanta's Pete Maravich moving from behind to knock ball from Johnny Johnson of the Trail Blazers, who had just come down with rebound, in game at Atlanta last night.

Arvid Anderson, chairman of the Office of Collective Bargaining, announced yesterday that the New York City Housing Authority and Local 237 of the Teamsters Union had accepted a fact-finding report issued by an impasse panel in their contract dispute.
Egypt and Israel reached agreement today on separating their forces along the Suez Canal and limiting the arms each is to have in the area.
Mayor Ralph Perk of Cleveland has asked Vice President Ford to help get Amtrak to reinstate the Albany-Chicago 'lake shore route" through Cleveland.
WASHINGTON - Winter daylight "saving" time has spurred outrage in West Virginia, whose people have tried to develop a protective fatalism in the face of repeated disasters.
EN GARDE Anyone weary of the traditional and in the mood for a sample of the avant-garde might try wending his way to Carnegie Recital Hall tonight at 8, where the wares of two Tom Johnson

The record of the 1973 World Team Championship in Brazil, recently published by the American Contract Bridge League, will be of particular interest to two American teams, the North Americans and the Aces, which suffered yet another defeat at the hands of Italy.

An American resource-surveying satellite that has been orbiting the earth since 1972 has yielded photographs of the Soviet Union's secret space launching complex at Baikonur in central Asia. The secret Baikonur space launching complex appears as the upper dark spot near center of the photograph (top) taken from an American satellite. The photo, together with its detailed interpretation, directly below it, was published in Soviet Aerospace, a Washington newsletter.

Getting to work on time is not an overwhelming problem for New Yorkers, according to the results of the survey. More than threequarters of them said they felt relatively confident they could get to work on time if they left on time.

The Atlanta Flames scored four goals in the second period tonight and went on to defeat the California Golden Seals, 6-2, in a National Hockey League game. John Stewart got two goals for the Flames, his 11th and 12th of the season. Bob Leiter had one goal and two assists for the winners.

Herbert J. Stern, the United States Attorney for New Jersey who gained a reputation as a vigorous prosecutor of corrupt pub1ic officials, was sworn in today as a Federal judge. Mr. Stern's first assistant and close personal friend, Jonathan L. Goldstein, was sworn in as Acting United States Attorney. Judge Mitchell Cohen, right, swearing in Herbert J. Stern as Mr. Stern's wife, Sandra, held the Bible, and his parents, Samuel and Frances, looked on.
Despite another week of hearings on the White House tape recordings the central question only looms larger:

The energy crisis has created a paradoxical new approach to electric rates. Utilities are now seeking increases to make up for reduced demand brought about by voluntary conservation programs. To date, five large electric utilities-the Consolidated Edison Company, the Boston Edison Company, the New England Power Company, the Northern States Power Company and the Wisconsin Electric Company-have applied for rate rises on this basis.

Murder indictments against six convicts accused of killing three prison guards were dis missed here today by a judge who ruled that the indictments were invalid because they had come from a grand jury, that had too few members of racial minorities, blue-collar workers and the young.

Major developed and developing countries agreed here today to cooperate to ease the impact of sharply higher oil prices on their economies. Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Valery Giscard d'Estaing, French Finance Minister, right, arriving for I.M.F. session in Rome yesterday.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 213.7 from 212.4 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 134.9 on Jan. 15, 1973.

Secretary of State Kissinger and President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt said here today they would press Syria to enter into disengagement talks with Israel, now that Egyptian-Israeli agreements covering the Suez front were completed.
Daniel J. Haughton

WASHINGTON--The Federal Government's civil-rights activity last year can best be described as when the cat's not looking the mice will play. With White House officials busy defending the President and themselves against mounting Watergate and related scandals, lower-echelon officials were left to their own devices, and they thereby gave the Administration a stronger pro-civil rights record than it might have desired. William H. Brown 3d

When John Smith set up business as a money manager two years ago he had the usual struggle to get accounts. In fact, he was only able to get one by May, 1972. He still has just the one account, pension-fund money, and he is by no means assured that he will be able to continue in the business even to this day. John Smith

Coach Larry Brown of the Carolina Cougars reportedly has been fined $1,300 by the American Basketball Association for shoving an official at halftime of the Virginia Squires-Carolina Cougars game her Dec. 30. Carl Scheer, the president and general managers of the Cougars, said today he did not deny the report and did not confirm it.

President Park Chung Hee of South Korea proposed today a nonaggression pact with North Korea. Mr. Park made the offer at his first news conference of the year when he was asked to comment on Pyongyang's repeated call for a peace treaty to replace the 1953 truce agreement and have American troops withdrawn from South Korea.

Thomas J. Mackell, the former Queens District Attorney, sought a mistrial yesterday on the ground that a full-page newspaper article about Special State Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari might have prejudiced the jurors who will decide his fate.

INNESBRUCK, Austria, Jan. of Austria won a European f Austria won a European Cup downhill ski race today at Steinach Am Brenner near here. Her time was 1 minute 59.43 seconds Marianne Ranner of Austria was second in 1:59.84 and Marianne Hefti of Switzerland was third in 2:01.61.

The Rangers, having shown last night that they could lose even with Emile Francis coaching, found themselves another man short today as they practiced for tomorrow afternoon's encounter with the Black Hawks at Chicago. Blues and Rangers sprawling on the ice Thursday night in St. Louis after Pete Stemkowski (21) of New York tried in vain to score. Bryan Lewis, right, the referee, cooled tempers before penalties were needed.

Viewed from Israel, the disengagement accord signed with Egypt today holds out the promise of a genuinely observed cease-fire and the possibility of much more. Maj. Gen. Mohammed Abdel Ghany el-Gamasy, left, of Egypt and Lieut. Gen. David Elazar of Israel outside United Nations tent at Kilometer 101 on Cairo-Suez road, where they signed accord on disengaging military forces.

The Public Service Commission today overruled two examiners' recommendationss and authorized the Consolidated Edison company of New York to increase gas and steam rates by 4.6 per cent and 7.8 per cent, respectively.
Robert Penn warren, tne only person to win the Pulitzer Prize for both fiction and poetry, has been chosen to deliver the Jefferson Lecture in the Humanities this year.

When the Notre Dame basketball team upset U.C.L.A. three years ago, 89-82, John Shumate, then a freshman, hurried out of the stands and lifted Austin Carr onto his shoulders. "To help him cut down the net," Shumate recalls. "But what I remember most about that game is that the atmosphere was awesome."

Thirteen harness drivers Indicted four weeks ago on charges of race-fixing learned yesterday what races they were supposed to have fixed. However, the Government's "bill of particulars" contained little more than the accusation that 48 superfectas had been rigged last year at Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways between Jan. 24 and April 13. Hal Meyerson

The directors of the Pennzoil Company, a Texas-based producer and refiner of oil products, cancelled plans for a new refinery yesterday because the company said it lacked assurance of foreign crude oil sup plies. At the same time, Pennzoil pointedly warned that the remainder of its plans to expand facilities to help meet critical energy needs might be jeopardized if tax laws were changed to limit oil industry profits.

The Citywide Political Convention I opened here today to select a "Community Choice" slate of candidates for the municipal elections in May. It was at a similar convention that Kenneth A. Gibson began his successful campaign for Mayor four years ago.

At first it seemed there would be an easy victory, and then it seemed their might be a gallant rally, but in the end the New York Knicks lost a 96-90 decision to the Houston Rockets tonight, to the delight of a noisy crowd of 6,348 at the Hoffheinz Pavilion on the University of Houston campus.

A Penn Central commuter train ripped down 2,300 feet of overhead power lines in the Hudson River tunnel early yesterday, delaying 200 commuter and Amtrak trains to and from Pennsylvania Station. Train riders seeking information at Pennsylvania Station as an accident in the Hudson River tunnel jammed up commuter and Amtrak trains. One clerk told a passenger, "You'd better take the bus."

Tilford C. Gaines, economic for The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company told businessmen in Detroit yesterday that the auto industry could look forward to "years of record production and sales" despite the present slump related to gasoline shortages.

United States officials said to day that the Central Intelligence Agency's operations in Thailand would be sharply reduced soon. The C.I.A. has been conducting a sizable counterinsurgency program against Communist guerrillas in Thailand for almost 10 years.

Following is the text of a statement issued today by Aleksandr 1. Solzhenitsyn, as translated by The New York Times: The full ferocity of the press campaign conceals the main point from the Soviet reader: What is this book about? What is the strange word "Gulag" In its title? Pravda lies:

The President's newest proposals for welfare reform, promised for last spring and then for fall, have not yet been disclosed. Apparently, James T. Lynn, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, wants a program of housing allowances for poor people but Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, thinks that that may pre-empt his department's position. Still, it is said that Mr.

Two more storms pounded the flood-ridden Pacific Northwest today after a week of rains that have taken 15 lives and caused damage estimated at more than $72million. In Idaho, Gov. Cecil D. Andrus called the flooding the worst natural disaster in state history.

Many fruit and vegetable markets here began running out of supplies yesterday, while others reported paying as much as twice the normal price for dwindling produce as a wildcat strike by warehousemen at the Hunts Point Market continued into its third day.

A tanker carrying 18,000 tons of fuel and a Norwegian freighter collided near the mouth of the Mississippi River today and both vessels caught fire. The oCast Guard said that two persons were killed, 16 were still unaccounted for and 61 were rescued, including the wife and two children of an officer of the freighter.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 18 (UPI)-Monika Pflug of West Germany won the women's 500 and 1,500meters races today on the opening day of the world junior speed-skating championships, while Gerard Cassan of Canada won the men's 500-meters in 41.88 seconds.

About 30,000 commuters who ride Transport of New Jersey buses into the city every day will have to pay at least a nickel more for a one-way ride beginning tomorrow. The company, the state's largest bus line, announced yesterday that it was putting into effect a 4.2 per cent fare increase. A company spokesman added that fares would be rounded out to the nearest nickel or dime.

Prices dropped in quiet trading on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market yesterday as investors expressed increasing concern over the nation's economic growth. The concern evident ly was deep enough to nullify the enthusiasm generated by the success in the Israeli-Arab negotiations.

Eastern Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to authorize a 6 per cent increase in domestic air fares on March 1 to help the airlines meet rising jet fuel bills. In a related development, a proposal to raise international air fares by 7 per cent ran into a snag because of an airline disagreement yesterday.

For the city's more than 880,000 liberated pupils, yesterday represented a release from cold and littered schools, the start of a welcome threeday weekend. There was a chance to sleep late in homes left quiet by working parents, to puzzle over the tangled webs of daytime soap operas or to dawdle and drift through the city's busy public places.

Gold leaped today to its highest price on record while the dollar lost value in major European markets. Dealers in Paris bid gold up to a closing price of $136.58 an ounce, the highest price the metal has ever reached and more than triple the "official" price set by the United States of $42.22 an ounce.

The Grand National Team Championship, introduced last season, has become a highly popular event. It gives many tournament players their only opportunity to compete in a major national championship in their own area. About 25,000 players are expected to compete this year, including some 1,500 from a Western area that mustered only eight teams last year.

The Gulf Oil Corporation divulged, yesterday the wholesale prices it charges for gasoline and home-heating oil in New York and Massachusetts, the first time a major oil company has made such disclosures. The move came as oil companies continued an industrywide campaign to answer charges by critics that there was insufficient information and figures to assess energy problems.

Two correction officers at the Trenton State Prison were dismissed today for "neglect to duty" in the scalding death of a 21-year-old inmate in his pre-Civil War cell three week ago. Both state employes, Lieut. Robert Maddux, 49 years old, and Officer William Jaichner, 25 years old, remain subject to criminal charges, which could be brought by a grand jury studying the case.

The second stage of a Delta rocket misfired tonight, apparently scrubbing an attempt to put a British military communications satellite into orbit, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said. A spokesman said as a result of the misfiring, the Skynet 2 satellite could not achieve its proper orbit.

reaction officers at the Trenton State Prison were dismissed today for "neglect to duty" in the scalding death of a 21-year-old inmate in his pre-Civil War cell three weeks ago. Both state employes, Lieut. Robert Maddux, 49 years old, and Officer William Jaichnet, 25 years old, remain subject to criminal charges, which could be brought by a grand jury studying the case.

Linton D. Well, a registered representative with Bache Co., Inc., for more than 16 years, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, in Roosevelt Hospital. he was 67 years old and lived in Wingdale, N.Y. He was a 1930 graduate of Dartmouth College.

A FIELD GUIDE TO MEXICAN BIRDS AND ADJACENT CENTRAL AMERICA. By Roger Tory Peterson and Edward L. Chalif. 298 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $8.95. THE LIFE OF THE HUMMINGBIRD. By Alexander F. Skutch and Arthur B. Singer. 95 pages. Crown. $9.95.

Look out, world, Mr. Balanchine is in his avant-garde mood againl For his latest work, given its premiere by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater on Thursday night, George Balanchine is using musique concrete. The ballet is called "Variations Pour une Porte un Soupir."

Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, acknowledged today that he had received "a file" of unauthorized documents taken in 1971 from the office of the National Security Council in the White House. Adm. Thomas H. Moorer

William Bancker Bailey, a retired New York lawyer, died Thursday in Midtown Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 511 East 20th Street. Mr. Bailey graduated from Columbia University and the New York Law School. His widow, the former Louise Peterson, survives.

Issues on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday gave up the gains won Thursday following news of the agreement for separating Israeli and Egyptian troops along the Suez Canal. The Dow-Jones industrial average dropped steadily throughout the day and wound up at 855.47, down 16.69 points at the session's lowest level. On the previous day, the Dow advanced 16.07 points.

Peter M. Mocco, the Mayor of North Bergen, was indicted by a Hudson County grand jury on charges of criminal conflict of interest and conspiracy. The jury charged that Mr. Mocco had an interest in a company that serviced township vehicles and that he approved vouchers submitted by the company for payment when they came before the North Bergen governing body.

The recent paintings of Lois Dodd at the Green Mountain Gallery, 135 Greene Street have a gently surreal quality: armchairs, a mirror, an ornate Victorian table are placed, forlornly, in a woodland glade, recalling the ghost of the human presence in an otherwise natural setting. "Night Window With Shade" is one of the paintings by Lois Dodd on view at the Green Mountain Gallery.

A stretch of 4 1/2 minutes of intimidating defensive play in the early part of the third quarter tonight helped the New York Nets to a 112-105 victory over the Memphis Tams before a crowd of 8,249 at Nassau Coliseum. Julius Erving of the Nets shooting against the Tams last night in Uniondale, L. I.

A tentative settlement was reached last night in one of the two strikes by custodial employes that had virtually crippled the 1.1-million-pupil city school system. The agreement, which is subject to a ratification vote tomorrow by the membership of the maintenance and cleaning workers' union, came on the third day of the twin strikes.

Judge John J. Sirica asked the special Watergate prosecutor tonight to give "immediate and serious consideration" to a grand jury investigation of the erasure of 181/2 minutes of a crucial Watergate tape recording and the alleged nonexistence of two other subpoenaed tapes.

Outraged consumer, tormented by the escalating price of a gallon of gasoline, dreading the day when 128 ounces of petrol may cost $1, consider the prices of some other gallons. Swallow milk at $1.65 a gallon, orange juice at $1.30. Intoxicate the senses with beer at $2.50 and egg creams at $5. Sweeten with Sweeta at $74.50 a gallon. Favor the breath with Binaca drops, $686 the gallon.

A smoky fire burned through the upper portions of a row of 10 wooden tenements in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn last night, leaving at least 50 persons homeless on one of the winter's coldest nights.

Viewed from Israel, the disengagement accord signed with Egypt today holds out the promise of a genuinely observed cease-fire and the possibility of much more. Maj. Gen. Mohammed Abdel Ghany el-Gamasy, left, of Egypt and Lieut. Gen. David Elazar of Israel outside United Nations tent at Kilometer 101 on Cairo-Suez road, where they signed accord on disengaging military forces.

Paul Francis Linz, who was a partner from 1932 to 1949 in C. M. Loeb, Rhoades Co., member of the New York and other stock exchanges, died in Mexico City on Wednesday. He was 74 years old and lived there and in South Kent, Conn.

Triumphantly flourishing a $3.02 million certified check-a good faith deposit on the $302-million bond underwriting agreement the New Jersey Sportsand Exposition Authority signed today-David A. Werblin, the authority's chairman, poinitedlykept the name of the bank on which the check was drawn covered with his fingers.

In an effort to improve Japan's unfavorable balance of payments, the Ministry of Finance has quietly imposed a series of restrictions on Japanese businessmen, limiting their purchases of foreign stock, real-estate and other "nonessential" properties such as hotels and restaurants.

Brooklyn College will start the spring term on Feb. 4 with a mandatory remedialreading program for students whose reading scores fall below the bottom quarter of the national norm. A program of voluntary remedial-reading courses had been drawing about 600 students who needed extra help, but a test given to freshmen last fall, and reports from freshmen and sophomore instructors, indicated that the voluntary program was not reaching enough of the students.

In the arresting exhibition area just past the entrance to the Winter Antiques Show, the glitter of brass, the gleam of well-waxed woods and the vibrant glow of lacquer work seem brighter in intensity than in many a season.

A consumer group under Ralph Nader's direction asked the five members of the Civil Aeronautics Board today to order Allegheny Airlines to stod giving special treatment to the five members of the board. In a complaint filed with the C.A.B,, the Aviation Consumer Action Project charged that Allegheny had directed its employes to give "special treatment and hospitality" to the board members and to all members of the House and Senate.

World Team Tennis, which has yet to swing a racquet, scored its biggest victory yesterday when Walter Elcock, United States Lawn Tennis Association president, announced the U.S.L.T.A. was prepared to sanction the new league for five years.

Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, confirmed today reports that his office had had discussions with key figures under investigation and aides of the prosecutor later indicated that those discussions could lead to plea bargaining.

A 5 per cent cutback in voltage by Consolidated Edison has led to a week's interruption of radiation therapy for patients at the Memorial-Sloane Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan, a spokesman said yesterday.

A "newsreel" camera rushes rather feverishly through the Civil War and its key battles, hovering over the outrageously ironic conflict between President Abraham Lincoln and Gen. George B. McClellan, chief of the Union forces, for an overcrammed historical tour tomorrow night at 7:30 over the American Broadcasting Company television network.

Following, as issued by the Israeli Government, is the text of the agreement signed today by Israel and Egypt on the separation of their forces on the Suez front: Secretary of State Kissinger taking leave of Foreign Minister Abba Eban before leaving Israel yesterday.

Maine today became the 31st state to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment to the United States Constitution when the State Senate voted 19 to 11 in favor of the measure. The House of Representatives approved amendment yesterday 76 to 68.

Secretary of State Kissinger and President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt said here today they would press Syria to enter into disengagement talks with Israel, now that Egyptian-Israeli agreements covering the Suez front were completed.

A military tribunal her sentenced six Moroccans to death today for their part in a left--wing uprising against the regime of King Hassan II last March. Three others were given life imprisonment, and four drew 30 years each. The verdicts, handed down after a three-day trial, bring to 22 the number of men sentenced to death in the case.

There's a barber pole outside and Japanese and Spanish guitars hang on the wall of. the shop itself, but the important thing at A La Bonne Cocotte is that you can buy plenty of new kitchen equipment there.
Terence Stamp in "The Collector" (1965), on Channel 7 at 11:30 P.M.

When Senator George McGovern drove into Langford, a village of about 400 in the northeast corner of the state, the other morning not long after a belated daylight-saving dawn had broken, a hand-lettered banner was stretched across the snow-swept main street. Senator George McGovern talking with students at the high school In Newell on his trip across South Dakota

Sleet and freezing rain glazed roads throughout the metropolitan area last night, causing numerous traffic accidents and pile-ups. Some main arteries were periodically ordered closed, but no serious injuries were immediately reported. A lot of people who covered their faces here yesterday didn't have a thing to hide-they were coping with the bitter cold that was a prelude to the sleet and freezing rain that struck the metropolitan area last night.

An American woman drove her car through a crowd of angry demonstrators outside the United States commissary today, killing a Vietnamese man and injuring a Vietnamese woman. United States Embassy officials said.

Habitues of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum could be forgiven for feeling that the, very last thing this museum needed was another exhibition of the work of Vasily Kandinsky. The museum was more or less founded as a shrine to Kandinsky's art, and its permanent collection even today contains the single most comprehensive collection of Kandinsk's work in existence. Kandinsky's woodcut for the cover of a 1911 almanach is at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

Five Americans, most of whom have been active in the peace movement, ended a twoweek visit to South Vietnam today with a denunciation of President Nguyen Van Thieu's rule and a plea to Congress to halt all United States aid to South Vietnam.

The state rested its murder case against Colin C. Carpi today after presenting 36 witnesses and introducing into evidence 67 exhibits during two weeks of testimony. Mr. Carpi, a 42-year-old Princeton investment consultant once named by Fortune magazine as one of the nation's most prominent young businessmen, is charged with killing his estranged wife, Laura, with a pistol on Feb. 8, 1971.

The Saigon military command reported this morning that fighting had broken out between South Vietnamese and Chinese naval and ground forces in a disputed archipelago in the South China Sea. Lieut. Col. Le Trung Hien, the South Vietnamese spokesman, said that at 8:30 A.M. today a Vietnamese Navy commando team landed on Duncan Island in the Paracel Islands and encountered a number of Chinese troops.

WQXR. Piano Concerto in A minor, Hummel; Symphony in D, Clementi; Prelude to Act II from Saul and David, Nielsen; Angelus from Scenes Pittoresques, Massenet; Symphony No. 7 in D minor, Dvorak; Overture in D, Boccherini; Violin Concerto No. 3 in B minor, Saint-Saens; Die Meistersinger: Excerpts, Wagner.

Mrs. Agnes O'Gorman Shanley, widow of J. Sanford Shanley, an architect who died in 1969, died Thursday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Rodney F. Joselyn, in Bucks County, Pennsylvania. She was 78 years old and lived at 4 Sniffen Court in this city and in West Cornwall, Conn.

A Superior Court jury today sentenced a third man, Wayne Carl Coleman, to death for the murders of six members of the Alday family last May. The prosecutor, Peter Zack Geer, had asked for the death penalty and told the jurors Mr. Coleman was "callous beyond rehabilitation."

Three years ago, the University of California, Los Angeles, basketball team suffered its last defeat right here, to Notre Dame, 89-82. After a record 88, straight victories, including three of its seven consecutive National Collegiate championships, U.C.L.A. meets Notre Dame here again tomorrow in what may be the Bruins' strongest test since that loss on Jan. 23, 1971.

William E. Simon, head of the Federal Energy Office, expressed optimism yesterday that gasoline rationing could be averted this year and that world oil prices could be rolled back to more reasonable levels. William E. Simon speaking during interview yesterday

" The Pajama Game," the musical co-starring BarbaraMc Nair, Cab Calloway and Hal Linden, will end its run at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater after tomorrow's matinee. It will have played 49 performances. The show by George Abbott, Richard Bissell, Richard Adler and Jerry Ross was produced by Mr. Adler and Bert Wood in association with Nelson Peltz.

Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday of William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, with a panel of reporters for The New York Times. Q. What Information do you have about a relaxation of the Arab embargo, what is your expectation in terms of a resumption of imports? What you expect will be the price of imported oil?

Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, confirmed today reports that his office had had discussions with key figures under investigation and aides of the prosecutor later indicated that those discussions could lead to plea Bargaining.

Paul Libin, president of the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers, disputed yesterday a statement by Actors Equity that the Round. about Theater was operating under the current Off Broad. way contract.

" Ahmed," a massively tusked elephant that had become a major tourist attraction, died yesterday, a notable victim of an increasingly severe drought in this East African nation. The great elephant, whose tusks swept outward and down to touch the ground, is to be mounted as a display at the National Museum here by order of President Jomo Kenyatta. Ahmed

The United States Export-Import Bank announced today four credits totaling $37.78-million to help Soviet purchases of American goods and services. Under legislation that has passed the House and is pending in the Senate, such credits would be barred. Such United States credits do not represent funds leaving the United States; rather they support American exports and produce foreign exchange earnings along with interest.

David L. Crawford, who served as president of the University of Hawaii for 25 years and wrote three books on the Hawaiian Islands, died in a nursing home here yesterday of Parkinson's disease. He was 84 years old. Mr. Crawford was born in Hermosillo, Mexico, to American missionary parents. After doing graduate work at Cornell University in 1927, he became president of the University of Hawaii.

There is an old joke about a dying winemaker who summons his sons to hear his final words of wisdom. Gasping his last, he whispers: "You can even make wine from grapes." In recent years, some Italian and German firms have been found to be fabricating wine from a variety of substances, ranging from common bulk chemicals to animal blood. Now a prominent French distillery has been charged with making kirsch--clear cherry brandy--without cherries.

The chiefs of staff of the Egyptian and Israeli armies, flnked by a United Nations general and two American diplomats, today signed an agreement to disengage their military forces along the Suez Canal. United Nations soldiers guarding tent at Kilometer 101 on the Suez-Cairo road where disengagement agreement was signed

Controller Goldin has just given the city's taxpayers -- and, we hope, his colleagues in the Board of Estimate and City Council --a useful reminder of the high cost of "economizing" on the municipal operating budget by borrowing to pay for day-to-day expenses that should be financed out of current revenues.

About a thousand Czechoslovaks today attended the funeral here of Josef Smrkovsky the former reformist leader who died of cancer Monday at the age of 62. Well-known former politiclans, writers and journalists of the liberal "Prague spring," which was brought to an end by invading Warsaw Pact troops in August, 1968, were among the crowd packing the Motol crematorium, where a 20-minute service was held.
The Governor of Grenada, the only woman to hold such a post ?? the British Commonwealth, ha resigned amid anti-Government demonstrations on the troubled island In the eastern Caribbean

Jo Jo White sparked a 10point Boston burst at the start of the fourth period to help the Boston Celtics record a 98-94 National Basketball Association victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight. The Celtics led, 78-76, after three periods. John Havlicek hit a basket at the third period buzzer for the 2-point lead. Opening the final period, White hit a field goal, fed Paul Silas for another and sank another shot himself.

The special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, said to day that his office was considering filing criminal charges in connection with the Government's settlement of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation antitrust

Variable Speech Control, which was patented this week, is designed to enable people to listen as fast as they read. The electronic Left: A mockup of a portable dictating machine equipped with Variable Speech Control. Right: Murray M. Schiffman, inventor of the device. It allows words to be played back at twice the rate of delivery.

Record gold prices abroad attracted heavy buying of silver futures here. Prices of silver on the Commodity Exchange once again set record highs, with the March delivery moving up to $3.80 6/10 an ounce and closing at that level, about 8 cents higher than the former high on Thursday.

Frank Howard, the 6-foot-8-inch 275-pound slugger, who signed for a reported $108,000 bonus with Los Angeles in 1958 and led the majors in home runs at Washington in 1968, has decided to move on to greener, and smaller, pastures. He was signed earlier this week by the Taiheiyo Lions of the Japan baseball league. He was released after last season by the Detroit Tigers.

Union members have ratified a two-year contract betweenthe Wire Service Guild and The Associated Press, reflecting annual increases of about 6.4 percent in wages and fringe benefits. The ratification vote, announced yesterday, provides for a $17 weekly increase in the top news and photo classifications, retroactive to Jan. 1, which would bring the minimum to $317 weekly for employes with six or more yearsof experience.

The latest Government data on gross national product indicate that the United States economy is entering the second recession of the Nixon years. In the final quarter of 1973, real G.N.P. -total output corrected for inflation -was still crawling upward at an annual rate of 1.3 per cent. However, even that virtually stagnant rate of output would not have occurred had business not miscalculated on production scheduling.

The technical facility and fastidious musicianship that Zola Shaulis demonstrated at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night made listening to her piano recital a generally pleasant, though not very stimulating, experience. Miss Shaulis, who tied for first prize in the 1971 Naumburg Award competition here, still plays like a contest winner, in that she gives each piece a smoothly machined finish.

The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers announced yesterday that it planned to strike the Long Island Rail Road at 5 A.M. Monday because of the railroad's elimination of the second man in the cab of passenger diesels. William E. Skutt, a vice president of the union, contended that the removal of the second man was "an arbitrary section in violation of Federal law" and that efforts to resolve the dispute with management had been unsuccessful.

William V. Shakespeare, star halfback for the University of Notre Dame in the nineteenthirties, died last night at Good Samaritan Hospital at the age of 61. He is survived by his widow and two sons. Bill Shakespeare at Notre Dame in 1935.

Premier Hedi Nouira of Tunisia said today in an interview that negotlations with Libya would be undertaken to settle the difficulties in the way of union between the two countries. He indicated that it would take four or five months before the Tunisian Constitution could be amended to allow for a referendum--originally scheduled for today-on a merger creating the Islamic Arab' Republic.

Fred Levin, a former executive president of the Equity Funding Corporation of America, today changed his plea to guilty on charges of conspiracy, mail fraud and illegal wiretapping. Mr. Levin, 40, changed his plea on four counts of a 105count indictment issued against him and 21 other persons by a Federal grand jury last year.

Edward L. Morgan, the former White House aide who was at the center of the controversy over President Nixon's gift of Vice-Presidential papers to the National Archives, resigned today as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury to resume private law practice.

Louis W. Schneider, staff director of the worldwide program operations of the American Friends Service Committee for 14 years, today was named the national executive secretary of the American Quaker organization. Mr. Schneider, 58 years old, a Quaker, who lives at Highspire Farm, Glenmore, Pa., succeeds Bronson P. Clark of Philadelphia, Louis W. Schneider

The Environmental Protection Agency announced yesterday that it would propose air pollution emission standards for motorcycles. A spokesman for the agency said the regulations would be the first such motorcycle standlands lards in the nation.

Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, acknowledged today that he had received "a file" of unauthorized documents taken in 1971 From the office of the National Security Council in the White House. Adm. Thomas H. Moorer
Major developed and developing countries agreed here today to cooperate to ease the impact of sharply higher oil prices on their economies.

World Team Tennis, which has yet to swing a racquet, scored its biggest victory yesterday when Walter Elcock, United States Lawn Tennis Association president, annourlced the U.S.L.T.A. was prepared to sanction the new league for five years. Under terms of the proposal from Elcock, W.T.T. would pay sanction fees amounting to $144,000.

Preston A. Champney, who retired in 1940 as traffic manager of the American Can Company after having served it since March, 1901, a month after its organization, died today. He was 96 years old and formerly lived in Upper Nyack, N.Y.

Commissioner Richard J. Sullivan of the State Department of Environmental Protection, submitted his resignation to Governor Byrne reluctantly today, provoking a storm of criticism among environmentalists and Republican legislative leaders who charged that the new Democratic Governor had forced the Commissioner out. Richard J. Sullivan

City officials and spokesmen for the landlords of hundreds of thousands of rent-controlled apartments here met privately yesterday to discuss the problem of sharply rising fuel costs, but they could not even agree afterward on what had been said.

Benjamin Kalmenson, who retired at the end of 1969 as president of Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., which was then known as Warner-Seven Arts, Ltd., after 42 years with the company, died today at his home, 186 Audubon Avenue. He was 75 years old. Benjamin Kalmenson

The Right Rev. Stephen F. Bayne, long a leader in the Episcopal Church and the Anglican Communion and a former chaplain of Columbia University, died yesterday in a hospital in Santurce, P.R., where he and his wife had been vacationing. He was 65 years old. Bishop Stephen F. Bayne

President Nixon announced the nomination of ambassadors to Ethiopia, Niger and Togo. Thomas W. McElhiney, a career diplomat, was nominated to the post in Ethiopia, to succeed E. Ross Adair, who has resigned. Mr. McElhiney now is a Foreign Service inspector. To be envoy to Niger to succeed the retired Roswell D. McClelland, Mr. Nixon chose L. Douglas Heck, who has been deputy chief of mission in Iran since 1970.

William E. Simon, head of the Federal Energy Office, expressed optimism yesterday that gasoline rationing could be averted this year and that world oil prices could be rolled back to more reasonable levels. William E. Simon speaking during interview yesterday

The coalition Government of Belgium collapsed today after the National Iranian Oil Company announced that it was pulling out of a joint project to build a refinery near Liege. Premier Edmond Leburton said. after a Cabinet session that he would hand in the resignation of the Government to King Baudouin. The SocialistChristian-Liberal coalition Government had come into power last Jan. 25.

The White House is disregarding demands by the Federal energy chief, William E. Simon, that Presidential staff members give up their telephone-equipped, chauffeur-driven limousines as an example to the rest of the nation to conserve fuel.

Cultural groups have received assurances from William E. Simon, administrator of the Federal Energy Office, that he would give "case by case" attention to instances in which a. fuel shortage affects the tours or other activities of performing-arts groups.

President Nixon's budget for the fiscal year 1975, starting July 1, now reported to be in the area of $305billion, will go to Congress Feb. 4, sources here said today. Originally, the White House had planned to send the spending document to Congress on Jan. 30, but it reportedly decided later to change that schedule.

Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn charged today that the campaign by Soviet authorities against his new book, "The Gulag Archipelago, 1918-1956," revealed their "animal fear of exposure." The dissident Soviet writer, who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1970, predicted that "the time will soon come when this book will be widely and even freely read in our country." Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn in Moscow yesterday.

Dean Martin Jr., 22-year-old son of the singer-actor, was freed on $5,000 bond today after being charged with illegal possession of seven unregistered machine guns and an antitank cannon found in his home.

A frustrating kind of fear--one that can neither be ignored nor documented-pervades the narrow, winding streets of New York's Chinatown these days. Residents and merchants of the area, long regarded as an island of tranquility in a stormy city, are complaining angrily about what they consider a, rising crime wave and clamoring for greater police protection. Policemen, left, patrolling Doyers Street, one of Chinatown's narrow streets
The board of directors of DuPont Walston, Inc., a major securities firm beleaguered with more than $10-million of losses over the past six months, has scheduled an unusual Saturday session today.

Secretary of State Kissinger and President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt said in Aswan that they would press Syria to enter into disengagement talks with Israel, now that Egyptian-Israeli agreements covering the Suez front had been completed. Mr. Sadat said that he would confer in Damascus today with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and would try to get talks started.

The oil industry yawned when in 1968 the Federal Government first tried to lease some of its oilshale lands. For two parcels, the industry bid a paltry $500,000 and the Department of the Interior said no thanks. An oil-shale test site in Rocky Mountains of Colorado. Oil-shale tract near Rangely (map below) has been leased.

Canada's two major railways have estimated that a recent arbitration award will cost them more than $500-million. Canadian Pacific, Ltd., requested an "immediate" meeting with the Government to discuss Federal aid. A former Supreme Court justice, Emmett Hall, a Government-appointed arbitrator, Wednesday awarded 90,000 railway workers pay increases up to 24 per cent over two years.

Geneva court fixed bail tonight for Bernard Cornfeld, deposed founder of the now disintegrated Investors Overseas Services mutual fund empire, at a record of 8 million francs (about $2.34-million). However, lawyers for the 46-year-old American financier said that he would have to remain in jail because the sum could not be raised.

Mrs. Grace Rifbjerg Mann, a theater, movie and television actress under the name of Ann Summers, died Tuesday in Hollywood after a short illness. She was 54 years old and lived there. Surviving are her husband, Robert Mann, a screen writer, and her parents.

Robert Byrne, the United States chess champion, and Boris Spassky, the former world champion, adjourned the third game in their quarterfinals Candidates Match after 41 moves last night in San Juan, P. R. Byrne, who is the chess columnist for the New York Times drew with Spassky in the first two games of the match, in which the winner is the first player to win three games out of a maximum of 16.

Developing shortages of oil and other vital resources add a new dimension of urgency to worldwide efforts to curb population growth. Because of recent advances in birth control techniques and a marked decline in fertility In this country in recent years many Americans tend to believe that the population problem is well on the way to solution. That unfortunately is not the case.

J. D. Sawyer, who managed Attorney General Wilham B. Saxbe's 1968 Senate campain, was chosen by Mr. Saxbe yesterday to be associae attorney general. Mr. Sawyer, a businessman from Middletown, Ohio, will coordinate Justice Department Personnel apopintments and supervise the personnel and public-information offices of the department.

A tentative settlement was reached last night in one of the two strikes by custodial employes that had virtually crippled the 1.1-million-pupil city school system. The agreement, which is subject to a ratification vote tomorrow by the membership of the maintenance and cleaning workers' union, came on the third day of the twin strikes.
A 41-year-old woman was found stabbed tc death in the driveway of her $150,000 house here last night. Her 5-year-old son had been slashed with a knife but was not seriously hurt.

The American Electric Power Company plans to acquire two privately owned coal companies in West Virginia for $24-million, it has been disclosed in a prospectus on the sales of bonds of a subsidiary. The proposed purchases would be made by the Appalachian Power Company subsidiary for which the bonds are being sold.

Two Chinese brothers, babysitting for their two younger brothers, were shot to death yesterday reportedly with a 9-mm. Luger wielded by one of four Chinese youths who had pushed their way into the victims' fourth-floor walk-up in Brooklyn.

Team handball may be a sport with an identity crisis, but not in the home of Dr. Peter Buehning, which has become a sort of headquarters for the game in this country. Dr. Buehning, a German-born engineer, served as chairman of the Olympic Team Handball Committee for the Munich games, the first time the sport was included in the Olympics since 1936.
Following is the text of the communique issued here today by the Committee of 20 at the close of the meeting of finance ministers of the International Monetary Fund:

As a first step toward nationalizing foreign-owned oil companies, the Indian Government said today that it would take over 74 per cent of equity in Esso Standard Eastern, Inc. Payment will be made over a seven-year period, at the end of which the Government will acquire full control. The price was not announced.

When Senator George McGovern drove into Langford, a village of about 400 in the northeast corner of the state, the other morning not long after a belated daylight-saving dawn had broken, a hand-lettered banner was stretched across the snow-swept main street. Senator George McGovern talking with students at the high school in Newell on his trip across South Dakota
The Government awarded a $2.1-million contract today to several manufacturers, including the Ford Motor Company and Volkswagen, to make a research safety vehicle.

The state rested its murder case against Colin C. Carpi today After presenting 36 witnesses and introducing into evidence 67 exhibits during two weeks of testimony. Mr. Carpi, a 42-year-old Princeton investment consultant once named by Fortune magazine as one of the nation's most promising young businessmen, is charged with killing his esttanged wife, Laura, with a Pistol on Feb. 8, 1971.

Willie Mosconi continued his mastery over Rex Williams of Britain in their S20,000 Black Velvet billlards-snooker competition. Mosconi scored a 21-11 victory over Williams last night before an overflow crowd at the Press Club as he won the billiards competition, his specialty, and one of the three snooker games.

Sales and earnings of the Caterpillar Tractor Company reached new highs in the final quarter and for 1973, according to the company's results issued yesterday. The nation's largest manufacturer's of earth-moving machinery and equipment, reported fourth-quarter net earnings at $56.7-million, or 99 cents a share, up 11.6 per cent from $50.8-million, or 89 cents a hare, for the final three months of 1972.

hushed courtroom, 26-year-old Samuel M. De Nicola pleaded guilty today to killing a C. W. Post College student, Patricia Ann Sullivan, "because I like to kill-I get satisfaction out of it." At times silent, at other times laughing or shouting obscenities, the defendant detailed his actions of last June 15, the day of the murder, until Supreme Court Justice David T. Gibbons asked: "Did you kill Patricia Ann Sullivan?" Samuel M. De Nicola

The population of New Jersey increased by more than 66,000 persons in 1973 and by more than-200,000 over the last three years, according to the state's Labor and Industry Department. The department also said yesterday that the population decline in major cities appeared to have ended.

Charlie Mahoney's two foul shots with 41 seconds left to play clinched a 73-67 victory for Manhattan College over Seton Hall tonight in the Miami Beach Basketball tournament. Biscayne College defeated Fairfield College, 67-58, in the second game. Tonight winners meet for the championship tomorrow night.

Outraged consumer, tormented by the escalating price of a gallon of gasoline, dreading the day when 128 ounces of petrol may cost $1, consider the prices of some other gallons. Swallow milk at $1.65 a gallon, orange juice at $1.30. Intoxicate the senses with beer at $2.50 and egg creams at $5. Sweeten with Sweeta at $74.50 a gallon. Favor the breath with Binaca drops, $686 the gallon.
Kenneth Reese Cole Jr. is widely admired for his pleasant manner. "Bright and cordial" is the way one friend describes him. Moreover, urban leaders praise the In the Nixon pattern

CLASS REUNION In the world of jazz, virtuosity as a bassist is synonymous with the name Charles Mingus. In a professional career that dates back to 1940, he has Performed with Louis Armstrong, Kid Ory, Alvino Rey, Bionel Hampton and Charlie Farker, among others. As a composer and an instrumentalist, he has won acclaim for widening the horizons of jazz.

The Federal Energy Office made a commitment today to increase Consolidated Edison's dwindling oil reserves from a 9 1/2day supply to a 12-day supply. "It will take six to eight weeks but that's only an estimate," said John W. Weber, assistant administrator for operations and compliance, after a 90-minute meeting with New York State and City officials and representatives of Con Edison and the New England petroleum Company, the utility's supplier.

Monika Pflug of West Germany won the women's 500 and 1,500meters races today on the opening day of the world junior speed-skating championships, while Gerard Cassan of Canada won the men's 500-meters in 41.88 seconds. Miss Pflug clocked 45.05 seconds in the 500-meters, with Sylvia Burke of Canada second in 46.06 and Margriet Pomper of the Netherlands third in 46.38.

Mayor Beame has decided to appoint James R. Dumpson as Human Resources Administrator and Robert A. Low as Environmental Protection Administrator. sources at City Hall said last night. The Mayor has also decided to offer an unsalaried post to Orin Lehman, who ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic nomination for Controller in 1966.

A 5 per cent cutback in voltage by Consolidated Edison has led to a week's interruption of radiation therapy for patients at the Memorial-Sloane Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan, a spokesman said yesterday.

However the Israelis may assess the disengagement from a diplomatic and political point of view, from a military point of view Israel's withdrawal from her major bridgehead west of the Suez Canal, and Egypt's retention of positions on the eastern' bank and of bridges across the canal, appear to shift the strategic balance in Cairo's favor.

Eartha Mary Magdalene White, who sponsored civic projects here, died today at the age of 97. Miss White, who had been a businesswoman here since 1904, supplied the energy and dedication that gave Jacksonville a nursing home, a 120-bed hospital, two boarding homes for the ill, aged or handicapped, two child-care centers, a lodging house for alcoholics, a mission to help the poor and a community center for recreation and education. In 1970.

(To the tune of "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean") Oh, Mister Galiber, Oh, Mister Galiber, For the record, let me set the record right: Even though you're nicely black I must take my offer back, For I'm not convinced your reputation's white! Oh, Mister Beame, Oh, Mister Beame,

Secretary of State Kissinger and President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt said in Aswan that they would press Syria to enter into disengagement talks with Israel, now that Egyptian-Israeli agreements covering the Suez front had been completed. Mr. Sadat said that he would confer in Damascus today with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and would try to get talks started.

Erich Leinsdorf, Who came to the rescue of the New York Philharmonic two weeks ago and replaced an ailing, conductor (Riccardo Muti), is doing the same thing this week for Thomas Schippers, who is still recovering from major surgery. However, he is sharing the repeat concerts with Morton Gould, who will be conducting this evening. Erich Leinsdorf

City officials and spokesmen for the landlords of hundreds of thousands of rent-controlled apartments here met privately yesterday to discuss the problem of sharply rising fuel costs, but they could not even agree afterward on what had been said.

Frozen track conditions set up an unusual daily double payoff at Liberty Bell Race Track today. After some trainers refused to run their horses over the frozen strip, there were five late scratches in the first race and four late withdrawals in the second. This set up a five-way payoff on the doubles.

Mrs. Stella Stitch Colt, who bred thoroughbred horses and owned and operated the Jumping Brook Farm racing stable, with training quarters in Miami, died yesterday at her apartment in the Hotel Pierre. Her age was 71. Mrs. Colt was the widow of James J. Colt, industrialist and owner of lands in northern New Jersey and the Jumping Brook Golf and Country Club in Neptune, N.J.

Judge John J. Sirica asked the special Watergate prosecutor tonight to give "immediate and serious consideration" to a grand jury investigation of the erasure of 18 1/2 minutes of a crucial Watergate tape recording and the alleged nonexistence of two other subpoenaed tapes.
The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase prices on almost all RCA color television models presented this year to offset mounting production costs. William E. Boss,

With a 71, Johnny Miller's score was nine strokes higher than his spectacular opening round of 62 yesterday, but he still set the pace in the $150,000 Dean Martin Tucson open. He had a 133 for 36 holes. Allen Miller, a 25-year-old former Canadian amateur champion from Pensacola, Fla., not related to Johnny Miller, was in the runner-up spot at 137, trailing by four strokes.

Thanks to intervention by Chairman Vincent McDonnell of the State Mediation Board, one-half of the crippling strike by school furnace and maintenance workers is over and the other half seems likely to end in time for reopening of classes Monday. But these welcome developments do not remove the need for a change in the degrading system of employment highlighted by the twin walkouts.

Vice President Ford made a news splash the other day by stepping out of character. He has always been good stolid old Jerry, regular guy, who makes a virtue of having neither bark nor bite, and when he suddenly appeared in Atlantic City Tuesday sounding faintly like the Spiro Agnew of old the press naturally took notice.

Thirteen harness drivers Indicted four weeks ago on charges of race-fixing learned yesterday what races they were supposed to have fixed. However, the Government's "bill of particulars" contained little more than the accusation that 48 superfectas had been rigged last year at Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways between Jan. 24 and April 13. Hal Meyerson

Memorabilia contained in a bronze box deposited 100 years ago for safekeeping in the cornerstone of the New York Tribune Building, near City Hall, was purchased for $725 by an unidentified collector. The collection, which was auctioned off by the Charles Hamilton Galleries at. the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, included signed manuscripts by Horace Greeley, The Tribune's founder,

Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, a conservative Democrat, said today that President Nixon should not put the country through a prolonged procedure over his removal from office but should consider resigning if the House Judiciary Committee recommended his impeachment.

Miss Janice Lynn Jeffers, a senior at Smith College, and Harry Winston Long, a second-year student at Harvard Law School, plan to be married. Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Jeffers of South Ozone Park, Queens, Miss Jeffers' parents, have announced the engagement.

On the mornings he does not have an early call, Edward Birdwell, who plays second horn in the New York City Ballet orchestra, takes out his instrument at home and gets in an hour of practice before commuter traffic spills off the West Side Highway and disturbs the silence.

A lastperiod aggressiveness, which seemed to be missing until Emile Francis returned as coach, paid off today for the New York Rangers with a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks. The triumph before a national television audience brought the Rangers' six-game trip to a fruit-ful climax with three victories and a tie.

RIO DE JANEIRO-At a time when many of the world's leaders are fearful about industrial downturns, Brazil's military leaders are struggling to keep their soaring economy from smashing through the roof.

The line of old, blind, and disabled stretched a block outside the entrance of the Brooklyn Borough Hall Social Security district office and into the two heated buses, motors constantly runnlng, that Social Security has provided.

Mayor Beame made it official yesterday, confirming reports that he would appoint James R. Dumpson Commissioner of Social Services and that he intended to dismantle the Human Resources Administration. Mr. Dumpson, 64 years old, will take a leave of absence as dean of Fordham University's Graduate School of Social Service.

Whether it's three rooms over the delicatessen, a luxury high-rise, a garden-apartment complex or a condominium development with its own golf course and bridle path, the apartment, by whatever name, is coming to suburbia. Already there are more than 1.5-million multiple-familyoccupancy units, as compared with 2.3-million single-family units, in the 26-county suburban area surrounding New York City, according to the Regional Plan Association.

The U.C.L.A. basketball dynasty, under Coach John Wooden, has been a succession of "mini-eras" spanning a quarter-century of unequaled success. Yesterday the latest of the mini-eras ended. More such eras will probably come.

JAKARTA, Indonesia--The head of the Government's oil corporation rides around Jakarta in a Rolls Royce "Silver Cloud" passing by tar-paper slums where the masses live in filth and disease, earning 25 cents a day or less.
The Milwaukee Bucks, led by Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's 34 points and a career-high of 20 by Cornell Warner, posted a 121-106 victory today over the Portland Trail Blazers.

A Government report on the massacre at Flumicino international airport on Dec. 17 stated today that it was carried out by five Arabs who had arrived shortly before from Tripoli, Libya, by way of Madrid.
LODI -- An urban-renewal project is jeopardizing the future of the small business district on Main Street, at one time the hub of this Bergen County borough of 28,000 people.

With the beef cattle that were held back during last summer's price freeze now sold and eaten, the supply of beef was dropping once again this week and prices were starting to climb again as a result.

A bitter interunion battle over the right to represent 10,000 school aides in the city heated up last week. The United Federation of Teachers had been trying to organize the aides, but it is not clear now whether the U.F.T. will continue, in the face of a ruling by the AF. L.C.I.O under the parent labor organization's constitution.
Nol said today that the current offensive by Communist-led guerrillas would be decisive for the future of Cambodia's 7 Million people.

The Staten Island carpenter, Thorbjorn Ryen, is having a great winter. He won his fifth straight tournament today, with jumps measuring 149 feet for 202.4 points and outscored the Class A competition for the third meet in a row.

A Federal mediator announced a new agreement yesterday to end the wildcat strike by warehousemen at the Hunts Point Produce Market, raising hope that the flow of fruits and vegetables into the city's depleted grocery stores might resume sometime today.
GOLD coin collectors and Customs inspectors will find life more enjoyable under a new ruling of the Treasury Department's Office of Domestic Gold and Silver Operations.

Miss Marguerite Whittlesey Felt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Pomeroy Felt of Darien, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married here yesterday afternoon to Michael Cary Bowen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Bowen of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

THERE are some very complex and confusing elements to the energy crisis in the United States, but they hardly compare with the horrendous difficulties that the shortfall of oil has posed for so many other nations-and the real trauma arises from the fact that nobody seems to know how to tackle this overwhelming problem effectively.

Dr. Henry A. Kissinger, the scholar, took over today from Secretary of State Kissinger, diplomat and peacemaker, for several hours of extracurricular delving into the history and culture of the ancient Egyptian civilization.
NEWARK--It was Christmas Eve, 1950, when George C. Richardson received a "present" that he has never forgotten. It was a small amount of light powder (heroin).
The September batting rally by Cleon Jones earned the New York Mets' outfielder an "unspecified salary increase" yesterday and the club's list of signed players increased to six for the 1974 season.

Doug Swift, linebacker and player-representative of the Miami Dolphins, has misgivings about the future of the Super Bowl champions: "You can expect to see a lot of new faces on next year's team. A lot of important contracts come up for renewal and you can bet the guys will be asking more than the management wants to pay."

Fourth-ranked Maryland recovering after a listless start, scored 15 consecutive points late in the first half and went on to defeat Navy, 72-50, in basketball tonight as Tom McMillen scored 27 points.

THE TALK OF THE TOWN--Little but politics is ever doing in Delhi, and the talk of the town in the capital currently revolves around the gala military-political spectacle which is scheduled to take place here next Saturday in observence of India's Republic Day.

A 39-yearold woman has been giving Communion in a Roman Catholis church on Italy's east coast since Christmas, but lavish news coverage of the development is embarrassing the Vatican.

An American official said today that Israel and Egypt had informally agreed that it would be pointless to continue discussions on a final peace settlement until it was clear that both sides had carried out the terms of their disengagement agreement satisfactorily.
Rallying from off the pace, Theodore Chankin's Crafty Caller came on to score a popular half-length victory in the fifth running of the $27,550 Heirloorm Stakes at Liberty Bell Park today.

Antioch College, a venerable symbol of innovation and quality in American higher education, is struggling to survive. A basic problem is money. It persists despite harsh measures designed to reverse the results of years of what some see as slipshod management.
Frederick L. Van Lennep has been horse-crazy since he was 10 years old, about a half century ago, but he also was a realist.

Lynn Redgrave, the youngest member of the theatrical Redgraves, who was thrust into stardom by her performance in the 1966 film "Georgy Girl," has been signed to star on Broadway this season in the Charles Laurence comedy "My Fat Friend."

" Your school is hurt if you disrupt the routine. 'Normal' is the standard," said Martin Ulivicky, principal of William Cullen Bryant High School in Long Island City, Queens, last Thursday. "Meanwhite, I'll just play it by ear."
President Nixon's new budget will all but abandon last year's highly controversial device of "impounding" funds for programs approved by Congress.

LINCROFT--Former State Supreme Court Justice Haydn Proctor, now an adjunct professor in Human Affairs at Brookdale Community College, will give four lectures at the college on controversial topics of the day.

Barbara Tepper of the Bronx, a 32-year-old librarian at Baruch College in Manhattan, uses crutches because of arthritis and the weakening side-effects of nearly four years of blood-dialysis treatments for kidney disease.
After struggling since 1970 with a program of forced busing of students, this city has relucatantly abandoned its determination to make school integration work.

To the Editor: Father Andrew M. Greeley ("A Christmas biography," Dec. 23) has cut through all the verbiage that confuses us today about Christ to clarify the essential message Jesus wanted to give man: God loves us.

With a defense that allowed only two filed goals in the first 15 minutes and 20 points in the first half, St. John's defeated Villanova, 9271, in basketball last night before 4,310 fans at Alumni Hall in Hillcrest, Queens.
MINEOLA, L. I.--A program designed to create 157 jobs primarily for poor persons over 55 years of age will be submitted tomorrow for ratification by the Nassau County Board of Supervisors.
Corporation Counsel Adrian P. Burke says he favors hiring 80 lawyers exempt from Civil Service-a practice under attack by Civil Service lawyers as a historic carryover of the spoils system.
MORRISTOWN--Until further notice, the Morris County Park Commission is offering free firewood every third Saturday of the month. The first pick-up day was yesterday.

HAVANA, Cuba--What first strikes visitors these days to Havana, once a playground of the Americas, is its run-down look, 15 years after Fidel Castro's revolution. With its cracked and peeling buildings, its spluttering fleet of nineteen-fifties cars and its shops nearly empty of luxury consumer goods, the capital looks like a city that has come under siege.
The Indian Government, slow to awaken to the full impact of the oil crisis, is facing a severe economic setback that will cut food production and industrial growth.

The Baltimore Banners, an entry in the new World Team Tennis League announced the signing of Jimmy Connors tonight. Connors is co-ranked with Stan Smith as the top player in the United States and was the Banners' first draft choice.

Leonard Shecter, a writer whose tough-minded approach to sports challenged the "gee whiz" school of reporting, died yesterday of leukemia at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived at 200 East 16th Street.

Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated: 'Lorelei' at the Palace Jan. 22-New York Botanical Garden. Tickets, $50, $40 and $30, from Mrs. Harry Rafter, 91-15 Lamont Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens.
Free bsic boating courses, open to the public, will be given by the 21 member squadrons of Distruct 3 of the United States Power Squadrons in Kings, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

The National Park Service's desire, which was made public late last summer, to stop spending millions of dollars in essentially ineffective beach erosion control is praised by Gary Soucie in the January issue of Audubon magazine.

The energy shortage is raising doubts about continued heavy demand for second homes. That three-hour trip from New York to a ski lodge in Vermont isn't quite so simple now that gasoline is practically unobtainable on Sunday.

Aside from the fact that there were five changes in cast, the Metropolitan Opera's performance of "Manon Lescaut" on Friday night had two handicaps. Harry Theyard, who was to have made his debut with the company as Des Grieux, had substituted the previous evening at the house in the strenuous role of Hoffmann in Offenbach's "Les Contes. d'Hoffmann." WITH 1974 barely under way, there are already changes of import to philatelists as Papua New Guinea and Grenada, Island lands oceans apart, move uneasily and gingerly on the road to independence.
